fields.headline: Rangers' title drive stalls again
fields.trailText: Rangers are too used to passing examinations of their character to panic over drawing three of their last four league matches, but this latest outing has at least added interest to a Premier League championship that had seemed over once again. If the Ibrox side had their bad luck, St Johnstone deserve huge credit for the resolve which allowed them to hold the champions for the second time in as many weeks.
fields.body:
Rangers are too used to passing examinations of their character to panic over drawing three of their last four league matches, but this latest outing has at least added interest to a Premier League championship that had seemed over once again. If the Ibrox side had their bad luck, St Johnstone deserve huge credit for the resolve which allowed them to hold the champions for the second time in as many weeks.

One of the penalties for establishing a fearsome reputation is being forced regularly to encounter and overcome the kind of defending in numbers which opponents usually deploy to thwart Rangers. Dick Advocaat and Walter Smith before him have frequently been ridiculed for claiming that winning a championship is not always a sinecure, but on days like this their words have the truth of the Gospels.

St Johnstone should not be indicted, either, for their decision to contain on their own territory and hope to succeed at the other end of the field through the occasional counter thrust. Given the gap that separates the teams in talent and strength, caution indicates wisdom rather than deliberate spoiling tactics.

The visitors' relinquishing of attacking ambition was obviously expected by Advocaat, who departed from his normal defensive formation of a back four for a three of Lorenzo Amoruso, Tony Vidmar and Arthur Numan; even so, the last-named pair spent much of the time as auxiliary wingers, pushing into threatening positions on the flanks.

The result was a stifling overcrowding in the vicinity of the St Johnstone goal, with little space in which to manoeuvre. Jorg Albertz, Giovanni van Bronckhorst and Claudio Reyna probed intelligently, but the diligence of the visiting defenders made clear opportunities a rarity.

Indeed, through the entire first half, Rangers were restricted to three half-chances, the first of which brought a comfortable save from Allan Ferguson as he gathered Rod Wallace's low drive in his arms. The goalkeeper would frustrate the home side twice more before the accident that forced his departure - to be replaced by the inexperienced Stephen Robertson - after 40 minutes.

St Johnstone had called on Ferguson only because of a groin injury to their Scotland squad member, Alan Main. Ferguson had saved at the feet of Seb Rozental and made a similar block from Andrei Kanchelskis before landing awkwardly on his knee after a challenge for the ball in the air.

Rangers raised the tempo and produced a succession of near things. The most dangerous of these saw Kanchelskis on the six-yard line meet a cross from Rozental with a left-foot shot against the crossbar.

Rozental would later have a scoring drive cleared off the line by Gary Bollan, but the ball could not be willed into the net. But the result will encourage Celtic, who are nine points behind with a match in hand and two meetings with the champions looming. Suddenly, they can influence their own fate.

webTitle: Allow us to dream awhile and talk of contracts

fields.headline: Allow us to dream awhile and talk of contracts
fields.trailText: English cricketers are entitled to dream in March. With the season just a month away, new resolutions can be formulated, which cannot be dented by any inconvenient failures out on the pitch. This is the year when everything comes together. In their minds - and maybe in the indoor nets - the away swinger starts on middle and leg before darting obediently towards a slip cordon, where nothing is dropped. The on-drive is suddenly added to the batsmen's repertoire. It's an easy game in March.
fields.body:
English cricketers are entitled to dream in March. With the season just a month away, new resolutions can be formulated, which cannot be dented by any inconvenient failures out on the pitch. This is the year when everything comes together. In their minds - and maybe in the indoor nets - the away swinger starts on middle and leg before darting obediently towards a slip cordon, where nothing is dropped. The on-drive is suddenly added to the batsmen's repertoire. It's an easy game in March.

Which is why it's possible to view the lucky dozen who will enjoy ECB contracts this summer with carefree optimism. The list contained several surprises, unwelcome ones for the left-handed - Alan Mullally, Graham Thorpe, Nick Knight and Phil Tufnell were all absent - but great news for Dean Headley, Craig White and Chris Schofield.

We must assume that these 12 players are the ones that the selectors intend to use when the first Test against Zimbabwe starts on 18 May at Lord's, though a Thorpe double century and a Headley injury may well intervene.

It is remarkable that only six of the contracted players announced last Wednesday appeared in the final Test against South Africa - this is the sort of overhaul that is usually associated with disastrous tours. Again Duncan Fletcher and Nasser Hussain have revealed their ruthless streak.

Let's indulge ourselves with pre-season optimism while we can. This is the selectors' dream: Mark Ramprakash seamlessly converts into a Test match opener (I think this is a good idea), resuming a partnership with Mike Atherton, which first prospered on Young England's tour of Sri Lanka in 1987. Michael Vaughan progresses sedately and we learn that Fletcher truly does possess the key to unlock Graeme Hick's talents.

If Dean Headley is twelfth man, then the side gives the impression of having a remarkable depth in batting, mirroring the South African line-up: Andrew Flintoff at seven, White at eight and Schofield, who is no mug, at nine, leaving Darren Gough and Andy Caddick to fight over the number-eleven slot. It should take Henry Olonga and Co a while to get through that lot. White bowls as dangerously with the red ball as he often did with the white one on tour in Africa. Schofield, hot-housed by the ECB, flicks out his wrist-spinners unerringly. This team is starting to look invincible.

There is an alternative view. The killjoys - or are they the realists? - might make these observations: Ramprakash and Hick are burdened by past failures. The batting may look long, but who beyond Gough and Caddick are capable of taking Test wickets? In any case White averages 13 with the bat in his eight Tests and 41 with the ball. Last summer in the Championship - and we are constantly being reminded how lamentable the standard is in that competition - he mustered 17 runs per innings. Meanwhile Headley, when fit, averaged 39 with the ball last season. As for Schofield, he has played 12 Championship matches in his life. He's only there because he's lucky enough to be one of the few Englishmen who propels the ball from the back of his hand. Remember Salisbury.

I think the notion of central contracts is a good one, though I doubt whether they are so enthusiastic at Headingley. But there are misgivings. The theory of fielding a Test team with long batting and a wrist spinner is obvi ously fine, but it only works if the personnel enlisted are up to Test standard. There have to be doubts about whether White and Schofield, who is not yet ready, can reach that level this summer.

Moreover, the sudden elevation of Schofield betrays desperation and is an implicit vote of no-confidence in the ability of his county to oversee his development until he has come near to the required standard. It also says a lot about the general level of spin bowling in this country. In my dreams I can see Schofield dismissing the odd Zimbabwean in May; I'm not so sanguine about a possible duel with Brian Lara in June.

webTitle: Counties fail to pass the Test

fields.headline: Counties fail to pass the Test
fields.trailText: Nothing became the County Championship so much as its passing.
fields.body:
Nothing became the County Championship so much as its passing. Last week, the venerable old tournament was killed off by the small print of a contract.

Now promising young players will strive to be offered an ECB contract rather than grind their careers into the dust on the county circuit. Once they have signed on the dotted line they will be paid handsomely not to play county cricket. The Championship is on garden leave. The end will come soon.

It is in many ways an act of euthanasia. The cricket counties have conceded to Duncan Fletcher the final say as to who plays in their Championship team on two conditions. One, they receive compensation. The counties will receive £50,000 for each contracted player which is more than some of them take at the gate in an entire championship season. Two, the contracted players will be free to play in the NatWest and the Benson and Hedges. The priorities are clear. One-day cricket is more important than the Championship.

There was more evidence of its demise at the announcement at Lords on Friday of Middlesex's new sponsorship deal with that 'venerable investment institution' The Equitable Life. Rather than talk about winning championships, Phil Edmonds, the Middlesex chairman, said he wanted the team to be 'a conveyor belt for people to join the England squad'. And looking at his assembled squad warned 'if you're not performing by 27 or 28 we'll be very ruthless with you'. The emphasis will be on youth and hurrying talented players quickly into the England set-up.

Something Edmonds wishes had happened to his captain Mark Ramprakash. 'If this new system had pertained 10 years ago and Ramprakash been selected by an enlightened group_ then by the time he was 20 he would have been the fulcrum of the side and by now captain of England. He suffered because of the syndrome we had in this country that you have to prove yourself in county cricket.'

No longer. Chris Schofield has only played 12 county matches - not sufficient to become disillusioned unless he has an exceptionally low boredom threshold. He owes his place in the elite squad to a very successful England A tour.

It is be hoped that Schofield's inclusion will set a precedent. That the selectors will take more note of a young player per forming well against a variety of opponents on a variety of pitches than one who grinds out consecutive fifties at Leicester and Northampton.

Meanwhile, the Championship will meander along for a while. There will be moaning when Gough isn't allowed to play but Ramprakash is for, as far as it can be, vital Championship match. But no one will take any notice. The deed has been done. The County Championship, which is dependent on income generated from Test matches to survive, is now subservient to it.

On Friday, it was difficult to leave Lords because all the security staff were posing for a photograph reminiscent of those pre-war sepia numbers hung next to the poster of Winston Churchill in olde worlde pubs. It seemed appropriate.

fields.headline: Klusener clubs India
fields.trailText: South Africa, in the ascendancy since the first hour of the contest, are poised to win the second Test against India. With two full days to go, India, up against a first-innings deficit of well over 300, will have to stage a rearguard action to prevent a fifth defeat in successive Tests.
fields.body:
South Africa, in the ascendancy since the first hour of the contest, are poised to win the second Test against India. With two full days to go, India, up against a first-innings deficit of well over 300, will have to stage a rearguard action to prevent a fifth defeat in successive Tests.

However, even a draw will not deny South Africa distinction on two counts. They will, by virtue of their victory in the first Test last week, become the first country in 13 years to win a rubber on tour in India and the only one to have beaten all the three sub-continental teams on their own soil.

With the right mix of discipline and aggression, South Africa have made almost certain that they will not have to bat again, which is just as well for them because the pitch, which was a mosaic of cracks even before a ball was bowled, has become a snarling beast.

It was as gentle as a border collie for two days and a half. However, by tea, it was transformed into as fierce a rotweiller as any that guard the villas of Johannesburg's wealthier citizens. Having conceded only Daryll Cullinan's wicket during the first two sessions, South Africa lost four in the final 31 overs.

Not only was the pitch more responsive to the blandishments of the spinners' fingers, but utterly erratic in bounce, a feature that will only add to the perils India's batsmen will be posed today by South Africa's faster bowlers.

Most of yesterday was occupied by a stand between Kallis and Klusener, who came together for the fifth wicket halfway through the opening hour when Cullinan's bucaneering innings of 53, made off 86 balls, was cut short by Kumble.

Both were dismissed after tea when they were tantalisingly close to their centuries. Lack of familiarity with spin bowling has made Kallis bat here with greater circumspection than is normal with him. But, accepting his limitations against the twirly men, he has played with extreme dedication and application and this innings lasted only a shade under six hours, during which he faced 359 balls.

Cronje promoted Klusener ahead of himself because the Indians are uncomfortable bowling to left-handers. It was a shrewd move. Klusener in India is also a different player, adhesive and workmanlike, scoring square of the wicket except when presented with a rank half-volley.

He reached his 50 off only 64 balls, but then faced another 105 and eventually frustration tempted him to try and hit Kartik over the top, only to plonk the ball down mid-off's throat. Kallis was undone by extra bounce, caught off Kumble, at short-leg.

Kumble took five wickets in an innings for the eighth time in his career. He was due this measure of success for toil alone. Until late in the day, he looked the only bowler to command respect or to look a potential wicket-taker and Tendulkar depended on him to deliver 31 of the 90 overs India bowled in the day.

Kartik, the left-arm spinner playing only his second Test, would have been seen to greater advantage had a paucity of runs to bowl at not compelled Tendulkar to use him as a defensive weapon.

He reached his 50 off only 64 balls, but then faced another 105 and eventually frustration tempted him to try and hit Kartik over the top, only to plonk the ball down mid-off's throat. Kallis was undone by extra bounce, caught off Kumble, at short-leg. Kumble took five wickets in an innings for the eighth time in his career. He was due this measure of success for toil alone. Until late in the day, he looked the only bowler to command respect or to look a potential wicket-taker and Tendulkar depended on him to deliver 31 of the 90 overs India bowled in the day. Kartik, the left-arm spinner playing only his second Test, would have been seen to greater advantage had a paucity of runs to bowl at not compelled Tendulkar to use him as a defensive weapon.

webTitle: Next week in the Champions League

fields.headline: Next week in the Champions League
fields.trailText: Amy Lawrence previews the next round of big games.
fields.body:
Chelsea v Marseille

Bonne chance to the visiting Marseillais for this one. Judging by messages flickering over the Chelsea website last week the Blues are hellbent on exacting revenge for a thoroughly unenjoyable evening in the south of France last Tuesday. Marseille, whose best players have been picked off during this testing season, lack sufficient star quality, high-level experience and classic European virtues to progress through Group D. It's asking a lot to expect Robert Pires to make lightning strike twice. In beating Chelsea, and Manchester United in the previous phase, OM exceeded expectation. At Stamford Bridge Gianluca Vialli's men ought to win at a canter. But Chelsea do make heavy weather of overcoming supposedly inferior opponents. Tactically there is something askew - playing four right-footers across the midfield with Gus Poyet stuck out on the left leaves them lacking balance. It is not helping a team whose scoring touch remains elusive.

Key man - Gianluca Vialli Touchline ban over, might it be time for Vialli to reconsider playing himself? Tore Andre Flo and Gianfranco Zola have scored one goal each in 2000, both against Gillingham. Chelsea urgently need more end product. With George Weah ineligible and Chris Sutton ineffectual, if Vialli doesn't want to inspire from the front he must make sure his chosen ones do.

Bordeaux v Manchester Utd

Short of a freakish shock it's difficult to see anyone other than Barcelona preventing Manchester United from retaining their trophy. The holders now radiate an aura of indestructibility in Europe, and their performance against the French champions was almost routine when they won 2-0 on Wednesday. A glitch at the Parc Lescure is unlikely - United are equally effective at home and away in the Champions League and psychologically Bordeaux are virtually beaten already. Without a goal in their last five European games, making the necessary inroads without two of their key midfielders, Christophe Dugarry and Sylvain Legwinski (both ineligible), looks too tall an order. Sir Alex Ferguson will probably have half an ear cocked towards Spain for news of Valencia v Fiorentina: A Spanish triumph will prise open the group, while victory for the Italians would give themselves and United breathing space.

Key man - Roy Keane Ryan Giggs and David Beckham both shone last Wednesday but the powerful presence of Roy Keane was again the influential factor. Bordeaux have some capable playmakers, notably Johan Micoud and Correntin Martins, but they were never able to hit their stride thanks to the United captain. Keane will need to exert as much authority for United to be sure in France.

webTitle: Vintage Claridge gives Ipswich a nasty surprise

fields.headline: Vintage Claridge gives Ipswich a nasty surprise
fields.trailText: Nationwide round-up with Jason Tomas.
fields.body:
Steve Claridge, the veteran Portsmouth striker in trouble with the Football Association for placing a bet on his team - for a match in which he scored a hat-trick - produced the surprise of the day. It was his goal which gave relegation-threatened Portsmouth a 1-0 win at Ipswich - the home team's first defeat in 19 matches.

The 33-year-old Claridge struck midway through the first-half, hurling himself through a ruck of players to convert Sammy Igoe's cross. Portsmouth, with only two previous wins away from home this season, could and should have made it 2-0. Lee Bradbury fired over the bar from eight yards after being handed a clear opening by Thomas Thogersen.

Manchester City did not have the best of afternoons either, at Crystal Palace. City, inspired by Mark Kennedy, had the fillip of scoring the first goal. But Palace deservedly levelled through Clinton Morrison, and City then relied heavily on some excellent saves by Nicky Weaver - notably from Simon Rodgers - to avoid going under.

But there is no stopping Charlton, who recorded their eleventh win in succession, at Bolton.

Both their goals came in the last 10 minutes. Martin Pringle got the first and a mistake by Bolton defender Mark Fish led to Andy Hunt getting another a minute later.

It was Charlton's first win at Bolton since 1955, and it has taken them 10 points clear in the title race.

Perhaps the best in dividual scoring performance in the First Division came from Huddersfield's Martin Smith. His two goals - both in the first half - gave Huddersfield a 2-0 win over Wolves.

Two youngsters attracting attention are inevitably David Healy and Alex Notman, the 20-year-old Manchester United strikers who are experiencing their first taste of regular first-team football through loan spells at Port Vale and Sheffield United.

That Vale were able to get Healy was something of a coup for their manager, Brian Horton. The day after the loan agreement was con cluded, Healy was unexpectedly given his Northern Ireland debut against Luxembourg, and scored two of their goals in a 3-1 win. Horton describes him as a 'natural goalscorer,' adding: 'His pace alone is always going to cause teams problems.'

The one drawback, though, concerns the question of the service relegation-threatened Vale can give him. As Horton admits: 'He has probably had better players alongside him in Manchester United's reserve team than he has in our side.'

Healey, who did well on his debut against Stockport, without scoring, certainly found chances difficult to come by at Fulham. The home side, despite having three of their four senior strikers unavailable, established a 2-0 half-time lead through Lee Clark and Andrew Melville, and Clark made it 3-0 after the interval.

However, it was not all doom and gloom for Healy. He had produced Vale's best scoring effort in the first half, and confirmed himself as their most dangerous oplayer by getting his first goal for the club in the 74th minute.

Will Notman be celebrating any goals today against Queen's Park Rangers?

Notman, a Scotland Under-21 international now in his second month on loan at Sheffield United, has only scored once.

But United's assistant-manager, Kevin Bramwell, says: 'It was always going to take him time to adjust to the Nationwide League, because the game here is more physical and quicker than he is used to. In the circumstances, he is doing reasonably well. The great thing about him is that in all his matches, he has made a lot of good runs off the ball and never let his head drop. For me that sort of attitude is bound to help him become a top player.'

Bramwell bridles at the suggestion that players like Notman cannot find it easy to being with 'lesser' clubs.

'I do not think that any reserve team player can look upon coming here as a backwards step,' he says. 'Manchester United's reserves play at Gigg Lane, so playing-wise being here represents the biggest stage he has been on.

'We do not usually take lads as young as Alex for our first team. Playing in big matches at Bramall Lane can be quite intimidating for them.'

fields.headline: Said & Done
fields.trailText: How David Shayler, wanted by MI5, slipped secretly back into the country last month to watch Middlesbrough.
fields.body:
MI5 miss Shayler at Boro

Exiled spy David Shayler, wanted by MI5, slipped secretly back into the country last month to watch Middlesbrough.

Shayler, being sued by the Government in an attempt to silence him, drove from France to see his hometown club play Coventry without being traced. Shayler reveals how he outsmarted customs, police and security agents in the Boro' fanzine, Fly Me to the Moon . In an article headed 'Shayler at Large', he writes: 'I wish I were doing this routinely without that awful fear of being caught.' Shaylor tells how he stayed in Paris until 1.30am on the match day, pretending to be drunk in a bar, before hopping into a hired Mercedes. He reached England by Euroshuttle and went through customs on a borrowed passport, arriving at the Riverside in time for kick-off. There, he says, he disguised himself with face paint in the club's red and white colours, telling his agent, Chris Joseph, who met him at the stadium, 'to risk all this to see Boro lose would be too cruel'. Fortunately for him, Boro won 2-0.

Scots girls bite back

Celtic's Stilian Petrov - voted Bulgaria's sexiest footballer - has kicked off a massive row in Scotland after criticising the lack of 'decent talent' in his new homeland. 'I'm disappointed with Scottish women because most of them are not beautiful,' he told a local paper. 'There's no room for comparison with Bulgarian girls.' Scottish tabloids were unimpressed. Under the headline: 'Silly bhoy: 'sexy' footballer yearns for land of shot-putters', Scotland's biggest seller the Daily Record printed a picture of hefty shot-putter Svetlana Mitkova as an example of 'Bulgarian beauty'. Stilian has now apologised. 'I absolutely do not think Scottish women are ugly,' he told the Record , posing alongside three attractive female journalists. 'There are in fact some very beautiful ladies in this country.' The Record , however, remain unconvinced that Scottish women will forgive him. 'Next time he goes for a night out,' advises the paper, 'if he's got any sense, he'll fly over one of those strapping female athletes his homeland specialised in under communism - as a bodyguard.'

Lonely Olga could sink Villa

On-loan Villa striker Benito Carbone could be forced out of England in the summer by his lonely wife. Olga Carbone came to this country with better English than her husband, but has been unable to improve her linguistic skills because she doesn't know anyone to practise on. While Carbone himself has adjusted to life in England since his move from Inter to Sheffield Wednesday four years ago, he has become increasingly concerned about his wife's plight. 'I have a big problem with my family,' he tells next month's Match of the Day magazine. 'My wife hasn't spoken to anyone for three years. She doesn't know anybody. When we came to England I knew no English, and she spoke a bit. After four years my English is better, but hers is like the first year. She doesn't talk to anyone. It's so, so difficult.'

Mellor: man without purpose

David Mellor strikes again. Yesterday Crystal Palace supporters launched a glossy Supporters Trust brochure (right), detailing their plans to save the club from liquidation. Championed by manager Steve Coppell, backed by celebrity fans Eddie Izzard and Jo Brand, praised by Culture Secretary Chris Smith, legally drafted by leading law firm Cobbetts, advised by the Football Trust, set up via the Co-operative Bank and now being promoted by the Government as the best, most ambitious example of a supporter-led initiative, the scheme has won backing from fans, professionals, and media commentators alike. With, that is, one exception. Asked for his opinion of the plans on his midweek Radio 5 Live radio phone-in, Voice of the fans , Mellor was amused. 'Shaking a few coffee tins', he told a Palace fan who called up, 'is hardly going to do the trick.' After telling the caller to get real, he cut him off. The consolation: any scheme not backed by Mellor has got to succeed. This one certainly deserves to.

Brochures are available from the Crystal Palace Supporters Trust, Selhurst Park, 122 Whitehorse Lane, London SE25 6XB, 0208 653 7088, trust@cpfc.org. More details from <A HREF="http://www.cpst.org.uk."" TARGET="_NEW">www.cpst.org.uk.

webTitle: Kanu can - but can he against Ehiogu?

fields.headline: Kanu can - but can he against Ehiogu?
fields.trailText: Coventry's manager on Villa v Arsenal.
fields.body:
Some of the men with the responsibility of preventing the opposition creating scoring chances tend to carry it out with greater relish than others. Aston Villa's defender Ugo Ehiogu is a great example, he always gives me the impression that he loves his job. The qualities that separate the top defenders from the rest are concentration and discipline. Ehiogu certainly has them. I am hard-pressed to think of any back man who can take being under pressure more than he does; and it strikes me that if ever there was a good time for him to emphasise this, it would be in today's match against Arsenal.

In view of Arsenal's remarkable 5-1 drubbing of the Spanish league leaders, Deportivo La Coruna, in the Uefa Cup - Deportivo's heaviest European defeat in six years - the challenge facing Ehiogu and Villa's other central defenders, Gareth Barry and Gareth Southgate, would appear mind-boggling.

It says much about the variety of high-class scoring options for Arsenal nowadays that they were able to start the tie with Nwankwo Kanu and Davor Suker on the bench. As for the match itself, I have mixed feelings about the view that Arsenal's performance was one of the best by any British team in Europe for years. To an extent, the scoreline flattered them - there was precious little to choose between the teams until Deportivo had a player sent off, with the Gunners leading 2-1. It was at that point that the visitors disintegrated.

However, some of those Arsenal goals were stunning, and none more so than that effort from Kanu, when he beat two defenders and then, without touching the ball, forced the keeper to dive the wrong way. It was the sort of goal that all attacking players dream of scoring, but would probably be beyond any British player. As I have said before, this man not only comes from a different country, in the football sense he also comes from a different planet.

But it will come as no surprise to me if even Kanu fails to find the net today. Villa have conceded only seven league goals at home, the best record in the Premiership. Moreover, this is a totally different Villa team from the one who appeared to be haunted by relegation worries earlier this season.

In view of their recent League and cup success, it does seem difficult to believe that a short while ago their manager, John Gregory, was reportedly on the verge of being sacked. However, if there is one thing I have learnt as a manager, it concerns the extent to which seemingly small things can transform one's fortunes.

The most vivid ray of hope for any manager in trouble has to be the memory of that misplaced Oxford back-pass in the 1984 Milk Cup tie against Everton - a mistake that led to Everton getting a 1-1 draw and proved to be the launching pad from which their then-beleaguered manager, Howard Kendall, steered the club to the most successful spell in their history.

There are countless other examples of seemingly remarkable turning points. I know it's a truism, but in most cases the key word in explaining the difference between teams at the top and bottom is confidence. It is amazing how easily it can be lost - and regained.

In Villa's case, one thing I have noticed about them is the results when Ehiogu has not been playing. Of the eight first-team games he has missed this season, they have lost five and won only one. He is quick and brave. He is strong in the tackle and in the air. He is one of the most difficult defenders for any striker to play again. It surprises me that Ehiogu has not had more opportunities with the England squad, especially as England use the same defensive system - with three central defenders - as Villa.

Southgate, of course, is firmly established as an international player while Barry, who was brought in to the squad for the first time for the recent clash with Argentina, is widely expected to achieve the same status.

At 18, Barry is already some player. One of the things he has going for him is that he is naturally left-sided. The other is his skill on the ball. It is difficult to disagree with Gregory when he says: 'He has great vision and a great range of passing. His touch on the ball is second to none throughout our whole club.'

However, what Ehiogu has to offer against Arsenal today is no less important.

fields.headline: Explain... Italian melt-down
fields.trailText: Over the past few weeks racism has returned to Italian football, explains Simon Burnton.
fields.body:
Over the past few weeks racism has returned to Italian football. Following Nazi salutes at Lazio, Bari's match against Torino last week ended with the club being fined 30 million lire (£9,500) for the racist behaviour of their fans.

The worst event occurred towards the end of the game; an altercation between the home side's captain Luigi Garzya and Torino's Senegalese defender Djibril Diawara. 'I was elbowed in the face,' explained Diawara, who sustained a broken nose in the incident. 'I went up to Garzya for an explanation. He insulted me terribly and pushed his hand in my face. I was really angry, I shouted but I did not spit. A bit of blood may have accidentally come off my face but I didn't spit.' It was this 'bit of blood' which caused the row: as he walked off the pitch, someone shouted: 'You black bastard, I'm being attacked by Aids.'

Then Eugenio Fascetti (pictured), the Bari manager, compounded the problem in his press conference. 'It would be better if they stayed at home,' he said. 'That spit could be infected.' Fascetti now faces charges from the Italian FA, although he swiftly back-tracked. 'I was referring to those who spit at opponents, and certainly not to blacks and to their countries of origin. Besides, when spit is mixed with blood, it is possible to transmit infections.' Fascetti's black players jumped to his defence, too. 'Fascetti a racist? You've got to be kidding,' said Bari's Moroccan international Rachid Neqrouz. 'If everyone thought like him racism wouldn't be a problem.'

'I'm sure that Garzya only talked about Aids to wind me up,' said Diawara, 'but that doesn't stop it from being offensive. It was offensive to our entire race and the black community, not just me. There are some things that you shouldn't say to anybody.'

fields.headline: Wigan pressure not quite enough
fields.trailText: Even with counter-attractions abounding, from Six Nations action in a rugby-loving community to a Manchester-Mersey derby, the lure of a Second Division promotion clash was great for the Bristolian public, a record Memorial Ground league crowd of 11,109 witnessing two hugely impressive records maintained.
fields.body:
Even with counter-attractions abounding, from Six Nations action in a rugby-loving community to a Manchester-Mersey derby, the lure of a Second Division promotion clash was great for the Bristolian public, a record Memorial Ground league crowd of 11,109 witnessing two hugely impressive records maintained.

It was almost akin to the omnipotent force colliding with the immovable object. Bristol Rovers, Second Division leaders, had not lost at home in over four months, while Wigan Athletic started protecting the country's last remaining unbeaten away record.

Even on a pitch that had required irrigation experts to be called in after the West Country deluge on Thursday, Wigan's incisive counter-attacking style immediately underlined why they are such a good side on their travels.

With Andy Liddell playing in the hole behind the front two, Wigan look to use his pace as promptly as possible. Not having lost a League game on the road since last season's thrilling run-in was ended in their play-off semi-final defeat at Manchester City, Colin Benson's side have only picked up four points from a possible 21 prior to yesterday's crucial clash but they got off to the best possible start.

Simon Haworth, the former Plymouth Argyle and Coventry City target man, was fouled in the centre-circle and, even as the Bristol Rovers defence chugged slowly back into position, the centre-forward dispatched his free-kick over their retreating backs. Liddell reacted most swiftly and, though his shot was a bobbly affair, it decieved on-loan goalkeeper Rhys Evans, Chelsea's fourth-in-line custodian, conceding in the fourth minute of his home debut at the Memorial Ground.

Rovers have not been undone at their high-on-the-hill home since Notts County prevailed here in October but Ian Holloway's resources were fully tested yesterday. The world game stretches far and deep these days and international call-ups had split up Rovers' 43-goal partnership as Jason Roberts, who has scored 22 times, was away for Grenada's tussle with Barbados. And recent signing Nigel Pierre was also off jet-setting, preparing to play for Trinidad and Tobago against Dutch Antilles. If Ian Porterfield can't count on Manchester United's finest, he can always call up Bristol Rovers'.

So Jamie Cureton, scorer of 21 goals this term, was left to lead Holloway's attack and he didn't disappoint. After Steve Foster's shot, following Andy Tillson's flick-on of David Hillier's corner, was superbly tipped on to the crossbar by Roy Carroll, it was the former Norwich City striker who dribbled a way through the Wigan defence only to find the Northern Ireland international custodian twice saving his efforts.

Cureton had a hand in Rovers' equaliser in the 19th minute. It was his pass to the right corner of the penalty area that Roberts' deputy, Nathan Ellington, controlled before displaying some wonderful skill to cross to the back post. There Trevor Challis, who had just switched with Mark Walters to revert to left-wing-back, appeared to strike home the first goal of his professional career, at the age of 24.

Perhaps it was the rigours of a pitch which is home to Bristol Rugby Club as well as Rovers and their reserve team but by the start of the second half Wigan's squad strength was also being challenged. All three substitutes had to be used and, while they dominated the latter period of the first half, it was Rovers who came out firing in the second.

Mark Walters sent Cureton into space and, even though he may have been impeded, the impish forward contrived to get in a shot which skimmed the far post. Then Rob Trees tried his luck from distance and once more Carroll had to stretch.

fields.headline: Watford's woe
fields.trailText: The matchday programme billed him as the saviour of English football, but the West Ham manager Harry Redknapp was having none of it as the game's most talked about teenager lost some sheen by being relegated to the substitutes' bench.
fields.body:
The matchday programme billed him as the saviour of English football, but the West Ham manager Harry Redknapp was having none of it as the game's most talked about teenager lost some sheen by being relegated to the substitutes' bench.

At least Joe Cole will not be relegated from the entire Premier League come the end of the season, as Watford undoubtedly now will be, and it just might be that the youngster learnt more from watching than playing in this uninspiring game.

West Ham had the base for an easy win when they led through first-half goals from Steve Lomas and Paulo Wanchope. But the visitors seemed to lose motivation after the break and Watford finished the stronger side after Heidar Helguson scored, and they probably deserved a draw for their effort.

The East End's finest looked a touch cream crackered coming into this match as the demands of a season which started last July, with the InterToto Cup, seemed to have taken its toll.

After a 4-0 drubbing from Everton last weekend it was no wonder then that Redknapp made four changes to his side, in an attempt, no doubt, to breathe some life into a weary run of two wins in their last 10 games before this one.

Watford, however, dream of such form as they rapidly get cast further adrift at the bottom of the Premiership table and are without a win this year.

So, it came as little surprise that West Ham started the better side and Lomas gave them the lead in their first attack after just three minutes.

Wanchope made it possible when he beat a Nigel Gibbs challenge on the halfway line and ended a forceful run when he found Frank Lampard to his right. The young England midfielder played the ball swiftly into the path of Lomas, who swept a first-time shot into the net from 12 yards out.

Watford almost equalised three minutes later when Peter Kennedy met a Nordin Wooter cross at the far post but he could do nothing more as he stood and watched his powerful header squeezed on to the crossbar and over by the visiting goalkeeper Craig Forrest.

But there was little to commend from either side until the Costa Rican Wanchope -still the subject of much transfer speculation this week - produced one of his truly magical moments, as only he can, to score West Ham's second goal in the 35th minute.

He juggled a Trevor Sinclair pass from his shoulder to his head to beat the defender Robert Page, and then let the ball bounce before swinging a powerful right-foot volley to send the ball booming into the top of the net.

Graham Taylor fears he is in a minority of one in his belief that his team can avoid relegation. Indeed, before kick-off today he said as much although he was quick to justify it by adding that a football miracle was also needed.

And so it was that the Watford manager vainly attempted to save this game by making a triple substitution at half time. It worked, for a time at least, in that Watford dominated for a spell after the re-start, first going close with a sweetly struck Allan Smart volley.

They finally broke through in the 62nd minute through Helguson in the 62nd minute.

The Icelandic international benefited when Wooter's run at the West Ham defence was blocked, and the ball broke kindly for Helguson to volley in his third goal in six Watford appearances.

It was a start, yes, but surely not enough in the time remaining to turn Taylor's dream of a footballing miracle into reality.

fields.headline: United survive Berger's bullet
fields.trailText: Manchester United have now dropped four of their last six Premiership points since the victory over Leeds that seemed to have settled this season's title argument.
fields.body:
Manchester United have now dropped four of their last six Premiership points since the victory over Leeds that seemed to have settled this season's title argument.

With a seven-point lead there is no need to panic, but supporters are starting to wonder if the Jaap Stam and Dwight Yorke of last season have been body-switched by aliens. United are not playing well and could have had few complaints had a below-strength Liverpool recorded a first Old Trafford victory for 10 years.

In the end it was the visitors who left complaining, particularly about the circumstances surrounding Ole Gunnar Solskjaer's equaliser on the stroke of half-time. United had not succeeded in making any impression on Liverpool's defence throughout the first half, but when a studs-up challenge by Solskjaer saw the excellent Sami Hyypia depart on a stretcher five minutes before the interval, Gérard Houllier delayed making a substitution and saw his gamble doubly backfire. First Solskjaer had the cheek to take advantage during the period Liverpool were down to 10 men, and then when Hyypia hobbled out for the start of the second half he quickly realised he could not carry on and had to be substituted after all.

'Solskjaer is not a nasty player and he apologised at half-time, but I was very unhappy about the challenge,' said Houllier, who made his feelings known to the United striker at the time of the incident. The Liverpool manager took responsibility for waiting while Hyypia had stitches inserted into an ankle wound, claiming the tall Finn was so important to the defence it was worth giving him every chance. As Solskjaer was able to prove. 'They are so clinical, they are better than us in front of the box,' Houllier said. 'They only had one chance in the first half and scored - we came off at half-time with the feeling we had been really unfairly treated.'

As Liverpool, by Houllier's own admission, created and squandered at least four clear additional goal chances, perhaps they ought to be satisfied with a point and the knowledge that they had the champions worried. Still lacking Jamie Redknapp and Robbie Fowler, with Steven Gerrard suspended and Vegard Heggem lasting only half as long as Hyypia before sustaining a hamstring injury, they certainly gave United a game, even if Houllier's argument for a moral victory was undermined by Jamie Carragher having to clear off his line three times.

A draw was fair, both managers agreed, but whereas Sir Alex Ferguson said he was pleased by his teams effort and intensity, Houllier will reflect on what might have been had he handled his three substitutions differently. He had little choice over Heggem after 16 minutes, but Rigobert Song at right back was given a roasting by the in-form Ryan Giggs, giving United an attacking lifeline which ultimately led to their equaliser.

Song was not in position when Giggs got through on the left and though Carragher partially blocked the cross, the ball sat up for Solskjaer to score with a deflection off Dominic Matteo.

Carragher was switched to centre-back for the second half, with Danny Murphy replacing Hyypia, but was unable to perform with his earlier authority. United were able to get into the Liverpool box with comparative ease in the second half and Liverpool had cause to thank Carragher. A superb pass from Giggs took out Song and Stephane Henchoz and allowed Solskjaer to beat Sander Westerveld, but the goalkeeper slowed the shot allowing Carragher to tidy up.

By the time the same defender had also denied Giggs and then Teddy Sheringham in the final minute, he could be said to have atoned for the two own-goals he contributed to United's 3-2 victory at Anfield in September.

Liverpool's third substitution was to introduce Michael Owen for the last 15 minutes. A clever pass from Murphy put him clear on Raimond van der Gouw almost immediately, perhaps too quickly, for Owen produced a chip which bounced tamely wide rather than a match-winner.

Vladimir Smicer had no such excuses 10 minutes earlier, and Liverpool could also have done with Patrik Berger and Titi Camara finishing more clinically. Liverpool had to be content with Berger's opening goal, a piledriving free-kick which fairly whistled past Van der Gouw after Stam had clumsily brought down fellow Dutchman Erik Meijer at what he probably thought was a safe distance 30 yards out.

It is doubtful Mark Bosnich would have stopped the shot either, even if he had been playing. 'Mark doesn't enjoy being left out, but he's part of a pool of players,' Ferguson said. 'I left two fantastic strikers out today. Nobody likes that.'

fields.headline: Showman Wright eclipsed
fields.trailText: 'Wrighty, Wrighty, what's the score?' mocked the 4,000 followers of Preston as this clinical destruction was completed. The message wasn't so much meant as an insult to the biggest icon on the field as an indication of priorities for these famous old clubs: Burnley could keep their showbiz attraction, North End would sooner focus on promotion.
fields.body:
'Wrighty, Wrighty, what's the score?' mocked the 4,000 followers of Preston as this clinical destruction was completed. The message wasn't so much meant as an insult to the biggest icon on the field as an indication of priorities for these famous old clubs: Burnley could keep their showbiz attraction, North End would sooner focus on promotion.

There was something surreal about Ian Wright's infiltration of this age-old local affair. An awe inspiring, almost alien presence, oozing London cool and television host twinkle, gatecrashing the earthy hostility of a history-stoked Lancashire derby. It was like a character from EastEnders breezing into an intimate gathering at the Rovers Return.

Getting his name into a fanzine named Bob Lord's Sausage (in honour of the club's former chairman) is surely a new experience for the striker who has packed everything from non-league dreams through FA bans to Premiership medals into his treasure chest of football memories.

Anyone who thought a step down the divisions would make for gentler afternoons was much mistaken. This was physical, frenetic and bruising, marked by late tackles and reckless arms. A violent, two-footed assault by Lenny Johnrose on Sean Gregan ended the Preston captain's involvement after eight minutes. Feelings were running high. Before half-time the Clarets were reduced to 10 men when Dean West was punished for the second of two clumsy hacks.

Evidence of the fever ignited by the effervescent striker - Ian Wright Wright Wright scarves were doing a fine trade outside the ground before kick off - had melted into far hotter emotions.

Preston's determined start paved the way for an early goal, Michael Jackson's powerful header arcing into the top corner inside 90 seconds.

North End looked the better side in the opening period and were unlucky not to increase their lead. Burnley needed a surge of inspiration to peg their neighbours back, and it almost arrived courtesy of Wright. Twice around the half hour mark he steered headers agonisingly close to Tepi Moilanen's goal.

There is no doubting the effect Wright has had since his arrival. The corresponding fixture a year ago attracted half this attendance. A new season ticket deal for the remaining home games has been unveiled to deal with fresh demand.

Quite what Preston president Tom Finney made of Burnley's veteran signing is anybody's guess. The 77-year- old one time England ally of Sir Stanley Matthews can reflect, like Wright, on the cherished experience of scoring for his country and setting goal records for the club closest to his heart.

Then again there are notable differences. Gentleman Tom, a one-club man, was never booked and always renowned for his sportsmanship.

Having promised he would see out his career at Highbury, Wright has worn the colours of four clubs this season: from the claret and blue of West Ham to Burnley, via the red of Nottingham Forest and the green and white of Celtic.

And so to Lancashire, a county that is reviving itself as a powerhouse in the game. With Bolton in the FA Cup semi-finals and Blackburn only recently exiled from the Premiership, the fact that Burnley and Preston can attract a sell-out gate of 22,000 for a Second Division game makes the footballing heart beat faster for these high flying clubs. An ambitiously refurbished Turf Moor would not look out of place in the Premiership.

But it looks like Preston are closer to that pipe dream. This result has certainly given their promotion push a much needed fillip after a Deepdale blip that saw them drop five points from a possible six. In fact they have accrued more on their travels than at home this season.

Burnley, though, deserved credit for a brief rally in the second half in spite of their depleted numbers. Stan Ter nant's men regained their composure and they applied pressure with a series of corners.

The more they pushed, though, the more they were vulnerable to the counter attack. And how brutally they were punished. During one four white shirts bore down on two clarets, but Paul Crichton stood his ground to beat away brilliantly from Iain Anderson.

Respite was brief. Moments later Crichton denied Anderson again, only for the ball to bounce straight back to the North End man. His square pass found Jonathon Macken in ample space to pick his spot for his 23rd goal of the season. Then Rob Edwards got in on the party, squeezing a low drive into the bottom corner from 25 yards.

Having promised he would see out his career at Highbury, Wright has worn the colours of four clubs this season: from the claret and blue of West Ham to Burnley, via the red of Nottingham Forest and the green and white of Celtic. And so to Lancashire, a county that is reviving itself as a powerhouse in the game. With Bolton in the FA Cup semi-finals and Blackburn only recently exiled from the Premiership, the fact that Burnley and Preston can attract a sell-out gate of 22,000 for a Second Division game makes the footballing heart beat faster for these high flying clubs. An ambitiously refurbished Turf Moor would not look out of place in the Premiership. But it looks like Preston are closer to that pipe dream. This result has certainly given their promotion push a much needed fillip after a Deepdale blip that saw them drop five points from a possible six. In fact they have accrued more on their travels than at home this season. Burnley, though, deserved credit for a brief rally in the second half in spite of their depleted numbers. Stan Ter nant's men regained their composure and they applied pressure with a series of corners. The more they pushed, though, the more they were vulnerable to the counter attack. And how brutally they were punished. During one four white shirts bore down on two clarets, but Paul Crichton stood his ground to beat away brilliantly from Iain Anderson. Respite was brief. Moments later Crichton denied Anderson again, only for the ball to bounce straight back to the North End man. His square pass found Jonathon Macken in ample space to pick his spot for his 23rd goal of the season. Then Rob Edwards got in on the party, squeezing a low drive into the bottom corner from 25 yards.

fields.headline: Return of Kinkladze the king
fields.trailText: Manchester City fans will recognise the symptoms: the swooning, the adulation, the sheer love the man inspires. Yet, Georgi Kinkladze is back to his best. Only this time the love affair may not end in the disappointment of unfulfilled promises.
fields.body:
Manchester City fans will recognise the symptoms: the swooning, the adulation, the sheer love the man inspires. Yet, Georgi Kinkladze is back to his best. Only this time the love affair may not end in the disappointment of unfulfilled promises.

Kinkladze wooed the home faithful with his best performance since he was forced to quit Maine Road for Ajax nearly two years ago. Kinkladze, on loan till the end of the season, scored the goal which set Derby on the road to a vital victory which eases their own relegation fears but increases Wimbledon's substantially.

Just as used to be the case when he was with Manchester City, Kinkladze's love affair with the home fans grew with every flick and cheeky touch. But, as it also used to be at Maine Road, it was the visitors who threatened the greater cutting edge, a point illustrated as Wimbledon went close three times in just four minutes.

First, in the 37th minute, Seth Jobson blocked Jason Euell and then two minutes later Carl Cort saw a close range header brilliantly beaten out by Mart Poom. Cort again came close in the 41st minute with another header from an Alan Kimble corner that scraped the top of the crossbar.

But Kinkladze consummated his relationship with Derby when he put them ahead in the 65th minute. Stefano Eranio passed to Malcolm Christie, who laid the ball into the path of the Georgian on the edge of the area to place a shot beyond Sullivan.

If there is a rival for Kinkladze's affections then it is Christie, who scored the second goal six minutes later. Even then Kinkladze contributed indirectly. The fact he was off the pitch receiving treatment seemed to throw Wimbledon's defence into confusion.

So when Horacio Carbonari's free kick was fired in they all seemed to be wondering where Kinkladze was and had forgotten about Christie as he fired a shot into the roof of the net. Christie left the pitch to his own standing ovation two minutes from time and it was left to the substitutes, Deon Burton and Dean Sturridge, to wrap up victory with two goals in the final minute.

fields.headline: Poyet sting for Robson
fields.trailText: Newcastle United's unbeaten home record under Bobby Robson was always likely to be tested to the limit by a Chelsea team whose recent results include impressive performances in Turkey and Italy.
fields.byline: John Wardle at St James' Park
fields.body:
Newcastle United's unbeaten home record under Bobby Robson was always likely to be tested to the limit by a Chelsea team whose recent results include impressive performances in Turkey and Italy.

So it proved as Gustavo Poyet's goal midway through the first half ensured Chelsea broke down the barricades of a ground that Newcastle fans had started calling Fortress St James' after 14 games without defeat.

Chelsea, so lacklustre in Marseille in midweek, held on with a determination - epitomised by Dennis Wise and Emerson Thome - which indicated it may be premature to dismiss them in the Premiership reckoning.

Defeat in France may have damaged their European ambitions this season, but they could yet finish high enough in the league to feature among the Champions League qualifiers.

The return of former England defender Steve Howey for his first league game in 12 months provided a lift for Newcastle, but there was a flipside. A defence, looking sound lately, was reshuffled to accommodate Howey, whose recovery from an achilles injury had proved lengthy and complicated.

Robson reverted to the three-man defence which he has used on occasions this season, but they looked uncomfortable against Chelsea's front two - on this occasion Chris Sutton and Gianfranco Zola.

When Zola is winning the ball in the air on the edge of the area, as he did midway through the first half, you know you have problems. The uncertainty transmitted itself to the midfield

Indeed, one of Robert Lee's misdirected passes led directly to the 21st minute goal which rewarded Chelsea's organised and thoughtful start to the game.

Lee, under no pressure, played the ball straight to Roberto Di Matteo who waited for Jody Morris to overlap enthusiastically. Morris's eventual cross carried enough power and accuracy to make Gustavo Poyet's near post header a formality.

Newcastle are unaccustomed to being behind at St James' Park, where their form has been formidable since the arrival of Bobby Robson. And their efforts to repair the damage were not assisted by the lack of width which inevitably accompanied their formation and Robson's decision to restrict Nol berto Solano to the bench. They had their opportunities, though, even with Alan Shearer and Duncan Ferguson policed in muscular fashion by Frank Leboeuf and Emerson Thome.

Chelsea keeper Ed De Goey, one clean sheet away from beating a record set by Stamford Bridge legend Peter Bonetti, illustrated why 21 teams had thus far failed to find a way past him. Even so, he he had some trouble with a 20th-minute Speed drive that he clutched at the second attempt.

Speed again found De Goey in his way when he was the first to meet a Lee cross, but the Dutch keeper's finest moment of the opening half came in the dying seconds. Ferguson finally rediscovered his touch to play in Keiron Dyer, whose burst into the area and first-time shot was met with a fine reaction save by the keeper.

To nobody's surprise, Robson's reaction to such an unconvincing start was to turn to Solano, the Peruvian who angered his manager by his determination to play in the Gold Cup last month.

Didier Domi was the player sacrificed as United reverted to a more familiar four-man defence and the effect was virtually instantaneous.

Aaron Hughes, freed to drive forward down the left, delivered an excellent cross which De Goey dropped on as two Newcastle players moved in.

Chelsea's first change three minutes into the second half was not as beneficial to their prospects, with Di Matteo leaving his replacement Dan Petrescu uncomfortable on the left of midfield.

But Gianluca Vialli's team still possessed enough composure to pass the ball sweetly and leave Newcastle looking increasingly frustrated as a disappointing half wore on.

fields.headline: Jewell's work ethic pays off
fields.trailText: Paul Jewell, Bradford's forthright manager, had admitted before the game that his side might not be able to compete with the big boys in terms of pure football, but they would not be found wanting in terms of commitment and effort.
fields.byline: Gerry Cox at White Hart Lane
fields.body:
Paul Jewell, Bradford's forthright manager, had admitted before the game that his side might not be able to compete with the big boys in terms of pure football, but they would not be found wanting in terms of commitment and effort.

His point was perfectly illustrated in a one-sided first-half, when after being outplayed and outclassed by Tottenham, Bradford equalised shortly before the break with their first effort on target.

It was Jamie Lawrence, no longer sporting a scarlet coiffure, who left the Spurs defence red-faced when he exchanged passes with the two Deans - Saunders and Windass - before slipping the ball past Ian Walker.

Although it was against the run of play, the goal could not be called undeserved if only because Bradford's refusal to buckle under enormous pressure from Spurs was admirable. Aidan Davison, in particular, was outstanding in goal. He may be Bradford's third-choice goalkeeper, playing only because of injuries, but he produced three superb saves in the opening period.

His first was a tip over at full stretch to keep out a looping shot from David Ginola that took a heavy deflection off David Wetherall in the tenth minute. From the ensuing corner, Chris Perry had a full-blooded drive from 20 yards that was not only saved but superbly held at full-stretch by Davison. He had little chance with Tottenham's goal in the 14th minute, however. Ginola was fouled by Gunnar Halle out on the left, and Darren Anderton's free-kick to the far post was headed over the line by Steffen Iversen.

Steve Carr then sent the lively Anderton in for a good chance, but again Davison saved well, and then the keeper made another excellent low stop to keep out a flick from Chris Armstrong following a well worked move down the right.

Bradford's only serious effort up to that point had come when Saunders sprang the offside trap in the 18th minute, took the ball round Walker on the edge of the area but shot wide of the far post from a tight angle. However, Lawrence restored parity in the 41st minute to send the sides in level.

The second half followed much the same pattern - crunching tackles, hopeful balls forward and desperate clearances - only this time it was from Spurs. Bradford did what they do best, Spurs could find no answer and they were soon reduced to the same level. Players who had previously looked sharp, bright and inventive ran out of steam or ideas, while Bradford began to dominate midfield.

Consequently there were few clear-cut chances. Ginola tried tirelessly to provide some inspiration, but Davison was not called upon to repeat his first-half heroics. Even when Les Ferdinand was introduced as a substitute, giving George Graham the luxury of three fit forwards on the field for the first time in six months, Spurs could not score. Ferdinand headed over, Iversen flashed a volley just wide, but in the end it was Bradford who were celebrating. Spurs, meanwhile, will talk to John Hartson today with a view to signing him.

fields.headline: Hoddle pays penalty
fields.trailText: There still remains the possibility that two teams managed by former England managers will be relegated this season, following Southampton's failure to win a match they should have yesterday afternoon.
fields.body:
There still remains the possibility that two teams managed by former England managers will be relegated this season, following Southampton's failure to win a match they should have yesterday afternoon.

Graham Taylor is almost down and Glenn Hoddle is not yet safe. If Southampton had defeated a Middlesbrough team who came for just the one point, they would have gone level with them and too far away from Bradford. Now, as Glenn Hoddle wrote in the programme: 'Football teaches you that something is always round the corner....'

For the visit of Middlesbrough Hoddle opted for 4-4-2 with Pahars and Mathew Oakley filling the wide roles in an adventurous midfield. It seemed a clever system as Southampton made a bright start with Marian Pahars in particular moving in from the right and threatening in the middle.

Meanwhile at the other end Francis Benali and Hamilton Ricard got to work. Ricard banging into Benali, Benali nailing him back, and a friendly brush of foreheads prior to a corner. Then it was back to Pahars with a 25-yard lob being palmed desperately away by Mark Schwarzer. Back at the other end Benali allowed Richard through and then felled him with a perfectly fair but perfectly violent challenge. Twenty minutes in and the pattern was established. Wizardry from Pahars at one end; Benali versus Ricard at the other. The Good, The Bad and the Ugly (in the footballing sense, that is Benali is no more physically ugly than Ricard is a bad man).

Middlesbrough appeared lopsided. Either Bryan Robson had forgotten to pick a right-sided midfielder or Neil Maddison and Mark Summerbell were ignoring instructions and making a bid for the vacant England left sided midfield role.

Despite this imbalance they nearly took an unlikely lead. Maddison should have done better with a shot from just inside the area and a chip from Summerbell drifted over. Middlesbrough were being out-played but they were creating the better chances and after the Saints offside trap collapsed to reveal a gaping hole Ricard should have scored.

As should Hassan Kachloul for Southampton. Feeble defending by Boro allowed him a free shot on the turn from six yards. He hit the ball cleanly but too near Schwarzer who saved well.

Southampton then took the lead, Pahars twisting through on the right side before curling a left foot shot from outside the area just inside the far post. Less than a minute later the game was level. Claus Lundekvam pulled on Brian Deane's shirt the referee Steve Dunn awarded a penalty and Ricard scored from the spot.

The shirt tugging continued as Colin Cooper pulled at Jo Tessem and was perhaps fortunate to escape a yellow card. Matters became bad tempered. Plenty of niggle, and, Pahars aside, very little dribble. Summerbell and Deane were both booked for chaotic challenges and a red card seemed more likely than a winning goal. Southampton forced corners but made no use of them. Too often simple passes went astray; too rarely was anything more complicated attempted.

Middlesbrough, meanwhile, just existed. It was not until the 70th minute that Juninho made his first contribution when playing a nice one-two with Deane but then scuffing his shot. The game petered out in the most pitiful manner. Speculative shots always going wide and much huff-and-puff. In the 84th minute, Robbie Mustoe came on for Juninho. It had become that kind of game.

fields.headline: Everton ride their luck
fields.trailText: While the other half of Merseyside received its early- morning alarm call to take part in one of the showcase games on the British football calendar, Everton turned over and hit the snooze button.
fields.body:
While the other half of Merseyside received its early- morning alarm call to take part in one of the showcase games on the British football calendar, Everton turned over and hit the snooze button.

For Liverpool and Manchester United, there is the promise of Champions League football next season. Bizarrely, the two combatants at Goodison could also be in Europe next year, Everton via the dreaded InterToto Cup and Wednesday possibly through the even more absurd Fair Play card. As a preview of potential Uefa Cup representatives, this was an embarrassment.

It is a sign of the strides taken at Everton under Walter Smith that a time of year that has of late seen supporters casting anxious glances at the bottom of the Premiership has the club firmly established in the division's top 10.

Further, with only seven fixtures remaining at Goodison this year, starting with this visit of Wednesday, there is the real prospect of Everton going through an entire sea son unbeaten at home. Heady stuff, especially considering the last time they achieved such a feat, in 1962-63, they were crowned First Division champions. But if there was a danger of getting carried away by such prospects, the quality of football in the first half yesterday removed any such concerns.

With the sun shining, the game bore more than a passing resemblance to the sort of meaningless end-of-season contest that will surely become the norm for Wednesday long before the middle of May, so inevitable is their fate.

At least there was a goal to momentarily lift the tedium, although it said more about Sheffield's defending than any offensive flare on Everton's part. A 34th-minute left-wing corner from Nick Barmby found centre-half David Weir unmarked inside the six- yard box and presented with a free header, 1-0.

It was hard to see Wednesday forcing their way back although in Niclas Alexandersson they possess a player of some skill and guile. In fact, the Swedish winger might have given Sheffield the most unlikely of leads after three minutes following interplay between Danny Sonner and Gilles De Bilde, only for his shot to be saved.

Aside from two wasted off-target long-distance strikes from Mark Pembridge, they were the sum total of goalmouth incidents in a first half that could not end quickly enough.

The suspicion that Everton, so impressive in a 4-0 victory at West Ham last week, had been dragged down to their opponents' level, was confirmed after the interval. Slow to the ball, inaccurate in the pass, unsure at the back, they capitulated the first time Wednesday had the ball in the home area, after 49 minutes.

Gerald Sibon collected an Alexandersson pass, saw his cross deflected but turned the rebound into the path of Alan Quinn who drove in the first goal of his career from 15 yards. There was little improvement thereafter and if De Bilde had not been so honest, keeping his feet and seeing a shot saved by Thomas Myhre after a clear foul by David Unsworth, Wednesday would have had a penalty and the chance to end that unbeaten Goodison run.

webTitle: Adebola joy as Little is abused

fields.headline: Adebola joy as Little is abused
fields.trailText: Trevor Francis could not have been more wrong. The Birmingham City manager had predicted a tight, tense local Derby against a side scrapping for their First Division lives.
fields.body:
Trevor Francis could not have been more wrong. The Birmingham City manager had predicted a tight, tense local Derby against a side scrapping for their First Division lives.

What he got was a one-sided victory of almost embarrassing proportions that stretched his own team's impressive run since the turn of the year.

At one stage of the season, Birmingham were in thirteenth place, having accumulated a crippling injury list embracing 14 players. Now, they have collected 25 points from their last 10 games and look a good bet to preserve a play-off position.

fields.headline: Time please to ban booze
fields.trailText: The press this week has been full of accounts from Chelsea fans about the behaviour of the French riot police and the Marseille supporters. All the accounts have one thing in common.
fields.body:
In the pub after Spurs' home game with Chelsea I found myself apologising for the behaviour of the so-called Tottenham fans who had ambushed and attacked two of my friends, one of whom was pregnant. Despite this frightening incident they told me of their plans to go to Marseilles for Chelsea's European game. I recalled for them my experience in Marseilles with England and warned them not to go. They now wish they had taken my advice.

The press this week has been full of accounts from Chelsea fans about the behaviour of the French riot police and the Marseille supporters. All the accounts have one thing in common. The police did nothing about the throwing of missiles by the French fans and the police treated the away fans like animals. Those England fans who went to Italy for the World Cup qualifier will know what the Chelsea fans were talking about. There is little doubt in my mind that the Chelsea fans' accounts of events are entirely accurate and the use of tear gas was totally unacceptable. But if ever there was a case for the majority suffering at the hands of the tiny minority, this was it, because no one can deny that there was a small group of Chelsea fans out to cause trouble. They were part of the fascist Combat 18-linked 'Chelsea Headhunters', and London police confirmed that one of the Chelsea fans arrested was known to the National Criminal Intelligence Service but not subject to an exclusion order. Why not? This incident comes in the same week that Michael Johnson, the Birmingham City defender, received a death threat from Combat 18.

While we may only have a relatively small problem with racism in British football and the Johnson case shows it's still there, in Italy it's still a major cause for concern. Things have got so bad at Lazio that some Italian fans now call them Nazio. The infamous 'Curva Nord' fans have recently been unfurling racist and fascist banners including one with a picture of the Serbian war criminal Arkan with the words 'We all respect and love Arkan' and another inscribed 'Niggers go home'.

Anti racist groups have been shocked that the authorities have taken so little effective action. They blame the Lazio owner, Sergio Cragnotti, and point to the fact that Lazio have no black players - a bit like Everton some years ago. Cragnotti was forced to act, however, when Feyenoord made it clear to Lazio that they would take their players off the pitch if any racist banners appeared during their Champions League match. No banners were seen but racist chants persist. Some players are now beginning to talk out, with Roma's Damiano Tommasi saying: 'The violence in the stands, the insults, the racist chants, the banners all pain me tremendously.'

Bari, too, has a reputation for racism and a recent incident against Torino has done nothing to dispel it.

One wonders why there was not much trouble when the Chelsea mob met up with the Lazio scum in Rome last year. But it was the Leeds fans who occupied the 'Curva Nord' this week in the Olympic Stadium and it was they who had a little taste of Roman hospitality from the 'Curva Sud', the Roma end of the ground. One teenage fan was stabbed and others were attacked outside the Stadium.

Before the return visit of Lazio to London, Chelsea have the little matter of a visit to Rotterdam. More than likely the fans will go to Amsterdam first to sample the nightlife and get stoned as well as drunk.There is no doubt that trouble in Marseilles during the World Cup was almost entirely due to drinking and that something can be done about it. In Italy in 1990 there was a drinks ban for 24 hours before every game and this undoubtedly helped in keeping down the violence. The FA has failed to persuade Charleroi to do the same before the England-Germany game, so don't expect a peaceful summer.
