fields.headline: A whole Lothar love...
fields.standfirst: Surprise, surprise. People are warming to Lothar Matthäus as the end of an era draws near
fields.trailText: They say you should never meet your heroes, but it's also dangerous to meet your villains: Simon Kuper now thinks Lothar Matthäus is a nice guy.
fields.body:
A crocodile of tracksuited German footballers mooches into the conference room for a team talk. At the back is a little middle-aged man with a large head, waving and pulling faces at bystanders to show how boring the talk will be. At 38, Lothar Matthäus is recognisably a child.

On Tuesday, in the Champions League against Real Madrid, he plays his last game for Bayern Munich. Two days later he flies to New York, to take up residence just off Central Park and play for the local MetroStars, an outfit described a while ago as 'the worst team in soccer'. Even though he will return to play for Germany in Euro 2000, an era ends this week.

After the team talk the players mooch out of the conference room, all but Erich Ribbeck, the German coach, and his two senior players, Matthäus and Oliver Bierhoff. When Bierhoff leaves, he smiles at the waiting journalists. 'You have an interview with Matthäus? Always interesting!'

Matthäus can no longer find anyone to call on his mobile phone, so the half-dozen journalists from around Europe are invited into the room vacated by his team-mates. The notepads on their desks are covered with talentless doodles.

We sit down and Matthäus sends us to the drinks cabinet to stock up, checks that everyone's tape recorder works. Then, for almost two hours, he talks. At one point he says, 'I'm saying everything tonight, talking from the sewing box' - a German phrase for giving away private details.

Matthäus always talks from the sewing box. It explains why there isn't a statue of him in every German town. For most of his extraordinary career he was admired but disliked.

Born in 1961 in a small town in northern Bavaria, Matthäus grew up in a Germany that barely exists any more: a poor country, where the economic miracle was still unfolding and had yet to reach his family. His father worked in the local Puma factory. There was drink around the house. After school Matthäus qualified as an interior decorator, expecting a life of laying carpets.

But in 1979 he turned pro at Borussia Mönchengladbach, and in the European Championship of 1980, made his debut for Germany against Holland. He gave away a penalty, though he still claims the foul was outside the area. Soon after, on a German winter tour of South America, he marked Diego Maradona and Zico out of matches.

'I think my breakthrough was at the World Cup 1986,' he told us. Germany reached the final against Argentina, where the coach, Franz Beckenbauer, put him on Maradona again.

'That was a mistake of Franz Beckenbauer's, I think. I concentrated on Maradona, but we neglected our own game. When they went 2-0 up we changed it around, Karl-Heinz Förster was put on Maradona, I went forward more and we got back to 2-2. Then we made a dumb mistake and lost.'

Even so, from then on Matthäus was now Germany's main man, the 'Chef' as the Germans say. The problem was that he got up everybody's nose. Opponents considered him the ultimate gamesman: no referee could spot his fouls, but typically, it was a Matthäus dive in 1986 that led to a red card for the Dane Frank Arnesen, whose World Cup ended there.

His team-mates objected to Matthäus' chatter. Saying horrible things about colleagues and leaking to newspapers are traditions of German football, but Matthäus took them a bit far. He could not seem to cope for a second without attention. Also, irritatingly, he talked about himself in the third person.

Ribbeck, German assistant manager in the early 1980s, commented, 'Even when we're discussing the meal plan, he quacks something in between.' Rudi Völler, a team-mate, once advised him to direct his views at the toilet seat. Yet as a player Matthäus was only getting better. In Germany's first match of the 1990 World Cup against Yugoslavia, he scored twice and led his team to a 4-1 victory from which they never looked back. 'It was the best game of my international career. Important in a big tournament is how you start. With a great match at the start you can distance yourself from the unrest from outside. And it increases the respect among opponents.'

A few weeks later, after another final against Maradona, he was standing in a Roman stadium wearing a captain's armband and holding aloft the World Cup. He was 29 and at his peak. In 1990 he was voted World Sportsman, World Footballer, European Sportsman, European Footballer and German Footballer of the Year.

What kind of a player was he then?

'I was certainly no Maradona,' he says. 'I was a very fast player. When I saw a space, I used it. When I went past somebody, he didn't catch up with me again. I was a player who came with a run-up. What Maradona could see in a small space, I saw over long distances.'

Was he complete?

'I'm small, but for instance I'm good at heading. Yes, the thing that made me strong was that I had something of everything. I always had a weak left foot, and Trapattoni taught me to use my left. I was 28 then.'

And, we say, there is his will to win. Whereas for some players everything is fine again half an hour after a defeat, for you...

Matthäus interrupts. 'Five minutes after the game everything is fine again! After the Champions League final against Manchester, I had to comfort my girlfriend, not she me. She was more upset than I was.'

The complete footballer , yet he always lacked something. Towering over the German game is the figure of Franz Beckenbauer. 'Der Kaiser' was imperious: elegant, calm, cool. Matthäus was desperate for attention, ostentatiously trying. When the legendary photographer Annie Leibowitz shot him for a credit card advertisement, it was as an exhausted labourer covered in sweat.

Beckenbauer was above the fray; Matthäus was in the middle of the fray.

Even on the pitch he was human. With five minutes to go in that World Cup final of 1990, and the score 0-0, Germany won a penalty. Matthäus was the penalty taker, but it was Andy Brehme who stepped up to put the ball into the bottom corner. Later it emerged that the boots in which Matthäus had played for four years had given out during the marathon semi-final against England in Turin. He lacked sufficient faith in the new ones to place a penalty-kick. Even so, it would never have happened to Beckenbauer.

In April 1992, playing for Inter Milan, Matthäus tore a knee ligament. For a 32-year-old footballer, this looked like the beginning of the end.

One day he got a phone call from Beckenbauer, who had become Bayern president.

Matthäus said: 'Look, Franz, I don't feel right here.'

'So come back to Bayern,' said Beckenbauer.

'But Franz, I have a ligament injury.'

'I know you have a ligament injury. Come back to Bayern.'

Inter, thinking he was a long way from fitness, sold him for about £1.4 million. Twenty-five days later he was playing in the Bundesliga again.

Then, at the Munich beer festival, he allegedly told a Dutch tourist who was irritating him: 'They forgot you in Adolf's time.' The story broke.

Alleged racist and sexist comments have been a feature of Matthäus's career. He is no fascist, just a bad boy saying naughty things. The one member of the German side who upbraided him for them was Jürgen Klinsmann, who was growing into the team's new 'Chef'.

Klinsmann is Matthäus's opposite: a man at ease with himself, diplomatic and, by footballers' standards, intellectual. 'He thinks too much,' says Matthäus.

Both men played at the 1994 World Cup where Germany were knocked out in the quarter-finals, after every conversation in the team camp had made the papers. Matthäus and Klinsmann came to hate one another. Berti Vogts, the manager, sided with Klinsmann. Matthäus says he now regards the public row with Vogts and Klinsmann as the biggest mistake of his career.

From 1994 to 1998 he did not play for Germany. It was said the players had decided to do without him. Much of the time he was injured anyway, again apparently nearing retirement. Vogts said he caused unrest. Beckenbauer said of him, 'If you talk a lot, you talk a lot of nonsense.'

How upset Matthäus was became clear when he published My Diary in 1997. The book is distinguished chiefly by the banality of the entries, which are reminiscent of Adrian Mole. There is also the bitterness familiar from politicians' diaries. On Sunday 21 July 1996 Matthäus writes from the Bayern training camp: 'Today the European champions have returned: Helmer, Ziege, Babbel, Kahn, Strunz and Scholl. There was a big hallo. And from me, sincerely felt congratulations. European champions - for all of them, it's the peak of their careers.'

Or, decoded: 'None of them won the World Cup.'

Gradually everything came right for him. His injuries cleared, while those of the much younger Sammer did not. The German side got worse. When Vogts recalled him for the 1998 World Cup, he gladly came back. As he once said, 'If I couldn't speak to or work with all the people with whom I've had problems, I'd often be alone on the pitch.'

This return was a mixed success: Germany went out in the quarter-finals again, but Matthäus played quite well. Still, he seemed to be joking when he said after the competition, 'Quit? Why would I want to do a thing like that?'

And, yet, there he still is. He says, 'I like football. It's fun winning the ball from someone, it's fun shooting at goal, it's fun hitting a ball over 60 metres that arrives. It's like in golf: if you hit a ball and it flies and flies and flies, you enjoy it.' And if you don't play, you don't get attention.

As the German team declined he became more important. After they lost 3-0 to the United States a year ago, Matthäus was called to Ribbeck's hotel room, where he explained that Germany had to play with two wingers. It came to pass.

With Matthäus as libero, Germany qualified for Euro 2000. But as Beckenbauer said, even if they were dragged out of their beds in the middle of the night to play barefoot, the World Cup winners of 1990 would beat this team.

Matthäus himself is not the player he was. Yet he has become more popular. 'In the last two or three years I haven't noticed the same whistles, the same songs against me. I think that for many people, even in other professions, I have become a sort of example.' He claims that a man in his fifties had written to him saying that he had successfully cited Matthäus in a job interview, as proof that performance matters and not age.

His team-mates, too, have learned not to take him seriously. When there is a story in Bild , or Kicker , they grin and say, 'Oh, Lothar.' And most of the time he is kind. To younger players, he can be something of an uncle.

He becomes enthused when he talks about New York. In previous months he had worried the Americans with comments such as, 'They can't drag me to New York in handcuffs. I've been misled and deceived. That can be done with others, but not with me.'

This time he reveals: 'I said to myself, "Man, New York, it's a big city, an interesting city, and you can learn something now there, namely English".'

But if he wanted a big, interesting city in which he could learn English, why not London?

'Even if you don't believe me, three months ago I had two offers from London. No, it had to be New York.'

How does he view the England team, Germany's opponents in Euro 2000?

'I know the Englishman has a lot of respect for the German. The many negative results of England against Germany, they're hard to put out of your head.'

What advice does he have for David Beckham?

'I would advise him to keep his private life out of the media, even if that is very difficult. Something will always get in the papers, but he shouldn't open the curtains. I made that same mistake.'

By the way, Lothar, which London clubs wanted you?

'Which club is bottom of the Premier League? Bradford? No, Watford. Watford and Fulham.'

He is keen to answer more questions. We have none left. He clasps all our shoulders, clearly sad to see us go. They say you should never meet your heroes, but it's also dangerous to meet your villains: I now think Lothar Matthäus is a nice guy.

We stagger out and he lights on a fan in the bar who wants an autograph.

In appalling English, Matthäus asks him: 'How you write name?' Determined to get it right, he makes the fan write his name on a magazine before he signs.

Then, at nearly midnight, when all his team-mates are long tucked up in bed, he takes a stool at the bar with two Kicker journalists and starts to gossip.

Matthäus says he now regards the public row with Vogts and Klinsmann as the biggest mistake of his career. From 1994 to 1998 he did not play for Germany. It was said the players had decided to do without him. Much of the time he was injured anyway, again apparently nearing retirement. Vogts said he caused unrest. Beckenbauer said of him, 'If you talk a lot, you talk a lot of nonsense.' How upset Matthäus was became clear when he published My Diary in 1997. The book is distinguished chiefly by the banality of the entries, which are reminiscent of Adrian Mole. There is also the bitterness familiar from politicians' diaries. On Sunday 21 July 1996 Matthäus writes from the Bayern training camp: 'Today the European champions have returned: Helmer, Ziege, Babbel, Kahn, Strunz and Scholl. There was a big hallo. And from me, sincerely felt congratulations. European champions - for all of them, it's the peak of their careers.' Or, decoded: 'None of them won the World Cup.' Gradually everything came right for him. His injuries cleared, while those of the much younger Sammer did not. The German side got worse. When Vogts recalled him for the 1998 World Cup, he gladly came back. As he once said, 'If I couldn't speak to or work with all the people with whom I've had problems, I'd often be alone on the pitch.' This return was a mixed success: Germany went out in the quarter-finals again, but Matthäus played quite well. Still, he seemed to be joking when he said after the competition, 'Quit? Why would I want to do a thing like that?' And, yet, there he still is. He says, 'I like football. It's fun winning the ball from someone, it's fun shooting at goal, it's fun hitting a ball over 60 metres that arrives. It's like in golf: if you hit a ball and it flies and flies and flies, you enjoy it.' And if you don't play, you don't get attention. As the German team declined he became more important. After they lost 3-0 to the United States a year ago, Matthäus was called to Ribbeck's hotel room, where he explained that Germany had to play with two wingers. It came to pass. With Matthäus as libero, Germany qualified for Euro 2000. But as Beckenbauer said, even if they were dragged out of their beds in the middle of the night to play barefoot, the World Cup winners of 1990 would beat this team. Matthäus himself is not the player he was. Yet he has become more popular. 'In the last two or three years I haven't noticed the same whistles, the same songs against me. I think that for many people, even in other professions, I have become a sort of example.' He claims that a man in his fifties had written to him saying that he had successfully cited Matthäus in a job interview, as proof that performance matters and not age. His team-mates, too, have learned not to take him seriously. When there is a story in Bild , or Kicker , they grin and say, 'Oh, Lothar.' And most of the time he is kind. To younger players, he can be something of an uncle. He becomes enthused when he talks about New York. In previous months he had worried the Americans with comments such as, 'They can't drag me to New York in handcuffs. I've been misled and deceived. That can be done with others, but not with me.' This time he reveals: 'I said to myself, "Man, New York, it's a big city, an interesting city, and you can learn something now there, namely English".' But if he wanted a big, interesting city in which he could learn English, why not London? 'Even if you don't believe me, three months ago I had two offers from London. No, it had to be New York.' By the way, Lothar, which London clubs wanted you? 'Which club is bottom of the Premier League? Bradford? No, Watford. Watford and Fulham.' He is keen to answer more questions. We have none left. He clasps all our shoulders, clearly sad to see us go. They say you should never meet your heroes, but it's also dangerous to meet your villains: I now think Lothar Matthäus is a nice guy. We stagger out and he lights on a fan in the bar who wants an autograph. In appalling English, Matthäus asks him: 'How you write name?' Determined to get it right, he makes the fan write his name on a magazine before he signs. Then, at nearly midnight, when all his team-mates are long tucked up in bed, he takes a stool at the bar with two Kicker journalists and starts to gossip.

fields.headline: November cup finals - why not?
fields.trailText: The international game is withering before our eyes and will become even more marginalised as club football's influence grows. It's time to do something.
fields.body:
So farewell then Alan Shearer. A nation mourns. 'At the end of the day.' That was your catchphrase. And now it is.

Or nearly is, or actually should be. Leaving aside the argument that it might be best if Shearer went now rather than be allowed to dictate his retirement from international football after Euro 2000, his announcement that he wants to concentrate on club football and his family has sent out a maelstrom of messages for the game at home and abroad, all of them alarming.

The first is in physical toll. Injuries have clearly sapped Shearer, to the point where he cannot see his now 29-year-old frame making it to the World Cup in 2002. Despite his insistence to the contrary, that in itself is an admission of some sort about waning potency. He has probably been unlucky with absences, even if fortunate to play in an era when medical science renders them temporary rather than permanent, but the exacting demands of the modern game have undoubtedly hastened his end.

Then there is the subtext that his club is more important than the national team. It is a growing theme in the world game. You only have to look at Ryan Giggs - unfit to go to Qatar with Wales 10 days ago, fit to play, and brilliantly, for Manchester United at Wimbledon and at home to Bordeaux within the next week - to realise where priorities increasingly lie.

The worry is that the international game is withering before our eyes and will become even more marginalised as club football's influence grows. When an England captain announces openly which side his bread is buttered, and when such fixtures as Greece v Austria recently draw 600 spectators, it has become time to reassess and reorganise.

Fifa are trying. It was timely during the week that Michel Platini presented the report that the world governing body asked him to compile about harmonising the football calendar. The starting point was the frightening statistic that 80 per cent of players in the quarter-finals of France 98 were taking painkillers as a result of too many games in seasons that varied in length and intensity in different parts of the world.

Platini suggested a football year running from pre-season in January to November, with December as the month off. February to June would be for domestic and European club competitions, July and August for international tournaments and September to November for the conclusion of domestic leagues.

Naturally, the Premier League rejected the plans the same day, without even having heard Fifa's executive debate on the subject, to be held later this month. To this observer, they make powerful sense if the game is to solve an over-playing problem that is wearying both player and spectator.

We can't have the FA Cup final in November, say the traditionalists, though the same people seem to have no problem in switching games and draws around for the benefit of television. Anyway, it could still be played at the end of May as a fitting finale to the first half of the season.

For the spectator and the clubs, the benefit would be that certain players were not dragged away at inconvenient times, such as for the African Nations Cup and Gold Cup recently, with all the consequent arguments about the varying fairness on clubs. It is becoming a growing problem with the English game now so cosmopolitan, and former colonies cottoning on to the eligibility of British players.

The player would also know that certain set-aside international dates would place him in a less invidious position, forced to decide whether to keep club or country happy. We might thus see fewer injuries, either real or reported. Under the plan, clubs, countries and players would all be on the same level playing field and all excuses simply gripes.

It is Fifa's way of seeking to secure the future of the international game and here they will need to negotiate cleverly with the clubs and Uefa. Fifa might suggest that countries should be willing to pay some compensation to clubs, which would also give national associations more rights, while both organisations might realise that the dash for cash behind the abundance of matches is counterproductive.

Fifa, for example, might consider that smaller nations play pre-qualifying competitions so that bigger countries are not involved in silly mismatches. They might also concede that there should be fewer friendlies.

Uefa might in turn become more willing to put pressure on England and Spain to reduce their leagues to 18 clubs and more conciliatory about the growth of the Champions League. With 17 matches needed to reach the final (19 if qualifying is included), it is in danger of becoming the new international game, eclipsing national teams. Andy Cole's quote about not playing for England - 'I play international football with Manchester United' - says much.

Both European and world governors should beware. The game in England, where a sold-out Wembley usually bears testimony to the fact that it is the only country that does not play friendlies, may be booming, but elsewhere there are signs that supporters are voting with their feet. Old Trafford was full last week, but Florence and Marseille were less enthralled.

The lesson is that less is more, that fans will pay to watch meaningful games, both for club and country, but will not keep being fooled. It falls to the administrators to balance the needs of television and spectators with those of the players. The Premier League might start by being more open-minded about change so that fans, already feeling fleeced, are better served and players find the workload more tolerable.

It is curious how the global game can seem villagey sometimes. Kevin Keegan, who bought Shearer for Newcastle United, said he understood his captain's decision. It may have been because he himself was piqued by his rejection by the current Newcastle manager Bobby Robson when he took over the England manager's job in 1982.

Of course Shearer has the right to decide whether or not to play for his country, and when. Equally, an England manager has the right to decide who should play. Keegan will be straight into a World Cup qualifying campaign after Euro 2000 and should be looking at successors in the match against Brazil on 27 May. In the longer term, the game needs to ensure that there are no more Alan Shearers who fear burn-out to the point where they jump before they are pushed.

webTitle: Clubs hit jackpot with spinning turnstiles

fields.headline: Clubs hit jackpot with spinning turnstiles
fields.trailText: A look at the game's soaring popularity.
fields.body:
When Lord Taylor condemned the state of English football stadiums a decade ago, with its cattle fences, Victorian sanitation and stench of stewing onions, attendances in the top division had slumped to their lowest level since the Second World War. During the 1988-89 season, each game, on average, filled the stadium to 55 per cent of capacity. Since the inception of the Premiership, that figure has risen steadily and, although most stadiums are smaller, currently stands at a staggering 94 per cent.

Because of the game's soaring popularity, the requirements of the Taylor report haven't simply been met, they have been massively exceeded. As a result, next season should see turnstiles click more busily than for over 20 years.

By the time the 2000-01 season kicks off, completed developments at Old Trafford, St James's Park and the Stadium of Light will account for another 32,000 bums on Premiership seats at every home game. And that's not all: consider the swap factor. Should, say, Manchester City and Birmingham City win promotion at the expense of Bradford and Watford, that would be another 22,000. A few years down the line, when extensions at West Ham, Aston Villa and Leeds have been built and Arsenal, Coventry, Leicester and Southampton have settled into roomy new homes, the Premiership will possess the potential to hit an average gate of 40,000, the biggest since the masses flocked to see Stanley Matthews and the rest in the Fifties.

'If clubs are going to develop their fan base they have to create a situation where new fans are not excluded by sell-outs and season ticket policies. The only way is to increase capacities and clubs are responding,' says Premier League spokesman Mike Lee.

At first, it seemed the Taylor report recommendation to do away with our beloved if bedraggled terraces would drastically reduce capacities. The most practical way for clubs to cope with the demands of all-seater grounds was to drill rows of seats on to existing concrete banks. Little did they imagine the need for a second phase of expansion. 'Nobody in 1990 could have predicted the runaway success of the Premier League,' notes Simon Inglis, author of the Football Grounds of Great Britain . 'Look at the strategy of a club like Newcastle, who, when they redeveloped to a figure of 36,000, it seemed a perfectly sensible way forward. After all, they were only getting 18,000 not long before. Now they are looking at 51,000. Similarly Chelsea. That's the unpredictable nature of football.'

But before the cement mixers move in, clubs would do well to note events at Aston Villa this season. Dismal results equalled dwindling crowds. The missing claret-and-blue legions indicate a new tendency for disaffected supporters to be selective. While value for money barely came into the equation when you turned up on the spur of the moment and dug around for a few coins in exchange for your slab of terrace and a guaranteed singsong, it's another matter when £30 buys a torpid atmosphere and a terrible game. There is a question mark when fans don't feel part of the spectacle. There is doubt when that crucial sense of identifying with the players entrusted to represent the shirt is dimmed by short contracts and swift movement in this post-Bosman age. There is concern pay-per-view will be another punch on the nose to supporters trying to defend the traditional values of the people's game.

Sceptics fear pretty much every expanding club, except Manchester United, are wading in precariously deep waters and may end up with half empty stadiums. Inglis argues that won't happen, instead envisaging benefits for the old school faithful: 'I think the boom is going to end, but that doesn't necessarily mean the market will go. Take Newcastle, for example. If they can't fill their stadium they will have to go back to the fans with cheap deals. Therefore we will return to the pre-Taylor scenario where fans can arrive on the day and buy tickets at a much healthier price. Now is the perfect time to build while clubs can afford to develop using television money and the boom, and eventually those extra seats can be sold cheaply.'

Interestingly, Tottenham have announced a freeze on ticket prices for next season. This is the first sign of a club recognising that football in the twenty-first century has its price - and it is a price with limits. Either that or the penny has finally dropped that a team without a striker will eventually stretch unconditional loyalty to breaking point.

webTitle: Liverpool left to rue their chance

fields.headline: Liverpool left to rue their chance
fields.trailText: Ian Ridley's verdict on the big match.
fields.body:
Football, sport, is full of them, those 'if only' moments. If only Michael Owen had snatched that late chance instead of snatched at it, probably not even the chastened Mike Reed would have been able to resist leaping in the air to acclaim a winning goal on the young prodigy's return to action, a goal that would have been a tonic for a Premiership seemingly resigned to Manchester United disappearing into the distance again.

But while these days you may get something for finishing second, third even, you still get nowt for if onlys. Owen, six weeks out recovering from a hamstring injury, had been on the pitch two minutes and was not fully sharp so Liverpool had to be content with a point.

United seemed content enough. Again they failed to produce the trademark expansive, flowing football that Old Trafford craves but again they eked out a result, the denial of two points to the opposition, as they showed in a recent confrontation with Arsenal, appearing as important as the one gleaned towards retention of the title.

Credit Liverpool, though, rather than concentrate on the fallibility that might still see United stumble rather than gallop towards the finishing post. In recent seasons United have admitted to admiring Liverpool's approach play, but felt they rarely hurt and could be a soft touch when the going got tough. Now Liverpool possess a presence and resilience to worry the best as they seek a 19th title - United have 12 - the last of them 10 years ago. 'You're not famous any more' taunted the United fans 'They are a very physical team,' said Sir Alex Ferguson. 'Everyone except Vladimir Smicer is over 6ft. They have an athletic prowess which will help them handle the demands of the Premiership.' He added that they reminded him of his 1993/94 Double-winning team. That says a lot. It was the Liverpool manager Gérard Houllier who recommended Eric Cantona to his United counterpart.

'Gérard has made important decisions,' said Ferguson. 'He has done it quickly to allow himself to get on with the job.' You sensed Ferguson was talking about the decision, one he himself once took, to sell Paul Ince.

'We have speed and skill. We are improving,'said Houllier. 'You need mental and physical toughness, which United have and we are acquiring.' The difference between the teams, he said, was United's clinical finishing.

That much could be seen in the first half. Patrik Berger's wondrous 32-yard strike from a free-kick to rival the one against Leeds United that landed Mr Reed in trouble for punching the air when he allowed an advantage as he refereed the game gave Liverpool a deserved lead.

Jamie Carragher made up for the absence of the suspended Steven Gerrard by commanding the space in front of the back four and Dietmar Hamann eclipsed Roy Keane to orchestrate the game from midfield. The turning point was the nasty challenge by Ole Gunnar Solskjaer on Sami Hyppia and an angry Houllier's risky decision not to substitute; one could see his point, given the importance of the Finn to the team. The Norwegian, having missed earlier, needs no second invitation and his equaliser simply compounded the injustice.

By then, United could have been two down, with Berger and Titi Camara missing good chances. The surgery of Hyppia replacement altered the mobility of the game, however.

Seeking to get Ryan Giggs in against the wandering substitute Rigobert Song, his nickname should be 'Plain' on this evidence, United still created chances even if not fully firing, David Beckham's crossfield passing a danger to them. Liverpool were grateful that Carragher thrice cleared from the line to make amends for two own goals in the previous meeting between the two teams at Anfield.

For all that, it would have been no surprise had Owen pinched all three points. It was agonising for the Liverpool bench to watch. 'The ball spun out at the last moment. From where we were, it was going in for a long time,' said Houllier. Then, the gap of 10 points between them and United would have been seven - which is where those two words come in: if only.

webTitle: Lofthouse is due his lion's share

fields.headline: Lofthouse is due his lion's share
fields.trailText: Nat Lofthouse is set to finally join the ranks of footballing knights.
fields.body:
Nat Lofthouse is set to finally join the ranks of footballing knights. The Lion of Vienna, one of the last surviving greats of English soccer, is expected to receive a knighthood in the Queen's Birthday Honours this summer. Many influential figures in the game are puzzled as to why, although Lofthouse was made an OBE in 1994, he has never been honoured in the same way as his contemporaries Tom Finney and Stanley Matthews.

Discreet soundings have left the honours' committee in no doubt about the strength of feeling that recognition is long overdue, and the omission looks sure to be rectified when the next batch of gongs emerges on 17 June. Lofthouse's record should leave Her Majesty's representatives in no doubt: 30 international goals in 33 games and 255 goals for his beloved Bolton Wanderers.

His name is synonymous with so much of English football folklore: the 1953 'Matthews' Final', when his team took a 3-1 lead but lost 4-3 thanks to the Wizard of the Wing's brilliance; the 'Munich Final' five years later, when Bolton defied the popular will that wanted Matt Busby's patched-up post-aircrash team to triumph; and, of course, the game against Austria in 1952 when he earned his nickname by scoring England's winner just before the end and knocking himself out in the process. Now 74, he would be a fitting entry to a pantheon of heroes that already includes legends such as Hurst and Charlton.

fields.headline: Kidd talks continue
fields.trailText: Brian Kidd is back on track for a surprise return to Manchester United's backroom staff.
fields.body:
Brian Kidd is back on track for a surprise return to Manchester United's backroom staff - as first disclosed by The Observer last month.

Kidd, out of football after being sacked by Blackburn last year, was approached by the Old Trafford chairman and chief executive Martin Edwards with a view to taking up the post of director of football when Sir Alex Ferguson's contract expires in two years.

Ferguson subsequently claimed the deal had fallen through, though he admitted he had considered taking Kidd back as a way of healing the rift with his former right-hand man following critical comments of him in his autobiography. Ferguson had accused Kidd of repeatedly going behind his back to Edwards.

Privately, Ferguson was said to be angered by recent revelations that officials had been holding secret discussions with Kidd. But Observer Sport has learned that far from talks having broken down irreparably, United were still talking to Kidd before he left for a holiday last week.

A source at the club admitted that negotiations were continuing with the intent of appointing Kidd as youth coaching director in the short term. He would then take over as director of football upon Ferguson's retirement.

It was suggested that should Steve McClaren, the man who replaced Kidd as Ferguson's assistant, be overlooked for the manager's job and leave at the same time as Sir Alex, Kidd could even regain his old post working directly alongside a new team manager.

The source added: 'There was a short hiatus when news of the discussions became public but they have continued. Despite what happened at Blackburn, Brian is still held in high regard by many people at Manchester United and having him once more work with our youth players, given the success he enjoyed previously in the same role, is something we look forward to.'

webTitle: Say it ain't so... don't expect stars to raise our kids

fields.headline: Say it ain't so... don't expect stars to raise our kids
fields.standfirst: Kate Hoey's view is understandable - up to a point. But politicians are easily caught up in public outrages and on this she is wrong
fields.trailText: Kate Hoey's view is understandable - up to a point. But politicians are easily caught up in public outrages and on this she is wrong, argues Kevin Mitchell.
fields.body:
Joseph Jefferson Jackson was an illiterate country boy whose clean hitting of a baseball in the colours of the Chicago White Sox more than 80 years ago was reckoned to be every bit as good as that of Babe Ruth.

Shoeless Joe, the stuff of American sporting legend. In a land that craves heroes, Joe was what the papers wanted. The kid who took a president's name for his own had a special role to play, whether he knew it or not. The doughboys had just come home after winning the First World War (with a little help from a few million dead Europeans) and the Twenties were starting to roar, nowhere more loudly than in Chicago, home of gangsters and illicit booze. As an antidote to excess, Joe was Abe Lincoln in cleats.

And then he went and spoilt it.

'Say it ain't so, Joe,' is the quintessential plea of the disillusioned young baseball fan. It was allegedly uttered by a moist-eyed urchin as Joe and seven team-mates emerged from a court house in 1921, accused of throwing the 1919 World Series. Whether it was ever said is doubtful. But it fitted the circumstances. And America, we are told, went into mourning over the shame of a guileless hick they imagined could never be corrupted. The tears of a small boy were the ultimate condemnation.

Pure Hollywood.

Nowhere is the moral cliché more entrenched than in the home of fantasy, and Joe Jackson was just another victim of this unforgiving American righteousness, a disease which seems to have caught on here recently. Joe might have wanted to be a hero, but he surely never asked to be a role model, which is an important distinction to make.

Lately, we have let the argument run out of control. The most recent debate started a few weeks ago with the undignified touchline bullying of a referee by a clutch of Manchester United footballers whose combined wealth could fund a small town. They were rightly condemned for their actions, apologised - albeit reluctantly - and there the matter might have ended.

But the media machine was rolling. Looking for stuff to fill their columns, the moral watchdogs pounced on every stray elbow, every sulking fit, every spit and late tackle. All of a sudden we had an epidemic on our hands. Small children everywhere were stunned to the soles of their expensive trainers by the horror of the public spectacle that daily unfolded before their impressionable eyes, apparently. Gripped by the epidemic, they went out and behaved badly all over the place. Look at me, I'm David Beckham not turning up for training. I think I'll go and spit at the postman.

Up to a point, I can understand Kate Hoey's concern, outlined in her interview above. She is, after all, a politician and politicians are easily caught up in most public outrages. The urge to 'do something' is hard to resist. But the Minister for Sport is as wrong as all the columnisers on this one.

It is fair enough to ask footballers to behave decently; it is unrealistic to expect them to be responsible for the actions of others. If, by some chance, the errors of the grown-up delinquents persuaded even a minority of brats to copy them, it is surely up to their parents to rectify the bad behaviour, not the so-called role models. That is the view, at least, of Neil Barnard, whose letter in these pages last week made more sense than any of the bleatings by professional opinion-formers.

'As a child, I was football-mad from the moment I could first stand up and kick a ball,' he wrote, 'but it was never supposed that footballers had the task of raising me. That was the province of my parents and no one else.'

Ian Wright said a couple of weeks ago that it had never occurred to him that he was a role model, that he did not become a footballer to shape the lives of those who came to see him play. It is so obvious a truth it is hard to understand why people can't see it. Kate Hoey even questions Wright being awarded his MBE.

Harvey Frommer wrote a good book about the Joe Jackson scandal, Shoeless Joe and Ragtime Baseball , in which he gives the central character a sympathetic treatment. So I was a little surprised at his response when I asked him if he thought athletes should be held up as role models.

'I do think that athletes have a responsibility to their fans, to the sports they play, to the owners who are paying a salary. With each new incident of poor behaviour - killing, drugs, battling, bashing . . . even verbal assaults on fans - the image of the athlete goes more and more downhill. In the past, in the days of Shoeless Joe, there were problems but never the way they are today.

'So I say, Say It Ain't So Joe - and John and Jim and all the others who somehow crossed the line of decent behaviour thinking they are above the law or in a category more important than ordinary people.'

But that's how it is in America. When another 'Jefferson', Bill Clinton, was dragged through the courts, on television, there was almost universal revelling in his discomfort. Yet we were uncomfortable in the end, in this country at least, at his public humiliation over the most human of failings. After we'd had our fun, we felt guilty for enjoying it. Clinton, even in the United States, came out of it as a victim, and we all resumed our mundane lives, reminded that nobody's perfect.

If an American president can run a country with his pants around his ankles, surely Wright can get on with being a minor celebrity without worrying if his every idiocy is being mimicked in a thousand bedrooms. Do we want to sign up to the Blame Culture?

Say it ain't so, Kate.

fields.headline: Kate on a moral crusade
fields.standfirst: Managers must hit cheats in the pocket and refuse to select them, says the Minister for Sport
fields.trailText: Managers must hit cheats in the pocket and refuse to select them, says the Minister for Sport.
fields.body:
On her first day in office Kate Hoey criticised Manchester United's 'shabby' decision to forsake this season's FA Cup, prompting Martin Edwards to label her 'ignorant and disgraceful'. More headlines followed when she urged Sir Norman Foster to keep Wembley's twin towers, said she'd like to scrap the whole £475 million new national stadium and questioned the wisdom of awarding Ian Wright an MBE when he has such a dodgy disciplinary record. Not bad going for someone who, seven months after succeeding Tony Banks as Minister for Sport, says: 'I'm quite pleased that I have kept out of the news.'

Hoey has recently been busy keeping out of the news again by suggesting that police officers might prosecute players who whack opponents or intimidate referees during games. Typically candid, she rejected Alex Ferguson's claim that recent misbehaviour was just 'media hype', castigated the 'appalling behaviour' of six named Premiership clubs and asked football to rediscover 'the moral dimension'. By regularly referring to 'ethics, morality and decency', she sometimes sounds more like a religious leader than her real job which, as one child put it when Hoey recently opened a new sports centre near Rotherham, is to be 'the Prime Minister of Sport'.

Compared to her predecessor's jokey, laddish, easy-copy style, Hoey is downbeat and earnest. Banks was effectively the Minister for Football (especially welcome at Stamford Bridge); she intends to be the minister for all of sport. He loved photo opportunities; her preoccupation is 'helping the grassroots'. But with much of sport in disarray, it's time to get serious.

Hoey admits to worrying that football's soul is being stained by the influence of money, the pricing-out of less affluent fans and, especially, player misbehaviour. 'Children mimic all these things - spitting, chasing after referees, intimidating people - because they think they're not being a proper footballer unless they do it. That's a terrible, terrible example to youngsters.' When she bemoaned spitting by footballers, 'I got at least 100 letters from people saying "you're absolutely right". Schoolteachers wrote saying children in their playgrounds were mimicking what they'd seen on television. Some older people wrote saying "this didn't happen when I was playing sport". People in other, sports such as hockey and women's football, said "this doesn't happen in our sports". And I don't see cricketers doing it and I don't remember seeing Stanley Matthews spitting.'

So how do we stop it? She has suggested heavier fines than the current two-week maximum. Now she goes further: clubs should voluntarily drop stars who step out of line. 'The clubs have to put penalties on them; they have to be chosen not to play, ultimately. Everybody within football has to do their bit to sort the game out, including the FA, club management, PFA and players themselves. Managers shouldn't be doing anything other than taking the blame and saying "we're sorry" and make the players take responsibility. It's always somebody else who's responsible for what happens on the field and that blame culture in football has got to stop.'

The Minister is genuinely puzzled why the national game has become so indisciplined. She ponders aloud over money, society and footballers' backgrounds as possible explanations, then discounts each one. 'I was at the Imperial War Museum the other night where Sir Stirling Moss, Sir Roger Bannister, Sir Henry Cooper, Fred Trueman and Nat Lofthouse were talking about sport after the war until The Beatles came along,' she explains. This is sport's Golden Age, when the maximum wage, absence of a drugs culture and respect for fellow competitors meant sportspeople rarely got - to borrow a favourite Hoey-ism - too big for their boots. 'Nat Lofthouse was asked if players in his day got angry with referees. He said, "Of course; sometimes you thought the referee was wrong, but you just accepted it".'

At the Stade de France two weeks ago for France v England, she saw the hosts run in a try that could have changed the game completely. 'Everybody thought it had been scored, including the French Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, who was sitting beside me; he was jumping up and down. But when the referee ruled it out, that was it. The players didn't scream and race after him; they accepted it,' recalls Hoey. 'Likewise there was huge physical contact in the game, with players walking over people, yet at the end they clapped each other off and went to dinner together. There's a professional behaviour about what happens in rugby that we just don't get in football.'

The Minister recalls how, growing up in Northern Ireland in the Fifties, both at home and at school, 'I was taught what was right and wrong, how to behave, when to say sorry and thank you and how to both lose and win with dignity in sport. A lot of that has changed and sport is really reflecting the changes that have gone on in attitudes within society.'

Changes in human behaviour, though, do not justify sportspeople behaving badly. Hoey is determined to reassert 'the moral dimension'. She is planning a 'summit on sportsmanship' where sports-governing bodies, and some leading stars, will produce ideas on how to get back to the time-honoured virtues of fair play and integrity. Hoey's own contribution to the debate is still in its infancy: an 'ethics charter' requiring both ruling bodies and individual sportspeople receiving National Lottery cash to display and promote proper behaviour.

She has already held initial discussions with UK Sport about inserting an 'ethics clause' in the funding agreement signed by athletes on the World Class Performance programme, our aspiring Olympic and world champions. One condition of receiving cash would be not to cheat; UK Sport has already decided that any publicly funded competitor testing positive for drugs will never again receive public money. Another would be to show responsibility by 'putting something back' into both their sport and society as a whole. Athletes would have to visit schools, take training sessions or give drugs awareness talks on a set number of days per year.

'Denise Lewis and Katherine Merry both do loads for Birchfield Harriers, the club in Birmingham they came up through. Judy Simpson worked with the London Coaching Foundation where she generally acted as a bit of an inspiration. Writing a requirement to do things like that into a funding agreement would make everyone realise that behaviour, responsibility and discipline is not an add-on, it's actually central to everything sport is about, if sport is to mean anything.' Amen to that.

Hoey's big test comes soon when the Government's much-delayed new sports strategy finally emerges. 'The Prime Minister of Sport' warns that it will not be a sexy, headline-grabbing document full of flashy but half-baked initiatives. 'It will build on the good things about sport: facilities are OK, there's a lot of brilliant people working in sport, plenty of talent and more money than ever before. The trouble is that at the moment people get to the top in spite of, rather than because of, the system.'

She tactfully describes the wasteful, overlapping bureaucracy that is British sports administration as 'not ideal', but too much recent upheaval means it will survive untouched. She will, though, streamline the distribution of the Lottery's millions to sport. 'Success at the top is important, but we have to get the base of sport right by providing good quality sporting opportunities for young people and ensuring everyone has a chance to fulfil their potential.' Don't expect instant results, she warns.

There will be new measures to help school sport, in poor shape because of playing-field sell-offs and the downgrading of sport within the curriculum; a coaching initiative designed to narrow the skill gap between Britain and elsewhere; and some new money from the Treasury.

Hoey admits that being Sports Minister involves more influence than actual power, and that frustrates her. 'You have the opportunity to say things and, on the whole, people listen.'

New Labour's blueprint for sporting renewal will tell if it's worth listening.

fields.headline: Houllier's slag-heap past
fields.standfirst: David Barnes on the Liverpool manager's roots - if he could make it here, he could make it anywhere
fields.trailText: David Barnes on the Liverpool manager's roots - if he could make it here, he could make it anywhere.
fields.body:
The passion for Liverpool football that Gérard Houllier took into the enemy stronghold of Old Trafford yesterday was kindled long before he signed on the dotted line of his contract.

Thanks to the testimony of one of his closest and most enduring friends, his love and respect for all things Anfield can be traced to a magical evening in the Liverpool stadium and a few beers with their fans almost two decades ago.

And, oddly enough, what one-time Polish international centre-forward Joachim Marx has to say locates French intellectual Houllier, a former teacher of English, in the same area of working-class values that drive Sir Alex Ferguson, his Manchester United rival in that classic North-West showdown.

Marx, who won a gold medal with Poland at the 1972 Olympics, was down to play against England at Wembley the following year in the World Cup qualifier that still has echoes of national regret. Domarski, who took his place when Marx was injured in a league match a few days before, scored the famous goal that eliminated England.

Marx later moved into French football where he eventually ended up at the little mining town of Noeux-les-Mines where Houllier, three years his junior, was trying to secure his first toehold in the game.

Houllier's ambition was, in part, fired by afternoons watching Liverpool when he was a young teacher gaining experience on Merseyside in the late Sixties. But this was different, now he was earning his living from the game.

Marx now says: 'Let me tell you first about Gérard and Liverpool because it is really like a fairy-tale that has come true. After he made his name with Noeux-les-Mines, Gérard was made coach of the First Division club Lens and made me his assistant.

'We wanted to sign a Polish player, Smolarek, of Widzew Lodz, who were due to play the return leg of a European tie against Liverpool at Anfield in 1983.

'I got tickets for the game through my Polish connections. I could see from the start that something was getting to Gérard. He seemed very excited about something. The football, of course, was fantastic. Liverpool won 3-2, but it was not enough because they had lost the first leg 2-0 in Poland.

'There was something else, though. It was the noise, the passion, the red-brick stadium, the little working-class houses all around. Gérard was spell-bound by the whole thing. We were from an area of industrial France where poor miners had the same feelings for the game and their team.

'We went to a pub nearby after the game and drank a few beers. No one, of course, knew who Gérard was even though he was a top coach in France. He talked football with the fans just like he was one of them. What really impressed him was that, whereas an eliminated team got whistled in France, these supporters were still 100 per cent behind their team.

'As we left the pub, Gérard made a remark to me that I have never forgotten. He said: "You know, Joachim, I would love to be the coach of this club one day." I honestly believe Gérard never lost that dream and I am convinced that he will make Liverpool the champions of English football before he leaves them.

'Smolarek, by the way, was too expensive and later played for Eintracht Frankfurt but, as it has turned out, it was no wasted trip for Gérard.'

The first Kop that Houllier encountered in football was a cone-shaped hill that rises with improbable steepness behind the tiny ground of Noeux-les-Mines in northern France. It is, in fact, an old slag heap - now covered by grass. Georges Blondel, groundsman at the time, says he can still remember seeing Houllier pull up at the ground on his moped in search of a job coaching the juniors.

Even now, the most prominent team picture in the club's cramped quarters features Houllier alongside the provincial part-timers he turned into celebrated giantkillers on a national scale.

Marx, capped 27 times by Poland and twice a winner of their championship with Ruch Chorzow, recalls: 'Gérard was given the first team job after they had been relegated. They were in a bad way. He wasted no time in totally rebuilding the team and won promotion during his first season in charge.

'A lot of people wondered whether Gérard had made a mistake in buying so many new players for Liverpool at the same time, but it is not the individuals who count so much for him. He would rather have two players who understand each other than one big star. Whatever the level of football, he has always known what he wanted.

'He thinks only of the collective. What he has done at Liverpool, he already did at Noeux-les-Mines. The only difference is he knows more players, better ones and has the money to get them now.

'Gérard gave me a three-year-contract to sign for Noeux-les-Mines from Lens when I was 35. The town has 13,000 inhabitants, there were average gates of just 800 people and, to get 5,000 in, we had to erect a temporary metal stand behind a goal.

'We did our training three evenings a week, running all over the slag heap which served as a free vantage point for some fans on match days. What happened there in Gérard's time was simply phenomenal. Our ground would not hold the people who wanted to see us in really big cup ties.

'We had to go to Lens to play those. There were 15,000 there to see us beat Nantes in the French Cup and 30,000 watched us lose narrowly to Paris St. Germain the next round. Can you imagine? I was used to big crowds, of course, but Gérard spent most of his time teaching English to sixth-formers in Lille; we had electricians and car mechanics in the team.

'Some of us worked for Bernard Leroy, the club president who owned a chain of shops. I was a salesman in the kitchen furniture department for two years. They were great days. Gérard's own keenness and excitement spread through the team

'But he hardly ever slept. He once explained to me that he had picked up the habit as a student reading his books all night. It was funny, he would drop into my house for a chat, sit on the settee and say, "Give me five minutes." Then he would immediately fall asleep. His eyes would open five minutes later and we would start talking football. He used to drive my wife mad when he rang up in the middle of the night.

'He would send me to watch the opposition for him and he could never wait until I saw him to get the information. He was hungry for knowledge.

'He was especially strong on analysing the opposition. There were some who did not believe in him at first because he had not been a footballer, but he soon changed their minds.

'When the president was killed in a car crash, the money dried up at Noeux-les-Mines and Gérard was picked up by Lens. He took them to fourth place in the First Division and European football before winning the championship with Paris St Germain.'

Houllier retains a natural courtesy not always apparent in the vigorous hurly-burly of Premiership football, but Marx, now established in the schools coaching set-up devised by Houllier in his time with the French Football Federation, can bear witness to the steely nature that lies within.

There is now only one boss at Liverpool since Roy Evans was pushed off the tandem and one Guvnor - as England star Paul Ince, who styled himself thus - discovered to his anger and dismay.

Marx adds : 'I knew Gérard was having problems with Ince and I also knew there would be only one outcome.

'When I joined Gérard at Noeux-les-Mines, another player from Lens came with me. He kept telling Gérard he was a pro and so knew better. He disagreed with Gérard in the dressing-room. It was not long before he was no longer there.'

Liverpool were champions on that March night of destiny when Houllier watched them go out of the European Cup at the quarter-final stage at Anfield. He has a clearer picture of his progress towards restoring them to that status after that Old Trafford encounter with the team he dreams of supplanting.

fields.headline: 'Tapping up' a fact of life
fields.trailText: It's morally reprehensible and illegal, but almost everyone in the game accepts it. Including Alan Smith.
fields.body:
There is nothing new about illegal approaches for players. 'Tapping up', as it is known, has been going on for years and even the great Tom Finney said recently that he was offered almost 20 times his weekly wage of £8 to play in Italy in the post-war years.

What is remarkable is the extent to which it goes on and the fact that it is largely accepted, albeit reluctantly most of the time. Arsenal complained last year that Real Madrid made an illegal approach for Nicolas Anelka, which led to a £23m transfer, while continental moves for Frank Leboeuf and Marc Overmars put the issue back in the spotlight this week.

And the hottest topic at a recent meeting of youth academy directors was the movement of players aged under 16, an issue highlighted when West Ham were ordered by an FA tribunal to pay £500,000 compensation each for two youngsters, Jermaine Defoe from Charlton and Leon Britton from Arsenal.

It is no secret that players are tapped up a lot of the time. What happens is instead of Manager A picking up the phone to Manager B and enquiring about a player in the correct manner, it is much more likely that he will ask one of his players to contact the 'target' player surreptitiously and make his club's interest known.

Players are always the best way to get to other players, especially when they meet up for international duty. Younger players from smaller clubs are especially vulnerable to this approach - once they have been told that Manager A wants to take them to a bigger club, it is very hard for Manager B to keep them happy.

I've encountered this situation often. When I was at Crystal Palace, we had a problem with Geoff Thomas. He had just broken into the England squad, and suddenly there were daily stories that Blackburn Rovers - who had two England players at the time - wanted to sign him.

Of course Thomas was interested. We did not want to sell him though, and kept him for another season, but he was unsettled, his performances deteriorated and we were relegated that season.

The following season, our leading striker Chris Armstrong kept being linked with Everton. I never received a single phone call from Everton about him, but they were obviously interested. In this case, I suspected an agent was the go-between, and this is another common problem - managers using agents to get players. This is strictly against the rules, of course, but how do you prove it? And if you complain, what good does it do?

Almost every player in the top two divisions now has an agent. Though it is technically illegal for an agent to take a cut of a transfer fee, there is nothing to stop him taking a big slice of the signing-on fee or the ludicrously titled 'loyalty bonus'. Some managers buy their players almost exclusively from the 'stable' of an agent they get on with. We also have more agents in this country than anywhere else - about 80 with Fifa licences and as many again unlicensed.

In youth football, the FA have tried to resolve the problem of poaching young players by stipulating that anyone attending a club's academy must live within an hour-and-a-half's travelling distance. The idea is to ensure that all clubs with academies have a fair chance of getting the best youngsters in their area.

The two clubs most opposed to it are Arsenal and Manchester United, who want to be able to pick up young players from all over the country. Yet Liverpool's academy director Steve Heighway thinks it is a positive thing for his club, as does Alan Irvine at Newcastle - after all, his club spent an awful lot of money bringing Alan Shearer back home.

The whole situation is a world away from that of Finney, who was Preston born and bred, never moved from his hometown club and still lives there now. But we live in a different age now. Tapping up players is morally reprehensible and illegal, but almost everyone in the game accepts that it is part of life.

fields.headline: Fiction paperbacks, 5 March
fields.trailText: A provocative portrait of the death of reality, plus Single & Single, Cult Movies, Rodinsky's Room, Bloggs 19
fields.body:
The Cybergypsies Love, Life and Travels on the Electronic Frontier
Indra Sinha
Scribner £7.99, pp392
Buy it at BOL

Sinha warns that although everything in cyberspace is fantasy, the terror is real. And how! His book, described by his publishers as 'narrative non-fiction', is a provocative portrait of the death of reality in the search for pleasure, a nightmare vision induced by the 'phosphorescent crucible' of the computer screen.

Like the author once was, the narrator, Bear, is an advertising exec addicted to the Internet. Nightly, he deserts his wife for the fantastical worlds of Shades and Vortex, role-playing games rich in erotic possibility. Bear's marriage collapses unnoticed. Even while writing ads against torture for Amnesty International, he starts believing nothing is real. Cybergypsies is nostalgic for the days before our friends became electric. Sinha cleverly articulates the contemporary anxiety over technology - Bear is both cyber pioneer and modern opium eater.

Single & Single
John le Carré
Coronet £6.99, pp415

The Single and Single investment house isn't burdened by ethical concerns. 'We are maximisers,' says patriarch Tiger Single. 'We go where others fear to trade.' The market is the former communist bloc, the business money-laundering and exporting Russian blood to sell in the West.

But the Wild East is dangerous: the book opens with the murder of a Single house lawyer in Istanbul. Gradually, a treacherous web emerges, extending from slothful Whitehall wallahs to the Single family itself. Oliver Single, revolted by his father Tiger's methods, spies on him for a customs official, tracking him down when he disappears. Le Carré's portrayal of the West's smash-and-grab investment in Russia in the last decade seems to ring true. A high-octane thriller imbued with deadly amorality.

Cult Movies
Karl French and Philip French
Pavilion Books £14.99, pp240
Buy it at BOL

Coppola's 1979 Vietnam film Apocalypse Now is among the 150 movies the authors consider cult because of moments like Robert Duvall proclaiming: 'I love the smell of Napalm in the morning.' Any quotation 'instantly establishes a shared knowledge'. Forbidden Planet, the 1956 sci-fi version of The Tempest, qualifies because Planet Altaira echoes the naïve futurism of Fifties magazines. It is also camp: 'My evil self is at the door,' shrieks Dr Mobius, 'and I have no power to stop it.' The 1995 soft-core skin flick, Showgirls, is cult because it's so bad it's good. Culthood is nothing new. This collection of oddities is an irresistible invitation to chew the fat over the peculiarities of movies, the stuff that fuels obsession.

Rodinsky's Room
Rachel Lichtenstein and Iain Sinclair
Granta £8.99, pp363
Buy it at BOL

In 1969, David Rodinsky mysteriously disappeared from the East End synagogue where he lived, abandoning his room full of the detritus of a life. Unopened for more than a decade, the room for Sinclair was a trap, a work unfinished. For the artist Lichtenstein, whose grandparents had come from Poland and lived on the same Spitalfields street as Rodinsky, the vanishing man became an obsession. While she supplies staccato reportage on her search for Rodinsky - her own biography meshing with his incomplete narrative - Sinclair runs a deeper dragnet. What emerges is a complex meditation on presence and absence, an elegy for the fading old Jewish East End. A wonderful, moving contribution to the ongoing urban genome project - the psychogeographic mapping of London.

Bloggs 19 - The Story of the Essex Range Rover Triple Murders
Tony Thompson
Warner Books £6.99, pp277
Buy it at BOL

Darren Nicholls's life changed at South Mimms service station, where he was arrested for distributing counterfeit money in 1992. In prison, he met Michael Steele and Jack Whomes. Six years later, Steele and Whomes were convicted of shooting dead three notorious villains in a Range Rover in a quiet Essex lane.

The key prosecution witness was Nicholls, a small-time criminal who, fearing for his life, turned supergrass. With Nicholls's co-operation, Thompson tells the gripping inside story of the build-up to the murders - the emergence of the Firm and the shifting power balance in the Essex underworld. On the witness protection programme, Nicholls became Bloggs 19, his old identity erased. In unsentimental prose, Thompson reveals the human cost of betrayal, of living a lie and always looking over your shoulder. An extraordinary insight into criminal society.

Culthood is nothing new. This collection of oddities is an irresistible invitation to chew the fat over the peculiarities of movies, the stuff that fuels obsession. Rodinsky's Room Rachel Lichtenstein and Iain Sinclair Granta £8.99, pp363 Buy it at BOL In 1969, David Rodinsky mysteriously disappeared from the East End synagogue where he lived, abandoning his room full of the detritus of a life. Unopened for more than a decade, the room for Sinclair was a trap, a work unfinished. For the artist Lichtenstein, whose grandparents had come from Poland and lived on the same Spitalfields street as Rodinsky, the vanishing man became an obsession. While she supplies staccato reportage on her search for Rodinsky - her own biography meshing with his incomplete narrative - Sinclair runs a deeper dragnet. What emerges is a complex meditation on presence and absence, an elegy for the fading old Jewish East End. A wonderful, moving contribution to the ongoing urban genome project - the psychogeographic mapping of London. Bloggs 19 - The Story of the Essex Range Rover Triple Murders Tony Thompson Warner Books £6.99, pp277 Buy it at BOL Darren Nicholls's life changed at South Mimms service station, where he was arrested for distributing counterfeit money in 1992. In prison, he met Michael Steele and Jack Whomes. Six years later, Steele and Whomes were convicted of shooting dead three notorious villains in a Range Rover in a quiet Essex lane. The key prosecution witness was Nicholls, a small-time criminal who, fearing for his life, turned supergrass. With Nicholls's co-operation, Thompson tells the gripping inside story of the build-up to the murders - the emergence of the Firm and the shifting power balance in the Essex underworld. On the witness protection programme, Nicholls became Bloggs 19, his old identity erased. In unsentimental prose, Thompson reveals the human cost of betrayal, of living a lie and always looking over your shoulder. An extraordinary insight into criminal society.

fields.headline: Audio: Dubliners
fields.standfirst: Jim Norton's performance brings an uncanny realism to Joyce's characters
fields.trailText: Jim Norton's performance brings an uncanny realism to Joyce's characters
fields.body:
Dubliners
James Joyce
Parts 1 and 2 unabridged Read by Jim Norton
Naxos
Part 1: Running time 3hrs 12mins; Part 2: Running time 3hrs 42mins
Each part: cassette £9.99; CD £13.99
Buy it at BOL

Joyce wrote these 15 stories between 1904 and 1907, to present Dublin to the world. On the page, his characters are remarkable; in Jim Norton's performance, their realism is uncanny.

With his impressive vocal range and his Irish intonation modulated to portray various areas of Dublin, Norton brings to life Maria singing in her quavering voice; Annie cooing 'My little mannie' to soothe her baby; little Tom pleading 'O, Pa!' to stop his father beating him; the gallant's swaggering boasts. But despite the bustle, the drinking and the music in these Dubliners' lives, what might have been is all too often a sad contrast with what is.

Taken from original recordings of songs - scratches and all and echoing old Joe's nostalgic musing that 'there's no time like the long ago' - the music which ends each story reinforces the poignancy. Little Chandler, whose old friend has boasted about his experiences in Paris, stands at the story's conclusion feeling like 'a prisoner for life', the melancholy 'The memory of the past' voicing the aching regret in his heart.

In another story, Mrs Mooney makes sure that Mr Doran will pay for his moment of pleasure with her daughter, Polly, by marrying her. Polly is crying upstairs until her mother calls: 'Come down, dear. Mr Doran wants to speak to you.' The song's romantic refrain, 'The love I bear for thee', contrasts painfully with the reality of Polly's future as settled for her by her mother.
