fields.headline: Hideous Kinski
fields.standfirst: Klaus Kinski wanted to put 'big red ants' in his director's eyes. Werner Herzog wanted the actor dead. Yet, he admits to  Denis Staunton, he still misses him
fields.trailText: Klaus Kinski wanted to put 'big red ants' in his director's eyes. Werner Herzog wanted the actor dead. Yet, he admits to Denis Staunton, he still misses him
fields.body:
Werner Herzog doesn't look like a murderer. In his spartan office in Cologne, he smiles sweetly and gazes out his office window at the peaceful waters of the Rhine. But here he is, recounting how he very nearly killed his friend, Klaus Kinski.

'It was just a beautiful idea,' he says, 'like a beautiful screenplay with a perfect murder and alibis in all directions but it was close to reality because I was stopped very close to doing it. Shortly after that, I learned that he had equally precise, elaborate plans to kill me.'

The director Werner Herzog and the actor Klaus Kinski were one of the most dazzling creative partnerships of the modern cinema, responsible for such epic, poetic films as Aguirre, Wrath of God and Fitzcarraldo . But their personal relationship was explosive and often violent, and they regularly brought filming to a halt with fist fights and murder threats. The feud was often thought to be just a movie legend, but more recently the full gory details have emerged. Or have they? It is difficult sometimes to separate the fact from the fiction.

The BBC are celebrating Herzog's work in a weekend season called 'Herzog: Madman or Genius' later this month. The celebration includes Herzog's revealing documentary portrait of Kinski, My Best Fiend , which shows hitherto unseen footage of some of the actor's most violent tantrums and reveals for the first time how close the two men came to killing one another. It caused a sensation when it was screened at last year's Cannes Festival.

When I met Herzog in Cologne last week, the city was preparing to put on its party clothes for Carnival, a five-day, drink-driven revel that loosens up even the stuffiest of Rhinelanders. But Herzog, the mad genius of poetic cinema, had no intention of entering the party spirit. 'It's terrible. You can't get any business done,' he said.

In fact, one of the director's most striking characteristics is his controlled, soft-spoken manner and the impression he gives that most of his anecdotes and observations have been rehearsed a hundred times. As he spoke on the phone to his lawyer and fiddled with his laptop, he seemed for all the world like an ascetic chief executive dressed in baggy khakis for a working weekend.

When Herzog began working with Kinski, in Aguirre , the actor already had a reputation for poisoning the atmosphere on every film set he entered and walking out of projects mid-shoot. Aguirre was shot in the Peruvian jungle and within a few weeks, weary of Kinski's tantrums and frequent violence, the native Indians who played the extras offered to kill the actor on Herzog's behalf.

Herzog declined but when Kinski stormed off the set during an especially violent fit of rage and threatened to take a boat to the next town, the director took out his gun. He told him that if he stepped on to the boat, he would get eight bullets in the head. The ninth would be for Herzog himself.

'The film was much more important than our private existences. I mean, mine and his. We knew that, both of us. And he would have violated something so deeply that I wouldn't like to have lived on as a man without dreams. I was prepared for the ultimate and I told him when this incident occurred that this was not a joke and I had made up my mind months ago. I wouldn't need a second of deliberation and this was what was going to happen next. If he took a boat, if he left, he'd be shot. I know I would have done it.'

Kinski's rages could be sparked by anything from a lukewarm cup of coffee to a disagreement about the interpretation of a line. But, most of the time, his tantrums were a protest against anything that threatened to supplant him as the centre of attention. 'Klaus was one of the greatest actors of the century, but he was also a monster and a great pestilence. Every single day I had to think of new ways of domesticating the beast,' says Herzog.

Although Kinski acknowledged that his best work was with Herzog - not least because the German was almost alone among more than 100 directors he worked with who could endure the actor for more than a few days - the actor was venomous about the director.

'Big red ants should piss in his eyes, eat his balls, penetrate his asshole and eat his guts,' Kinski wrote in his crazed autobiography. 'He should get the plague. Syphilis. Malaria. Yellow fever. Leprosy. In vain. The more I wish the most horrible of deaths on him and treat him like the scum of the earth he is, the less I can get rid of him.'

Kinski claimed in the book that he was born into such poverty that he had to wash corpses as a child and was forced to steal on behalf of his family. In fact, he came from a well-to-do family of pharmacists, but he reinvented himself so successfully as the mad poet-actor that few of his fans discovered the truth.

Herzog was 14 years old when he first met Kinski, who moved into the Munich apartment where Herzog and his mother lived. In My Best Fiend , Herzog visits that apartment, now occupied by a prosperous, middle-aged couple and recalls Kinski's violent tantrums when his shirts were not ironed properly or when a critic's praise for one of his performances was not judged sufficiently effusive.

'I think I was the only one who was not frightened,' Herzog recalled, 'because he was like a tornado, passing into this apartment and destroying it within the first 48 hours in a fit of rage and destroying the entire furniture and the bathroom. I believe that I was the only one who was not afraid. I was rather in stunned amazement, like somebody watching a tornado wreaking havoc on the landscape. I was fascinated.'

Herzog attempts to be fair to Kinski by interviewing Eva Mattes and Claudia Cardinale, probably the only two actresses in the world with a kind word for him. But he makes no excuses for the fact that the film is a subjective portrait of Kinski, in keeping with his theory that documentaries should aim for what he calls 'ecstatic truth', as opposed to the 'accountant's truth' of cinéma vérité.

'Cinéma vérité basically confounds fact and truth, and the accountant's truth is what they can reach, a superficial truth. But I do believe that poetry, for example, or cinema has ways to discover a very deep, inherent truth, other strata of truth that are possible to discover,' says Herzog.

Herzog is in Cologne to work on Invincible , his first feature film for 13 years, the story of a Jewish strongman in the 1930s which stars Tim Roth and starts shooting in Latvia in two weeks.

For Herzog, the line between features and documentaries is blurred and, although his next three or four films will be for the cinema, he does not regret that he spent the 1990s making documentaries.

'I was fascinated, I wanted to do them, I love what I did. And some of these works are better than any feature film I ever did. I love them. And I keep saying that Fitzcarraldo is my best documentary.'

As a filmmaker who struggled to produce all his films himself since he started at the age of 17, Herzog has little patience for what he calls 'the culture of complaint' among many young directors. His first 12 films, including Aguirre, Wrath of God , were shot with a camera he stole from a film school in Munich and he financed his film studies by working night shifts as a welder.

His advice to young filmmakers is to take their destiny in their own hands and to capitalise on the new opportunities offered by digital technology to make films more cheaply than ever before.

'Nowadays, we have a technical background which makes it possible to shoot a feature film for $10,000 to $15,000. You can do it on digital video cameras. Look at the Danish, how they are doing it. You don't have to follow the rules of their manifesto, their Dogme, forget about it. But you do it yourself and if the film is really good, you'll find the money to transfer it on to real film and exhibit it in theatres. Nowadays, it is much easier to make a long feature film with enough intensity and enough imagination and a story that has some calibre. And all the rest that is needed is an able-bodied person who would work as a taxi driver, as a bouncer in a sex club or whatever, to work for half the year and he would have the money and do it. Just go for it,' he says.

The success of My Best Fiend at Cannes has highlighted the central role Kinski played in Herzog's career but the director feels little nostalgia for the glory days when they were the mad geniuses of the German cinema. Although he knows he will never have a similar relationship with any other actor, he insists that he and Kinski did everything they could have done together and that he has not been prevented from making any film because Kinski is no longer there.

'He was what he was. I fulfilled my duty as a good soldier, holding out at an outpost that nobody would have manned. Do I miss him? It's hard to admit but I have to say yes. Sure I do.'

The BBC2 season, Werner Herzog: Madman or Genius, runs on 18 and 19 March; it includes Aguirre, Wrath of God and The Enigma of Kasper Hauser

 Denis Staunton writes for the Irish Times

fields.headline: Safety chiefs 'too close to BNFL'
fields.trailText: MPs will voice serious concern this week that the nuclear safety watchdog may have become too close to British Nuclear Fuels to regulate it effectively.
fields.body:
MPs will voice serious concern this week that the nuclear safety watchdog may have become too close to British Nuclear Fuels to regulate it effectively.

The worry follows the crisis over the falsification of data at BNFL, which has already led to John Taylor's replacement as chief executive by Norman Askew.

Members of the Commons Trade and Industry Select Committee want to know why the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate did not pick up the problem over the data on fuel assemblies at BNFL's Sellafield site in Cumbria for three years .

Last month the inspectorate published three damning reports on BNFL, cataloguing management and resourcing problems.

Now the committee has summoned Laurence Williams, head of the NII, to a hearing on Tuesday. This was scheduled to consider the NII's advice on government plans to sell off 49 per cent of BNFL. However, committee chairman Martin O'Neill will use it to grill Williams over the NII's failure to identify the Sellafield problem faster, and about its relationship with BNFL.

O'Neill told The Observer : 'One of the things the committee will look at is the nature of the relationship with BNFL. It seems that some of the quality management process problems had gone unnoticed for several years. It begs the question of the role of the inspectorate.'

He did not believe that there was a conspiracy to cover up the issue, but he feared that the relationship between the NII and BNFL may have become too close.

He compares this with difficulties at the Atomic Energy Authority's nuclear plant at Dounreay in Scotland, where problems remained uncovered for a long time.

fields.headline: BNFL's 'unsafe' uranium seized
fields.standfirst: 'I wanted four children. I have one left and she thinks she will be next'
fields.trailText: 'I wanted four children. I have one left and she thinks she will be next'
fields.body:
A fresh crisis has hit British Nuclear Fuels over potentially disastrous defects in the fuel it supplies to Britain's nuclear power stations.

The industry's safety regulator, the Nuclear Installations Inspectorate, has impounded four batches of uranium fuel at BNFL's Springfields manufacturing site, near Preston, because it would be unsafe to use in nuclear reactors.

The fuel assemblies were due for dispatch to two reactors run by privatised nuclear generator British Energy, but were seized by NII inspectors last Thursday because weldings in the assemblies were cracked.

If they had been loaded into a power station's core, radioactive material would have leaked from the containers into the reactor's cooling system, causing serious safety problems which would shut down the plant if detected.

NII sources said that, although they did not believe there were cracked assemblies currently loaded in reactors, it could not rule out the possibility.

The latest setback comes after the BNFL chief executive, John Taylor, was dismissed following last month's damning NII reports into the safety management failures and the falsification of quality control documents at its Sellafield reprocessing plant in Cumbria.

The NII will now start a fresh investigation of fuel production at Springfields.

It will add further embar rassment to the company and the Government which has had to apologise to Japanese customers of BNFL over the falsification scandal. Ministers were incensed by the affair, and made clear they wanted Taylor out.

One NII source said: 'This is yet more terrible news for BNFL. They don't seem to do anything right.'

The latest revelations follow a statement on February 18 by BNFL which said current systems and processes at Springfields 'meet customer requirements'.

An NII spokesman confirmed that it had impounded the fuel assemblies, and was keeping them in a storage facility at Springfields. 'We have taken some fuel into our possession. There may be a quality control problem in terms of welds in stainless steel cladding in fuel containers into which fuel rods are inserted.'

He said inspectors had gone to Springfields after BNFL and British Energy alerted them to problems.

BNFL has halted supply of fuel to seven modern Advanced Gas Cooled Reactors owned by British Energy until the NII has fully investigated the problem.

Asked how long this would be, an NII spokesman said: 'How long is a nuclear fuel rod?'

Nuclear industry expert Frank Barnaby said: 'This is very alarming. It poses a very serious question over quality control at BNFL and about the management systems to guarantee it. It suggests they are trying to cut down on costs and as a result cutting down on checks and safety. The fact that they reported it to the NII makes it even more odd. Normally they would set the fuel aside and repair it themselves.'

Industry experts say there have been concerns about fuel produced at Springfields for some time, although this is the first batch to have been identified with faulty welds.

A Greenpeace spokesman said: 'We have been worried about Springfields for some time. The bottom line is that we don't believe BNFL can produce high quality nuclear fuel. '

The latest problems could wreck government plans to partly privatise BNFL by selling a 49 per cent stake. On hearing the news, one City investment banker, who knows the company well, said: 'I just don't believe this. No one in their right mind is going to touch them now.'

In last month's reports, NII chief executive Laurence Williams slammed the company for falsifying quality control data for fuel shipments to Japanese power utilities.

Williams said there was no excuse for the falsification, which had gone on for years in the full knowledge of management, which had done nothing to stop it. He added that plants may have to close unless major improvements were made.

Industry experts say there have been concerns about fuel produced at Springfields for some time, although this is the first batch to have been identified with faulty welds. A Greenpeace spokesman said: 'We have been worried about Springfields for some time. The bottom line is that we don't believe BNFL can produce high quality nuclear fuel. ' The latest problems could wreck government plans to partly privatise BNFL by selling a 49 per cent stake. On hearing the news, one City investment banker, who knows the company well, said: 'I just don't believe this. No one in their right mind is going to touch them now.' In last month's reports, NII chief executive Laurence Williams slammed the company for falsifying quality control data for fuel shipments to Japanese power utilities. Williams said there was no excuse for the falsification, which had gone on for years in the full knowledge of management, which had done nothing to stop it. He added that plants may have to close unless major improvements were made.

webTitle: Can you pick the century's  five top cricketers?

fields.headline: Can you pick the century's  five top cricketers?
fields.standfirst:
Wisden editor Matthew Engel explains how he spent a year putting together the most complete poll ever of worldwide cricketing brilliance.
The players to choose from
Enter the competition
Some of the experts' choices (including the editor's)
fields.trailText: There has already been a surfeit of millennium lists, not all of them brimful of historical validity. This one, I trust, is just a little different.
fields.body:
There has already been a surfeit of millennium lists, not all of them brimful of historical validity. This one, I trust, is just a little different.

Wisden Cricketers' Almanack has been choosing its Five Cricketers of the Year since 1889, and the list of past winners includes all the greats of the game, nearly all the near-greats, and quite a few indifferents: the choice has always been the preserve of Wisden editors and the odd idiosyncratic, even eccentric, selection that would never quite pass a committee has helped give the game's oldest award its enduring flavour.

When the 137th edition of Wisden is published on 6 April, there will be something else: in addition to the normal Five of the Year, there will be Five Cricketers of the Century. Given Wisden's traditions, I don't believe there has been an honour quite like it in this sport or any other.

On this occasion, it would have been wholly impertinent to impose one man's judgment: droit du seigneur can only go so far. On the other hand, a public ballot - how can one put this without sounding like someone from Millbank? - might not have produced the right result. It would have entirely depended on the level of turn-out one could get from Wisden's readers, a well-informed lot but predominantly UK-based, which was a potential source of bias. We weren't quite ingenious enough to devise an electoral college that gave Millbank the right of veto, but we're only learners.

Instead, we devised a more straightforward electoral college, comprising 100 cricketing figures (97 men, three women) from around the cricketing world. Each country was given a weighting depending on its role in Test cricket through the 20th century: thus England got 28 votes, and Australia 20, down to three for Sri Lanka and one for Zimbabwe. More than half the voters were Test players; nearly all the rest were cricket writers and historians.

They ranged from the press-box doyen EW Swanton, who died in January aged 92, and the England fast bowler Alf Gover, who celebrated his own 92nd (or 23rd) birthday on February 29, to the current Australian captain, Steve Waugh. Also on the panel were Fred Trueman, Sir Alec Bedser, Richie Benaud, Ian Chappell, Sunil Gavaskar and Clive Lloyd, all of whom not merely voted, but received votes as well. However, we did not ask some of the most obvious candidates for the award: it seemed wrong, for instance, to try to subject Sir Donald Bradman, another nonagenarian, to the decision of whether or not to vote for himself.

The voters were each asked 'to set aside any bias to your own country and your own era, and name the five whose excellence at cricket during the 20th century you think has made the greatest contribution to the game'. They did not have to put the five in any order of merit; every vote was equal.

And they were given just two pieces of advice. One was the point that has made the selection of Cricketers of the Year far more than just picking the players with the best average: 'Excellence,' we suggested, 'can be interpreted broadly. It is legitimate to take into account leadership qualities, personality, character and impact on the public.' The other one was simple: 'Please don't vote for WG Grace. We consider him a Cricketer of the 19th Century.' WG played his last Test at Nottingham in 1899 when he was almost 51, had a creaky sort of game, and whispered to his team-mate FS Jackson: 'It's all up with me, Jacker.'

It was, too. And a vote for WG in this context would have been wrong- headed. There were, however, 49 later players who did receive votes. To give you guidance, they are listed here. Five of them emerged clear of the field (there was no argument at all in the end) to become the Five Cricketers of the Century. But which five? A-ha.

I can give you just a couple more hints. Firstly, the Five do represent a pretty fair spread of the century, so don't concentrate your search on any one era. Secondly, don't think you can crib by asking any of the panel members how they voted. Not one ballot paper came up with the exact five that were chosen.

Got them yet? No, I thought not. Anyway, have a try. You only have to perm five from the 49 which makes it easier than the Lottery; and there is some scope for skill. Name your five and enter the Wisden/Observer Competition.

fields.headline: The players to choose from
fields.standfirst:
Engel explains the rules
Enter the competition
fields.trailText:
Curtly Ambrose
Right-arm fast bowler (Leeward Islands, Northamptonshire, West Indies)
88 Test matches 1988: devastatingly accurate quick bowler who uses his great height to extract dangerous bounce. Has been particularly effective when playing against England.
fields.body:
Curtly Ambrose
Right-arm fast bowler (Leeward Islands, Northamptonshire, West Indies)
88 Test matches 1988: devastatingly accurate quick bowler who uses his great height to extract dangerous bounce. Has been particularly effective when playing against England.

Sydney Barnes
Right-arm medium-fast bowler (Warwickshire, Lancashire, England)
27 Test matches 1901-14: a bowler of immense stamina who in the 1913-14 series against South Africa, at the age of 40, took 49 wickets in four Tests. Many regard him as the best bowler ever.

Sir Alec Bedser
Dogged medium-fast bowler (Surrey, England)
51 Test matches 1946-55: took 100 wickets in a season 11 times. Outstanding bowler who left the field of play only once when he vomited at the boundary's edge and then continued play.

Richie Benaud
Masterful leg-spinner, right-hand batsman and notable all-rounder (New South Wales, Australia)
63 Test matches 1952-64: in 1961 took six for 70 to save the Ashes for Australia when England had been 150-1. Competitive and enterprising leader, one of the all-time great Australian captains.

Colin Bland
Fantastic cover fielder and right-hand forcing batsman (Rhodesia, Eastern Province, Orange Free State, South Africa)
21 Test matches 1961-66: destroyed England at Lord's in 1965, brilliantly running out Ken Barrington and Jim Parks to turn the course of the series. The Jonty Rhodes of his era.

Allan Border
Left-hand batsman (New South Wales, Queensland, Gloucestershire, Essex, Australia)
156 Test matches 1978-94: a ruthless accumulator of runs who became an outstanding captain. Tough, wilful, enduring scourge of English cricket.

B.J.T. Bosanquet
Right-hand batsman and inventor of googly (Oxford University, Middlesex, England)
Seven Test matches 1903-05: his six for 51 in Sydney in 1903-04 won the series for England. He famously said of the googly that it was 'not unfair, only immoral'.

Ian Botham
Flamboyant batsman and fast-medium bowler (Somerset, Worcestershire, Durham, England)
102 Test matches 1974-93: first man to complete double of 5,000 runs and 300 wickets. Wayward Ashes hero and superstar.

Sir Donald Bradman
Legendary right-hand batsman (New South Wales, South Australia, Australia)
52 Test matches 1927-48: hit 6,996 runs (99.94) in Test matches. The most successful batsman of all, briefly stopped by bodyline.

Denis Compton
Right-hand batsman and occasional left-arm bowler (Middlesex, England)
78 Test matches 1937-56: made 1,000 runs a season 17 times, won League with Arsenal in 1948 and FA Cup in 1950. The original Brylcreem Boy, dazzling at cricket, successful for Arsenal.

Bhagwat Chandrasekhar
Right-arm leg spinner (Karnataka, India)
58 Test matches 1963-79: bowled India to first success against England taking six for 38 at The Oval (but one of worst batsmen to play Test cricket, achieving four pairs of noughts). Childhood polio sufferer, who used his withered arm to ferocious effect.

Ian Chappell
Right-handed (South Australia, Australia)
75 Test matches 1964-80: made 105 catches in Test cricket; inspirational captain, outstanding batsman, world-class appealer.

Sir Learie Constantine
Unorthodox right-handed batsman and fast bowler (Trinidad, Barbados, West Indies)
18 Test matches 1928-39: in his final Test hit 79 in 57 minutes and took five for 75. Brilliant but inconsistent all-rounder, became High Commissioner for Trinidad and Tobago. Later became Lord Constantine.

Allan Donald
Right-arm fast bowler (Orange Free State, Warwickshire and South Africa)
61 Test matches 1992: South Africa's all-time leading wicket-taker with 297 Test wickets (to date), regular destroyer of English Test teams and should soon become the first man from his country to take 300 Test wickets.

Godfrey Evans
Wicketkeeper and right-hand batsman (Kent, England)
91 Test matches 1946-59: 219 Test dismissals (173c, 46st). Irrepressible wicket-keeper, disproved theory that keepers should be sound rather than showy.

A.P. 'Tich' Freeman
Right-arm spin bowler (Kent, England)
12 Test matches 1924-29: took 3,776 (18.42) wickets for Kent. Tiny (5ft2) bowler whose lack of height regularly deceived batsmen.

Sunil Gavaskar
Right-hand opening batsman (Bombay, Somerset, India)
125 Test matches 1971-87: scored 10,122 runs (51.12) in Test matches. The Little Master was the most consistent batsman of his generation.

Lance Gibbs
Right-arm off-spinner (Guyana, South Australia, Warwickshire, West Indies)
79 Test matches 1958-76: took 309 Test wickets. Outstanding finger-spinner, renowned for stamina, courage and racing knowledge.

Clarrie Grimmett
Slow leg-break bowler (Wellington, Victoria, South Australia, Australia)
37 Test matches 1925-36: in 1936 took 44 wickets against South Africa at 14.59 each. 216 Test victims all told, known as 'the Gnome', with a deadly accurate eye.

Sir Richard Hadlee
Fast-bowling all-rounder (Canterbury, Nottinghamshire, Tasmania, New Zealand)
86 Test matches 1973-90: New Zealand's highest wicket taker with 431 (22.29) in Test matches. From untidy scruff to knight of the realm, the fortunes of New Zealand cricket rested squarely on his shoulders.

Walter Hammond
Right-hand batsman (Gloucestershire, England).
85 Test matches 1927-47: one of the greatest slip fielders. Daring but regal batsman who hit six Test double-centuries.

George Headley
Right-hand batsman (Jamaica, West Indies)
22 Test matches 1930-54: 2,190 runs in Tests, including 10 centuries. Known as the Black Bradman and Atlas because his country's hopes rested on his shoulders.

Sir Jack Hobbs
Right-hand opening batsman (Surrey, England)
61 Test matches 1908-34: 98 of his 199 centuries were made after age of 40. Deceptively frail appearance hid iron will; first man to score more centuries than W.G. Grace.

Michael Holding
Fast bowler (Jamaica, Lancashire, Derbyshire, Tasmania, Canterbury, West Indies)
60 Test matches 1975-87: 249 wickets in Test cricket. Elegant bowler known as 'Whispering Death' because of his silent approach.

Sir Leonard Hutton
Right-hand batsman (Yorkshire, England)
79 Test matches 1937-55: 40,140 runs for Yorkshire, 19 centuries for England. Former Observer columnist, holds the record score against Australia - 364 at The Oval in 1938, which stood as a world record for more than 20 years.

Kapil Dev
All-rounder (Haryana, Northamptonshire, Worcestershire and India)
131 Test matches 1978-94: 434 (29.64) Test wickets. Current coach of India, one of only three players to have scored 3,000 runs and taken more than 200 wickets in Test matches.

Imran Khan
All-rounder (Lahore, Pakistan International Airline, Dawood Club, Oxford University, Worcestershire, Sussex, New South Wales, Pakistan)
88 Test matches 1971-92: first Pakistani to pass 200 wickets and their greatest all-rounder. Former playboy of the Eastern world.

Harold Larwood
Right-arm fast bowler (Nottinghamshire, England)
21 Test matches 1926-33: on the bodyline tour took 33 wickets at 19.51. Shy, modest man who reduced Bradman to mortal status with fierce leg-theory bowling.

Dennis Lillee
Fast bowler (Western Australia, Australia)
70 Test matches 1971-84: won the Centenary Test for Australia in 1977 with six for 26 and five for 139. Showman bowler of outstanding skill with a vicious streak.

Ray Lindwall
Right-arm fast bowler (New South Wales, Queensland, Australia)
61 Test matches 1946-60: took six for 20 against England at The Oval in 1948. Skilled purveyor of outswingers whose calm and lack of histrionics stood out.

Clive Lloyd
Left-hand batsman (Guyana, Lancashire, West Indies)
110 Test matches 1966-84: in 1980-81 played nine first-class innings in Caribbean and failed to reach 50 only once when run out on 49. Gangling, bespectacled captain with a remarkable eye for a man who wore glasses.

Stan McCabe
Right-hand batsman (New South Wales, Australia)
39 Test matches 1930-38: in 1938 scored 232 (out of 300) in less than four hours at Trent Bridge. Tenacious batsman who even won admiration of team-mate Don Bradman.

Malcolm Marshall
Right-arm fast bowler (Barbados, Hampshire, Natal, West Indies)
81 Test matches 1978-91: in 1985 took seven for 80 against New Zealand and 27 wickets (18.16) in four Tests. Not built like a fast bowler but one of the most effective pacemen of his or any generation.

Bruce Mitchell
Right-hand opening batsman (Transvaal and South Africa)
42 Test matches 1929-49: in 1929, aged 20, scored more runs (1,615 at 32.95) than any other member of the side. Perfectly balanced batsman and complete player who was at his best in Tests.

Bill O'Reilly
Right-arm spin bowler (New South Wales and Australia)
27 Test matches 1932-46: took 10 for 129 in Australia's sole victory on the bodyline tour. Tenacious bowler, known as 'Tiger' and described by Bradman as the greatest bowler of his time.

Graeme Pollock
Left-hand batsman (Eastern Province, Transvaal, South Africa)
23 Test matches 1963-70: scored 64 centuries in first-class cricket. Skilled but brutal player who may well have made the record books but for South Africa's exclusion from international cricket in the late Sixties.

K.S. Ranjitsinhji
Right-hand batsman (Cambridge University, Sussex, England)
15 Test matches 1896-1902: passed 1,000 runs in the 12 seasons in which he appeared regularly. Legendary inventor of the leg glance whose skill made David Gower look crude.

Wilfred Rhodes
Slow left-arm bowler (Yorkshire, England)
58 Test matches 1899-1930: over his career dismissed 4,187 batsmen - no other cricketer has come close. The archetypal Yorkshireman, tough, formidable and dour.

Sir Viv Richards
Right-hand batsman (Leeward Is, Somerset, Queensland, Glamorgan, West Indies)
121 Test matches 1974-91: in 1980 he was leading batsman in both Test matches and first-class cricket in England. The unofficial king of the West Indies, a superb, stylish batsman and emotional captain.

Sir Garfield Sobers
Left-hand batsman and multi-faceted bowler (Barbados, South Australia, Nottinghamshire, West Indies)
93 Test matches 1954-74: at 21 scored 365 not out against Pakistan, breaking Len Hutton's record, which had stood for 20 years. The most graceful all-rounder of all.

Maurice Tate
Right-arm fast medium bowler (Sussex, England)
39 Test matches 1924-35: between 1922 and 1925 captured 848 wickets in first-class cricket. Started as a batsman before finding his forte as a surprisingly successful bowler.

Sachin Tendulkar
Right-hand batsman (Bombay, Yorkshire and India)
76 Test matches 1989- : in 1989, aged 16, became the youngest player in cricket history to score a Test 50. From child prodigy to international superstar.

Fred Trueman
Right-arm fast bowler (Yorkshire, Derbyshire, England)
67 Test matches 1952-65: first man to take 300 Test wickets. Great bowler, great character, always convinced he was the best man for the job.

Victor Trumper
Right-hand batsman (New South Wales, Australia)
48 Test matches 1899-1912: dominated 1910-11 Test series against South Africa with 661 runs. Ultimate batsman of golden Edwardian age.

Shane Warne
Spin bowler (Victoria, Australia)
81 Test matches 1992- : took 34 wickets in six Tests against England in 1993, including 'Ball of the century' to Mike Gatting. Brash, flashy but annoyingly good, on course to be one of the greatest bowlers of all.

Sir Pelham Warner
Right-hand batsman (Oxford University, Middlesex, England)
15 Test matches 1899-1912: once claimed to have made a duck in every British Dominion except India. Known as 'Plum', a polished batsman, his reputation suffered as England manager during the controversial 1932-33 bodyline tour.

Wasim Akram
Left-arm fast bowler (Lahore, Pakistan Automobile Corporation, Lancashire, Pakistan)
92 Test matches 1985- : scored his first Test century in 1990 against Australia, then hit 257* against Zimbabwe in 1996-97. Tough and often difficult, with Waqar Younis has formed one of history's great fast bowling pairs.

Frank Woolley
All-rounder (Kent, England)
64 Test matches 1909-34: held England together against Australia in 1922 with 95 (out of 187) and 93 (out of 283). Taciturn but famously described as showing 'all summer in one stroke'.

Sir Frank Worrell
Right-hand batsman (Barbados, Jamaica, West Indies)
51 Test matches 1948-63: elegant stylist who captained his side in two of international cricket's most breathtaking finishes - the tied Test in Brisbane in 1961 and at Lord's in 1963, which was drawn after all four results were possible as the last ball was bowled.

Bruce Mitchell Right-hand opening batsman (Transvaal and South Africa) 42 Test matches 1929-49: in 1929, aged 20, scored more runs (1,615 at 32.95) than any other member of the side. Tenacious bowler, known as 'Tiger' and described by Bradman as the greatest bowler of his time. Ranjitsinhji Right-hand batsman (Cambridge University, Sussex, England) 15 Test matches 1896-1902: passed 1,000 runs in the 12 seasons in which he appeared regularly. fields.headline: From Trenchtown to  your town
fields.standfirst: Chris Blackwell, the founder of Island Records, put reggae on the global jukebox. Now, he tells  Neil Spencer,  his Palm Pictures outfit wants to do the same for Jamaican cinema, starting with the new movie  Third World Cop
fields.trailText: Chris Blackwell, the founder of Island Records, put reggae on the global jukebox. Now, he tells Neil Spencer, his Palm Pictures outfit wants to do the same for Jamaican cinema, starting with the new movie Third World Cop
fields.body:
Kingston's Carib cinema holds fond memories for Chris Blackwell. When he was a boy, back in the postwar era, the Carib was one of the few air-conditioned buildings offering relief from the gritty swelter of Jamaica's capital, a place literally to chill out while taking in a Tyrone Power movie or whatever US import had arrived on the boat from Florida.

Later, the cinema became a place of hot excitement, where over-enthused ghetto youth would draw pistols and shoot at the cinematic action, ensuring that the Carib's films were viewed on a screen peppered with bullet holes. At the premiere of The Harder They Come in 1972, a crowd of 6,000 marched on the Carib, breaking down doors and muscling aside VIPs. Even the film's star, Jimmy Cliff, couldn't get in.

The Carib is now a multiplex and a shadow of its old self, but remained the venue of choice when Blackwell, record magnate turned film producer, premiered his latest movie, Third World Cop, last year. A low-budget action yarn set amid the grainy streets and ghettos of Kingston, and spilling over with guns and reggae, Third World Cop quickly broke the Jamaican box-office records previously held by Home Alone 2 and Dancehall Queen, another Blackwell production.

It is a small-scale triumph - with a population of around three million, Jamaica is a less important market than north London - but for Blackwell a big step in realising his dream of building an indigenous film industry with the same international appeal exercised by the island's music scene.

As the founder of Island Records and a champion of Bob Marley, Blackwell was instrumental in bringing reggae to a global audience in the Sixties and Seventies, helping turn his tiny impoverished homeland into a cultural force.

The ambition to pull off a similar feat via the more daunting medium of cinema at first seems misplaced - Jamaica is better known as a backdrop for Bond movies than for the score or so movies the island has made about itself - yet Blackwell is convinced he has the strategy to make it work. Sitting in the London offices of Palm Pictures, the company he established two years ago after he had sold Island to Polygram, the elegantly grizzled Blackwell exudes the confidence of an assured media operator. The key elements, he insists, are low overheads, abundance and authenticity.

'The success of Third World Cop and Dancehall Queen in Jamaica shows there is a demand there for coherent tales of Jamaicans, speaking and being Jamaican. That's our base market. For a long time there has been the idea that you can't make a Jamaican film without bringing in a foreign star, but it has always ended up fake. My interest is to get as close as possible to the musical culture - Jamaican records make no concession to anything, they're made for the home market, yet travel round the world.'

Perry Henzell's The Harder They Come , at least, has already achieved exactly that kind of success. With Cliff in the lead role as a tearaway, gun-toting rude boy, the movie became with Bob Marley 'the double whammy that broke Jamaican culture,' according to Blackwell. 'It didn't do it in the first week like you're meant to; it took years, but there seem to be very few people who haven't seen that film.'

The cult appeal of The Harder They Com e, a deftly sewn crime parable with a storming soundtrack, has cast a shadow which subsequent Jamaica movies have struggled to escape. Smile Orange and Rockers in the Seventies and Countryman and The Lunatic in the Eighties all lacked its novelty, its class and the charisma of Cliff's performance.

Dancehall Queen in 1997, directed by black Londoner Don Letts, and Third World Cop, directed by Jamaica-born Chris Browne, have fared better partly because they return to the world of drug-running, reggae and gunplay of The Harder They Come - a couple of scenes in Third World Cop pay explicit homage to Henzell's trailblazer.

Third World Cop follows a maverick detective, Capone, as he tries to bust a gun-running racket. Capone is based on a real-life cop, Trinity (so-called because he had three lives), a personal enforcer for ex-Prime Minister Edward Seaga. Here he becomes a Jamaican Dirty Harry whose boast is 'We run tings, tings nuh run we', but whose loyalties are soon tested as his trail leads to his old ghetto spar, Ratty.

There's plenty of shoot-em-up action, but the film's heartbeat is its vivid cameos of life in the zinc-fenced mazes of Kingston's ghettos. Carl Bradshaw, a survivor from The Harder They Come, is compelling as a ghetto don, while Mark Danvers, as the compromised Ratty, quietly steals the movie from its star, Paul Campbell (Capone).

For Blackwell, Dancehall Queen and Third World Cop are the low-budget templates for future productions. Both movies cost around $500,000 and were shot on DVD rather than film, and both are able to present Caribbean scenarios to a wider audience.

Jamaica, reasons Blackwell, is a natural resource for movies; packed with great stories, larger-than-life characters, dramatic backdrops and, of course, brilliant music. 'I want to bring young writers to Jamaica and let them loose. You just have to read the newspapers and go to the law courts and you will hear scenarios that you could never imagine.' He cites a true-story instance in Third World Cop , where a ghetto child leads the cops to an AK47 rifle pinned on to a clothes line inside a sheet.

Blackwell's plan is to make Palm Pictures 'a company that specialises in seeking out low-budget movies and directors. Huge budgets smother creativity, there's no room to play, you're not taking a bloodbath financially, and you may catch some wider mood. I'm trying to get scripts and stories for two or three films a year.'

It was his belief in small-scale operations, he claims, which lay behind his decision to sell Island. 'I like a hands-on company, and Island had become too corporatised. When someone started talking about who should be senior vice-president I lost interest. We'd become a small army, and while a guerrilla force can fight big armies, small armies have no hope.'

Palm Pictures' current project list, however, reveals a mixture of the medium and small scale. Julian Simpson's imminent film noir, The Criminal (starring Steven Mackintosh and Eddie Izzard) cost $3.5 million, while James Toback's Black and White (starring Robert Downey Jr, Brooke Shields and Claudia Schiffer) has more then doubled its original $2m budget. 'I agreed to extend the budget to get the names,' says Blackwell, who joined forces with Sony to bankroll the movie.

He is more animated talking about the funkier end; about Boy Shaman , a movie set in Africa to be shot by wildlife director John Dunn, and about Lockdown , a prison movie made by basketball playing African-American director Master P. 'I wanted to get experience of the American urban market, because that's the best place to cross over my Jamaican projects,' says Blackwell. 'At the time of Bob Marley and The Harder They Come the crossover route was through the white middle-class college crowd, but Jamaican music is now much closer to rap than to cultural music.'

Third World Cop itself is already spawning two sequels. 'I loved the title because you can have follow-ups forever,' laughs Blackwell. In one, Capone takes his crime-busting skills to Toronto. The other film follows the fortunes of the two 13-year-old boys we glimpse in Third World Cop , tucking a pair of smuggled automatics in the swagger-bands of their trousers; a pair of twenty-first century ragamuffins.

Jamaica, whose murder rate is around 1,000 a year, remains a place where life is cheap, though Blackwell insists it is no more dangerous than anywhere else; most of the crime is related to the island's role in drug-running from Central America and to its still grinding poverty. Third World Cop , though, suggests that it is at least as interesting a subject for movies as, say, South-Central LA. Blackwell, for one, is convinced. 'Making films there is actually more fun than sitting in the first world watching TV.'

Sound and vision... landmarks in Jamaican cinema

The harder they come (1973)
Groundbreaking film starring reggae singer Jimmy Cliff. He plays country boy Ivan Martin who becomes an infamous gangster. The film is probably best known for its lively soundtrack, which helped popularise Jamaican music.

Countryman (1982)
A fast-paced road movie enlivened by Jamaican folk magic. The easy-going, eponymous hero is threatened by local heavies and decides to leave town with his enemies in tow. The soundtrack features Bob Marley and the Wailers.

The lunatic (1992)
Bawdy sex comedy about an amiable village simpleton who is able to converse with trees and bushes. He begins a torrid affair with a voluptuous German tourist, launching a series of strange events. Directed by Lol Creme.

 'Third World Cop' opens in Britain on 24 March. The soundtrack is released tomorrow.

fields.headline: Did the dictator dupe us?
fields.standfirst:
Andy McSmith reveals details of the medical tests that let the 'ailing' Pinochet return to Santiago, from where Jonathan Franklin reports on jubilation, and anger, at his arrival

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Andy McSmith reveals details of the medical tests that let the 'ailing' Pinochet return to Santiago, from where  Jonathan Franklin reports on jubilation, and anger, at his arrival
fields.body:
The crowd cheered, the band played. The commander-in-chief of the armed forces, old comrades and political allies were there to greet him.

General Augusto Pinochet beamed with pleasure. The world watched as a man supposedly too ill to stand trial walked steadily across the tarmac, greeted his children, embraced his brother officers and raised an arm in a triumphant salute.

What many saw as a crude show of strength by the army has infuriated much of Chilean civil society, including those close to the President, whose plane was diverted to allow the ceremony.

But more immediate questions presented themselves to startled observers. Was it the air of his homeland which revived the frail old man on his return after 503 days of detention in Britain? Or could it be that he had hoodwinked the doctors whose report gave Home Secretary Jack Straw humanitarian grounds for his return?

The Pinochet who flew home in triumph was very different from the frail old man who arrived in Northwick Park Hospital in a wheelchair two months earlier for an examination by a team of medical specialists. He had to be helped into bed and have his hearing aid checked.

Human rights organisations have claimed a Chilean naval psychiatrist had been staying in England with Pinochet since last August and that she had coached him on how to fail the tests.

The medical report is still unpublished, although a version was leaked to the Spanish press. Last week the full text was made available to MPs, one of whom passed it to The Observer .

The morning session was taken up with questions and tests by a three-man team headed by Sir John Grimlet Evans, from Oxford's Radcliffe Infirmary. They saw an old man who groaned from an aching pain in both buttocks, and had to be helped out of bed and held upright.

The team was also told that the general was unable to dress himself or shave without cutting himself. They forecast that 'further deterioration in both physical and mental condition is likely'.

The more important examination, which would finally put Pinochet beyond the reach of European courts, came after lunch. It was conducted by Dr Maria Wyke, a consultant neuropsychologist based at Devonshire Hospital, London, and a fluent Spanish speaker.

She started with an IQ test known as the Wechsler Adult Intelligence scale. Pinochet's vocabulary was very good, suggesting an IQ of around 125, but when given other tests, like being asked to remember a sequence of numbers backwards, he scored so badly that he was bordering on the subnormal.

Next, he was shown collections of pictures which formed a series, and asked to pick out the one which completed the series. This time his IQ measured around 100.

Finally, he was given three different types of memory test, in all of which he faltered badly. For instance, he was told a short story and asked to recall 20 details from it. He could only recall one.

Dr Wyke also tried to get him to play a game in which he was given a list of Spanish words, then asked to pick out one which paired with a set word. But the general could not understand the rules of the game, so she gave up.

After about an hour, the doctor was in no doubt that she was talking to a man who had suffered serious brain damage, destroying his short-term memory. She was convinced he could not be faking the results because 'his performance on both memory and intelligence tests declined only in relation to the difficulty of the task [and] was consistent across all the tasks'.

Her findings convinced the team that, if Pinochet were extradited to Spain, they would be putting on trial an old man who would be unable to understand what was happening or to remember the offences he was accused of committing.

But other experts say that this was a grand conclusion to base on just one session, in which the patient was put through a relatively small number of tests.

After reading the report, shown to her by The Ob-server , Dr Danitza Jadresic, a Sheffield-based consultant psychiatrist specialising in neuropsychiatry, whose father was arrested and forced into exile after Pinochet seized power in Chile in 1973, insists that the evidence in it was insufficient to justify Pinochet's release.

She said: 'The most striking aspect of the medical report is the lack of independent corroboration to General Pinochet's own account of chronic memory problems. There is also conflicting evidence about his ability to understand instructions.'

In Chile, there was considerable disquiet about Pinochet's apparently sprightly health. But civilian officials, including President Eduardo Frei, were also incensed that the army used the general's return to flex their muscles and harass civilian authorities.

Not only did the army divert the presidential plane to a separate airfield in order to accommodate the arrival of Pinochet, but abrubtly ejected journalists from covering the ceremonies at an air force base, then said they had done so on orders from the Frei administration.

On Friday, Pinochet left the military hospital at 6:40pm, just over eight hours after he had arrived, and went to one of his private homes in a wealthy Santiago neighbourhood. His heavily armed escort, watched over by helicopters, spoke eloquently of the army's support.

As scepticism about his health filled the Chilean media, his daughter Jaqueline said: 'He boarded the aeroplane [a] destroyed [man] and, with the passing of hours, he began to recover. Originally various plans were studied, even using a stretcher. I was even surprised, but I don't want to say he is healthy. Bit by bit he recovered while he flew.'

A military hospital spokesman, Colonel Alejandro Campusano, announced - after taking blood and urine samples - that the 84-year-old was in good health.

But not all the news was good for Pinochet. On Friday 60 different criminal complaints also awaited him. While there are significant hurdles to his prosecution, all factions of society - with the exception of the armed forces - have now placed the integrity of Chile's judicial system above their differences. Even many right -wing supporters of the former commander-in-chief are now invoking the right of Chile's courts to investigate any Chilean, even the patriarch.

Judge Juan Guzmán, who is co-ordinating the legal actions against Pinochet, initiated court proceedings. An application also began to remove his immunity as a life senator.

He has also requested new medical tests. Mere physical ill health will not save Pinochet from trial: under Chilean law he has to be either senile or mad. The man who bounced on to the tarmac in jubilation on Friday looked neither.

On Friday, Pinochet left the military hospital at 6:40pm, just over eight hours after he had arrived, and went to one of his private homes in a wealthy Santiago neighbourhood. His heavily armed escort, watched over by helicopters, spoke eloquently of the army's support. As scepticism about his health filled the Chilean media, his daughter Jaqueline said: 'He boarded the aeroplane [a] destroyed [man] and, with the passing of hours, he began to recover. Originally various plans were studied, even using a stretcher. I was even surprised, but I don't want to say he is healthy. Bit by bit he recovered while he flew.' A military hospital spokesman, Colonel Alejandro Campusano, announced - after taking blood and urine samples - that the 84-year-old was in good health. But not all the news was good for Pinochet. On Friday 60 different criminal complaints also awaited him. While there are significant hurdles to his prosecution, all factions of society - with the exception of the armed forces - have now placed the integrity of Chile's judicial system above their differences. Even many right -wing supporters of the former commander-in-chief are now invoking the right of Chile's courts to investigate any Chilean, even the patriarch. Judge Juan Guzmán, who is co-ordinating the legal actions against Pinochet, initiated court proceedings. An application also began to remove his immunity as a life senator. He has also requested new medical tests. Mere physical ill health will not save Pinochet from trial: under Chilean law he has to be either senile or mad. The man who bounced on to the tarmac in jubilation on Friday looked neither.

webTitle: Child superstar Anna Paquin's vampish turn

fields.headline: Child superstar Anna Paquin's vampish turn
fields.trailText: Anna Paquin has got something tucked away in her closet: an Oscar. The now 17-year-old actress picked it up for The Piano in 1994, and it's been nestling among her clothes ever since. Modesty aside, it's a smart move. Putting the little gold man on prominent display would only tempt fate. After all, who knows what her future career holds? However, Paquin did it for another reason, 'It would be awkward and uncomfortable for my friends,' she says.
fields.body:
Anna Paquin has got something tucked away in her closet: an Oscar. The now 17-year-old actress picked it up for The Piano in 1994, and it's been nestling among her clothes ever since. Modesty aside, it's a smart move. Putting the little gold man on prominent display would only tempt fate. After all, who knows what her future career holds? However, Paquin did it for another reason, 'It would be awkward and uncomfortable for my friends,' she says.

Becoming the second-youngest Academy Award winner is a tough act to follow. As Holly Hunter's watchful daughter in The Piano, she made a startling screen debut. On the big night, she gasped and spluttered through an impromptu acceptance speech, which is now a feature in all good Oscar highlight videos.

Fast-forward six years. Now she is a runaway teen waif who gets intimate with Sean Penn and Kevin Spacey in Hurlyburly a savage tale of Eighties indulgence and Hollywood misogyny. It's a pivotal supporting role. More important, it should help banish perceptions of her as that spirited little thing in a bonnet.

It follows a similarly vampish turn in weak teen romance She's All That, and one as a rebellious hippie chick in Sixties-set Walk on the Moon . Paquin has had quite a career makeover. If the key to thespian kudos is versatility, then Paquin - who still looks eligible for a child-rate bus pass - is currently going through her lascivious stage. Like the teenage Jodie Foster, she is experimenting with her image in public.

The most surprising thing about Anna Paquin is that she has never had an acting lesson. To use a cliché, she is a natural. She grew up in Wellington, New Zealand, the youngest of three children of teacher parents. At nine, she went along to the open audition of The Piano because all her friends were going. Three call-backs later and she had won the part. Director Jane Campion later noted that she seemed to be the smallest and shyest girl in the room but was impressed by her colourful improvisation.

Paquin followed up The Piano with three years of screen silence. She re-emerged in two family films, Fly Away Home and Jane Eyre in 1996, moving to Los Angeles with her recently divorced mother. She now attends advanced classes at an LA high school. In between lessons and making movies, she likes alternative rock, visiting thrift markets and photography. Later this year she aims to follow Claire Danes and Natalie Portman into Ivy League education, scaling down her acting work. She wants to study psychology.

Before college, she has significant roles in two eagerly awaited films. She plays Rogue, a genetic mutant, in the big-budget adaptation of superhero comic book X-Men, directed by Bryan Singer (The Usual Suspects). In Cameron Crowe's provisionally titled Stillwater, she is a soulful groupie infatuated with Jason Lee's Seventies rocker.

She won the role after the Jerry Maguire director was bowled over by her wave during the audition. 'I asked her to say goodbye to a hotel room she'd stayed in for a few days, where stuff had happened, and I must have watched that tape a thousand times. It was so great,' he said. So, there you have it, she gives good waves and intriguing performances.

Five things you should know about Anna Paquin

1: Her character in Stillwater is the bizarrely-named Polexia Aphrodesia.
2: Her favourite television show is Dawson's Creek and her favourite movie is The Wedding Singer.
3: On acting, she says: 'None of the characters I've played are really like me. That would be boring. It wouldn't be acting.'
4: When she was younger she wanted to be the Prime Minister of New Zealand, a lawyer or an astronaut. Why no train driver?
5: She beat more than 1,000 girls for the role of Flora in The Piano.

fields.headline: Fed up with seconds
fields.standfirst: Hollywood is just nutty about sequels to the big hits
fields.trailText: The US movie calendar has kicked off in familiar style. A sub-par Bruce Willis movie, The Whole Nine Yards, currently sits on top of the box-office charts, closely followed by Chevy Chase (remember him?) in a critic-proof kiddie comedy called Snow Day.
fields.body:
The US movie calendar has kicked off in familiar style. A sub-par Bruce Willis movie, The Whole Nine Yards, currently sits on top of the box-office charts, closely followed by Chevy Chase (remember him?) in a critic-proof kiddie comedy called Snow Day.

The latter is a surprise hit. Hollywood loves that kind of surprise, but generally prefers a sure thing. That's why this year will see a glut of sequels, following last summer's undeserved hits, Star Wars: Episode 1 - The Phantom Menace and Austin Powers: The spy who shagged me.

Don't get me wrong, a sequel can be a wonderful thing - Toy Story 2, The Godfather Part II - but usually they're not. The law of diminishing returns tends to apply, especially after the first couple of follow-ups. Anyone for Police Academy 6?

So far this year in the States, Scream 3 and Next Friday have topped the charts despite being uninspired re-treads. That's just for starters. This summer the overriding emotion in cinemas won't be fear or laughter but déjà vu. Stand by for: Nutty Professor 2: The Klumps, Mission: Impossible 2, Pokeman 2, 102 Dalmations, The Blair Witch Project 2, Rugrats in Paris, The Flintsontes in Viva Rock Vegas, and Godzilla 2000. Phew, what a scorcher.

There's no chance of film-makers learning from their mistakes when they've proved so lucrative. The Nutty Professor began shooting without a finished script, causing writers to create dialogue as fast as Eddie Murphy could recite it.

In Australia, the set of Mission: Impossible was a disaster zone: crew members deserted mid-shoot, the budget spiralled and filming over-ran so much co-stars Dougray Scott and Thandie Newton had to withdraw from their next films. According to reports, only Tom Cruise emerged unscathed, but following his record-breaking stint on Eyes Wide Shut, nothing can faze him.

The current wave of indie-influenced studio films has garnered much praise but generally hasn't made for great box-office.

So, dull sequels are there to balance the slate and the books. For every American Beauty there has to be a Nutty Professor. Thanks a lot Eddie.

webTitle: Men of genius who transcended the game's boundaries

fields.headline: Men of genius who transcended the game's boundaries
fields.standfirst:
Engel explains the rules
The players to choose from
Enter the competition
Some of the other experts' choices
fields.trailText: My Five Cricketers of the Century are:
fields.body:
My Five Cricketers of the Century are:

Don Bradman

Denis Compton

Garry Sobers

Viv Richards

Ian Botham

I can give you a clue. Wisden's editor, Matthew Engel, a secretive soul in these matters, has nonetheless revealed that the quintet above is not the right quintet. In fact, he tells me that no one voter in the Wisden poll wrote down all five of the cricketers finally chosen. I suspect the selection procedure makes the attempts to find a mayor for London seem a mundane and straightforward operation.

I can't pretend the names above are controversial. I chose them, Engel reminds me, because all five reached beyond the normal cricketing audience. For example, Don Bradman is treated with the same reverence in Australia as the Queen Mother generally is here. His record can't be surpassed: a century every third innings and a Test average of 99.94. He was super-efficient and a genius or, as Robertson-Glasgow rather more deftly put it, 'an artist without the handicap of an artistic temperament, a genius with an eye for business'. The nearest we have to him today, by Bradman's own assessment, is Sachin Tendulkar, another credible candidate (in all there were 49 nominations).

Garry Sobers still generates the same feeling of awe in Barbados. And, when I was an 11-year-old in Somerset, he was the man I wanted to emulate, although I had some difficulty bowling left-handed. Even Neville Cardus, who venerated the all-rounders of his youth - Wilfred Rhodes and Frank Woolley - thought Sobers might be the best. He wrote: 'Nobody has seen Sobers obviously in labour. He makes a stroke with moments to spare. His fastest ball - and it could be very fast - is bowled as though he could, with physical pressure, have bowled it a shade faster. He can, in the slips, catch the lightning snick with the grace and nonchalance of Hammond himself. The sure sign of mastery, of genius of any order, is absence of strain, natural freedom of rhythm.'

If legend is to be believed, Denis Compton only had to strain to get to the ground on time - sometimes clad in his dinner jacket. Compton was our post-war national hero, the 'Brylcreem Boy', who darted down the wing for Arsenal and gaily thrashed runs for Middlesex and England. His cricket mirrored the relief and joy that the War was finally over and the conviction that life was now for living. When he suffered a knee injury, the nation awaited the latest bulletin on Denis's fitness with far more interest than we now devote to Michael Owen's hamstring. But Compton was no fair-weather cricketer. Witness his courage against the pace of the Australians at Manchester in 1948. A Lindwall bumper struck his head and he had to leave the field for stitches. He returned to complete an undefeated 145; no one else passed 50.

I may be accused of bias in my last two choices since I was a colleague of both of them at Somerset (I thought about Colin Dredge, but eventually relented). Viv Richards was the best batsman I played with or against. I have never seen anyone bat with such intensity or with the ability to will himself to score runs when it really mattered. The better the bowler the more determined Richards was to subjugate him as Bob Willis and Derek Underwood ruefully discovered. Mere survival would have been a demeaning goal for Richards, while wearing a helmet might be interpreted as a sign of frailty. Almost singlehandedly, he put Antigua on the map, not to mention Taunton.

Ian Botham's greatest quality was that he set no limits on what he might achieve. This meant that he allowed himself to succeed - or fail - spectacularly. That takes courage; most of us settled for safe mediocrity. There was a period in the early Eighties when he was easily the most recognisable English sportsman, outstripping any of the soccer players. He was forever on the back and front pages, usually, but not always, for the right reasons. No cricketer today would make the top 20, another reason why Matthew Engel is stepping back once he's produced his Millennium Wisden. Good luck.

fields.headline: World Wine Web
fields.trailText: Australian Shiraz
fields.body:
Australian Shiraz

What's the bottle? 1997 Peter Lehmann Shiraz, Barossa Valley

Price and stockist? £6.99 from Sainsbury's and Waitrose

What's interesting about the wine? Barossa Shiraz has emerged as one of Australia's great wine styles in the last decade, thanks (in substantial measure) to the efforts of Peter Lehmann. The man they call the Baron of the Barossa is a chain-smoking, tough-talking Aussie who believed in the future of warm-climate areas at a time when cooler regions were all the rage. While big companies were encouraging growers to grub up their old vines and do something else, Lehmann continued to believe in grapes such as Grenache, Semillon and especially Shiraz. As prices have risen in Australia, Lehmann continues to produce some great-value reds.

What does the wine smell and taste like? This is a big wine, with a deep, inky colour and plenty of oak and fruit, but it's not a clumsy one by any means. Lehmann, more than anyone, knows how to combine concentration with comparative subtlety. On the nose, the wine is rich with chocolate, damsons, blackberries and vanilla oak. On the palate, it's attractively oaked, with fine tannins, sweet, stylish fruit and notes of liquorice, vanilla and black fruits. It wears its alcohol lightly and its finish is delicious.

What does it go with? Nothing too fancy. Barbecues, burgers, pasta - the wine's so delicious it's a meal in itself.

Serving temperature? 16-18 C, but you can chill it.

Will it keep? Yes, no problem for two to five years - or longer.

What are we tasting next? 1997 Château Sauvage, Premières Côtes de Bordeaux (£5.99, Thresher, Victoria Wine, Wine Rack)

 Send your views to tim.atkin@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Double trouble
fields.standfirst: Despite their lofty ambitions, when two big wine producers go into partnership to create a new wine, it often seems the only thing that increases is the price
fields.trailText: Despite their lofty ambitions, when two big wine producers go into partnership to create a new wine, it often seems the only thing that increases is the price
fields.body:
Students at American business schools are brought up on something called the pig and chicken theory, an Aesop's fable for the corporate age. A chicken walks up to a pig and says: 'Hey, we should form a partnership. You provide the bacon and I'll provide the eggs.' 'Great,' says the pig, 'but I don't wanna die.' The moral of this tale is simple enough: in joint ventures, someone always gets screwed.

I found myself thinking about pigs and chickens recently at the launch of Col Solare, a 'unique' joint venture (aren't they all?) between Chateau Sainte Michelle of Washington State and Antinori of Tuscany. Who, I wondered, would provide the bacon this time? My conclusion was that both producers were looking to lay eggs. The bacon will come from anyone foolish enough to pay £55 for a bottle.

Joint ventures are increasingly popular in the wine world. It's a neat coincidence that Opus One, the trend-creating partnership between California's Robert Mondavi and Baron Philippe de Rothschild of Château Mouton-Rothschild, has just celebrated its 20th anniversary. The success of Opus - one of the few New World wines, apart from Penfolds' Grange, to have made a serious impact on the auction scene - has encouraged a number of imitators.

Several of these, wouldn't you know it, seem to involve Mondavi and Mouton. In the past three years, Mondavi has released Seòa (with Errzuriz) in Chile and Luce (with Frescobaldi) in Tuscany, while Mouton has launched Almaviva, a partnership with Chile's largest producer, Concha y Toro. These wines have two things in common: they're red and they're laughably over-priced.

There's nothing wrong with a bit of ambition - too much modern wine is singularly timid - but this is madness. You could buy mature claret from a great vintage like 1986 for the price of Seòa. The same (and more) goes for Col Solare. 'We tasted the wine against the competition and thought it stacked up,' one of the winemakers told me. The wine is certainly very good - as complex as anything I've tasted from Washington State - but there are thousands of better-value wines in the world.

The problem with joint ventures is that they invariably serve the producers' egos rather than the consumer's interests. Seòa comes from much the same vineyards as a wine called Don Maximiano (which sold at under £10 a bottle not so long ago). The same thing applies to Alma Viva, which bears a considerable resemblance to Concha y Toro's Don Melchior. My conclusion is that Robert Mondavi, Mouton and Antinori think their names and expertise are worth £20 a bottle or more.

Not all joint ventures are a rip off. New Zealand giant Montana's partnerships with Cordier (for red wine) and Champagne Deutz (for fizz) have produced some genuinely interesting, well-priced wines. The same is true of Seven Peaks in California, Casa Lapostolle in Chile and D'istinto in Sicily.

But such successes are outnumbered by the duffers, where companies have 'found their strategies incompatible' (ie they found they detested each other) or just produced mediocre wines together. Having two famous names on a label ought to be a guarantee of quality. All too often, it is nothing of the sort.

Having two famous names on a label ought to be a guarantee of quality. All too often, it is nothing of the sort.

fields.headline: Slaughterhouse three
fields.standfirst: Three Kings has everything - exploding cows, gut reactions and a serious message
fields.trailText: Philip French: Not always convincing and the ending is a trifle pat and not entirely plausible. But it is punctuated by fascinating, often surreal detail and full of disturbing incidents and encounters
fields.body:
The American independent director David O. Russell is best known for two bizarre comedies about severely dysfunctional families - Spanking the Monkey and Flirting With Disaster . He has now entered the Hollywood mainstream with a big-budget war movie, Three Kings , the title of which alludes, with heavy irony, to the Magi.

In the film, there are four kings, not three. They're in the Orient but not of it. They come not to worship a Saviour but as people taught to think of themselves as saviours. And they are not bearing gifts but seeking loot, specifically gold. Forget the frankincense and myrrh.

The movie begins in March l991. Operation Desert Storm has been a triumph, the Iraqi army has collapsed and the virtually unscathed American troops are dancing to rock music in the desert, celebrating their easy victory. The landscape after the battle has a harsh, burnt-out look. It is an ugly spectacle, the kind that breeds easy cynicism. Saddam is still in power; President Bush has encouraged Iraqi dissidents to rebel but then provided no assistance; a feudal regime has been restored in Kuwait.

Two American infantrymen - the decently patriotic Sergeant Troy Barlow (Mark Wahlberg) and the dim red neck Private Conrad Vig (Spike Jonze) - discover a map concealed in the rectum of a prisoner-of-war they're searching. It apparently shows the secret bunker where the stolen Kuwaiti bullion is stashed.

An experienced Special Forces officer, Major Archie Gates (George Clooney), gets wind of the discovery and takes over. Sniffing the map he remarks: 'You're on the path of truth when you smell shit.' With two months to go before retirement, the disaffected Gates decides to get hold of a multi-million-dollar nest egg and has little trouble persuading Barlow, Vig and their comrade, Staff Sergeant Elgin (Ice Cube), a born-again Christian, to join him. All he needs to ask them is - do you want to go back to your old jobs in civvy street?

Traditionally in dramatic literature, piles of gold and other assorted treasure belong to whoever gets their hands on it, and what follows is, on the face of it, a slap-up action movie along the lines of the 1970 Clint Eastwood yarn Kelly's Heroes , in which a party of military mavericks take time off in the last days of the Second World War to grab some hidden Nazi gold.

But Russell has additional things in mind. He wants to show the madness of modern warfare in general and the horrors of the Gulf War in particular, and to expose the indifference of American soldiers and statesmen towards the people they profess to assist. At the same time, his quartet are close kin to Peckinpah's Wild Bunch: they are honest outlaws with an unswerving loyalty to each other, a deep distrust of those in power on either side, and a developing concern for the innocent victims of war and civil strife.

From this emerges, first, a proper understanding of what sacrifice means, and second, the conditions for redemption. Russell's characters grow in the course of the film, and behind the blood, dirt and stubble, the four leading actors register their moral development.

Though we see women soldiers in the background early on, none is given a line of dialogue, and the only two women prominently on view are a pair of foolish TV reporters who put career advancement before all else.

Three Kings is not always convincing and the ending is a trifle pat and not entirely plausible. But it is punctuated by fascinating, often surreal detail and full of disturbing incidents and encounters. As the quartet set off on their expedition, they throw coloured American footballs into the air like clay pigeons for target practice.

A cow steps on a mine in front of them, covering them in its blood, creating the terrifying impression among Iraqi troops and civilians they run into that they've come straight from a massacre. The Iraqi soldiers are initially too busy killing their own people to bother about the marauding Yanks, and there is an extraordinary scene in which a vast milk tanker is hit by a rocket and jackknifes, flooding the centre of a starving village with thousands of gallons of milk.

When the Iraqis attack Gates and his crew with CS gas, they're saved by a group of peasants who emerge in gas masks from underground caves looking like a tribe of troglodytes from Star Wars . Sergeant Barlow, however, is captured by Saddam's National Guard, finds a sack of mobile phones in his cell and calls his wife back in Detroit. Barlow is interrogated and tortured, and his surprisingly sympathetic inquisitor talks of his maimed wife and dead son, killed in air raids on Baghdad, and wants Barlow to agree that the racist American government forced Michael Jackson to turn white.

Undoubtedly, the film's most memorable image is a close-up of what a bullet does to a man's intestines This is initially to illustrate the battle-hardened Major Gates's vivid talk of warfare to his three inexperienced comrades. It's repeated later on when Barlow gets hit and we first see a picture of his churning guts and then another of the internal wound responding to morphine. I have never seen anything quite like it before.

Such things have, one suspects, been carefully reserved for the Army Medical Corps.
