fields.headline: Nigel Slater's milanese recipes
fields.standfirst: Milanese food is simple, straightforward and surprisingly redolent of British comfort cooking
fields.trailText: Milanese food is simple, straightforward and surprisingly redolent of British comfort cooking
fields.body:
The backbone of my daily eating remains unshakably Italian. This is hardly surprising when you realise that so many of my local food shops are, or were, Italian owned. Give me 10 minutes and I could bring you anything from a fine-grained salami Milano to silken spinach tortelloni. Yet it would take me an hour or more to come up with a black pudding or an Eccles cake worth eating, and even that would have to come from the nearest Marks & Spencer. But there is more to eating all' Italiana than the appeal of shopping locally. I like the simplicity of Italian cooking, its straightforwardness of preparation and, above all, its understated elegance on the plate.

If I was pressed a little further, I would have to admit to a love of northern Italian cooking, with its abundance of butter, cheese, rice and cream. I suppose its meat and dairy produce cannot help but appear closer to our own cooking than the sun-drenched olive oil, fish and vegetable-dominated diet of the south. Perhaps there is some familiarity in its bland heartiness. One could even argue that the nannying quality of a saffron-hued risotto alla Milanese is not a stone's throw from our own beloved rice pudding.

Forgetting the old Italian addiction to veal and frogs (whose little green heads they chop off before frying the rest whole), the cooking of Milan and its environs is my sort of food, by which I mean I feel comfortable with it. Its nurturing bean soups, blissful pork and cabbage stews and oozing, blue-veined Gorgonzola appeal every bit as much as any sun-dried tomato. Most of all, it is the silky risotti that ring my bell and, what's more, I like making them as much as eating them. Few kitchen-related jobs give me more pleasure than stirring a risotto, though I admit that for years I avoided it, obviously having spent too long listening to those scaremongers who insisted there was something difficult about it. There is not. You just need the right rice - which you can get at any supermarket - and some full-bodied stock.

I have not eaten the eponymous risotto alla Milanese, with its flecking of saffron and knobs of beef marrow, on its home ground, but further north, in Bergamo - a creamy, almost pumpkin-coloured plateful of round rice held together with stock and cheese. One of the few occasions I get excited about saffron is when it is used with rice - in pilau, perhaps - or in fish soup, otherwise its musty flavour can too easily dominate. However, the golden crocus threads are essential to a true Milanese risotto. The beef marrow, on the other hand, is much less essential, I think. Yes, it adds a certain richness, but I am not sure I miss it when I don't include it - which, I should add, is every time. At the risk of evoking (yet again) the wrath of every purist, I use home-made chicken stock in my risotto instead of the statutory brodo di carne with its trio of beef, veal and chicken bones. The unctuousness you give to the dish by using veal stock can be obtained instead with a really good chicken version made from a fat-boned free ranger. On the other hand, I have to disagree with those who say that stock from a cube is fine for a risotto - it isn't. The whole point of the dish is the texture you get by using the right rice - Carnaroli, Arborio or Vialone nano - and good stock. The magic only happens when the chalky starch of the rice is swelled by jelly-rich stock. You just don't get that with a cube. And no, you cannot make it in the oven, no matter who tells you that you can.

Risotto is not the only Milanese recipe that crops up in my kitchen. It is simply that it crops up more often than any other. Their way of cooking veal - lightly egged and finely crumbed, then fried briefly in butter till crisp and juicy - is just as interesting when applied to similar cuts of other meat. I have done it with pork, batting out the chop with the end of a rolling pin (for want of a cutlet bat) so that it is no thicker than a pinkie. The clever bit comes when you coat it in beaten egg and crumbs - you need a light hand with both - and fry it in butter gently so it does not burn. A splendid dish if done well.

Classical Milanese cooking also includes polpette, the little meatballs which they flavour with ricotta and Parmesan and which I find all too easy to eat, and osso bucco, that famous braise of veal with onion and white wine, which I don't, despite its coming to the table with a mouth-popping dusting of lemon, garlic and parsley.

On a sweet note, I must say I prefer my puddings â l'anglaise or even French, but I do have a soft spot for panettone, the soft, vanilla-scented fruitcake you see hanging from the ceiling of every deli around Milan's via Spadari - not to mention every deli from Glasgow to Penzance. A while ago, this buttery cake was just for Christmas; now you can get it all year round. I slice and toast it, then pour over a spoonful or two of Italian mascarpone stirred through with some softly whipped double cream just to make it, and me, feel at home.

Risotto alla Milanese
Use beef marrow if you can get it, but I must say Italian friends of mine claim that they happily use a few cubes of pancetta instead, though this is somewhat inauthentic. Serves 2

1 shallot or small onion, finely chopped
75g butter
50g pancetta, finely chopped
900ml stock (beef or chicken)
225g risotto rice
1 glass of white wine
1 tsp saffron strands
50g freshly grated Parmesan

Let the shallot cook slowly with half the butter and the chopped pancetta in a heavy-bottomed saucepan until it is translucent. Try not to let it colour. Meanwhile, put the stock into another saucepan and bring to the boil, turning it down to a virtually imperceptible simmer. Stir the rice into the onions, then pour in the wine and let it almost evaporate before adding a ladleful of stock. Sprinkle in the saffron threads and continue gently simmering until the stock starts to disappear, then ladle in more stock. As the stock is absorbed by the rice, you will see it swell and turn a beautiful, pale gold.

Continue adding stock until the rice is thick and creamy but still has some bite left in it. This should take about 20 minutes, depending on the rice you choose. The texture you are after is one where the rice grains are still separate but bound together by a general creaminess. If it appears soft and mushy, then you have overcooked it. Season with salt, pepper and the rest of butter, stirring in the Parmesan as you bring it to the table. You can offer more if you wish.

Risotto with Gorgonzola
I sometimes wonder whether it is Gorgonzola rather than risotto that is the best thing to come out of Lombardy. Here, you get the chance to enjoy both. Serves 2

900ml (maybe a little more) home-made chicken stock
1 small onion or shallot, finely chopped
50g butter
250g risotto rice
1 glass of white wine

to finish
1 walnut-sized lump of butter
250g creamy Gorgonzola

Gently heat the stock in a saucepan. Cook the onion in the butter in a heavy-bottomed saucepan. When the onion is pale gold and soft, add the rice and stir through the butter. Pour in the wine, let it evaporate, then add about a third of the hot stock and cook gently, until the rice has absorbed almost all of the stock. Add a second third of the stock, cook slowly (again stirring regularly), then the final third. By the time almost all the stock is absorbed, the grains should be soft and plump yet with a little chalky bite to them. The total cooking time for the rice will be about 20 minutes.

Stir in the knob of butter and the blue cheese, crumbled into small lumps. Taste and season with salt and black pepper. Serve as the cheese starts to melt.

Toasted panettone with mascarpone cream
I have used panettone, the light, buttery Milanese cake, for everything from trifle to bread-and-butter pudding, but I prefer it simply toasted and served with cream cheese. I find mascarpone too rich to serve alone, so let it down with some softly whipped cream. You could add some grated dark chocolate, or a little orange zest. Enough for 6

1 small panettone
250g tub of mascarpone
150ml whipping cream

Slice the panettone and toast it lightly on both sides. Meanwhile, whip the cream until it will stand in soft waves, then carefully fold it into the mascarpone. Serve the toasted panettone with the mascarpone cream.

fields.headline: The X-factor
fields.trailText: Is it possible the Dome netted the wrong M. Gerbeau(x)? One ex-Disneyland director is Jean-Marie Gerbeaux, 52-year-old corporate high-flier who now runs the French railways. Another is Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, a charming 34-year-old Mr Fixit whose beacon triumphs at the French theme park were sorting out ticketing and parking. The New Millennium Experience Company hired the second.
fields.body:
Is it possible the Dome netted the wrong M. Gerbeau(x)? One ex-Disneyland director is Jean-Marie Gerbeaux, 52-year-old corporate high-flier who now runs the French railways. Another is Pierre-Yves Gerbeau, a charming 34-year-old Mr Fixit whose beacon triumphs at the French theme park were sorting out ticketing and parking. The New Millennium Experience Company hired the second.

Such things happen. Roy Plomley once invited popular novelist Alistair MacLean to the Garrick to discuss appearing on Desert Island Discs . The men were deep into pre-recording details before Plomley realised that this MacLean was actually something big in the Forestry Commission. Winston Churchill found himself similarly trapped in conversation with the wrong Mr Berlin. A great admirer of philosopher Isaiah Berlin, who had filed dispatches from Washington throughout the Second World War, Churchill called him in to discuss Anglo-American relations. Songwriter Irving Berlin, whose thoughts on the matter were probably exhausted in the writing of 'God Bless America', must have been puzzled by the conversation. Then there is Evelyn Waugh's fictional reporter in Scoop. William Boot, the writer on rural matters for the Daily Beast , is mistaken for a similarly named hotshot correspondent and sent with calamitous consequences to cover an African war.

Did Plomley throw Mr MacLean off the show when he realised his error? Did Churchill leave Irving Berlin tapping his feet? Did Boot refuse to board the plane? Certainly not. M. Gerbeau has charmed us with his 'I can't believe I'm really here' urchin grin. We should wish him the very best of luck and remain as silent as the 'x' in his compatriot's name.

fields.headline: Many happy returns
fields.standfirst: There's more to spring perrenials than snowdrop and forget-me-nots, although they're a good place to start
fields.trailText: There's more to spring perrenials than snowdrop and forget-me-nots, although they're a good place to start
fields.body:
Our garden here is appallingly situated in relationship to the house, with the house stuck in one corner like an afterthought - except that someone thought it at least 700 years before I had the notion of the garden. It was built in an age when gardens were small and enclosed and primarily utilitarian, and the setting of the building was in a context where the river, tracks, parish boundaries, and the initial impression as you approached it, mattered far more than the inward relationship with the garden. Nowadays, though, gardens are a private landscape, to screen off the rest of the world as much as to stop it peering at us.

Outside our back door is a small brick yard with the garden swinging into a dog leg much longer than the dog. But there is room for a slither of a garden beyond the door. It is not quite 30 yards long, tapering away from 10 yards wide at the bricked end, to two. At this time of year, it invites you across the yard with a glimpse of snowdrops, hellebores, catkins and crocuses.

By June, this light, airy funnel becomes a green tunnel, the almost permanent shade spangled with light, as the wind shifts the branches like the twitch of lace curtains. Spring is its season. The snowdrops have done their bit (and a good bit it was, too), although I feel snowdrop-greedy and want them to mass right over the wider top half. The hellebores are fantastic, without question the stars of the garden at this time of the year, although I can not seem to grow Helleborus foetidus with the degree of success that I would like.

The first of the perennials to flower are the lungworts. We only have two types: there is the Pulmonaria officinalis 'Sissinghurst White', which has icy little flowers and leaves which look as though someone has spattered milk over them and it has dried, leaving a faded stain (lungwort is sometimes known as 'Mary-spilt-the-milk'). Leaves and stem are both covered in tiny hairs, soft as rabbits' ears with the grain, and as bristly as a pig's ear against it. We also have Pulmonaria angustifolia, which has violet flowers growing out of chocolate calyxes that look remarkably like dried seed heads until this very un-dried-up flower emerges.

Lungwort is so-called because the blotches on the leaves were seen to be a sympathetic indication of diseased lungs, and the name pulmonaria derives from the Latin pulmo, for lung. I have no memory of buying these plants, although it is worth hunting out good varieties. P angustifolia subspecies azurea, P longifolia (which is a rare native of the Isle of Wight and the New Forest), P saccharata 'Boughton Blue' and P 'Lewis Palmer' are all a rich violet-blue, although pulmonarias often start pink, turning bluer as they develop. I don't like the truly pink, almost apricot pulmonarias, but purely for prejudicial reasons. P rubra is a soft red, as are 'Margery Fish' and 'Leopard', and I am sure that they are much loved in their various homes. They grow best in cool shade and are ideally suited to a patch at the base of deciduous shrubs. They need splitting every two or three years, both to propagate new plants and to reinvigorate the old. They have a habit of growing vigorously outwards while dying back in the centre, forming a hollow ring which will promptly fill with weeds.

Another famously blue flower in the season of yellows is Corydalis flexuosa. This is one of my favourites, both for the incredible china blue of its flowers and its glaucous leaves that have a trembling fragility, yet it is a common enough plant and not difficult to grow. It is a close relation of the poppy and dicentra and also the common fumitory. Its blue flowers will retain a freshness and intensity of colour if they are grown in cool shade, which suits the plant anyway. C flexuosa only came from China in 1989, though it seems to have been around for ever. Although it likes moisture, it also needs good drainage but does not want to be too dry. Cool woodland is ideal and any border with shrubby deciduous plants and soil rich in organic matter qualifies perfectly. A hot summer will trigger a period of dormancy, so give it maximum shade to keep it flowering. There are a number of strains you can buy, such as 'China Blue', 'Blue Panda' and 'Pere David', which has bronzish leaves.

The yellow-flowering Corydalis lutea has effectively naturalised itself through its ability to grow happily on seemingly bare limestone walls. We have one behind a drain that seems very settled and happy there. Corydalis ochroleuca has creamy flowers tipped with yellow and has the same unfussy spreading habits as flexuosa but is less bullish about its occupancy so should be encouraged wherever it pops up. I don't grow it, but this has prompted me to put it on my list of must-haves.

Dicentras have similar leaves to corydalis and the best known varieties also come from China. This is bleeding heart. Dicentra spectabilis has little pink, heart-shaped flowers hanging in a neat row from its arching stem. The white version, D spectabilis 'Alba', is good and contrasts better with the glaucous leaves. Like the corydalis, dicentra is an essentially spring plant and I cannot imagine the season without it. I find that in our little spring garden it fulfils this almost celebratory, ritual function without any need for elaboration, but D formosa has a number of cultivars, with flowers working on variations of pink.

Despite pulling it up almost as fast as it spreads, our forget-me-nots (Myosotis sylvatica) were already flowering sporadically in early February. By April, they will be a misty blue haze shimmering above soil-level. It is technically a perennial but is effectively a biennial and seeds itself so prolifically that it should be treated as such. The major problem with forget-me-nots is the white powdery mildew that they often get from midsummer on. This is entirely due to drought, and if they are kept cool and moist it will not appear.

And seeding almost equally freely, albeit in a less rumbustious manner, are the aquilegias, whose tight rosettes of leaf are appearing everywhere. Their time is a month or two off, but when they are out, this spring garden is at its peak, which is wonderful but also tinged with sadness, as from there it slips into a midsummer green dotage. There are lots of other things to flower between now and then and lots of things left to write about another day, but just as I invariably find when I am planting in this sliver of garden, I have run out of space.

fields.headline: National anthem faces red card
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: It is English sport's greatest ritual. The white shirts line up, chests puff out and a military band strikes up the tune that will inspire the team to victory. Players and fans unite in belting out 'God Save The Queen' at the top of their voices.
fields.body:
It is English sport's greatest ritual. The white shirts line up, chests puff out and a military band strikes up the tune that will inspire the team to victory. Players and fans unite in belting out 'God Save The Queen' at the top of their voices.

But Her Majesty will not be amused to learn that the masses have launched protests against the national anthem being used as the official song for England's rugby and football teams. The Prime Minister has been deluged with letters from people demanding a new anthem.

Hundreds of citizens have written to Tony Blair from every part of Britain urging that 'God Save The Queen' is replaced by a 'more appropriate' tune. 'Their general opin ion is "England, get your own national anthem; 'God Save The Queen' is a British song",' explained a Downing Street insider.

'The protests haven't just come from nationalist Scottish and Welsh types. Quite a few are from people in England who also think the national teams should have a new, distinctively English anthem.'

Growing disenchantment with the monarchy, devolution of power to Edinburgh and Cardiff and increased national pride in Scotland and Wales have raised questions about why one part of Britain has 'appropriated' a song which is meant to signify British national unity and pride. 'Jerusalem', William Blake's evocation of 'England's green and pleasant land', is the most popular alternative.

The tide of correspondence began during last autumn's Rugby World Cup, got into full swing during the two England v Scotland Euro 2000 football play-offs in November and has intensified during the current Six Nations rugby tournament.

Blair has deliberately avoided getting embroiled in the controversy by insisting that it is a matter for the Football Association and Rugby Football Union to decide. Both governing bodies admit opinion is divided even within their sports about whether the national anthem is the most fitting song for their teams. The FA said: 'We do get calls from punters sometimes asking us to switch, with "Land of Hope and Glory" the alternative usually mentioned. We're sticking with "God Save The Queen" because the English recognise it as our national anthem.'

If change comes, however, the FA is unlikely to start using 'Land of Hope and Glory' or 'Rule Britannia' as both are associated with far-right racist elements among the England faithful.

The RFU said: 'People have been suggesting abandoning the national anthem on and off for years, mainly because Scotland and Wales have got their own respective anthems.' Uncertainty about whether 'God Save The Queen' was out-of-date prompted the RFU to poll its 2,100 member clubs last year asking if they wanted a new tune - few did.

Singer-songwriter and football fan Billy Bragg is among those who wants England to find a new song. 'It's totally incongruous England using "God Save The Queen". When we played Scotland recently, the Scots sang "Flower of Scotland", which is really powerful and has an obvious effect. We should have something like that. It's so flat that we look stupid singing it.'

Scots rugby legend Scott Hastings, capped 65 times by his country, said the national anthem was a time-honoured part of rugby's home internationals but added: 'It is a bit odd for England to still be using a British song. If they change, I'd go for "Jerusalem". It's a great song - and it's English.'

However, Sir Geoff Hurst - who scored a hat-trick for England when they beat Germany 4-2 in the 1966 World Cup Final - urged the FA not to break with decades of tradition. 'I'm definitely in favour of the national anthem, it's an integral part of representing your country,' he said. 'I'm extremely proud when it is played. It's very important. There's no reason to change it and replace it with anything else.'

fields.headline: Cash webwatch
fields.standfirst: Websites to help you manage your money
fields.trailText: Wanting to buy or sell your home throught the Internet? A new online domestic property service, www.easier.co.uk, allows you to advertise your home for free on the Internet. Following the Government's announcement last month that it will allow property contracts to be agreed electronically, easier.co.uk will develop the site with the Society of Licensed Conveyancers 'to allow clients to track their conveyancing transaction' on the Internet.
fields.body:
Wanting to buy or sell your home throught the Internet? A new online domestic property service, www.easier.co.uk, allows you to advertise your home for free on the Internet. Following the Government's announcement last month that it will allow property contracts to be agreed electronically, easier.co.uk will develop the site with the Society of Licensed Conveyancers 'to allow clients to track their conveyancing transaction' on the Internet.

You can already use the Net to buy Individual Savings Accounts because they do not need a handwritten signature. Legal & General has a special offer on Isas bought from its site, www.landg.com. Buy before 30 April and escape the annual management charge, if you hold the Isa until the end of the year.

People who pick their own Isas are offered an execution-only service with commission rebated by broker Berkeley Morgan on www.isaweb.co.uk. This firm is registered with the regulator, the Financial Services Authority, but others may not be. You can check by accessing the FSA and looking up the 'central register'.

For stock market investors wanting to find out about new share issues and flotations, www.shareissues.com offers details. You have to register first, however, either for a weekly email bulletin of future offers, or for a scheme which will give your details to stockbrokers who will contact you directly.

Professionals wanting part-time, contract or freelance assignments can visit www.swiftwork.com. You register your CV online and record a short audio version. Employers inspect them and pay a fee if they follow them up.

fields.headline: 17p to save a child's life
fields.standfirst:
Richard Attenborough , goodwill ambassador for Unicef, appeals for help for the stricken children

Mozambique floods: special report

Disaster Relief - MOD site

Disasters Emergency Committee - Mozambique Floods Appeal
fields.trailText: Richard Attenborough , goodwill ambassador for Unicef, appeals for help for the stricken children
fields.body:
The heartrendering images we have seen on television this past week, depicting the people of Mozambique as they struggle to survive monstrous cyclones and then widespread flooding, have upset me profoundly - as I'm sure they have readers of The Observer .

What we are witnessing is a double tragedy in which the immediate desperation of 900,000 men, women and children, some still dangerously stranded and most without food or shelter, will inevitably be compounded by the long-term effects of such utter devastation. Before disaster struck, Mozambique had worked tremendously hard - and successfully - to get back on its feet after more than a decade of civil war. Once the floodwaters recede, the work will have to start all over again.

From the safety of our own homes we have watched entire villages being washed away in muddy torrents and parents on rooftops scrambling to pass their precious children into the hands of helicopter crews. Thankfully, further help is already at hand through the work of the United Nations Children's Fund.

As a grandfather of seven, when I became one of Unicef's Goodwill Ambassadors in 1987 it was children such as these that I most wanted to help. So when I realised the sheer scale of the Mozambique tragedy last week I phoned Unicef's Ian MacLeod, whom I first met on a field trip to South Africa.

Ian's words go to the heart of the matter: 'Most of these people were already desperately poor, struggling to grow enough food for their families on small farms. And now they have lost everything. Whole communities have been swept away and the lives of survivors have been shattered.'

But there is more. Even before the flooding, one-third of Mozambique's children were chronically undernourished and malaria was the country's biggest killer. As I write, many of these same children - vulnerable at the best of times - are without any form of shelter and surviving on little or no food.

It is, of course, the children who are most affected by such catastrophes. At least 180,000 young children are now homeless and, while our own children and grandchildren are safely back at school after the half-term break, the children of Mozambique have no idea when, if ever, they will go to school again.

Before the floods at least half of Mozambique's children were being educated - a triumphant statistic for such a poor country - but, with many mud classrooms now swept away it may take years before it can be attained again.

The nature of the double tragedy that has hit this brave and resilient country is, of course, water. The floods have wiped out safe drinking supplies, and children now find themselves surrounded by water that is contaminated with sewage, cattle carcasses and the bodies of their former neighbours. Brutally, the diseases it bears - cholera, dysentery, diarrhoea - are all child-killers. And yet there is hope. If only we who are touched by this tragedy from afar are willing to reach out to the children of Mozambique, Unicef can help them, both now and in the future.

Right now Unicef is chlorinating water, making it safe to drink. At a cost of only 17p, it can provide the oral rehydration salts that will save a child from fatal diarrhoea. For far less than most of us would spend on any 'treat ', children can be immunised against other killer diseases, such as measles and meningitis. Just £25 will make sure that 250 of them do not die from malaria.

When I see such tragic images on television and learn the human stories behind them, I cannot but be grateful that my own children and grandchildren will never have to face such a devastating catastrophe.

I am sure I am not alone in this and that there are millions of caring people throughout the UK who feel as I do. I do hope that those among them who read The Observer will join with me in giving whatever they can to help the children of Mozambique in their hour of greatest need.

fields.headline: Relief ? No, just another disaster
fields.standfirst:
As an African nation cries out to the world, British helicopters lie in parts, their crews lie in the sun and political infighting paralyses Westminster

Mozambique floods: special report

Disaster Relief - MOD site

Disasters Emergency Committee - Mozambique Floods Appeal
fields.trailText: As an African nation cries out to the world, British helicopters lie in parts, their crews lie in the sun and political infighting paralyses Westminster
fields.byline: Special report by Chris McGreal and Burhan Wazir in Maputo and Patrick Wintour in London
fields.body:
When the rains came, the people fled and the world watched. It saw thousands trapped in trees, on roofs and on collapsing bridges. They died and they gave birth. But yesterday, eight days after a tragedy of biblical proportions swept across the villages and towns of Mozambique, the controversial British military relief effort to a country sinking under water was still nowhere to be seen.

Four RAF British Puma helicopters that have been at the centre of a coruscating political row between the Ministry of Defence and the Department for International Development are still in pieces at an airbase in South Africa - unable to fly until tomorrow at the earliest.

The ground crew for the Pumas - who arrived in an advance party at South Africa's Hoedspruit airforce base, set in the rolling tropical bush at the edge of the Kruger national park, have been pictured relaxing in the sun and reading.

Yesterday, the only British soldiers in Maputo, capital of a country whose economy and infrastructure have in one week been set back a generation, were slowly unpacking their satellite phones in the office of the British High Commission.

And what they will be doing now that the flood waters are beginning to clear - for the time being, at least - is not entirely clear. They were sent out to join the search-and-rescue missions scouring the country but yesterday the search-and-rescue phase was declared all but over, finished before the British pilots could join in.

Meanwhile the officer in charge of the British forward party, Colonel Jonathan Downes, admitted he had no experience of disaster relief. Instead he described his background in logistics in Germany and the UK - not in search-and-rescue.

And Downes had a further confession to offer. The Pumas - when they finally arrive - may be able to offer some assistance, but not where it is most needed in the country's north. The helicopters, he admitted, lacked even the range of the South African Orexs, whose aircrew have spent a week valiantly plucking stranded villagers from trees and rooftops.

How did it all go so wrong? In less than a week - the time it has taken the rains to obliterate a large part of an African country - what should have been good reason to celebrate Britain's swift commitment to the relief effort in Mozambique has been submerged in accusations of incompetence and marred by political rows between International Development Secretary Clare Short and her old enemy from her Birmingham days, the Defence Minister John Spellar.

For despite the best efforts of the Department for International Development (DfID) - which had been labouring almost alone in Mozambique since the first flood warnings came early in January until disaster hit late last Saturday night - the British effort has become mired in public recriminations.

In Downing Street yesterday the frustration was palpable, not only that the relief programme was proving so slow to reach the victims of disaster but that Britain's role at the forefront of the relief effort was being undermined by the tit-for-tat briefing war between the MoD and DfID.

At the centre of the row has been the willingness of the MoD to make its helicopters available to DfID - and at what price.

'Instead of getting credit for being there first with 11 of the 14 helicopters in the region,' said one Downing Street source, 'we are now embroiled in a row like this.'

To the frustration of the Prime Minister, the row over Mozambique has been tainted by other personal and departmental animosities. Bad blood has been raised in recent months between the two departments over arms exports. Privately, MoD officials blame DfID for leaking juicy details of Whitehall battles over MoD's willingness to sponsor arms sales to Indonesia and Zimbabwe.

The personal element has been equally destructive. The pipe-smoking Defence Minister John Spellar, a former right-hand man of the vehemently anti-communist electricians union leader, Frank Chapple, has little in common with Short, a free spirit from the Left with a history of unilateralism.

Their swords first crossed in the murky world of Birmingham Labour politics prior to the 1992 general election, when Short accused the electricians of using their block votes to mount a deselection challenge in her Birmingham Ladywood seat. Spellar, MP for Birmingham Northfield, has boasted in private about his union's role.

The first sign that problems existed between the two departments - problems that would lead to the tardy deployment of the British helicopters - emerged last Monday in the Commons as the full enormity of the disaster in Mozambique was made clear by the British media.

In the House to give a statement on the crisis, Short had outlined the already considerable work her department had undertaken in the previous weeks, including the hiring of helicopters for the World Food Programme, using British money.

But the first indication of the trouble ahead came as Spellar interrupted her when she reported that the MoD had said it had no resources within 3,000 miles and therefore could not help directly - a claim that Short has stuck to resolutely.

But even as Short and Spel lar were sparring over availability of helicopters for Mozambique, and how long it would take to get them there - a second damaging issue had arisen: how much the MoD was asking for the use of its aircraft.

By Tuesday the MoD - which had by now found four Pumas and five Seakings on a Royal Fleet Auxiliary in the Indian Ocean - was saying it wanted to charge £2.2 million, to be reimbursed by the DfID, for the use and transfer of the Pumas.

This price, the MoD would claim later, included the cost of the charter of a Russian Antonov transporter to fly them to Africa.

What happened next is at the centre of the controversy. The MoD claims it asked the Treasury if it could charge DfID just the 'marginal' cost of sending the helicopters, but was denied - a claim disputed by the Treasury, which says it was always happy for the MoD to incur the full cost.

Either way, an angry Short argued that the cost was excessive and that she would look for cheaper helicopters that were more quickly deployable.

But as Short explained this to the Commons, she was not aware - or did not say - that the MoD had gone ahead and hired an Antonov to take the helicopters to South Africa.

The next chapter in the saga appears to have been the final straw. For even as the MoD was arranging to get its aircraft to Mozambique and offering to discount the price its officials began briefing vigorously against Short, claiming that it was she, not the MoD, that was ultimately responsible for the delay.

By now Short's officials were warning Downing Street that she had had enough and was likely to express her frustration, which she duly did on Thursday morning, exposing the embarrassing division to a startled British public which had been digging deep in its pockets to help the victims of the floods.

Yesterday the rescue helicopters - the British ones excepted - continued to search for survivors, but now they have to journey further afield to remote locations. As many as a million have been displaced from their homes and it is anyone's guess how many are still stranded.

'There are still parts of the country that are badly covered by the helicopters,' says Roy Trivedi, a regional representative of Save The Children.

More than a third of the country, to the north, remains unexplored by rescue teams. Trivedi says: 'There is a logistical problem Helicopters have to refuel somewhere, and up there we don't yet have those facilities for them. So rescue teams are having to sit tight until extra help arrives.'

Criticism over the pace of the international community's response has already begun to emerge in Mozambique. Among the critics are foreign minister Leonardo Simao: 'The aid was slow to come. We had our first floods on 6 February. Our first appeal for international aid was on 10 February. Only now is aid coming in its visible form.

'If the response had been more quick, I believe that more lives could have been saved.'

The official death toll remains at just over 200 but there is little doubt that it really runs into the thousands. Simao said that landmines scattered during the country's brutal civil war that ended eight years ago have been dislodged and moved by the floods and will add to the threat from starvation and disease once the waters subside.

Mozambique President Joachim Chissano has also been vocal in his criticism of the speed of the Western response in recent days. Despite that, it is also clear that not a single Mozambican soldier has been deployed to rescue efforts in the flooded areas. Five of the country's military helicopters sit at one end of Maputo airport's runway. Four of them are said to be unserviceable.

Instead it has been helicopters from neighbouring South Africa that have provided the backbone of the rescue efforts. The crews have laboured tirelessly to pull people from the water, trees and roofs. The last time South African helicopters clattered across Mozambique in such numbers was during the apartheid era to attack African National Congress bases or to deliver supplies to Renamo rebels.

But the key to limiting the damage to Mozambique's economy will also be the rapid rebuilding of its infrastructure, particularly the roads and railways which provide vital trade links to its neighbours. Last year Mozambique produced its first food surplus since independence from Portugal 25 years ago.

Now it has lost about eight months worth of crops and President Chissano is pleading for relief from the $1.4m a week Mozambique pays to service its debt, and for tens of millions of pounds to rebuild.

Mozambique is often heralded as the great African success story. It has the fastest growing economy in the world. Maputo is transformed from a dormant, bureaucratic maze of a Marxist state into a vibrant, reborn African city. But the vast majority of Mozambique's 17 million people have yet to feel the benefits.

More than 70 per cent live in traditional huts in rural areas. According to last year's census, most do not have piped water, electricity or sanitation. Life expectancy is just 42 years.

Mozambique has an appalling infant mortality rate, although it is better than two decades ago. The average woman bears six children. Aids is rife. The literacy rate is just 40 per cent.

Up until now, the country's government was laying the economic ground to change all that. Whether the floods wreck these ambitious plans will depend on whether Western generosity is diverted once the waters subside and the television cameras leave Mozambique.

Already at least one offer is on the table - from Clare Short - who yesterday announced that the British Government would be giving Mozambique £70m over the next two years to help rebuild its infrastructure.

fields.headline: Britain gives £70m aid to Mozambique
fields.standfirst:
As flood victims count the cost, London helps reconstruction effort

Mozambique floods: special report

Disaster Relief - MOD site

Disasters Emergency Committee - Mozambique Floods Appeal
fields.trailText: As flood victims count the cost, London helps reconstruction effort
fields.byline: Peter Beaumont in London and Burhan Wazir in Maputo
fields.body:
Stung by the row over late deployment of RAF helicopters to help Mozambique flood victims, Britain yesterday announced aid of £70 million over the next two years to pay for the reconstruction of the devastated African state.

The announcement by International Development Secretary Clare Short of the extra cash, 30 per cent more than Mozambique would normally receive, came as four Puma helicopters remained standing at a South African air base as the rescue phase of the international aid effort was coming to an end.

British officers in Mozambique admitted to The Observer that the Pumas - which will not be ready for use in Mozambique until tomorrow at the earliest - lack the operating range to reach the north of the country where they are most needed. This comes at the end of an embarrassing week for Tony Blair, who was forced to watch as the MoD and Short's Department for International Development squabbed over who was responsible for the delays.

International efforts will now focus on the delivery of emergency supplies to an estimated 500,000 believed by the United Nations to be in urgent need of help. Announcing the £70m in emergency aid yesterday Short said: 'We need to plan now for the immediate reha bilitation and the longer term reconstruction efforts, which will require a massive, properly co-ordinated effort by the international community. When the waters subside we will need to help rebuild people's livelihoods. The UK has been in the lead in responding to the crisis.'

The Tories today called for a full public inquiry into claims that Government infighting delayed the deployment of rescue helicopters. A Downing Street spokesman said last night: 'Britain has moved more quickly than any other country to get emergency aid to Mozambique. DfID is now committing itself to funding a long term assistance programme to Mozambique.'

Shadow Foreign Secretary Francis Maude said: 'There has got to be a thorough and public inquiry. What seems to have gone on here is that precious days were lost when the key thing to try to help save lives - which was helicopters and physical support - was denied to Mozambique because of some silly scrap between two departments.

'There have been suggestions that this arose out of some petty, personal squabble between two Ministers. If that were the case it would be dreadful.'

He added that Prime Minister Tony Blair should have been 'knocking heads together' to sort out the problems, not getting his spin doctors working overtime in saying how wonderful Britain has been.

'There are few things more important than when a crisis comes up where people's lives are on the line and where minutes literally do matter,' he added.

'When you have got departments at war with each other and Ministers who can't talk to each other, then the Prime Minister has to deal with it.'

webTitle: Amazon's 1-Click may be neat but - patently - it's absurd

fields.headline: Amazon's 1-Click may be neat but - patently - it's absurd
fields.trailText: The Networker
fields.body:
Like many people in my line of business, I buy a lot of stuff from Amazon. It's by far the slickest, most efficient e-commerce operation on the Web. Unlike many of its competitors, it has cracked the 'fulfilment' problem - the tedious business of stuffing the goods into packets and getting them to my home in a stated period.

It is also one of the few e-commerce operations to understand that maintaining its website is a serious editorial job rather than a mere technical function.

Some time ago, the Amazon folks came up with an ingenious wheeze for harnessing 'cookies' - those tiny files that sites can deposit on your hard drive. Why not, they reasoned, use cookies to save customers the tedium of entering their personal details, credit card number and the like every time they make a purchase. So they crafted a system, christened 1-Click Ordering, which made this possible. If you've opted for this system, all you have to do after finding a book or a CD in the Amazon catalogue, is to click the button and the order is on its way.

Neat, eh? Too neat, as it happens, because 1-Click is very bad for one's financial health. It makes it too easy to buy stuff on impulse. Worse still, it makes it easy for your nearest and dearest to order books and records on your credit card - which is why many of us have learned to avoid 1-Click like the plague. In fact, it's so effective that one of Amazon.co.uk's own people told me she'd switched it off on her own machine because even her share options wouldn't cover the resulting bills.

Having conceived this excellent wheeze for parting intellectuals from their money, Amazon then did something naughty - it applied for a US patent on 1-Click. And, for some unfathomable reason, it got one, even though I cannot for the life of me see why. Where is the 'prior art' in 1-Click? It's merely a clever use of an established, open technology - the cookie protocol. Granting Amazon a patent on this wheeze is tantamount to granting a patent on a business process, like perhaps being able to patent going shopping on a Thursday afternoon in a yellow car.

Now the first law of intellectual property is that it has no value unless you defend it, and so when Barnes and Noble, the leading off-line bookseller in the US, decided to offer on their website a service similar to that provided by 1-Click, Amazon sued for infringement. B&N decided (rightly) to fight, and currently teams of m'learned friends on $600 an hour plus expenses are arguing among themselves.

As it turns out, Amazon was not the first company to exploit the idiocy of US patent law in this regard (though that's no excuse). It was simply following the path blazed by a guy named Jay Walker [sic], the founder of Priceline.com, who holds 18 patents on Internet business ideas and has about 250 more pending.

The implications of this crazy situation are alarming even to the brain-dead business community, which sees the Web as the new Klondyke. For if it's possible to patent a business process (rather than a genuine technology), commercial use of the Web will grind to a halt as lawyers slog it out over every new business idea.

And because the Web is global, the fact that it's US law that's defective is no consolation for Europeans. 'The time is fast approaching,' one leading UK lawyer said to me recently, 'when the first person every UK Internet start-up will have to hire is a US patent attorney.'

Meanwhile, another idiocy of filtering software has emerged. A reader reports that www.purenz.com the major New Zealand tourism site on the Web, is blocked by the software in use at his local public library.

Could this be anything to do with the fact that its outdoor activities section is labelled 'Thrill Zone'?

john.naughton@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: Four-letter word the US swears by
fields.standfirst:
Jamie Doward says CMGi has become a hit by mapping all routes to Net spending
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Jamie Doward says CMGi has become a hit by mapping all routes to Net spending
fields.body:
Try to remember this set of initials: CMGi. Few people in Europe have heard of the company, but it is perhaps the most talked about Internet business in the United States at the moment. Its reputation as an Internet investment vehicle is mercurial, a fact reflected in the jaw dropping pace at which its share price has headed upwards.

CMGi has been the best performing stock in the US over the last five years. If you had invested $100 in CMGi when it floated in 1994, you would now be sitting on a paper fortune of around $80,000 (£50,000). Today the company, which last year had a turnover of $500 million and has stakes in more than 60 Internet companies, is worth almost $40 billion. And soon it will be over here - over-financed and over-acquisitive - under its European head, a former manager of the rock band Genesis.

CMGi's stellar reputation is cited as one of the reasons why Richard Li, the new media entrepreneur and founder of 10-month-old Pacific Century Cyber Works, was this week able to initiate a merger with Cable & Wireless HKT, beating off the more established SingTel in the process (See opposite page). The fact that Li's business has an alliance with CMGi helped to convince C&W's chief executive, Graham Wallace, of the bid's credibility.

Last week CMGi cemented its relationship with Li when, in conjunction with US venture capital firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, it launched a $1.5bn global investment fund called @Ventures Global Partners.

CMGi likes to see itself as a hybrid, a venture capital firm that offers more of a 'hands on' incubator fund approach: an active adviser to its investments. 'Some companies like Softbank [the Internet venture capital firm] have portfolios of interests, others, like Microsoft, have a variety of companies which they manage. We have both,' said Marcus Bicknell, president of CMGi, Europe.

A cursory glance at the company's CV, however, might make more staid members of the investment community run for the hills. For a start, it began life as a direct marketing company.

Under the guidance of its chief executive officer, David Wetherell, the College Marketing Group initially concentrated on selling college course lists to textbook publishers.

By 1993, however, as the World Wide Web was taking off, Wetherell, a former software engineer, had realised how technology could help his business. His idea was to sell books through PCs. This required the creation of a Web browser whose construction immediately excited the interest of America Online. Wetherell sold the browser to AOL in return for shares in the online company.

Wetherell then focused the business on Internet technology companies. Lycos, the search engine in which CMGi has almost a 20 per cent stake, was one of his first investments. The fact that Lycos's share price plunged soon after CMGi took a stake alarmed Wetherell's co-directors and at one stage he nearly took the company private.

The company's investors, who saw the value of their shares rise by 870 per cent last year alone, will be glad that he didn't. Today CMGi (the name is derived from its Nasdaq ticket symbol) is capable of doing mega deals on the strength of its shares. The most high profile example of this came last year when it bought 83 per cent of the Alta Vista portal from computer giant Compaq for $2.3bn.

Wetherell's image as an Internet investment guru has earned him from Bicknell the epithet of 'the man who puts his money where his mouse is'.

And Wetherell's reputation as a decisive investor is matched by the speed at which he makes management decisions. Bicknell who, after managing Genesis between 1969 and 1971 went on to become European head of A&M Records, helped establish Star TV in the Far East and worked on the launch of BBC World, explains how Wetherell recruited him following a speech at a media industry event. 'He came up to me and said "When do you start?" I said "I've never heard of you". He said "Here's the salary, here are the stock options, this is what we do".'

CMGi's success on Wall Street has spawned imitators. Bicknell says CMGi's secret is that it views its investments holistically, not separately. Each acquisition is viewed in terms of how it would benefit or benefit from CMGi's existing portfolio of investments.

CMGi has made investments in companies across the Internet spectrum. It has stakes in businesses which specialise in content, infrastructure and e-commerce. Content draws the punters in, allowing CMGi to make money from them once they are on the Web. Bicknell describes the approach as pragmatic. 'Content doesn't make money. We give that away free. What makes money is advertising and e-commerce,' he said.

So, for example, a Web surfer could click into Alta Vista and then visit Thingworld.com, an online collectibles site (35 per cent owned by CMGi). From this site the surfer could then check out online jewellery seller Mondera.com, another CMGi investment. Ads on many of the sites visited will be sold by Adsmart. The effectiveness of the ads will be monitored by Adforce, which like Adsmart, is 90 per cent owned by CMGi.

Wherever the surfer goes CMGi lurks in the background, often suggesting services which are owned by... yes, you've guessed it. 'While the dot com companies are the public face, we're making money underneath. Every company in the group has three or four contracts with other companies in the group,' Bicknell said.

And while the user has been surfing its websites, CMGi has been learning about what he or she likes to visit, allowing it to build up a profile which can then be used to create bespoke advertising and services for individual users.

Of course, the problem is that a Web surfer might bypass Alta Vista altogether and thus become irrelevant to CMGi's virtuous circle business plan. No surprise, then, that Wetherell talks of turning the search engine into a 'megaportal', one which surfers would be compelled to visit. This also explains why a major marketing campaign promoting Alta Vista Europe is now underway.

Bicknell says that what CMGi is trying to do is really not that far removed from the company's original aims. 'The Internet is just an electronic extension of direct marketing, that's why he [Wetherell] wouldn't look to move into other areas that he doesn't understand.'

So far, Wetherell has shown just how much he does understand the Internet. But building CMGi's holistic world vision is predicated upon riding the Internet wave successfully. Most analysts predict there will be a shake out in the sector at some point. If this were to hit CMGi's share price, its ability to do deals would be hamstrung. Bicknell admits investors might be wary of pouring money in, considering CMGi's vertiginous share price. 'It's frightening in a way. Investors might think all the growth has happened already.'

But Bicknell argues that CMGi's approach to investment, both by owning or by taking minority stakes in companies, means that Wall Street appreciates it is worth more than the sum of its parts. Certainly when the Internet sector slumped 25 per cent between April and July last year, CMGi still managed to climb 10 per cent. Nevertheless, a slump in tech stocks would still send shockwaves through its share price. And if the market were to fall, CMGi would have further to fall than most.

fields.headline: Green belt sprawl halted
fields.standfirst:
VAT victory for Prescott as he stops urban spread
Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: VAT victory for Prescott as he stops urban spread
fields.body:
The erosion of Britain's countryside by sprawling new estates of executive-style housing will be halted under new planning restrictions unveiled this week.

The news broke as John Prescott, the Deputy Prime Minister, won his Budget battle to cut VAT on home renovations in an attempt to persuade people to remain in their city homes rather than move to new houses. In a landmark planning decision, likely to affect the future landscape of Britain well into the new century, Prescott will reveal the high-density planning rules as part of a package requiring the construction of 215,000 homes in the South-East over the next five years.

The size of the new building programme, likely to be concentrated at first along the Thames gateway, was condemned yesterday by Conservative Environment spokesman Damian Green as 'environmental vandalism'.

But the new planning guidance, applicable nationwide, is seen in Whitehall as marking a victory for the so-called 'crammers' who want to see more high-density building in existing towns and cities, including the architect Lord Rodgers, in their struggle against the 'sprawlers'.

It amounts to a rejection of Professor Stephen Crow's recommendation for 1.1 million new homes in the South-East between 1996 and 2016. Crow's scheme provoked accusations of desecration of the Home Counties from local councils, environmentalists and politicians.

Crow said the homes had to be built or else house prices would rise, transport would slow and business would flee to mainland Europe.

But Prescott will argue that developers must build to higher densities because 70 per cent of the demand will come from single people, most of them leaving London. He will issue new planning guidance requiring houses to be built closer together, with less space wasted on, for example, gravel driveways. Housing Minister Nick Raynsford said: 'We're not saying that they have all got to be pastiche Georgian terraces, nor that they have all got to be glass towers. We don't want them all done in one way, we want variety.'

The relentless demand for new housing in the booming South-East is coming not from migration from the North, but from the growth of one-person households, caused by a mixture of prosperity, longevity and family breakdown. For every 100,000 people who migrate southwards from the north of England, 95,000 go the other way.

Prescott will propose the construction of 215,000 houses over the next five years, implying, given current trends, more than 800,000 homes over the next 20 years. Ministerial sources said councils would have difficulty complaining about the plans since they would not require the release of more land than envisaged under their own proposals.

Changes to the VAT rating on renovations will be welcomed by environmentalists. They have long campaigned against the tax anomaly which encourages developers to build homes - which are zero-rated - rather than carry out renovations, which attract the full 17.5 per cent VAT. In Greater London alone there are 100,000 empty homes whose owners find it cheaper to pay the reduced council tax than make them habitable. Across England there are 790,000 empty homes, 667,000 of which are privately owned.

The ministerial sources said the new strategy would follow the Rogers agenda, including more 'imaginative' use of land.

webTitle: 'Heart tsar' leads blitz to cut deaths

fields.headline: 'Heart tsar' leads blitz to cut deaths
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: The government is to cut dramatically waiting times for heart surgery in a bid to end the appalling spectacle of patients dying while waiting for treatment.
fields.body:
The government is to cut dramatically waiting times for heart surgery in a bid to end the appalling spectacle of patients dying while waiting for treatment.

Last week, to the embarrassment of Ministers, a cardiologist from Bristol Royal Infirmary revealed that, over the previous six months, 10 of his patients were kept waiting for treatment so long that they died. Health Secretary Alan Milburn will unveil the new strategy tomorrow, cutting the maximum waiting time for bypass surgery from the present 18 months to three months.

The Government will also launch a register of millions of heart disease sufferers in a move which is expected to save up to 6,000 lives a year. All those on the register will be guaranteed the best available drugs wherever they live, ending the present postcode lottery of treatment. A network of more than 700 defibrillators - or heart shockers - is to be installed in public places, such as railway stations, to improve the chance of survival of those suffering cardiac arrest.

The announcements are part of a wide package of measures to tackle Britain's record on heart disease. The UK has a higher rate than almost any other developed country, with 140,000 people dying each year. Almost 1.5 million Britons suffer from angina, and 300,000 have heart attacks.

Milburn made tackling the two main killers - cancer and heart disease - his top priority within days of becoming Health Secretary last autumn. The new National Service Framework for Heart Disease will be overseen by a high-profile 'heart tsar', to be announced tomorrow.

Milburn said yesterday: 'We're launching a campaign against heart disease. We want to prevent it more effectively, diagnose it more rapidly, and treat it more urgently. Right across the country, but particularly in inner cities, heart disease is a big killer, but it is largely preventable.'

The Government hopes the measures will prove popular with its grassroots supporters, since the incidence of heart disease is far higher in Labour strongholds. They also tend to be areas where treatment is most backward. Heart disease is particularly prevalent among working-class men and ethnic minorities. People are almost twice as likely to die of it in both the north west of England and Scotland as in East Anglia.

Under the new strategy, doctors will have to put all patients with suspected or proven heart disease on a register, and then provide a minimum level of treatment for them. There has been wide concern that thousands of lives are being lost because treatment is patchy.

Patients on the register will be guaranteed regular check-ups and the best preventive medicine. The Dep- artment of Health estimates that by ensuring people get aspirin - which helps thin the blood - over 1,200 lives a year can be saved. Around 1,500 lives a year will be saved by ensuring that patients get beta-blockers, and another 3,000 lives a year from drugs known as statins.

The 700 defibrillators will be rolled out in the next month in rail and bus stations, airports, shopping centres and leisure centres.

Another plan is a new 'five a day' trial to encourage people to eat five portions of fruit or vegetables a day. The pilot - in five towns including Durham, Bradford and Sandwell - will involve schools, universities and councils. Estates with no access to fresh vegetables will be given mobile shops, and children will be taught how to cook with vegetables.

Imogen Sharpe, director of the National Heart Forum pressure group, welcomed the proposals: 'This is the first step in the long march to eliminate heart disease'.

 Email Anthony Browne at anthony.browne@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Sharif trial team quits over judge's 'gagging' order

fields.headline: Sharif trial team quits over judge's 'gagging' order
fields.standfirst: Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: Nawaz Sharif, the deposed Prime Minister of Pakistan, will appear before a Karachi court tomorrow on hijacking and terrorism charges without his top defence lawyer and is facing new accusations by the military regime of corruption.
fields.body:
Nawaz Sharif, the deposed Prime Minister of Pakistan, will appear before a Karachi court tomorrow on hijacking and terrorism charges without his top defence lawyer and is facing new accusations by the military regime of corruption.

Sharif's entire defence team quit in protest at the judge's handling of the case last week amid allegations that Pakistan's generals have been piling pressure on the judiciary for a favourable verdict.

On Friday, all Sharif's lawyers agreed to return to the trial, except Ijaz Batalvi, his leading counsel and one of the country's most senior lawyers.

'I will be present only on account of the insistence of my client,' said Khwaja Sultan, one of the defence team. 'Nawaz Sharif felt it would not be possible for anyone else to represent him.'

Now Sharif, who was over thrown in a military coup in October, is also facing two separate accusations of corruption at different courts. More investigations are expected to follow.

Sharif, 52, is accused of not paying tax on his purchase in 1993 of a $2 million Russian helicopter, which he used for electioneering.

He has also been ordered to appear before a court in Lahore to answer charges that in 1994 a family business, the Ittefaq foundry, defaulted on a loan from the state-run National Bank of Pakistan worth 729m rupees (£8.5m).

Two of his brothers, Shahbaz and Abbas, are also accused in the Ittefaq case.

Sharif has been held in detention for the past five months and was formally charged only in January, when his trial began at an anti-terrorism court in Karachi.

Sharif, Shahbaz and five former senior government officials have pleaded not guilty to charges of hijacking, kidnap ping, attempted murder and terrorism related to the night of the coup. They face the death penalty if convicted.

Hours before he was overthrown, Sharif sacked his army chief, General Pervez Musharraf, who was flying back into Pakistan after a trip abroad. Prosecutors claim Sharif ordered that the Pakistan International Airlines jet carrying the general should be refused permission to land, even though it was running low on fuel, thus endangering the lives of all 198 people on board.

Musharraf landed after troops seized Karachi airport and, within hours, he had taken over the country. Defence lawyers insist Sharif acted only after the army launched a coup.

Just before the defence was due to open its case, Judge Rehmat Hussain Jafri ruled that some of Sharif's evidence may not be released to the public on national security grounds. The defence team promptly quit, accusing the judge of censorship.

'The whole world for the last two months heard the prosecution malign and scandalise Sharif and now, when it was his turn to tell the truth, he has been asked to shut up,' Batalvi said. 'To say the least, this is not justice.'

His complaints were echoed by the New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists.

Lawyers on both sides expect the case to end this month. Sultan, now the leading defence counsel, insisted he was under no pressure from the generals.

'Throughout the trial there has never been any pressure from the military regime and I don't think the judge is under pressure,' he said. 'There is every chance of my client being acquitted.'

Although Sharif faces the death penalty, few observers here believe the military regime would carry out the sentence.

'Throughout the trial there has never been any pressure from the military regime and I don't think the judge is under pressure,' he said. 'There is every chance of my client being acquitted.' Although Sharif faces the death penalty, few observers here believe the military regime would carry out the sentence.

fields.headline: Brown's Budget balancing act
fields.trailText: In my view
fields.body:
I make no apology, as they say, for having gone on and on about the overvaluation of the pound. It is the single most important threat to the economy, to the success of Gordon Brown's chancellorship and to a satisfactory outcome of the Government's attempts to prepare the economy for membership of the European single currency.

In theory, one ought to be amazed at the way that, until very recently, the press and the body politic have tended to dismiss worries about the pound. But those who lived through the overvaluations of 1979-81 and 1990-92 will not have been surprised at all. Every time the competitiveness of British industry is threatened by an absurdly 'strong' pound, all sides argue that 'this time it is different'. How many times have you read recently that 'industry is adapting well' to it, or that 'exports are holding up well'.

Are they? The best guide to the trend of overseas trade is provided by the volume figures for 'total trade excluding oil and erratics'. 'Erratics' are items such as aircraft which are not exported or imported regularly, and which can seriously distort one month's figures. There was the famous episode in May 1970 when the import of two jumbo jets made the trend of the trade figures look a lot worse than it was - which was thought to have contributed to Labour's unexpected general election defeat that year.

The value of oil exports has obviously been boosted by the recent rise in the oil price. Stripping out these categories, one finds that in the last quarter of 1999, Britain's exports plunged at an annual rate of almost 10 per cent, while imports rose at an annual rate of nearly 11 per cent (both in volume terms). It is reassuring that the Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee has now fully got the message about the pound's overvaluation. Last Tuesday's MPC evidence to the Treasury Committee was dominated by the subject.

Some weeks earlier the Bank's Governor, Eddie George, had warned bankers: 'The most immediate challenges relate to the build-up of imbalances within and between the major industrial countries.

'The US and the UK are already operating close to overall capacity, with ultimately unsustainable growth of domestic demand offset by already sizeable external current account deficits.'

With due respect to New Labour, the importance of the US economy to the rest of the world far outweighs the importance of the UK. When currency traders finally panic about the extent to which the US is living on tick and not practising what it preaches to, say, East Asia, all hell will be let loose. But this week let us stick with the UK's little local imbalances. In his earlier speech George effectively said he could see no good underlying economic reason why capital was flowing into this country (thereby driving up the exchange rate). And it was clear at the Treasury committee session that the MPC is now Talking the Pound Down.

One reason for the combination of unsustainably rapid growth in domestic demand and a deteriorating overseas trade (and investment) situation lies with the all too successful U-turn by the MPC in the autumn and winter of 1998-99. That was when many feared we were to be plunged into the third recession in 20 years. The MPC not only began cutting interest rates aggressively; it also made no secret of the fact that, because the overseas trade picture was deteriorating, its job, under its remit from the Chancellor, was to stimulate domestic demand so that inflation did not fall below 2.5 per cent.

In the event, the output of the economy as a whole stagnated for a while, but did not fall. It is still a puzzle why there was such a rapid turnaround. We were always told that monetary policy worked with long and variable lags. But the lags experienced last winter and spring were very short indeed. We were also always told that economic policy is essentially about confidence - Keynes's 'animal spirits'. Between them the Chancellor and the MPC pulled off quite a confidence trick in averting recession and achieving rapid economic growth again.

Yes, the MPC stimulated domestic demand, and how! Down came interest rates, up went asset prices - at least in the South-east - and we have been experiencing something very close to the 'boom, boom, boom' psychology Brown is so anxious to avoid.

Which brings us to the great irony of the coming Budget. Here we are, with a Labour Chancellor being celebrated as more Gladstonian with the nation's finances than Gladstone himself, and an electorate that is crying out for more public spending. Now, there will be some public spending increases because, following the two-year spending freeze with which Labour began, that was planned to rise anyway.

But the idea that the Chancellor's large fiscal surpluses mean he will be able to spend a lot more does not, alas, quite fit in with the macro-economic reality, in which the MPC is actually trying to slow the economy down.

The ultimate irony is that this new Labour party that is so terrified of Rupert Murdoch, Conrad Black and the Daily Mail would have to raise taxes if it wanted a real public spending splurge.

What the MPC is watching is the fiscal balance. It has hinted of a pause in interest rate rises to try to dent sterling's strength. But if it thought the Chancellor was stimulating demand by using his surplus to spend more, adding to demand, the MPC would feel it had to tighten monetary policy further.

I cannot believe the Chancellor, despite his oft-proclaimed support for the MPC, really wants to relax fiscal policy, and risk a much greater further rise in interest rates than the Treasury is assuming. That way lies an even stronger pound.

webTitle: Councils hit by U-turn over asylum seekers

fields.headline: Councils hit by U-turn over asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The government has been accused of a U-turn after admitting that it will not be able to take on responsibility for dispersing asylum seekers across the country as planned in order to share out the burden on local authorities.
fields.body:
The government has been accused of a U-turn after admitting that it will not be able to take on responsibility for dispersing asylum seekers across the country as planned in order to share out the burden on local authorities.

The Government needs to find 40,000 bed spaces around the country for asylum seekers, but only around 4,000 have been secured so far.

A statement is expected tomorrow announcing a phasing-in of government responsibility instead of the full take-over scheduled for 1 April.

People who make their asylum applications at a port - the minority - will become the responsibility of the Home Office, while those who apply once they are in the country will remain the responsibility of local authorities for up to six months.

Local authorities are currently responsible for the care of asylum seekers and, although they receive some grant aid for this, Kent and London boroughs - which look after the majority - say they are around £30 million short of the cash they need to support them.

The delay will have a significant impact on councils in the South East, which will have to provide accommodation for around 20,000 asylum seekers for up to six months. Kent County Council and the London borough of Hillingdon have warned that the extra cost will have to be picked up by council tax payers.

The backlog of asylum cases reached a record of 104,890 cases in January.
