webTitle: How Gordon has trussed up Tony

fields.headline: How Gordon has trussed up Tony
fields.standfirst:
Gordon Brown still burns with ambition to be Prime Minister. I wonder why he bothers. In all but name, he is already
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown still burns with ambition to be Prime Minister. I wonder why he bothers. In all but name, he is already
fields.body:
Tony Blair's favoured way of describing the closeness of his relationship with Gordon Brown is as 'a marriage'. It's going through a rocky patch. You have not read about this - at least not until now - because one thing the Prime Minister and Chancellor learnt from the early turmoils of this Government was to draw the curtains before they threw crockery at each other.

Since Peter Mandelson's exile to the other side of the Irish Sea and the departure of Charlie Whelan, the outside world has observed only sweetness and light between Tony and Gordon. Yet, if anything, the differences between Blair and Brown, a struggle for supremacy which goes to the heart of the purpose of this Government, is wider than ever.

Their noisiest recent row - a humdinger, I'm told - was over the TV licence fee. Gordon wanted to introduce the supplement for owners of digital sets proposed by Gavyn Davies, the Chancellor's multi-millionaire friend and partner of his assistant, Sue Nye. But Tony was turned off by the idea of a digital licence. Rupert Murdoch slipped into Number 10 at the beginning of February to be given two hours of the Prime Minister's time to lobby against making digital, in which the media mogul has a massive investment, more expensive. I doubt there was a crude threat to the Prime Minister that the Sun would go down on him were the Government to impose the digital licence. These conversations tend to be more subtle.

And the digital licence had many other opponents, inside and outside Government. For a combination of reasons, the Prime Minister concluded that extra resources for the BBC should come from an increase to everyone's licence. Brown fought a protracted, fierce battle against this, partly because he feared it would be attacked by the Tories as another of his 'stealth taxes'. To Brown's not inconsiderable fury, Blair overruled him.

The small number of people at Number 10 and the Treasury aware of this story tell it with some wonderment. At the Treasury, it's muttered against the Prime Minister that his thraldom to the proprietor of News International led him to veto his Chancellor. At Number 10, the astonishment is that, for once, Blair insisted on getting his way with Brown.

If this is a marriage, it conforms to the old maxim about couples. Blair makes the life-and-death decisions: how to proceed in Northern Ireland; whether Britain should fight in Kosovo. Brown makes all the trivial decisions - in other words, the truly significant ones - about money. Blair has left himself dependent on Brown, not least because the Prime Minister's grasp of economics is light. Blair's interventions in Brown's empire are exceptional. A senior civil servant tells me that he has never known a Prime Minister to make fewer demands on the Treasury reserve.

The strength accumulated by the Chancellor will be vividly demonstrated in a fortnight's time. With his customary rabbit-pulling skill, Brown will use his Budget to produce tax lollies here and spending dollops for needy services there before sitting down to a thunderous ovation from the Labour backbenches. The Chancellor's poll chart may soar even higher. His approval ratings are already higher than the wilting score of the Prime Minister. And what may have started to dawn on Blair is that Brown has been purchasing popularity at the expense of the Prime Minister. While Iron Gordon has brilliantly positioned himself to garland all the plaudits for running a sound economy, it is Tony Blair who gets all the grief for being a tightwad towards public services.

Blair is a victim of the self-generated myth that he has created a presidential system of government. Sure, he wanted to. Yes, the Cabinet rarely gets consulted about any question more significant than whether they want one lump or two. There is a concentration of power at the top, but the master controller is not Blair. It's Brown. Under the aegis of his spending reviews, and by tying departments to his performance targets, the Chancellor has made every other Minister accountable and beholden to the Treasury. He whistles; they beg.

He's binding them even more tightly through a mechanism known as SR 2000. This is the review which will determine spending into the year 2004. Rather too late, Blair's advisers have realised that this effectively leaves the Chancellor to write nearly all the important chapters of the next manifesto. Brown will decide what the Government will do - and won't - well into the second term.

While no one was looking - has the Prime Minister even spotted it? - all of Tony Blair's ambitions for his government have become the prisoners of his Chancellor. Entry into the single currency will be determined by Brown's assessment of whether his five economic tests have been passed. Blair is in a box on Europe which only Brown can unlock. Another great project the Prime Minister set himself is the modernisation of health and education. Brown's consuming interest is welfare and work. These agendas do not have to be in conflict, but they are competitors for resources.

The winner of this competition has been the Chancellor. Billions of pounds have been poured into his New Deal schemes, and the child tax credit to be introduced in the Budget will give him direct control over another large slice of welfare spending. Health and education - Blair's interests - have been on a financial starvation diet. People at Number 10 talk wistfully of what they might have done for schools and hospitals with the £5 billion a year that the Chancellor is ploughing into his working families tax credit.

It gets better for Brown. Blair takes the brickbats for the state of the NHS, as he did when the Prime Minister exposed himself to the wrath of health professionals and patients on Newsnight. When the Chancellor produces a spending boost for the NHS in the Budget, he will Hoover up the bouquets.

Even more beautifully, from where the Chancellor is sitting, he's weaved the illusion, to which many on the Left have succumbed, that Red Gordon is the socialist soul of the Government who would do so much more for Labour's traditional supporters if only he were not stopped by Tory Blair. Let me tell you about the minimum wage. It was Brown who wanted it frozen. The TUC General Secretary, John Monks, and other trades unionists got no joy from the Chancellor. They were received much more sympathetically by the Prime Minister. Anxious about the mounting discontent in the Labour heartlands, Blair decided that the minimum wage should be raised. Spotting what was about to happen, Brown quickly spun the increase as an example of Generous Gordon. Even when Blair takes a popular decision, his Chancellor steals the credit for it.

Much of this flows from Gordon Brown's never forsaken ambition to be Prime Minister. There is no move that he makes - whether it is cooling towards the euro or letting it be known how much he hates the Millennium Dome - which doesn't include a calculation about whether it enhances or harms his prospects. I wonder, though, why he bothers anymore. In the crucial respects, he is already the virtual Prime Minister. Gordon Brown may not have the office- but he wields the power. I wonder whether Tony Blair has noticed that he is in office - but he is not in power. And when he does wake up, what then?

fields.headline: Shaming of America
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: By Wednesday, Senator John McCain's bubble may have burst. After triumphing in the Michigan primary, he stumbled last week and could crash out of the Republican race altogether on 'Super Tuesday'.
fields.body:
By Wednesday, Senator John McCain's bubble may have burst. After triumphing in the Michigan primary, he stumbled last week and could crash out of the Republican race altogether on 'Super Tuesday'.

But McCain's campaign has already been fascinating enough, not least for the way he has entranced liberal opinion and has the media eating out of his hand. This is odd. According to every survey, the media are well to the Left of the American mean, and McCain well to the Right.

So whence his appeal to liberals? Partly no doubt it's his genial personality and apparent authenticity in an age of political fakes. But the real answer is Vietnam. He served and suffered there, and most of his contemporaries - the ones now running the country, including its media - did not. McCain shows up a bad conscience, and a dirty secret haunting America.

I am English, but of the Vietnam generation. I know many Americans of my own age, now 50-something, and also - though to use a word with which the Americans are uneasy - my own class, journalists, lawyers, publishers, academics. And I cannot think of one who served in Vietnam.

Several million Americans did serve in Vietnam, and almost 60,000 were killed (along with two million Vietnamese). Others dodged the draft by going to Canada or Sweden, some truly conscientious objectors went to prison. But it was also possible to avoid the draft by working the system, notably by prolonging one's education.

During the Second World War, George Orwell remarked that, deplorable as our own rich might be, no one could deny them one aristocratic virtue. As every casualty list showed, the English upper classes were still prepared to die for their country.

A quarter-century later, the American upper classes weren't, something elo quently epitomised by the fact that no Harvard man died in Vietnam. There is no 1960s American equivalent to the long roll-call on the 1914-18 and 1939-45 war memorials in the chapel of every Oxford and Cambridge college.

Look at those who were young then and are their country's political leaders today. Bill Clinton spent two years at Oxford, where (as Maureen Dowd put it) he didn't inhale, didn't graduate and didn't get drafted. Bill Bradley was also a Rhodes Scholar, before returning home at the height of the war to do his bit as a professional basketball player. Al Gore did go to Vietnam - as an army journalist.

Most abject of all are the 'chickenhawks', the bellicose conservatives who discovered militarism after they had ceased to be of military age. George W. Bush is one. He didn't dodge the draft, he just pulled strings so that (like Dan Quayle) he could serve in the National Guard, a Dad's Army for daddies' boys. He now says that he felt no need to fight in Indo-China, since 'we could not explain the mission, had no exit stategy, and did not seem to be fighting to win'.

As Lars-Erik Nelson of the New York Daily News says, doubtless if those conditions had been met 'Bush would have been trudging through the boonies along with Pat Buchanan, Newt Gingrich, Phil Gramm, Dan Quayle and the rest of that blowhard army that shunned service in Vietnam.'

Vietnam was what Tony Blair would call a progressive war. It was the best and brightest of the Kennedy White House who took the fateful steps to war. They were supported by the moderate, anti-Communist Left, which met its nemesis in Vietnam. The trouble was that the best and brightest had sons, who decided that it wasn't a war they wanted to to wage.

And so for 30 years the dirty truth which has haunted the United States is this: the class which took America into Vietnam did not fight in that war. Nothing has so discredited the ruling élites of America, and they know it. That's what they acknowledge when they sing McCain's praises. He may not make it to the White House, but he has made a point.

Most abject of all are the 'chickenhawks', the bellicose conservatives who discovered militarism after they had ceased to be of military age. George W. Bush is one. He didn't dodge the draft, he just pulled strings so that (like Dan Quayle) he could serve in the National Guard, a Dad's Army for daddies' boys. He now says that he felt no need to fight in Indo-China, since 'we could not explain the mission, had no exit stategy, and did not seem to be fighting to win'. As Lars-Erik Nelson of the New York Daily News says, doubtless if those conditions had been met 'Bush would have been trudging through the boonies along with Pat Buchanan, Newt Gingrich, Phil Gramm, Dan Quayle and the rest of that blowhard army that shunned service in Vietnam.' Vietnam was what Tony Blair would call a progressive war. It was the best and brightest of the Kennedy White House who took the fateful steps to war. They were supported by the moderate, anti-Communist Left, which met its nemesis in Vietnam. The trouble was that the best and brightest had sons, who decided that it wasn't a war they wanted to to wage. And so for 30 years the dirty truth which has haunted the United States is this: the class which took America into Vietnam did not fight in that war. Nothing has so discredited the ruling élites of America, and they know it. That's what they acknowledge when they sing McCain's praises. He may not make it to the White House, but he has made a point.

webTitle: Payback time as Bush's buddies demand their money's worth

fields.headline: Payback time as Bush's buddies demand their money's worth
fields.standfirst:
On the eve of Super Tuesday, Ed Vulliamy in Orange County, California, reports a winner-takes-all war for the core of the Republican Party

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: On the eve of Super Tuesday,   Ed Vulliamy in Orange County, California, reports a winner-takes-all war for the core of the Republican Party
fields.body:
At the Ramada Hotel in Long Beach, Republican Party fundraisers were meeting over weak coffee and clean-cut sandwiches. They were businessmen, lawyers, doctors, corporate consultants.

The view out of the window was the breathtaking edge of America: the otherworldy port-scape of brightly-lit, fiery refineries and the hinterland of container depots and iron bridges.

The company harboured no doubts as to what John McCain means in their minds: 'A Clintonite liberal, not one of our kind,' said Ross Romaine, who had just given $500 to George W. Bush's campaign funds. 'Bush is the Republican Party, and we'll make sure he wins.'

McCain trails in the polls, has only two campaign staffers and no personal links to Los Angeles. His populist touch is as sure here as it has been elsewhere. But increasingly he fears that the election is being stolen from him by the Republican money-machine which has anointed Bush.

As the contest moved back to New York on Friday, a Texas businessman who is one of Bush's biggest contributors, said he had paid for $2 million for television commercials in New York and other primary states that criticised McCain and promoted Bush's record on clean air. The businessman, Sam Wyly, who recently sold a software company he co-owned for $3.9 billion, said he and his family paid for the advertising to draw attention to environmental issues. But McCain's aides accused the Bush campaign of being behind the advertising, which was scurrilous and part of a broader attempt to steal the campaign.

But it is California, with its 38 million citizens, which is the heart of Super Tuesday, and therefore of American politics over the next four years. And Orange County - fortress of the serious Republican Right - is its core. Although 17 states poll on Tuesday, neither candidate can survive the loss of California.

Even if McCain takes the the other mega-state, New York, he needs California too if he is to barnstorm his campaign into the last round, 'Southern Tuesday' comprising Texas and Florida. Bush, conversely, must establish his authority among hardline Republicans to enter he final count as the party's favourite son.

Bush is at once the familiar figure and the mystery in this campaign. Son of the ex-Presidentwhose career he has sought to duplicate, he is one of America's very few aristocrats; ubiquitous, he has a high-profile life behind him, and yet he remains something of an enigma. The question is 'What is George Bush?'

In 1998, the FBI in California opened a file on a curious case - the purchase of a boat from a financial consultant, Christopher Bower. Bower had sold the 47-footer to Tom Hicks, a Texas businessman who had never seen it, for $300,000 - $45,000 more than the original price. Bower had just advised the California state employees' pension fund to invest $100 million in Hicks's web of companies. Another $100m followed. The Feds found no reason to proceed, but the case afforded a peep into a remarkable empire built by Bush.

He is selling himself to voters in California as a man with a record of government in Texas. Yet he introduced himself to politics while he was an unsuccessful businessman drafted in to work for his father in Washington in 1987. From then on, Bush's inauspicious businesses developed a Midas touch, as powerful interests in Texas jostled for proximity to the son of presidential power. His small oil company, Harken, won a miraculous contract in Bahrain. Bush was able to harvest the resultant bonanza, only to unload his stock just in time before a 24 per cent price crash.

His tiny share in the Texas Rangers baseball team was mutated by a consortium of others into a high-profile and lucrative association worth $15 million.

But Tom Hicks the boat-buyer, one of the wealthiest men in Texas, was the man who really made Bush - and vice-versa. In return for a hefty donation to his gubernatorial campaign coffers, Hicks was made a regent of the University of Texas Board.

As such, Hicks revolutionised the way in which the university invested its funds, 'privatising' some $9 million of assets into a new investment management company, Utimco, which also guaranteed good salaries for Hicks and his fellow regents on the Board.

Utimco soon went into politics. The company placed $10 million with the Carlyle Group merchant bank in Washington, whose chairman was Frank Carlucci, Ronald Reagan's former Defence Secretary. Governor 'Junior' Bush has a seat on Carlyle's board.

The Republican Party likes this kind of synergy between politics, family and finance. This is why Bush personifies not only industrial and financial interests but with them the power elites on Capitol Hill and in governors' mansions across the country - elites that cannot and will not see him go down to a man who threatens their very raison d' etre .

Before Bush's candidature was made known publicly, some of the heaviest financial hitters in the land decided that Bush was the man to get their party back into the White House, come what may.

Word went out that Bush would stand, and fundraising began. Bush thus managed to amass the largest electoral war chest America has ever seen - some $70 million. The spending has been giddy, almost reckless, but until Bush's victory in the Virginia and Washington primaries last week largely ineffectual against McCain.

On Tuesday comes the moment when Bush's backers need to get what they are paying for: California. The coffers are now down to a reported $10 million, so to win California, The Observer is told, the drive against McCain has begun 'borrowing' from reserves earmarked to combat the Vice-President in the next race, to the White House.

But the Bush juggernaut can never run out of the essential fuel. It has too many friends in too many high places for that - especially in southern California.

Brad 'Fargo' Freeman, a merchant banker and multi-millionaire who likes to squire supermodels around Beverly Hills, is part of what Bush's campaign finance manager Don Evans calls 'a grassroots, broad-based individual effort across America'. Freeman, like 200,000 others, gave the maximum of $1,000.

But Freeman is also chairman of Bush's finance committee in California, and a leading 'Pioneer' - that is, one of a core working for Bush who manage a particular system of campaign finance manipulation which he has elevated into a fine art. It is called 'bundling': in addition to giving 'soft money' to the Republican Party, these 'Pioneers' get thousands of others to give their individual $1,000 to the candidate too. The system is simple: memoranda, circulars, phone calls and petition forms sent unsolicited around clients, employees, friends and contacts - urging them to join the club and support 'W'. Bush. The staff of entire companies has been invited to support the boss by helping his candidate.

California is of central symbolic as well as statistical importance in Tuesday, as home state of the man to whom George Bush Senior owed his career and whose legacy the son now claims - Ronald Reagan. But there's a twist: so does John McCain. McCain calls himself 'a proud Reagan Republican', while Bush calls his policies as 'Reaganesque'.

The choice of the Gipper is one of a figurehead, a man seen as the quintessential 'Un-Clinton', a Hollywood cowboy hero who united America on a wave of patriotic fervour, and who did so by winning the crucial middle ground - middle ground the Republicans have since lost.

This is becoming the theme at the kernel of the struggle between Bush's big-buck backers and McCain's challenge: the fact that, while Bush consolidates the Republican vote, McCain - especially after his withering attack on the Christian Coalition this week - is appealing further and further afield across the political spectrum.

The result - in California and beyond - is one that could blow the Republican Party apart: it is an 'open' primary inasmuch as all registered voters can poll for whoever they wish, but 'closed' inasmuch as only registered Republicans' votes will count towards the primary nomination result, and likewise for Democrats.

So there are two votes: the 'party' and 'popular' vote - the Republican nightmare is that Bush wins the former while McCain takes the latter.

Bush could emerge as the man with the party powerhouse interests and delegates behind him sufficient to win the nomination but lose the White House. McCain, meanwhile, would command the popular mandate and the polling power to beat Al Gore.

Whatever happens across the nation on Super Tuesday, it is in California that America will see itself in the mirror.

fields.headline: Families flee Serb gunfight battle
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: Fighting erupted between armed ethnic Albanians and Serb police early yesterday in a village inside Serbia .
fields.body:
Fighting erupted between armed ethnic Albanians and Serb police early yesterday in a village inside Serbia .

About 175 Albanian women, children and older men fled over the nearby border into Kosovo after the shooting began in Dobrosin just after midnight.

Peacekeepers are increasingly nervous about the emergence of a new guerrilla group in the area, which they believe is another threat to Kosovo's fragile stability under Nato and United Nations control.

Armed uniformed ethnic Albanians have been seen in Dobrosin in the past week, saying they were defending Albanians from Serb attack.

The guerrilla group has named itself the Presevo, Medvedje and Bujanovc Liberation Army, after three places in Serbia, with an Albanian population total-ling around 80,000. The area, once part of Kosovo, was swapped in 1950 for the Serb-dominated town of Leposavic.

Several thousand Albanian refugees from Serbia have already fled 'eastern Kosovo' for shelter in the international protectorate next door. More than 1,300 have registered with aid officials this year. The past few days have seen a 'dramatic increase', says one aid worker.

Bekim Dauti of the International Rescue Committee, which is responsible for refugees in the Gnjilane area, says newly arrived refugees are found waiting outside its office every morning. They complain that Serbian forces are threatening Albanians and burning houses.

'Some people say it is going to be a hot spring,' said Dauti. 'We need to be prepared.'

webTitle: Tory avengers set to win Ayr

fields.headline: Tory avengers set to win Ayr
fields.standfirst:
Labour stay-at-homes could be crucial in first Holyrood by-election
Devolution in Scotland: special report
Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Out of  the sweaty confines of Holyrood, all parties campaigning in the first by-election of the Scottish Parliament are being reminded that politics is different on the streets.
fields.body:
Out of the sweaty confines of Holyrood, all parties campaigning in the first by-election of the Scottish Parliament are being reminded that politics is different on the streets.

The recent obsessions of parliamentarians and press have little resonance in Ayr . Scottish Labour is keen to say the row over Section 28 is damaging their chances in the seat, where the Tories are heading for their first straight parliamentary victory since their wipe-out in the 1997 general election.

Yet all the parties agree the issue has not come up much. Instead that old fundamental of elections, the economy, is taking centre stage because the people of Ayr think they are getting a raw deal.

Labour proudly points to falling unemployment figures, but the streets of the town tell another story. Many shopfronts are boarded up. Thirty years ago the area was rich with coal and farming money. Nearby Prestwick airport seemed rich with the hope of the jet age. Tourists still came to the sandy local beaches. Now it has all faded. Each campaign team says the most asked question on the doorstep is about jobs and the economic future.

'Ayr's like many market towns in Scotland. It's trying to find a new role,' says Jim Wray, of South Lanarkshire Council Economic Development Department. He says the future is looking good. With harbourside redevelopment, three colleges and a fourth to open, a new confidence about Prestwick and the upgrading of the main road to Glasgow there are signs of recovery, Wray says.

'In three to five years' time the area will be enjoying an upswing in its fortunes.'

But that's too late for Labour. Among the three main parties there is a consensus that the Tories are in front. Both Labour and the Conservatives say the Labour vote is soft and disinclined to turn out. Labour is being pragmatic. The party says it was a stunning achievement to have won the Tory stronghold in the first place, and it is just suffering routine mid-term blues.

However, alarm bells are ringing in the Labour machine. Ayr was a high-water mark in Labour's 1997 popularity. Strategists worry that the only way from that peak is down. In 1997 Labour won 55 per cent of the vote in Scotland. And it delivered an end to the Tories, for which voters of many political hues were grateful. Six months later the party delivered a devolved Parliament.

But things are slipping now. The party's candidate in Ayr, Rita Miller, tells a meeting that Labour ended tuition fees. The audience guffaws, reminding her that Labour introduced them.

In Scotland, where Labour dominates local government, Holyrood and Westminster, the voters now have no one else to blame. 'To a certain extent we are victims of our own success,' says the party's new spin-doctor, John Scott.

It means the electorate of Ayr will probably plump for John Scott (no relation), a local farmer with the ruddy cheeks and good manners of old Tory stalwarts. Yet Conservative strategists say this marks only a small reversal of fortune. There is little evidence they are winning new voters from other parties, only that their traditional vote in Ayr is strong and they are winning back a few who switched to Labour.

What appears to be happening is that Scottish politics, which have long listed to the left, are very slowly moving back to an even keel.

The Tories and Labour have taken over empty shops in the town for their campaigns. The SNP is tucked away in a lock-up in an industrial area near the seafront. The battered door and puddles at the entrance disguise the nationalists' new efficiency and thoroughness.

Long recognised as masters at the guerrilla warfare of by-elections, they have swapped megaphones for laptops. They tap away at their new kit and claim something has changed: never before has the public been so receptive to their message. They are convinced they are going to come a good second.

In the new world of Scottish politics, the SNP's message has 'adapted'. There is less talk of independence and more of gaining new powers. The word 'change' was long banned from nationalist speeches and literature for fear it would scare voters. Now the Nationalists, as the official opposition, are pitching a message that voters will have to change if they want things to improve. Party strategists are confident they are winning new voters from old Labour ranks.

Their candidate, Jim Mather, is 'new Nationalist' at its best. The businessman is impressive. He represents an opposition far removed from the politics of identity, and firmly encamped in economic pragmatism.

In truth, as one economic adviser admitted to The Observer , whoever wins will make little difference to the economy of Ayr. All the parties support the various government agencies trying to regenerate the area.

The significance of the result will lie in what it will tell party workers about their chances for the next general and Scottish elections and about the changing face of the country's politics.

The candidates in Ayr are:

William Botcherby, Radio Vet; Gavin Corbett, Scottish Green; Kevin Dillon, Anti-Cloning; Robert Graham, Pro-Life; Jim Mather, SNP; Alistair McConnachie, UKIP; Rita Miller, Labour; Stuart Ritchie, Lib Dem; John Scott, Conservative; James Stewart, Scottish Socialist Party.

1999: I. Welsh (Lab) 14,695; P. Gallie (Con) 14,238; R. Mullin (SNP), 7,291; E . Morris (LD) 1,662. Lab majority 25.

webTitle: Evangelists pray for proof of faith's healing

fields.headline: Evangelists pray for proof of faith's healing
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: More things are wrought by prayer than this world dreams of,' wrote Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Queen Victoria's Poet Laureate. The line may have satisfied Her Majesty, but our more sceptical age seeks scientific proof of the power of faith.
fields.body:
More things are wrought by prayer than this world dreams of,' wrote Alfred, Lord Tennyson, Queen Victoria's Poet Laureate. The line may have satisfied Her Majesty, but our more sceptical age seeks scientific proof of the power of faith.

After an experiment in the United States, believers in Britain are to try to reproduce evidence that praying works.

The Pioneer group of evangelical churches, led by Gerald Coates, wants help in testing the beneficial effects of prayer on hospital patients. Next Sunday he will lead a discussion on prayer during the final programme of BBC1's The Heart of the Matter, which will examine the results of two studies funded by the Templeton Foundation and carried out in Kansas in 1988 and in San Francisco 10 years later.

The first experiment took 990 heart patients and had 75 Christians pray for them over 28 days. The patients showed a reported 11 per cent improvement in health, compared with a control group.

In the second experiment, volunteers were given the first names of a group of patients and prayed for their recovery. An improvement of 10 per cent was noted among them. Coates said: 'While the research does not prove the existence of God, the results will make not believing rather difficult.'

Physicist and Anglican priest John Pulkinghorn sees it differently. 'I am sceptical about these experiments,' the former president of Queens' College, Cambridge, said. fields.headline: Drumcree honours a republican
fields.standfirst:
The church on the hill is synonymous with Orange Order defiance, but the Protestant community's most celebrated son turns out to have owed his loyalties to the other side, reports Henry McDonald
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Drumcree, the citadel of anti-Agreement loyalism, has now become a shrine for the Orange Order's republican enemies.
fields.body:
Drumcree, the citadel of anti-Agreement loyalism, has now become a shrine for the Orange Order's republican enemies.

Republicans are set to pay homage at Drumcree parish church to one of the founding fathers of the Young Ireland movement, John Mitchel.

Under the noses of Orange protesters at Drumcree hill, several republicans from Newry visited the church last week to check parish records in order to confirm that Mitchel was married at the church.

Republicans organising an exhibition on his life travelled to Portadown last week. They learnt that Mitchel, who was transported from Ireland by the British for rebellion, was married in the church in 1837. His bride, 16-year-old Jane Verner, came from a prominent Orange Order family in Co Armagh.

The Rev John Pickering, the current rector at Drum cree, said the republicans who came to check the records were 'extremely courteous'. He added: 'They came to look at our records and the entry on John Mitchel and when he was married. They simply just wanted to see the book because they are planning an exhibition on Mitchel's life in Newry later this year.'

Pickering said he was glad to open the books to the republicans 'because our histories are entangled and I have an interest in history'.

He added that no one has yet approached him from the republican side over a future commemoration at the church in Mitchel's honour.

Mitchel, a Newry-based solicitor and son of a Presbyterian minister, was an outspoken republican involved in armed conspiracy to overthrow the British in Ireland. In 1848 he was sentenced to 14 years for treason and initially transported to Australia. However, he escaped to America and was only allowed to return to Ireland 40 years later, when he was given a hero's welcome.

Following his return, Mitchel was elected Westminster MP for Tipperary but died a short time later.

He married his child bride, whom he had tried to elope with a year before when she was just 15, at Drumcree because it was her home parish. Jane Verner came from a staunchly unionist, Orange, Church of Ireland Episcopalian family in the county, while Mitchel was a Unitarian.

Mitchel is buried in Newry's Protestant Unitarian graveyard where republicans hold an annual commemoration. There is also a statue of the 19th-century republican icon in the centre of the town of his birth.

Republicans in Newry said the marriage of Mitchel and Verner at Drumcree had reso nance for Ireland in the 21st century.

One republican said: 'Here are two people from a unionist background who held radical, republican beliefs and suffered for that. In fact, they symbolised the possibility of reaching out to the other side.'

Such is the sensitivity of the issue that the republicans involved will not disclose their names or say whether or not they are connected to Sinn Fein.

David Jones, the spokesman for the Orange Order in Portadown, said it was ironic that republicans could come to Drumcree church to check parish records but local Orangemen could not walk down the nearby, mainly nationalist, Garvaghy Road.

'I can't really object to someone coming to the church to check the records, Orangemen do that all the time in parishes across the province.

'Even during the day ordinary residents of the Garvaghy Road can walk their dogs past the church freely but if I tried to walk down the Garvaghy Road even without an Orange collarette on I would be taking my life in my hands.

'There is a rumour in the town that this republican group from Newry wants to march from Garvaghy Road to the church to commemorate Mitchel. All I can say is it's ironic if they're looking for a right to march while we can't parade in our home town.'

Jones added that Orangemen would be intensifying their protests at Drumcree over the next few weeks as the marching season begins. His members were determined to 'stay on the hill' despite the ban against the local lodge marching down Garvaghy Road.

webTitle: Jail visit to IRA suspect was bugged, says Shayler

fields.headline: Jail visit to IRA suspect was bugged, says Shayler
fields.standfirst:
Guildford Four solicitor says lawyers must now assume security services are recording prison interviews
Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: A confidential interview between a high-profile IRA suspect and his lawyer was bugged by the intelligence services, according to the former MI5 officer David Shayler.
fields.body:
A confidential interview between a high-profile IRA suspect and his lawyer was bugged by the intelligence services, according to the former MI5 officer David Shayler.

Gareth Peirce, the solicitor who famously represented the Guildford Four, was allegedly recorded taking a statement from her client, Michael O'Brien, while he was on remand at Belmarsh Prison in June 1992. The bugging was said to have been carried out by the Metropolitan Police Special Branch, which was responsible for counter-terrorist operations.

'A revelation of this significance could have a potential effect on an almost open-ended range of convictions,' said Peirce last night. 'Clearly all lawyers must proceed on the basis that this still continues.'

O'Brien was accused of involvement in the shooting of a special constable in Tadcaster, North Yorkshire, and later received an 18-year sentence for attempted murder. He was released in August 1998 as part of the Good Friday Agreement. He has always claimed he was inno cent of the crime. 'Many prisoners at Belmarsh at that time were convinced that their legal visits were being listened to,' said Peirce. 'I sought assurances from the governor about the position, as did other solicitors. We were provided with verbal and written guarantees that there was no such possibility.'

Client confidentiality is one of the central principles of the European Convention on Human Rights. A judge would be likely to stop a trial if it was shown that the prosecution had been in possession of recordings of legal interviews with a defendant.

Shayler claims he was told about the bugging operation in early August 1992, shortly after he was transferred to the counter-terrorist section of MI5. His section had recently taken over the lead role from the police in the fight against republican terrorism and was being briefed about previous Special Branch operations. Although the tape was later destroyed, Commander Don Buchanan, then head of Special Branch, listened to some of the recording, according to Shayler. It will be difficult for the Government to dismiss Shayler's latest allegations as 'bar-room gossip' or 'fantasy', as he learnt about the bugging operation in a briefing given by his line manager at MI5.

The allegations were due to appear in a column Shayler writes for the satirical magazine Punch on Tuesday, but were removed. Shayler's solicitor John Wadham has offered the evidence to the Government and Intelligence and Security Committee, but both have refused to take it. A spokeswoman for the Prison Service said she could not comment on security matters.

The Government last week stepped up its action against Shayler when officers from Special Branch demanded that The Observer hand over documents relating to allegations made in last week's paper. These concern the alleged secret involvement of the British foreign intelligence service (MI6) in a plot to assassinate President Gadaffi of Libya in 1996. A criminal investigation has been launched into whether the revelations represent a breach of the Official Secrets Act.

Shayler wrote to the Home Office in November of last year with full details of his allegations, including the names of the officers from Britain's intelligence services he alleges were directly involved with the plot and those in MI5 and MI6 who were told about it.

Meanwhile, the Government's lawyers could be tripped up in their attempts to sue the former MI5 officer for damages for breach of confidence and infringement of Crown copyright. In what would turn out to be a dramatic reversal of fortune for Shayler, the Government's case is set to be completely undermined by a judgement in the House of Lords later this month in the case of former Soviet agent George Blake.

Blake is mounting a challenge to the 1997 appeal court decision that he could not receive £90,000 of royalties from his memoirs, No Other Choice . The case, which reaches the House of Lords later this month, could herald the end of the time-honoured tradition that members of the British intelligence services are bound to a lifetime of silence about their activities. Lawyers acting for Blake are optimistic that he will win in the Lords - but, if that fails, they will take the case to Europe, where it is almost certain of success.

Blake was told that, in effect, the Government owned the copyright to his book because the information within it was covered by the Official Secrets Act.

The Lords decision will have major implications for Shayler's case and that of former MI6 agent Richard Tomlinson, who has also threatened to publish his memoirs. As a result of the Blake judgment, both men would be unable to enjoy the proceeds from their memoirs and, until now, publishers have been unprepared to risk astronomical legal costs by printing them.

Shayler, who lives in exile in Paris, said last night he was delighted the Blake case was under review. 'If Blake wins, this is extremely good news for me. This is an important freedom of information issue that needs to be resolved.' Shayler's lawyers will now consider applying for suspension of legal action against him by the Government while the Blake case is pending in the Lords.

 Email Martin Bright at martin.bright@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Fayed fury as Dodi gets the blame

fields.headline: Fayed fury as Dodi gets the blame
fields.standfirst: Diana's bodyguard has broken his silence about the Paris crash to point the finger at an 'arrogant' Dodi Fayed. Now the Harrods owner has hit back
fields.trailText: Mohamed Al-Fayed last night attacked Princess Diana's former bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones after the ex-paratrooper blamed Fayed's son Dodi for the crash that killed Diana and dismissed Fayed himself as a fantasist.
fields.body:
Mohamed Al-Fayed last night attacked Princess Diana's former bodyguard Trevor Rees-Jones after the ex-paratrooper blamed Fayed's son Dodi for the crash that killed Diana and dismissed Fayed himself as a fantasist.

The Harrods boss called Rees-Jones a 'money-grabbing' hypocrite in a furious response to an interview published yesterday in which the bodyguard spoke for the first time about the tragedy.

Rees-Jones condemned Dodi as dangerous and 'unpredictable' and said Fayed had concocted stories to explain the crash. But last night Fayed said Rees-Jones did not have 'a scrap of fresh information' about the tragedy. He was 'talking rubbish, rewriting history _ in an attempt to deflect blame from Trevor's own part in what happened.' He said Rees-Jones was exploiting the crash to sell his memoirs and make thousands of pounds.

'I am saddened and disappointed that Trevor has chosen to tell his story in this way,' Fayed said. 'While I have great sympathy for him - he went through hell - there are limits. I would have expected better of him than to exploit the Paris tragedy.

'I always paid him very well and he was always well treated by me and my family. He owes me a duty of confidentiality and I would hope a debt of gratitude for all I did to help him after the crash.

'Trevor made no criticism at all of Dodi at the time he was helping the inquiry - that came after he left my employment in May 1998. I can only see these criticisms raised so long after the event as an attempt to deflect blame from Trevor's own part in what happened.'

In an interview with the Daily Telegraph yesterday to publicise his forthcoming book on the tragedy, Rees-Jones said Dodi was arrogant and reckless - repeatedly and cynically breaking the basic rules of security over Diana. He made plans on the hoof, changed his mind halfway through journeys, travelled without security back-up and frequently overruled bodyguards Fayed had assigned to Diana. It was he who made the arrangements that led to drunken security man Henri Paul driving Diana's limousine into the Paris tunnel at high speed.

He dismissed as 'ridiculous' the conspiracy theories Fayed put forward to explain the tragedy. 'I still sympathise with him for losing his son. But I can't sympathise with him for accusing Prince Philip of murdering Dodi and the Princess, or me of not doing my job properly.

The biography, The Bodyguard's Story , will re-ignite the dispute over how and why Diana died. Ever since the tragedy two-and-a-half years ago Fayed has tried to blame MI5, the 'racist British Establishment', the Israeli secret service and an unidentified Frenchman in a white Fiat Uno. He has criticised Diana's security men and furiously denied claims that the driver of the limousine, Ritz security chief, Henri Paul, was drunk. But Rees-Jones, who suffered facial injuries in the accident, has pinned the blame firmly on Dodi.

Rees-Jones said he was planning to confront Dodi once the Princess had left Paris. 'I was going to say: "You've got to give us more information or get someone else in to do the job."'

On the night Diana died, Rees-Jones claims, Dodi changed the procedure for leaving The Ritz. He told Henri Paul to steer the limousine out of a concealed hotel exit to avoid paparazzi. To make Diana's getaway even more low-key, Dodi decided against having the usual back-up car. Even though the plan ran counter to accepted security practice, Rees-Jones said Dodi assured him it had been approved in London by Fayed. The Harrods owner later denied the claim.

Rees-Jones also criticised Fayed's London security headquarters. During the Mediterranean holiday when the press were circling Fayed's yacht Rees-Jones called Fayed in London to ask for back-up. 'They could send sand to Finland,' Rees-Jones recalls, 'but they can't send a few extra blokes to help us.' Fayed denies he received the calls.

Rees-Jones said he did not confront Dodi before the crash because Dodi was wilful and could have simply disappeared with Diana. 'If I had put my foot down, Dodi would have gone on his own. Working in the private sector, you haven't got the power. You can advise, you can try to point them in the right direction, but he who pays the wages...'

In yesterday's interview Rees-Jones told how he is still haunted by the knowledge that Diana died 'on my shift'. He said he would have traded his own life for hers and the two other victims, Dodi and Paul. 'If I could have died and those three survived I would have done it. If I could have done something ... I go mad thinking about if onlys.'

He still has nightmares about what happened in the Paris underpass. 'It happens even now. I'll be asleep and then Boof! I'll be awake suddenly, sitting up in bed remembering. I can wake up after six hours' sleep and be absolutely exhausted, my brain running round and round.'

Rees-Jones started work for Fayed in 1995 at £25,000 a year. They parted company acrimoniously when Fayed became exasperated at Rees-Jones's inability to remember details of the crash. Fayed has since accused him of failing to do his job properly.

 Email John Arlidge at john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

Rees-Jones started work for Fayed in 1995 at £25,000 a year. They parted company acrimoniously when Fayed became exasperated at Rees-Jones's inability to remember details of the crash. Fayed has since accused him of failing to do his job properly.  Email John Arlidge at john.arlidge@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Feud warning from loyalist terror group

fields.headline: Feud warning from loyalist terror group
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Loyalist Volunteer Force terrorist group has ruled out any mediation aimed at ending its bitter feud with the rival Ulster Volunteer Force.
fields.body:
The Loyalist Volunteer Force terrorist group has ruled out any mediation aimed at ending its bitter feud with the rival Ulster Volunteer Force.

Instead, the LVF warned this weekend that it was prepared to extend its war with the UVF into the rivals' heartland, Belfast's Shankill Road.

Sources close to the LVF leadership in Portadown told The Observer it was 'not backing down' from confrontation, and there would be no peace talks between the groups.

'The LVF have had enough - there will be no more bully-boy tactics. Retaliation will not be against an innocent UVF man. Targets will be correctly selected and dealt with.'

In a direct threat to the UVF's leadership, the LVF source said blame for the recent deaths of teenagers Andrew Robb and David Mcllwaine 'lies at the door of the Eagle' - the UVF's Shankill Road headquarters.

The UVF, however, has denied that its leaders sanctioned the torture and killing of the teenagers in Tandragree a fortnight ago.

Three people have died in the inter-loyalist conflict, including Portadown businessman Richard Jameson. Security sources say he was the leader of the UVF in Mid-Ulster but the murdered man's family denies this.

The LVF source alleged that the Jameson killing was not sanctioned by his organisation.

If the LVF carries out its threat to strike at the UVF leaders, this will mark a major escalation of the feud which has simmered since the LVF was formed following a split in the UVF's Mid-Ulster brigade in 1996. Although the LVF is strong in Portadown, its rival commands the loyalty of hundreds of experienced and ruthless paramilitaries in Greater Belfast.

The only way the LVF could operate there would be with the covert co-operation of the other loyalist terror group, the Ulster Defence Association. The organisations co-operated before the murder of the UVF's Billy Wright inside the Maze prison in December 1997.

The UDA had carried out a number of sectarian killings in north Belfast, and allowed the LVF to claim responsibility for them in the media. The organisations also worked together on the murder of nationalist solicitor Rosemary Nelson. The UDA pro vided the bomb which was planted under Nelson's car by an LVF member.

The UDA, however, is divided over its attitude to the LVF-UVF feud. Its Shankill Road units were deliberately seen in public with LVF members from Portadown at the funeral of Andrew Robb last week.

Johnny Adair, the former commander of the UDA's paramilitary wing, the Ulster Freedom Fighters, was among a number of prominent loyalists to attend the funeral. So was a legendary loyalist figure known as 'top gun', from the UFF's notorious C company in the Lower Shankill. He has a long record of involvement in sectarian killings in the last decade.

However, other so-called UDA brigades, including South and East Belfast, are extremely wary of siding with the LVF against the UVF. The different attitudes towards aiding the LVF reflect the disparate nature of the UDA, where some brigadiers hardly speak to one another.

Another sign that the internal loyalist war is far from over was seen in the death notices of the Belfast Telegraph . Someone paid for a death notice for a prominent UVF member from north Belfast, who was not in fact dead. The notice alleged - wrongly - that he was in Co Armagh on the weekend of the murders of Robb and McIlwaine.

The suspicion now is that someone inside the loyalist community is spreading misinformation with the aim of escalating the feud.

webTitle: Eton allows lower class in to play game

fields.headline: Eton allows lower class in to play game
fields.standfirst: Public schools set to share their sports fields
fields.trailText: It is an unforgiving routine: 6am runs, cold showers and freezing rugby games. Welcome to the sporting hell endured by generations of pupils at Britain's private schools.
fields.body:
It is an unforgiving routine: 6am runs, cold showers and freezing rugby games. Welcome to the sporting hell endured by generations of pupils at Britain's private schools.

Now students from poor backgrounds attending comprehensives are to sample the joys of this traditional, stiff upper lip approach to physical education.

In an historic assault on the huge class divide in Britain's education system, fee-paying schools - which charge up to £13,000 a year - will invite state pupils to use their often luxurious sports facilities.

In this unlikely sporting alliance, public school pupils will be introduced to the rough and tumble of the common man's game, football, while state pupils learn the finer points of gentlemen's sports such as rugby, cricket and tennis. Children who would otherwise rarely meet will also share sports coaches, who may act as mentors, and train together.

Leading private schools such as Eton, Harrow and Millfield will throw open their doors to children from local state schools. The ground-breaking scheme has been approved by Ministers, who are keen to see sport regain its place at the heart of the curriculum in state schools. Twenty years of decline have seen inter-school competitive sport fade away, the amount of time devoted to PE plummet and countless school playing fields sold off to developers.

Sports Minister Kate Hoey and Schools Minister Estelle Morris believe both teachers and pupils at comprehensive schools would benefit from exposure to the private school ethos that sport is an essential ingredient of every student's personal development.

The scheme is due to start this autumn, but Ministers are braced for opposition from local education authorities and teaching unions. Critics will claim the Government is having to 'rent' facilities at bastions of privilege because it does not give maintained schools enough money to provide for themselves.

Harrow School, where for mer England and British Lions rugby player Roger Uttley is head of games, already lets local youngsters use its eight tennis courts, nine-hole golf course and sports centre, which includes a swimming pool.

Headmaster Barnaby Lenon said they also hoped to share their athletics track, tennis courts and football pitches with state schools. The school would build new hockey pitches and establish a team of specialist coaches if enough local comprehensives joined the scheme.

'We've got extensive sporting facilities here, yet we only use them during term-time and never in the morning, so it makes sense to open them up,' said Lenon.

Hoey, a former PE teacher, wants a return to the days when secondary school teachers would give up their spare time to supervise games or take training.

In a damning assessment of attitudes in state-maintained schools, Hoey said they could benefit from following the example of teachers in fee-paying schools, 'where teachers are still, on the whole, prepared to do extra things and do it for the love of it, so you get maths teachers coaching cricket or taking hockey. That has gone from state schools.'

The scheme is the brainchild of Ian Beer, chairman of the Independent Schools Council, which represents most of Britain's top private schools. He said it was designed to use sport to break down 'huge social barriers', revive maintained schools' interest in physical activity and halt the alarming slump in fitness levels among teenagers.

Teachers could learn from each other too, said Beer, a former chairman of the Rugby Football Union and ex-headmaster of three private schools, including Harrow. They would effectively be 'trading places' with teachers from fee-paying schools taking sports lessons in comprehensives and vice versa.

Beer said PE had been largely 'squeezed out' of the timetable at many state schools, especially primaries, but that the independent schools' continued emphasis on sport 'shows that it is possible to find the time to do sport and exercise as well as all the numeracy, literacy and academic stuff'.

'We believe in the independent sector that we can't develop a child's mental abilities but at the same time neglect his or her physical education during adolescence the way, sadly, so many schools in the maintained sector do.'

 Email Denis Campbell at denis.campbell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Why can't they admit nuclear accident killed our children?

fields.headline: Why can't they admit nuclear accident killed our children?
fields.standfirst: A nuclear power plant worker and his wife blame radiation for the deaths of their three daughters. They tell of their fight for answers - and justice
fields.trailText: Life was looking up for Joe McMaster in the Fifties. After studying chemistry at Belfast University, he was thrilled to land a job in England on a salary of £475 a year. He was at the cutting edge of an industry hailed as the answer to the energy problems of the human race: nuclear power.
fields.body:
Life was looking up for Joe McMaster in the Fifties. After studying chemistry at Belfast University, he was thrilled to land a job in England on a salary of £475 a year. He was at the cutting edge of an industry hailed as the answer to the energy problems of the human race: nuclear power.

He had a young wife and a baby daughter. His new job meant he could afford a semi-detached home six miles from the Preston laboratory where he worked. Their future secure, Joe and Stella hoped to expand their family.

Then in 1953 an accident happened which they now believe determined their dreadful fate for the next three decades - Joe was exposed to uranium.

He was called to see his boss, who told him the radiation in his body was 28 times above normal but that there was little to worry about. Joe did not tell Stella about the accident since he had signed the Official Secrets Act.

But it was not his own health that proved to be at risk. He is convinced that the exposure he underwent is why he has had to bury three of his four children in 24 years. Two died of rare leu-kaemia-related illnesses; one baby girl died of lung problems. Sharon, the only surviving daughter, lives from day to day thinking she will be next.

Joe has been told by doctors that he has a chromosome abnormality, a rare deficiency linked to radiation exposure. He believes he passed the disease on to his children through his sperm.

Joe told The Observer : 'I blame myself. How could I not? I get off to sleep and then I'll be awake again. I end up listening to the radio all night.

'Something that always sticks with me is a man I heard on the television. It was the father of that girl Leah Betts, who died from Ecstasy. He said he mourned the grandchildren he'd missed out on. I know that feeling.'

The McMasters have been quietly campaigning against British Nuclear Fuels, the company that owned the laboratory, for the last 10 years. They do not want any money; all they seek is an acknowledgement that the cancer found in their children was caused by radiation.

They are backed by radioactivity research pioneer Dr Alice Stewart and by their MP, Tory Party vice-chairman Nigel Evans, who hopes to refer their case to the Department of Trade and Industry Select Committee.

The couple's first child, Lynn, died in 1987, aged 37, of a rare leukaemia-related blood disorder. She needed a bone marrow transplant and Joe learnt that he was a match. But his chromosome defect meant that he could not be a donor. No other donor could be found. Baby Jill arrived in 1955, born with an immune system deficiency. She trained to be a nurse but died, aged just 18, in 1973, of an unknown form of acute leukaemia.

In 1958 they had twin daughters. Sharon weighed 4lb 9oz and her stronger sister, Judith, 5lb 8oz. Three days after the birth, Judith died of lung failure.

'I wanted four children,' said Stella. 'I have one left and she's on a knife edge. Sharon just lives from day to day thinking she is next.

'In all those years Joe never told me what had happened. I suspected something, but after Lynn's doctors asked if she worked with radiation I sat him down and asked him straight out.'

Science is divided on whether they are either a tragically unlucky family or the victims of a gross injustice. Dr Richard Wakefield, BNFL's principal research scientist, said: 'I have met with the McMasters and it is all very sad, but it is scientifically difficult to see links between this tragic occurrence and Joe's work at Springfield. We have looked at this very hard indeed.'

He believes Joe's chromosome abnormality is due to ageing and pointed out that Lynn was born before he started at Springfield.

Dr Brian Lord, of the Paterson Institute in Manchester, said: 'No one can ever prove an individual cancer is related to radiation. There are several theories and no consensus. My research shows radiation could increase sensitivity to leukaemia, but BNFL don't want to hear that.'

A 1992 compensation case brought by families claiming a leukaemia cluster around Sellafield failed. The families' lawyer, Martyn Day, was angry that BNFL, 'in an unprecedented step', wrote to the legal aid board asking for families' claims to be denied.

He told The Observer : 'There was strong evidence on both sides, but I was disappointed in the result. It will be a long, long time before anyone would take BNFL to court again.'

BNFL was last month embroiled in safety scandals which led to the sacking of chief executive John Taylor. Safety at Sellafield was described as 'only just tolerable' by inspectors.

The McMasters just want justice. 'The day before Lynn died, we were in the hospital,' said Stella. 'She [Lynn] said to me: "It's not my dad's fault, don't blame my dad". She knew what was to blame and I won't rest until I prove it.'

 Email Tracy McVeigh at tracy.mcveigh@observer.co.uk

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Police identify body of woman washed up on Suffolk beach
fields.body:
Police identify body of woman washed up on Suffolk beach

Police believe they have identified the body found washed up on a Suffolk beach. The naked body of a woman, weighed down with chains, was discovered near Lowestoft on Thursday. A post-mortem examination revealed that the cause of death was drowning and police officers are treating the death as suspicious.

Following checks on a police fingerprint database, officers believe that the woman was in her late twenties and came from the Chelmsford area of Essex.

Toddler held at knifepoint

A four-year-old boy was held at knife-point while three teenage boys robbed his uncle of £70 in Oldham, Greater Manchester, yesterday.

Four arrested in GM protest

Four Greenpeace activists were arrested yesterday as a ship believed to be carrying genetically modified soya docked in Liverpool. They were allegedly trying to gain access to the docks. The Iolcos Grace arrived in Britain from the US.

Dog owner feared drowned

Rescuers are searching for a man who was swept away by the River Teifi in west Wales. The 54-year old was attempting to rescue his pet dog from the swollen river.

£500,000 drugs quiz

An 18-year-old woman is being questioned by police after £500,000 of drugs including Ecstasy, amphetamines and cannabis were recovered from a house in Stockton-on-Tees, Teeside.

Bells silenced by squirrels

Bellringers at St Michael and All Angels' Parish Church in the village of Stanton-by-Dale, Derbyshire, have had their chimes silenced after squirrels in the belfry ate through the ropes.

Alert over French cockerels

Animal welfare officers were drafted in to tend to any cockerels confiscated from French rugby fans when their team played Scotland in Edinburgh yesterday.

Church funds for hostages

The controversial Bishop of Edinburgh has pledged around £4,000 of his church's funds as bail for 13 of the hostages from the Afghan hijack. Bishop Richard Holloway said: 'There's a strong Christian responsibility and a principle to care for strangers, especially those in distress.' The bishop sparked controversy last year when his book Godless Morality was published.

Rare buy

A first edition of John le Carré's first novel, Call for the Dead, has been sold at auction at Sotheby's for £8,050. The 1961 novel introduced the hero spy George Smiley and is so rare that le Carré himself does not even own a copy.

Landmark visit

The Millennium Dome welcomed its one millionth visitor yesterday. Dome chief executive Pierre-Yves Gerbeau greeted Damien Nash and his children, Chloe and Harry, with a celebratory bottle of champagne.

webTitle: Net spins virtual lifelines to save village posties

fields.headline: Net spins virtual lifelines to save village posties
fields.trailText: The village post office will never be the same. Me.Gov, an Internet site covering advice on every aspect of public services, is to be installed in thousands of post offices as the centrepiece of the Government's new rural electronic revolution.
fields.body:
The village post office will never be the same. Me.Gov, an Internet site covering advice on every aspect of public services, is to be installed in thousands of post offices as the centrepiece of the Government's new rural electronic revolution.

Billed by Downing Street as Tony Blair's first big idea for a second-term Labour government, the website will provide help on banking, benefits, job vacancies, education, health and local transport.

The single portal or gateway will offer a range of services, providing 'a personal window' on government. Customers will be offered prompts or reminders when services change or when important dates approach, such as tax self-assessment deadlines.

The commercial contract for the full development of Me.Gov will be announced this month.

Access to the service is likely to be initially through a password based on a National Insurance number. One of the first services to go online will be a Learning and Education Bank providing details of all 400,000 job vacancies notified to the Employment Service. Over time, Ministers plan to add a Europe-wide job vacancy programme.

The service, being un-veiled this week by David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, will also give details of local job training and skills programmes for the unemployed.

In urban areas, the network is likely to be sited in shopping centres, Job Centres or special kiosks. Within 10 years, many of the services could be provided through digital TV in individuals' homes.

A new role for the local post office in rural communities is seen by the Government as politically urgent. The post office network is under severe threat from Government plans to pay key benefits, such as pensions, through automatic cash transfer into people's bank accounts, saving the Department of Social Security more than £400 million, but depriving the rural post offices both of cash and regular customers.

The automation of benefit payments, due to be phased in over two years from 2003, is likely to destroy village life. For generations, the rural post office has been a focus of social interaction and often the commercial bedrock of many village shops.

The Industry Secretary, Stephen Byers, has promised people will still be able to collect their benefits from the local post office even if they do have a bank account but the fall-off in business is likely to mean that rural post offices will have to diversify quickly. Nearly 40 per cent of rural post offices' income is derived from the Benefits Agency.

The threat to the Post Office is probably also the single biggest threat to Labour MPs in rural areas and dominates much regional and local press coverage. Ministers have already announced they are spending £480m automating the Post Office Counters network.

This will put the entire 18,500-strong network online by spring 2001. In his recent rural tour of the South West, Tony Blair promised to see post offices provided with cash dispensers. fields.bodyText: The village post office will never be the same. Me.Gov, an Internet site covering advice on every aspect of public services, is to be installed in thousands of post offices as the centrepiece of the Government's new rural electronic revolution. Billed by Downing Street as Tony Blair's first big idea for a second-term Labour government, the website will provide help on banking, benefits, job vacancies, education, health and local transport. The single portal or gateway will offer a range of services, providing 'a personal window' on government. Customers will be offered prompts or reminders when services change or when important dates approach, such as tax self-assessment deadlines. The commercial contract for the full development of Me.Gov will be announced this month. Access to the service is likely to be initially through a password based on a National Insurance number. One of the first services to go online will be a Learning and Education Bank providing details of all 400,000 job vacancies notified to the Employment Service. Over time, Ministers plan to add a Europe-wide job vacancy programme. The service, being un-veiled this week by David Blunkett, the Education Secretary, will also give details of local job training and skills programmes for the unemployed. In urban areas, the network is likely to be sited in shopping centres, Job Centres or special kiosks. Within 10 years, many of the services could be provided through digital TV in individuals' homes. A new role for the local post office in rural communities is seen by the Government as politically urgent. The post office network is under severe threat from Government plans to pay key benefits, such as pensions, through automatic cash transfer into people's bank accounts, saving the Department of Social Security more than £400 million, but depriving the rural post offices both of cash and regular customers. The automation of benefit payments, due to be phased in over two years from 2003, is likely to destroy village life. For generations, the rural post office has been a focus of social interaction and often the commercial bedrock of many village shops. The Industry Secretary, Stephen Byers, has promised people will still be able to collect their benefits from the local post office even if they do have a bank account but the fall-off in business is likely to mean that rural post offices will have to diversify quickly. webTitle: Bishop tried to cover up giant penis

fields.headline: Bishop tried to cover up giant penis
fields.trailText: The prehistoric chalk drawing of the Cerne Giant and his erect penis, carved on to a Dorset hillside, is Britain's most famous phallus. Some believe the Giant has fertility powers and many couples go there to have sex on its 26ft penis, hoping to have children.
fields.body:
The prehistoric chalk drawing of the Cerne Giant and his erect penis, carved on to a Dorset hillside, is Britain's most famous phallus. Some believe the Giant has fertility powers and many couples go there to have sex on its 26ft penis, hoping to have children.

Yet, according to confidential 1930s government documents retrieved from the Public Records Office, the Home Office was forced to consider covering up the genitalia after a complaint from the Bishop of Salisbury. One witty suggestion was to plant a grove of fig trees in a strategic position.

Home Office minutes, dated November 1932 and discovered by historian Dr A. D. Harvey, reveal the bishop objected to the 'indecent pubus' and wanted it made 'less objectionable'.

The civil servant charged with the task describes the complaint as a 'serious charge of indecency against a prehistoric national monument'. In the minute he revealed that he had approached the National Trust, which rejected the complaint because it had a duty to 'conserve and not to deface'.

The exasperated civil servant asks rhetorically: 'What does the complainant want us to do? Commit a nameless outrage? We cannot contemplate that. Plant a small grove of fig trees in a strategic position? We have not got the power.'

His suggestion is to write to the bishop saying the Home Secretary has found the figure is 'a prehistoric national monument, scheduled as such and listed by the National Trust. It has been in existence for over 2,000 years and no previous complaint has been registered. The Secretary of State regrets that he cannot see a way to take any action in the matter.'

The letter was copied to the Chief Constable of Dorset. A note in the margins from the head of the Home Office's children branch suggests the bishop has 'probably overlooked the legal maxim, de maximus ni curat lex - the law does not apply to giants!'

fields.headline: Euro court hands killers £1,000
fields.standfirst: Executive faces paying compensation to convicted murderers as Scots law on bail is found to be at odds with European Convention
fields.trailText: Executive faces paying compensation to convicted murderers as Scots law on bail is found to be at odds with European Convention
fields.body:
Convicted killers could get £1,000 in compensation from the Scottish Executive because Scots law on bail proceedings breaks the European Convention on Human Rights.

The Observer' s revelation adds to a list of legal hiccups which have brought into question civil servants' state of readiness for the introduction of the convention into Scottish law.

The Executive plans to change the law within two months to remove the anomaly over bail for murderers, but any case before that date could be open to challenge. Last week the European Court of Human Rights awarded £1,000 to a man convicted of manslaughter because he had been denied his basic rights when applying for bail.

The problem is simple. Article 5, paragraph three, of the convention states that the first judge a person accused of a killing sees must have the power to grant bail. That is impossible under Scots law. An accused will first see a sheriff, who has no powers to grant bail in cases of murder. The accused must apply for bail by making a specific plea to the High Court after seeing the sheriff.

Clive Caballero had already been convicted of manslaughter when he faced new charges of rape. His solicitor didn't apply for bail as, under English law, bail cannot be granted to a defendant with a previous serious conviction. He was subsequently convicted of the rape.

Caballero argued that being refused the option of bail was a violation of the European Convention. The European Court of Human Rights found unanimously in his favour and awarded him £1,000 in damages and £15,250 costs and expenses, less the amount received in legal aid from the Council of Europe.

Legal experts say the same could occur in Scotland. Though the law is different on the point of bail between the two countries, they both automatically deny bail in certain categories of crime. 'There is no doubt Scots law falls foul of the European Convention on this point,' said Professor Allan Miller of Strathclyde University.

Tory leader David McLetchie raised the issue in Holyrood during Thursday's debate on the impact of the convention on Scots law. 'Some believe that the current situation with regard to bail for murder is in breach of ECHR; because a sheriff does not have the power to authorise bail in such cases, it could be argued that bringing someone before a court without the necessary power to authorise their release on bail infringes their rights under Article 5 of the convention.'

His suspicion was right. Justice Minister Jim Wallace admitted as much in his response, but only said the executive was monitoring the impact of the Caballero case. 'We have taken note of the recent judgment in the European Court of Human Rights in the case of Caballero v United Kingdom and will consider our response to that. If that requires legislation, I will bring proposals to the Parliament. We are trying both to anticipate and to react.'

The law regarding bail is just the latest in a string of cases where the introduction of the ECHR will alter Scots law. The use of temporary sheriffs was found illegal last year and recently Section 172 of the Traffic Act was deemed at fault under the European Convention.

As The Observer exclusively reported a month ago, the Scottish Executive is conducting an audit of Scots law and governmental practice to see what else needs to be changed under the ECHR. It is expected that the treatment of children in the legal system and legal aid arrangements will also have to be altered.

The audit must be completed within months as the entire statute book must be compatible with the convention by October, when it is incorporated into UK law.
