webTitle: Egos fight over the soul of Scotland

fields.headline: Egos fight over the soul of Scotland
fields.standfirst:
They once were colleagues and friends - but now two newspaper editors are at war over a nation's future
Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText:
'[Jaspan]has been vociferous in the devolution debate [but he] barely knew where Scotland was when I sent him up from London a decade ago'
Andrew Neil
fields.body:
'[Jaspan]has been vociferous in the devolution debate [but he] barely knew where Scotland was when I sent him up from London a decade ago'
Andrew Neil

'The strain is obviously getting to Neil. He is a man rattled, running out of excuses for the poor performance of his papers. The problem is that Neil simply doesn't get it'
Andrew Jaspan

He gave him his big break and made him a broadsheet editor. The two men have shared jobs, offices and a view of the world. But now they are fighting a newspaper war that would impress even the most foul-mouthed tabloid editor.

On one side is Andrew 'bulldog in a china shop' Neil, editor-in-chief of the Scotsman, Scotland on Sunday and Sunday Business. Squaring up is the editor of Scotland's Sunday Herald, Andrew 'wee Jocky' Jaspan - the man who brought the Friday night pizzas when he worked for Neil on the Sunday Times and became so close to him that he was dubbed 'son of Neil'.

The clash of inky egos is so bitter it has escalated into a battle for the soul of the Scottish press and the future of Scotland: Neil, the Paisley-born right-wing Presbyterian who loathes Scotland's left-leaning Establishment, versus the Manchester-born Jaspan, who says he loves life north of the border so much he feels Scottish.

Their spat exposes the deep divide between tartan tigers, such as Jaspan, who say the Scottish Parliament has won the right to govern north of the border, and bitter-end Unionists, such as Neil, who believe the country's governing classes are not up to the job and should hand back control to Westminster.

The name-calling began when Neil sacked the editor of the Scotsman , Irishman Alan Ruddock. Neil told friends that Jaspan, an award-winning former editor of the Scotsman , Scotland on Sunday and The Observer , 'would beat the bullet train to Edinburgh' to edit the Scotsman . Jaspan, who has beaten Fleet Street's big guns to win a series of press awards including editor of the year, denied the claim. He would never work for Neil because he was a 'meddling bloody nightmare'.

Neil, who regards the Sunday Herald as little more than a college rag, lost his temper and used his Scotsman column to rubbish his protégé, who got his big break when Neil made him editor of the Sunday Times' Scottish edition 10 years ago. Jaspan, Neil wrote, filled his paper with 'drivel' which was designed to prop up members of the new Scottish Parliament who have been accused of pocket-stuffing and laziness.

'That is the predictable behaviour of low-grade politicians. It is dismaying to see the media joining in.'

In a personal demolition job on his former friend, Neil said: 'Even English editors of Scottish newspapers are at it. One who has been particularly vociferous in the devolution cause barely knew where Scotland was when I sent him up from London to Glasgow almost a decade ago.

'I remember him asking me if he would need to show his passport at the airport. Now he lectures me on Scottish patriotism.' In a 1,400-word editorial last week Jaspan hit back at the great Chieftain of Holyrood - the new home of the Scotsman . 'The strain is obviously getting to Andrew Neil. He is a man rattled, running out of excuses for the poor performance of his papers. The problem is that Neil simply doesn't get it. Much like the European , which he turned into the Anti-European and finally destroyed, he is well on the way with the anti-Scotland Scotsman .'

He dismissed as 'a big lie' Neil's claim that the Sunday Herald only sold 38,000 copies. It was 55,000 copies. 'What, of course, Neil wishes to draw a veil over is his record since taking over the Scotsman in 1997. Sales have fallen from an average 82,000 to barely 74,000.'

Neil lived 'in a virtual reality world between the Channel Islands, Nice, Manhattan and occasionally Scotland,' he added last week. 'Andrew is not happy about playing in "scrappy little Scotland". It irritates the f*** out of him. He is just taking out his frustrations on me.'

The spat may sound like media navel-gazing but behind the columns of print lies a battle for the soul of the new Scotland. The Scotsman is more than just an Edinburgh daily: it is Scotland's national newspaper. For years editors have backed devolution because they reckoned an Edinburgh parliament would be good for politics and even better for newspaper sales.

The new millennium has brought Edinburgh an economic boom and big hikes in property prices as well as the Parliament but, as Jaspan points out, sales of the Scotsman are at a 10-year low. Crit ics say Neil's attempt to use the Scotsman to do what Tony Blair has failed to achieve - force Middle-English, market-driven policies down Scottish throats - has alienated readers.

His excoriating criticism of teachers and Edinburgh's 'blethering classes' has caused much single-malt spluttering in the leather armchairs of the New Club, where the city's grandees end the day. Readers complain that the Scotsman hates Scotland as it is and wishes it would become like somewhere else - say, Guildford.

It does not help that Neil has just appointed an ambitious, Home Counties-educated Daily Mail executive - Rebecca Hardy - as deputy editor. 'Just when it should be more Scottish than ever the Scotsman is looking south. It's lost its soul,' one hack laments.

As the presses rolled last night, there was no end in sight to the tartan bickering. 'Poor wee Jocky,' Neil told The Observer . 'I just love tweaking his little tail. I spend 10 minutes a week writing a few paragraphs in my Scotsman column just for fun and he spends 10 hours responding with a 1,800-word article.

'To me it's just a joke, a bit of fun. But he seems to take it all so seriously. Maybe he's pissed off he was not considered for the Scotsman job. After what I have said this week I am looking forward to being the front-page splash tomorrow and on pages 2, 3, 4 and 5, with a 2,000-word profile in the magazine.'

In his Glasgow office Jaspan hit back: 'That piece I wrote was 1,400 words long, not 1,800, but then Andrew has never been good at sums. It took me just over an hour to do, so clearly he writes much more slowly than I do and also my lips don't move.

'Personally, I couldn't give a fart about egos. I am just delighted that Andrew has used his column to give us vast acres of free publicity while turning the Scotsman into a parish paper.'

webTitle: Wake up, it's an alien on line one

fields.headline: Wake up, it's an alien on line one
fields.standfirst: British scientists are at the heart of a new project to answer the old question - is there anybody out there?
fields.trailText: At 2.10am last Friday, astronomer Ian Morison was wakened by his pager. It bore a message from another world.
fields.body:
At 2.10am last Friday, astronomer Ian Morison was wakened by his pager. It bore a message from another world.

The giant Jodrell Bank radio telescope, on which Morison is working, had picked up a signal from a distant star, a series of electromagnetic pulses that suggested they had been transmitted deliberately by an extraterrestrial intelligence.

The signal had originally been detected by the giant US radio antennae at Arecibo, in Puerto Rico, and was then instantly relayed to the network of computers at Manchester University's Jodrell Bank dish. Details were then paged to Morison.

The origin of the emission seemed to be coming from a region of space around HD-124570, a star very like our own sun but slighter hotter that lies a mere 108 light years from Earth, effectively part of our galactic backyard. Could this be proof, at last, that we were not alone in the universe, wondered Morison?

He soon had his answer. 'Within minutes, a series of automatic checks were carried out by devices at Arecibo and Jodrell, and sadly we had to rule out HD-124570,' he said. 'It turned out that the signal was coming from a satellite in the same general direction.'

Undeterred, scientists over the next two weeks will be scanning the skies for a real signal from real aliens. And if they succeed, they will do so thanks to Project Phoenix, a remarkable collaboration in which Jodrell and Arecibo scientists are combining their efforts in a search for extra-terrestrial intelligence (Seti). For British scientists, it is their first serious search for civilisations in outer space.

Several Seti projects are being undertaken across the globe but Project Phoenix uses two of the world's greatest radio telescopes and remains mankind's best hope for detecting little green men.

Twice a year, for 25 days, scientists will scan the most promising stars in our galactic neighbourhood to see if any sentient, alien civilisations are beaming out a signal to let us know they want a chat.

The project was officially launched last year but was hampered by hurricanes that swept Puerto Rico, and mechanical problems at Jodrell Bank. But now the teams are carrying out their first sweeps of our galaxy's most promising life-bearing solar systems. These worlds will have to orbit hot, long-living stars, say astronomers. Stars that are too cool will not be able to warm planets sufficiently to sustain life, while short-lived stars will not be able to supply this sustenance long enough for complex life to evolve.

Over the next five years, Project Phoenix scientists plan to complete an exhaustive search of the entire radio spectrum of emissions of 1,000 nearby stars using equipment that will automatically pinpoint narrow-band broadcasts - the hallmark of a deliberately transmitted signal.

The telescopes are undertaking a search daily from 10pm to 10am, and are being used in unison because they can detect minute differences in the wavelengths of a broadcast and determine within minutes whether it is local, or coming from something beyond Jupiter. Half a dozen stars an evening will be surveyed this way, and one night astronomers may get lucky.

If they do, it will utterly transform mankind's image of itself. We will have clear evidence that alien civilisations are common and we are Uriah Heeps - just an ever-so 'umble species in a galaxy teeming with intelligent creatures. Alternatively, astronomers may continue to draw blanks. The former scenario suggests technological civilisations can be stable and long-lasting, the latter would indicate our species is precious and rare.

Until recently, most astronomers assumed we had neighbours. However, some scientists now speculate that we are alone in our galaxy. Two US scientists - geologist Peter Ward and astronomer Donald Brownlee - will this month publish a book, Rare Earth , in which they argue that primitive life may be ubiquitous, but only special conditions in our solar system provide enough stability for it to progress to complex forms. Earth's relatively large moon prevents the planet's axes from wobbling and so stops extreme, devastating climatic swings. Similarly, our giant outer planet Jupiter seems to have swept the inner solar system clean of comets, prevent ing them from crashing and devastating life on Earth.

Other astronomers still argue that life is common in the universe. However no one can be sure. Only a call from ET - and another disturbed night for Ian Morison - could answer that question.

Sixty years of false encounters

1938 Radio version of H.G. Wells's War of the Worlds is produced in the United States by a cast led by Orson Welles. Broadcast leads to widespread panic as listeners believe 'news' of the invading Martians is real.

1947 Roswell, New Mexico. Locals discover pieces of aircraft wreckage and claim it was a spaceship. The story acquires legendary status and is now the basis of a TV series. In fact, the crash involved a weather balloon.

1967 Radio waves discovered that beat with such rapid, regular precision, astronomers initially believe they are listening to 'little green men'. In fact the scientists had discovered pulsars, super-dense stars that emit radiation with clocklike accuracy.

1999 News report about signal detected from star HD 119850 triggers flurry of Internet conspiracy claims that intelligent aliens have been discovered. The signal is actually that of a communications satellite.

Could this be proof, at last, that we were not alone in the universe, wondered Morison? He soon had his answer. 'Within minutes, a series of automatic checks were carried out by devices at Arecibo and Jodrell, and sadly we had to rule out HD-124570,' he said. 'It turned out that the signal was coming from a satellite in the same general direction.' Undeterred, scientists over the next two weeks will be scanning the skies for a real signal from real aliens. And if they succeed, they will do so thanks to Project Phoenix, a remarkable collaboration in which Jodrell and Arecibo scientists are combining their efforts in a search for extra-terrestrial intelligence (Seti). For British scientists, it is their first serious search for civilisations in outer space. Several Seti projects are being undertaken across the globe but Project Phoenix uses two of the world's greatest radio telescopes and remains mankind's best hope for detecting little green men. Twice a year, for 25 days, scientists will scan the most promising stars in our galactic neighbourhood to see if any sentient, alien civilisations are beaming out a signal to let us know they want a chat. The project was officially launched last year but was hampered by hurricanes that swept Puerto Rico, and mechanical problems at Jodrell Bank. But now the teams are carrying out their first sweeps of our galaxy's most promising life-bearing solar systems. These worlds will have to orbit hot, long-living stars, say astronomers. Stars that are too cool will not be able to warm planets sufficiently to sustain life, while short-lived stars will not be able to supply this sustenance long enough for complex life to evolve. Over the next five years, Project Phoenix scientists plan to complete an exhaustive search of the entire radio spectrum of emissions of 1,000 nearby stars using equipment that will automatically pinpoint narrow-band broadcasts - the hallmark of a deliberately transmitted signal. The telescopes are undertaking a search daily from 10pm to 10am, and are being used in unison because they can detect minute differences in the wavelengths of a broadcast and determine within minutes whether it is local, or coming from something beyond Jupiter. Half a dozen stars an evening will be surveyed this way, and one night astronomers may get lucky. If they do, it will utterly transform mankind's image of itself. We will have clear evidence that alien civilisations are common and we are Uriah Heeps - just an ever-so 'umble species in a galaxy teeming with intelligent creatures. Alternatively, astronomers may continue to draw blanks. The former scenario suggests technological civilisations can be stable and long-lasting, the latter would indicate our species is precious and rare. Until recently, most astronomers assumed we had neighbours. However, some scientists now speculate that we are alone in our galaxy. Two US scientists - geologist Peter Ward and astronomer Donald Brownlee - will this month publish a book, Rare Earth , in which they argue that primitive life may be ubiquitous, but only special conditions in our solar system provide enough stability for it to progress to complex forms. Earth's relatively large moon prevents the planet's axes from wobbling and so stops extreme, devastating climatic swings. Similarly, our giant outer planet Jupiter seems to have swept the inner solar system clean of comets, prevent ing them from crashing and devastating life on Earth. Other astronomers still argue that life is common in the universe. However no one can be sure. Only a call from ET - and another disturbed night for Ian Morison - could answer that question. Sixty years of false encounters 1938 Radio version of H.G. Wells's War of the Worlds is produced in the United States by a cast led by Orson Welles. Broadcast leads to widespread panic as listeners believe 'news' of the invading Martians is real. 1947 Roswell, New Mexico. Locals discover pieces of aircraft wreckage and claim it was a spaceship. The story acquires legendary status and is now the basis of a TV series. In fact, the crash involved a weather balloon. 1967 Radio waves discovered that beat with such rapid, regular precision, astronomers initially believe they are listening to 'little green men'. In fact the scientists had discovered pulsars, super-dense stars that emit radiation with clocklike accuracy. 1999 News report about signal detected from star HD 119850 triggers flurry of Internet conspiracy claims that intelligent aliens have been discovered. The signal is actually that of a communications satellite.  Email Robin Mckie at robin.mckie@observer.co.uk

webTitle: A man of many words and few teeth

fields.headline: A man of many words and few teeth
fields.standfirst: It's no surprise to find the former Pogues frontman clutching a gin bottle - after all, wasn't he thrown out of the Priory recently? But it is odd to find him not drinking a drop from it :   'I'm completely Irish' he says in a completely English accent. He dismisses England as a 'miserable, boring, stupid waste of time'

But it is odd to find him not drinking a drop from it :   'I'm completely Irish' he says in a completely English accent. He dismisses England as a 'miserable, boring, stupid waste of time'
fields.body:
Rock'n'roll offers two long-term career paths: death or confession. Sooner or later, you either join the ranks of casualties (Elvis, Hendrix, Vicious) or rehabilitated survivors (Eric Clapton, Steve Tyler, Elton John). Actually, there is a third option. You could be Shane MacGowan.

For the best part of two decades the former frontman and songwriter for the Pogues has been treading a precarious path between addiction and annihilation. During that period his uncompromising lifestyle has gained a near-mythical status; a point neatly illustrated by the titles of a forthcoming book, Is Shane MacGowan Still Alive? and a new comic strip in Viz magazine, The Adventures of Little Shane MacGowan .

The 42-year-old man who shuffled into the Mean Fiddler in Harlesden, north London, last week was, if not very much alive, then certainly some way from dead. Clutching a bottle of gin at four in the afternoon, he looked as though he had just awoken, which, as it turned out, he had. He had been up till six that morning entertaining an Irish film crew that is making a documentary about him.

Dressed in a black suit decorated with unspecified stains, he cut a curiously equivocal figure: gloriously resilient, yet somehow pathetically resigned.

His appearance, of course, has long drawn comment. The jug ears and, in particular, the unique dental arrangement - his teeth look as if they had been removed and then randomly reassembled in unlikely parts of his mouth - have come to symbolise his indifference to the usual cosmetic vanities of rock stars.

Stranger than the teeth, though, is the fact that beneath the lank hair and the outlaw beard, MacGowan's skin looks unnaturally healthy, even youthful. Although pallid, there are few signs of wear and tear. Some years back, he fell out of a tour van that was moving at about 50mph. But there's not so much now as a cracked vein.

A couple of weeks ago it was reported he had been thrown out of the Priory clinic, after the latest in a series of abortive attempts over the years to dry out.

His two-week admission to a detoxification programme followed an incident last November in which singer Sinead O'Connor, MacGowan's erstwhile friend, contacted the police to allege that he had been taking heroin.

She has said it was an act of tough love. 'I love Shane and it makes me angry to see him destroy himself selfishly in front of those who love him.'

While he readily admits his alcoholism, MacGowan denies that he is addicted to any drug.

He was reluctant to discuss the matter at first, but changed his mind and responded to O'Connor's claim. 'I might as well clear up the fact that she's made out I was lying on the floor in a coma, whereas in fact I was sitting on the sofa having a G and T and watching a Sam Peckinpah movie, Cross of Iron .'

He sidestepped my inquiries about the hospitality of the Priory. 'The priory? It had a love cross outside, it was full of priests. They were buggering each other.'

When I suggested he must at times have been a cause of great concern to his friends, he paused for a second, and then said: 'I've heard a lot of people who whinge about how worried they are about me. How much it is to practise their acting techniques in case they're ever in a soap opera, I don't know.'

The disagreement between MacGowan and O'Connor brings into opposition two people who have in their differing ways revolutionised outdated images of Ireland and yet, at the same time, have managed to represent the two most dogged Irish clichés: the romantic boozer and the religious nut. O'Connor recently restyled herself as a priest called Mother Bernadette.

It was noticeable that, despite holding on to the bottle of gin and also accepting a can of lager chaser, MacGowan didn't take so much as a sip from either in the hour we spent together. I wondered how aware he was of his own mythology.

'I'm aware of it,' he said, 'but I don't think about it. I don't think. You know, William Burroughs said "exterminate all rational thought".'

He once said, by way of explanation for his thirsty proclivities, that 'you don't join a band to drink milk'. In the end, it was his drinking and drug use that saw him thrown out of the Pogues in 1991.

He later formed the Popes, a loose combination of backing musicians he occasionally fronts.

Bono, one of the many musicians who have paid tribute to MacGowan's talents as a songwriter, has said he thinks much of his self-destructive posturing is 'a mask, it's a way of ignoring people who he just doesn't want to deal with. Shane is more together than people imagine'.

If it is a mask, it's one he seems incapable of removing. He's certainly more articulate than he lets on. Once edited, MacGowan is an impressively fluent speaker. However, his raw conversation is littered with multiple 'likes' and 'ers' and 'yeahs' and 'd'you know what I means'.

The combined effect makes the mock-street talk of, say, Mick Jagger sound like Prince Charles.

Although born and raised in England (he gained a scholarship to Westminster public school), save for the six years he spent with his grandparents in Tipperary from the age of three months, MacGowan is defiantly Irish.

'I'm completely Irish,' he said in an accent that is completely English. He says he had his original voice 'kicked out' of him. He described his feelings on first arriving in England as 'disgust, hatred, fear, loathing', and went on to dismiss England as 'a miserable, stinking, boring, stupid, useless waste of a time'.

As we were both being filmed by the Irish documentary team, I suspected some of this invective was not for my benefit but for that of the viewers - the programme is to be broadcast on the Irish-language channel Telefis na Gaelige - who he may have assumed would be more sympathetic.

In the Eighties, on Pogues albums such as Rum, Sodomy and the Lash and If I Should Fall From Grace with God , MacGowan penned a number of hauntingly memorable ballads that drew on the experience of the Irish diaspora.

Although often traditional in form, they were uncannily vivid and determinedly irreverent. They were unmistakably Irish, but viewed from another perspective; viewed, in fact, from England. Perhaps this was the reason MacGowan endured a life here that was not to his liking, so that he was brought close to his subject of the uprooted.

He bristled at the idea and told me he spent half his time in Ireland now anyway, and this country provided him with no helpful viewpoint. He's currently working on an album entitled Twentieth-Century Paddy .

'All Irish people born in the twentieth century are paddies,' he explained.

'It's going to be about IRA men, lonely farmers that hang themselves because they can't get a wife. One is based on my mother who got into modelling and was then voted Colleen of the Year in 1954.'

I had heard that a young man had not long ago died of an overdose in MacGowan's Camden Town flat. Taking everything into account, did he think about death much himself?

'Death pops up every now and again on the old cinema in the back of my head. And I've seen a lot of death. Like any other human being, I wouldn't invite death.'

He told me he had once come close to dying and he had prayed to the Holy Ghost. 'I was screaming at him: "You fucking bastard, I have faith in you. Now fucking show yourself and get me out of this bed". I made an absolute recovery mentally and physically. I'm from sturdy peasant stock.'

How was he feeling now? With the untouched gin in one hand and an unlit cigarette in the other, he fixed me with a wide-eyed stare and said: 'Fine.'

fields.headline: Edward's mansion cost us £1.8m
fields.standfirst: The future of the monarchy: special report
fields.trailText: Almost £2 million of taxpayers' money was channelled into renovating Prince Edward's country mansion, despite Buckingham Palace's insistence that no public funds were used in the controversial project.
fields.body:
Almost £2 million of taxpayers' money was channelled into renovating Prince Edward's country mansion, despite Buckingham Palace's insistence that no public funds were used in the controversial project.

The Observer has learnt that the Ministry of Defence handed over £1.8m to the Crown Estate - the body that manages all royal property - for renovating Bagshot Park.

The 120-year-old former Army property is the home of Edward and the Countess of Wessex. The 88-acre property is also the headquarters of the Earl of Wessex's ailing television company, Ardent Productions. In 1997, Edward signed a secret 50-year lease with the Crown Estate and then agreed a refurbishment contract with builders C J Sims for £1.8m - the amount covered by the MoD funds.

The prince has since refused to pay a penny more, despite Sims demanding £600,000 for extra work it claims that Edward insisted upon. The company has since collapsed and blames Edward's 'dithering' over colour schemes and wallpaper for raising the cost. Other extras included a 'hotel-style' bathroom with matching sinks, gold-plated taps and towel rails.

MPs have expressed outrage at this use of public funds. Liberal Democrat frontbench spokesman Norman Baker said: 'It is astonishing the Ministry of Defence, which was unable to find £2m for Mozambique, paid nearly £2m to help renovate a home for one of the richest families in the world.'

Labour's Harry Cohen, a member of the defence select committee, said: 'It's shocking. There appears to be a sleight of hand here. Although the prince may not have received the MoD money directly, he still benefited.'

Baker has demanded details of the lease between the Crown Estate and the prince be made public and called for the public accounts committee to investigate the royal finances.

Last month The Observer disclosed that public funds were channelled into the project, despite the Palace's insistence this was not the case. Both the Government and the Crown Estate refused to give any other details.

Following further media inquiries the MoD admitted money had been paid but played down the amount. Even when two MPs tabled written questions, Defence Minister Dr Lewis Moonie avoided giving an answer.

Last Wednesday Moonie finally came clean over the MoD payment of £1.8m when Baker tabled a fresh parliamentary question.

It had long been a mystery how Edward could afford such an expensive restoration. He receives £96,000 a year from the queen for royal expenses, and his businesses are losing money.

The Crown Estate received the £1.8m from the MoD after September 1996 when it regained the lease from the Ministry. Under the terms of the lease the MoD, which had occupied the property since the end of the war, was required to return the building to a habitable state. The Crown Estate demanded £1.8m from the MoD and then struck a secret deal with Prince Edward, understood to be around £50,000 a year. But there still remain questions over how the prince paid the repair bills.

The Observer has established that he set up a shell company called Eclipse Nominees to run the contract. Monthly cheques for the work came from the prince's account at Coutts, but it is not known what the source of this cash was. If the Crown Estate passed the £1.8m to the prince in advance, it is possible Edward earned tens of thousands of pounds in interest, indirectly, from the MoD money.

A Buckingham Palace spokesman refused to give details saying: 'This is an entirely private matter between the prince and the Crown Estate. The repairs to Bagshot Park would have had to be carried out whoever had the lease.'

The Crown Estate also refused to give details.

fields.headline: Ahern: ceasefires are holding
fields.standfirst:
Taoiseach at odds with Britain on level of paramilitary threat

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, insisted yesterday that the main terrorist groups were maintaining their ceasefires despite warnings from the British Home Office that paramilitaries were gearing up to go back to war.
fields.body:
The Taoiseach, Bertie Ahern, insisted yesterday that the main terrorist groups were maintaining their ceasefires despite warnings from the British Home Office that paramilitaries were gearing up to go back to war.

Speaking before the Fianna Fail Ard Fheis in Dublin, Ahern said the groups threatening the peace process were few in number.

'There is no knowledge and no intelligence or information from main paramilitary groups on ceasefire. It has been well known for a long time that the security forces north and south of the border and in Britain have been very concerned about groups of dissidents,' he said. Ahern described the Home Office warnings as 'very worrying'.

The Irish Prime Minister used the Ard Fheis to repeat his demand that the Sellafield nuclear reprocessing plant be shut down.

Describing the plant as a threat to Ireland, Ahern told 5,000 delegates: 'We will not flinch from our objective. The closure of Sellafield remains a priority for this government.'Meanwhile Seamus Mallon, the SDLP deputy leader, accused Peter Mandel son yesterday of being absent without leave while the peace process faltered.

Mallon criticised the Northern Ireland Secretary for attending a conflict resolution conference in Israel at a time when the British and Irish governments should be trying to rescue the Northern Ireland peace process.

The Newry and Armagh MP also hit out at Dublin for spending more time at the conference in Tel Aviv than on the political deadlock closer to home.

'Conflict resolution at a conference in Israel while we have the problem sitting on our own doorstep doesn't seem to be the most urgent way of going about dealing with it,' Mallon said.

He contrasted the two governments' lack of action with the mood building since the suspension of the power-sharing executive last month.

'Look at the gable ends of walls in hardline republican and loyalist areas - you see the change in tone in the graffiti,' he said.

The comments by the former Deputy First Minister of Northern Ireland come after a Home Office report, compiled before the renewal of the Prevention of Terrorism Act, claimed recent arms and explosives seizures indicated that terror groups were gearing up for war.

Jeffrey Donaldson, the Ulster Unionist MP for Lagan Valley, demanded yesterday that the Home Office state explicitly which groups were preparing to resume violence.

The Irish government's view of the current impasse is that the parties should be allowed a period of reflection before re-entering new negotiations after St Patrick's Day celebrations in Washington, at which several of the leading players will meet President Clinton. Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein President, said he saw little chance of a breakthrough in the peace process in the near future.

fields.headline: Watchdog to cut power of BBC governors powers
fields.standfirst: The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: A new watchdog body for broadcasting is to be set up, curbing the powers of the BBC's Board of Governors.
fields.body:
A new watchdog body for broadcasting is to be set up, curbing the powers of the BBC's Board of Governors.

The move to create the new regulator, dubbed OfCom, is being championed by officials in the Department of Culture, Media and Sport as part of a Broadcasting and Communications White Paper.

Culture Secretary Chris Smith is believed to favour a modernised system of regulation for the BBC, which he believes enjoys too cosy a relationship with its governors. The move will be fiercely resisted by the BBC, which fears interference by politicians. A well-placed source predicted: 'There will be a very big row about this over the next few months'.

Officials believe the rise in the licence fee to finance the BBC's digital broadcasting, adding an extra £200 million a year to its £2.75 billion budget, has increased the need for a new regulator. There has also been anger at the slow response of the governors to criticism of the new BBC Director-General, Greg Dyke, for retaining shares in a rival commercial TV company.

Gavyn Davies, who chaired a committee looking at funding for the BBC, said yesterday: 'The governors are seen as part of the home team in the BBC. Many people are very sceptical at the idea they are representatives of the licence fee payer, regulating the use of £2.27bn a year.'

The governors are based at BBC headquarters. The staff, from inside the BBC, have to reconcile dual loyalty to the management and the board.

fields.standfirst: If it's Wednesday it must be... Dad's house. Increasing numbers of children have two homes, and new research suggests this is no bad thing

fields.body:
Rosie, nine years old, is concerned for the well-being of children whose parents, unlike hers, have failed to fall out and live their lives apart. 'It must be a bit boring,' she reflects, 'for children who don't have separated parents - well, obviously, unless their parents are separating, because then it's a bit confusing and scary.' This caveat aside, she speculates on what life might be like in an orthodox family unit with a hint of condescension. 'I mean, go to school, go home, just do whatever you do and it's the same every day.'

Rosie's remarks suggest she has been spared the worst pain we expect children to endure as the result of family breakdown. They also indicate that her contentment may be linked to the unusual arrangements her parents have made for her care. Because although her mother and father no longer live together, she continues to live with both of them, half her time with one, the other half with the other, swapping between them during the week. For some, this may seem intolerable, not least for the child. But for Rosie two homes - and two parents - clearly seem so much better than one.

This post-separation arrangement is known as 'co-parenting' and appears to be on the rise, especially among the liberal middle-classes. For co-parenting to work in practical terms generally requires that the two homes are within easy travelling distance of each other and the children's schools. It also requires both parents to be in a financial position to provide the comforts a child expects in a family home which, given the prevalence of households dependent on dual incomes and the often ruinous financial implications of separation, may not be easy.

But the great potential of co-parenting is that neither parent automatically loses their children, and, most importantly, their children don't automatically lose either of them.

Next week, the findings of research conducted by Carol Smart, Amanda Wade and Bren Neale at the Centre for Research on Family, Kinship and Childhood at the University of Leeds, are published. Focusing on the experience of 65 co-parented children, the results are revealing, not only of the pros and cons of co-parenting in particular, but also in confirming the often remarkable insights of children affected by separation or divorce into their own situations and those of their parents.

The children interviewed for the project ranged in age from four to 17. Although all split their time 50:50 (or sometimes nearer 60:40) between their estranged parents, there were important variations. In some cases, one or both parents had found new partners, meaning that the children had become part of stepfamilies which could include stepsiblings, too. Sometimes, relations between the blood parents were cordial or friendly; sometimes not. Sometimes, the children, like Rosie, felt deeply cherished by their mother and father alike. Others had contrasting feelings about each, and some felt still caught in the crossfire.

Even so, some unifying themes emerged. Most of the children felt it important to have both their parents involved in their lives, and those who had been moving between two different households from an early age regarded it as perfectly routine. Children also identified certain pretty basic advantages arising from their circumstances. Double birthday treats, for instance! Double holidays! Double toys!

Inevitably, there were drawbacks. The more prosaic centred on the simple inconvenience arising from frequent moving back and forth. As the Leeds researchers put it: 'Many of the children spoke of how they kept forgetting where their books were or how they needed to pop back to the other house to fetch something.' This was obviously more of a problem for those whose parents' houses were some distance apart.

But geography was not the only complicating factor. A greater one arose with parents who set down rigid rules against the transfer of belongings between the two homes, especially if one household provided particularly desirable items which the other did not. However, it was much more likely that the children would have problems simply because the general treatment in one home compared poorly with that in the other. This could be a result of individual parents' attitudes or relatively banal domestic matters. For example, some of the children complained that their fathers were poor homemakers. One girl reported particular discomfort with the state of the lavatory at her father's place.

Co-parenting, then, can clearly bring pluses and minuses for children, but if there is a single factor marking success from failure, it is probably the degree of continuing, conspicuous ill-feeling between Mum and Dad - inevitable though that sometimes is. A previous research project among adolescent children in the United States found that, in general, children who maintained close ties with both parents fared better than those who didn't. However, it also discovered that a majority of adolescents living in two homes (in this case not necessarily for equal amounts of time) reported experiencing 'loyalty conflicts' as a result. Co-parenting ex-partners need to be mindful of these.

The new work from the Leeds team is especially fascinating for its insights into co-parented children's capacity for 'moral reasoning' about their circumstances. There is a wealth of testimony to even quite young children's wishes to be fair to both their parents, to care for their needs and to have their own needs and wishes properly respected. These themes emerged time and time again, demonstrating that, far from being passive objects of concern, the children were equipped to make significant contributions to discussions about their dual-family set-ups.

Other research shows that such capacities are not limited to co-parented, mostly middle-class children like these. It is, nonetheless, impressive to see their sophisticated grasps of the difficult dilemmas they sometimes faced, such as the fact that a parent who only sees you half the time might like it if you weren't always off out with your mates. The children also had good ideas concerning practical arrangements.

For example, many found the transition from one household to another far easier if a school day provided a buffer period than if changeovers took place at weekends. Co-parenting remains a suitable case for further research. But the Leeds team emphasise one particular conclusion: 'Although divorce and parental separation causes disruption and problems for children there are reasons to be optimistic about how children can rise to the demands of post-divorce family life, particularly if they are in a position to participate in how their new lives are run.'

Rosie seems to bear this out. There's only one thing in her split family life that she would like to change: 'For there to be eight days in the week.' And what difference that would make? 'Four days with both people!'

What the children say

Tom B, 11 'Even though Mum and Dad don't love each other, they're still very kind to each other, and they just get on really well, even when we swap over.'

Lisa, 8 'You miss the parent and you can't really stop missing them until you see them again.'

Nick, 14 'It's almost made it easier, our mum and dad not living together, because before there was arguments and things like that and it was really difficult to live. But now that they've moved apart they're both much happier and more relaxed.'

Claudia, 12 'It's a bit hard [when my parents argue] because both of them want different things and if you agree with one, then the other one will feel a bit upset. I mean, they won't say that to you, but you can sense it.'

Anna, 16 'I'm just so used to it I can hardly imagine it any other way. There's a good side and a bad side to it. As there is with everything.'

James, 12, was asked: 'Has your relationship with your dad changed at all?' He replied: 'I appreciate him more. Sort of think about it more. Whereas before I just took it for granted that he was there.'

Caroline, 17 'I wanted to split [my time between my parents] because I wanted to keep my mum happy still and I wanted to keep my dad happy. So I thought, a week each. But my mum didn't want that. She wouldn't let me bring anything to my dad's house, nothing at all. When you're that young you have teddy bears and stuff like that. The only way I could get things out was by hiding them. I kept trying to take a photograph with me. I'd put it in my bag and then Mum would find it and take it out. Eventually she just ripped them up... I could never talk to her properly. I really did dislike her for what she was doing.'

Tom G, 12, was asked to suggest a way out of a hypothetical situation in which two sisters decided they were happy to be co-parented but their older brother wanted to live only with his father. Tom concluded: '[His age] would make a difference because if he's too young he's making the wrong decision, I would say. If he's over 13, it's his decision. But I wouldn't want that because you can't really have a life without both parents... the mum's meant to be there and the dad's meant to be there. That's how we've come to be a big civilisation, us humans.'

 A free copy of the findings of the Leeds University co-parenting report can be obtained from Michael Wylie at the Economic and Social Research Council, tel 01793 413122. The names of all children quoted in this article have been changed

fields.headline: My luxury? Less advice
fields.standfirst: Should it be Dylan the First or Dylan the Second? Verdi or Tallis?  Robert McCrum,  The Observer 's literary editor, relives his anxieties before being cast away on today's  Desert Island Discs
fields.trailText: Should it be Dylan the First or Dylan the Second? Verdi or Tallis?  Robert McCrum,  The Observer 's literary editor, relives his anxieties before being cast away on today's  Desert Island Discs
fields.body:
'Wagner!' as an Observer colleague stood over my desk and uttered this duosyllabic Teutonic command, I began to realise that to be invited to join Sue Lawley on Roy Plomley's Desert Island was not the prelude to a prolonged and dreamy reverie on the escapist satisfactions of solitude. Not at all. Everyone wanted to come.

From the minute the faxed invitation arrived, I lost all control - such as it is - of my destiny. Overnight, I became the helpless trustee of a peculiar set of uniquely British fantasies and ambitions, the seemingly universal urge (paradoxical in a nation widely believed to be tight-lipped) to talk to a comparative stranger about one's private life with an audience of millions of radio listeners.

'Wagner,' repeated my colleague. 'You've got to choose some Wagner.'

As I wrestled with this instruction, I grappled internally with a number of existential questions: why me? What did it mean? Why music? Why not books? (I know about books.) How would I prevent myself from appearing like a total idiot?

Taking these in order, I was at first convinced I had been mistaken for someone else, possibly one of my far cleverer and more articulate colleagues (this, apparently, did happen once, with the wrong Alistair Maclean. Old Plomley, a true pro, never missed a beat and the programme was recorded with a straight face, but never aired).

Once I'd cleared up that they were not after Robert McCrum the Arctic explorer or ditto the internationally acclaimed concert pianist, I began to address the larger question in earnest. What would my choice of music signify? What would it say about me? How on earth could I distil a lifetime of experience into just eight records?

What unpalatable insights into my character would my selection unwittingly betray? Could I make a selection which would fool at least some of the audience into mistaking me for a sophisticated and debonair cosmopolitan intellectual?

Like almost every Radio 4 listener in the country, I had a notional selection of discs in my head, didn't I? But as the recording date drew closer, suddenly nothing seemed so clear-cut. Every thing was up for grabs. Was I a Mozart or a Puccini kind of person? Could I plump for Marley over Lennon with a clear conscience?

The advice and assistance, from friends and co-workers, varied by the hour. Had I chosen Dylan? Or Steely Dan? Or Tallis's Spem in Alium ? Or Beethoven's Ninth? When I jotted down my first list it ran to more than 50 nominations, from 'Redemption Song' to Rossini's Petite Messe Solennelle .

Still that nagging question: what kind of person was I? Was I a stuck-up, classical-music trainspotter, spouting opus numbers and crackly vintage recordings ? How embarrassing was it to be unable to think of a single track of popular music after 1975? Could I get away with a selection of Messiaen or Pierre Boulez? And if I chose Schubert's Trout was I an utter prat? If I settled for the Rolling Stones, would I be like Tony Blair wearing easifit blue jeans on the steps of Number 10?

Music I'd taken for granted and listened to with simple pleasure for years suddenly became freighted with new significance. And yes, I adore Spem in Alium , but is it the kind of music I want to listen to over and over again on that tropical isle?

I spoke to my friend Anthony Wall, whose very first assignment at the BBC had been to 'assist' Roy Plomley. Anthony's advice was brilliantly succinct. 'Be yourself,' he said. 'Don't try to fake it.' Oh dear. Out went Beethoven's late string quartets and a pile of exquisite motets by composers with names like Byrd, Cornish, Fayrfax and Hygons.

Not long after this, I began to grapple with the Dylan dilemma. As more or less a child of the Sixties, and a lifelong Americanophile, I had to have some Dylan. But should it be Dylan the First or Dylan the Second? And was there, actually, a Dylan the Third ? And if it was Dylan the First, which song? More consultation inside and outside The Observer . For some, it could only be 'Like a Rolling Stone'; for others, not to have 'Tangled up in Blue' was to commit a sin against the Holy Ghost; still others said that if I omitted 'Positively 4th Street' they would never speak to me again. A hardcore noted that if I did not select 'New Morning', they would do such things (what they were, yet they knew not), but they would be the terror of the Earth. A few clever clogs referred knowingly to Act One of Stoppard's The Real Thing .

And so it went on. My character was continuing to change with disconcerting rapidity. I was giving masterclasses to chameleons. My sense of myself became more and more tenuous. I was now in the middle of a full-blown nervous breakdown and I had not even completed my list. One day, I'd doodle some names and I'd be this wistful, super-aesthetic, hello-sky-hello-clouds romantic, all Elgar, Vaughan Williams and Benjamin Britten, the next I'd be in jackboots and leather, strutting imperiously to the rhythms of Valkyrie and Tannhäuser .

There was a nasty moment when Verdi got into my system, like a computer virus, and I was having later and later nights with recordings of the Requiem with its stirring 'Dies Irae', and then Traviata , with its 'Follie! Delirio vano e questo! ... Sempre libera'. Was I a 'Dies Irae' kind of guy? Surely 'delirio vano e questo' was more my speed? And what about Macbeth (or should it be Falstaff , after all)?

For a little while, I decided to embrace the fact that my taste in popular music was irrevocably formed, like some of the most picturesque parts of the natural world, in the Jurassic Age and - to hell with it - choose from Cream, Procul Harum and the Beach Boys. This mood of nostalgia sent me spinning back to the school concert music of my Cambridge childhood: Beethoven's Fifth, the Moonlight Sonata , the 1812 Overture , the Sorcerer's Apprentice and Holst's Planets .

It was about this time that I came to the conclusion that I fitted Thomas Beecham's view of the English: 'They don't know much about music, but they like the noise that it makes.'

The next stage in this traumatic process was a date with the Desert Island Discs researcher, Julie Batty, who brought me down to earth and sketched the rudiments of a cure. Julie spoke warningly of the danger of having what she called 'a parrot on your shoulder' in the studio, and stressed the essentially personal nature of my choice. Julie gave me absolution for my omission of Mozart, Chopin, Richard Strauss and Shostakovich. Julie told me it was OK to include the spoken word. Julie pointed out that I could only have eight recordings. Then she whipped out a tape recorder and conducted an expert interview in which I poured out my soul, shared my hopes and dreams and blurted out a few stunning personal confessions.

When we'd finished, there was not a dry eye in the house. Just as hostage-takers and their prisoners may develop ever closer personal bonds, by the time Julie had finished I was ready to run away with her to the first available desert island and live a life of bigamous bliss.

That, I felt, was the interview I wanted to broadcast, but the ambient sound of The Observer 's canteen argued persuasively against this and, of course, it was only an aide-mémoire to the briefing notes Sue Lawley would have before her on the big day.

And so, finally, the moment came. I was being ushered into Sue's inner sanctum in Broadcasting House. By now I was convinced my life was utterly worthless, my opinions on everything pointless and stupid and that, in all probability, the programme would be taken off the air by a wise and reforming director-general. The experience in prospect seemed like a cross between a job interview, a visit to the dentist and an assignation.

In reality, the mood of the occasion was upbeat and terrifically warm. By the time we had played over my eight selections and had repaired to the Desert Island Discs studio itself, I was at one with myself again and would happily have spent all day discussing the infinitely fascinating subject of Me.

The recording took less than two hours, but, yes, they do play all the records at full length. Sue Lawley was probing and sympathetic in equal parts. There is, alas, no Wagner.

 Desert Island Discs featuring Robert McCrum is broadcast today on Radio 4 at 11.15am and repeated on Friday at 9am.

I was giving masterclasses to chameleons. My sense of myself became more and more tenuous. I was now in the middle of a full-blown nervous breakdown and I had not even completed my list. One day, I'd doodle some names and I'd be this wistful, super-aesthetic, hello-sky-hello-clouds romantic, all Elgar, Vaughan Williams and Benjamin Britten, the next I'd be in jackboots and leather, strutting imperiously to the rhythms of Valkyrie and Tannhäuser . Delirio vano e questo! ... Sempre libera'. Was I a 'Dies Irae' kind of guy? Surely 'delirio vano e questo' was more my speed? And what about Macbeth (or should it be Falstaff , after all)? It was about this time that I came to the conclusion that I fitted Thomas Beecham's view of the English: 'They don't know much about music, but they like the noise that it makes.' The next stage in this traumatic process was a date with the Desert Island Discs researcher, Julie Batty, who brought me down to earth and sketched the rudiments of a cure. Julie spoke warningly of the danger of having what she called 'a parrot on your shoulder' in the studio, and stressed the essentially personal nature of my choice. Julie gave me absolution for my omission of Mozart, Chopin, Richard Strauss and Shostakovich. Julie told me it was OK to include the spoken word. Julie pointed out that I could only have eight recordings. Then she whipped out a tape recorder and conducted an expert interview in which I poured out my soul, shared my hopes and dreams and blurted out a few stunning personal confessions. When we'd finished, there was not a dry eye in the house. Just as hostage-takers and their prisoners may develop ever closer personal bonds, by the time Julie had finished I was ready to run away with her to the first available desert island and live a life of bigamous bliss. That, I felt, was the interview I wanted to broadcast, but the ambient sound of The Observer 's canteen argued persuasively against this and, of course, it was only an aide-mémoire to the briefing notes Sue Lawley would have before her on the big day. And so, finally, the moment came. I was being ushered into Sue's inner sanctum in Broadcasting House. By now I was convinced my life was utterly worthless, my opinions on everything pointless and stupid and that, in all probability, the programme would be taken off the air by a wise and reforming director-general. The experience in prospect seemed like a cross between a job interview, a visit to the dentist and an assignation. In reality, the mood of the occasion was upbeat and terrifically warm. By the time we had played over my eight selections and had repaired to the Desert Island Discs studio itself, I was at one with myself again and would happily have spent all day discussing the infinitely fascinating subject of Me. The recording took less than two hours, but, yes, they do play all the records at full length. Sue Lawley was probing and sympathetic in equal parts. There is, alas, no Wagner.  Desert Island Discs featuring Robert McCrum is broadcast today on Radio 4 at 11.15am and repeated on Friday at 9am.

fields.headline: The dark lady of DNA?
fields.standfirst: Rosalind Franklin is seen as the 'Sylvia Plath of science', a wronged heroine robbed of fame by male jealousy and cut-throat intrigue. But did she really win the race to track DNA?
fields.trailText: Rosalind Franklin is seen as the 'Sylvia Plath of science', a wronged heroine robbed of fame by male jealousy and cut-throat intrigue. But did she really win the race to track DNA?
fields.body:
If bricks and mortar can heal, the dedication of a building in Waterloo this month could end one of the great personal quarrels in the history of science. The Franklin-Wilkins building of King's College London, to be opened by the Princess Royal on 22 March, will couple the names of two pivotal scientific figures who were bitter enemies during the two years they worked together: Rosalind Franklin and Maurice Wilkins Kings' intention is obviously to remind the world how much it contributed, through their work, to the discovery of the double helix of DNA in the spring of 1953. But irony will hang heavy over the occasion. King's was scooped to the discovery by James Watson and Francis Crick at the rival Cavendish Laboratory in Cambridge. And the celebratory address will be given by Watson and Wilkins, the men most responsible for casting Franklin as the 'dark lady' of DNA.

The event will also be overshadowed by the college's own unease over Franklin's unhappy experience there. 'No longer the "forgotten scientist" of the DNA story', the King's alumni magazine proclaimed this autumn, with a picture of Franklin on the cover. Inside, it rehearsed the facts: Wilkins won the Nobel Prize in 1962 with Watson and Crick. Franklin died before the prize was awarded. (Nobel Prizes are never given posthumously.)

The college now knows the part it played in creating the tension between Wilkins and Franklin. In 1950, the head of its biophysics unit, Professor John T. Randall, invited Franklin, working in Paris where she had acquired a fine reputation in X-ray crystallography, to apply her skills at King's. After she accepted, he changed his mind about what she should work on and directed her to working on fibres of DNA. She would have the project to herself, he told her, apart from a research student, Raymond Gosling, and an American temporary assistant. He did not tell her that Wilkins had already done formidable work on DNA and intended to continue. Wilkins was away at the time and never knew the terms of appoint ment. He believed Franklin was coming to join his team.

The stage - the dingy basement laboratories beneath King's College in the Strand - was thus set for trouble, even before the clash of temperaments that became apparent once Franklin heard Wilkins daring to voice his opinions on her results. On the one side was a quick, single-minded young woman with a passion for argument; on the other an exceedingly reserved man with a hesitant, circumlocutory manner and an aversion to direct eye contact.

Wilkins was aware that in Cambridge Watson and Crick at the Cavendish were barging in on King's territory by working on DNA, but intermittently and through using the entirely different route of model-building rather than taking X-ray photographs. On many visits to Cambridge he spoke freely to them of his troubles with Franklin who, he felt, had virtually shut him out of his own subject.

Franklin, on arriving at King's, realised she had made a terrible mistake. She loathed what she felt was the cold atmosphere of King's, where women were not allowed in the senior common room. As soon as she could organise the transfer of her Turner-Newall fellowship to another University of London college, Birkbeck, she announced she was leaving. Wilkins was delighted. Franklin, he felt, had been given the best cameras and DNA samples to work with, only to try to keep her results to herself rather than sharing them in the spirit of scientific collegiality.

As 1953 opened, Franklin wrote to a friend that she was leaving much work undone in order to get out of King's as soon as possible. At the end of January, when Watson visited King's, Wilkins showed him the best of her photographs. Numbered 51, it showed the B-form of DNA, with a stark, black cross of reflections. One look told Watson, a brash and ambitious 25-year-old from the American Midwest, that he and Crick were on the right track.

He returned to Cambridge and, with Crick, started to construct a model with double coils of paired atoms. Knowing that further experimental data from the work of Franklin and others at King's was in a report circulated among members of the biophysics committee of the Medical Research Council, source of the money for Randall's research unit, they asked Max Perutz, a Cavendish colleague, to let them see it. He obliged. On 7 March, a happy Wilkins wrote to Crick: 'I think you will be interested to know that our dark lady leaves us next week ... at last the decks are clear and we can put all hands to the pumps! It won't be long now. M.'

But it was too late. By the time Wilkins's letter reached Cambridge, the pair whose names will be forever linked had completed their model and were drafting for the scientific journal Nature the now-celebrated letter announcing in effect that they had discovered the secret of life. Published on 25 April 1953, it ended with the famous understatement: 'It has not escaped our notice that the specific pairing we have postulated immediately suggests a possible copying mechanism for the genetic material.'

It did escape Franklin's notice, however, that before completing their model, Watson had had the advantage of seeing her stunning Photograph 51 and of reading her precise calculations on the molecule's dimensions.

News that the Cavendish had scooped them caused much consternation at King's. There was some feeling that Wilkins had gone up to Cambridge too often, talked too freely, been milked for data by the clever Cavendish pair and given away what belonged to the home team. What has never been disputed are the brilliant perceptions - how the chains were linked by complementary pairs of base pairs and how they ran in opposite directions - that vaulted Watson and Crick to the summit.

Through some complicated old-boy networking between Randall, Sir Lawrence Bragg at the Cavendish and the editor of Nature , King's was allowed to announce its own progress on DNA in the same issue. There were to be, appropriately enough, considering the circumstances, two separate papers from King's: one from Wilkins and his colleagues, A.R. Stokes and H.R. Wilson, a second by Franklin and Gosling. This enabled her to put Photograph 51 into print at last.

A week before these publications, Franklin, now happily at Birkbeck, received more unpleasantness from King's. Randall wrote to say that she was to stop working, even to stop thinking, about 'the nucleic acid problem'. Furthermore, she was to cease supervising Gosling on his thesis. The reorganisation made necessary by her departure could not proceed 'while you remain, in an intellectual sense, a member of the laboratory'.

Franklin laughed off the dictatorial letter, saying: 'Just the sort of thing they do there [ie, at King's].' She and the young, genial Gosling, who were jointly working on several unfinished publications, had great fun meeting as if subversives. Moreover, she reasoned that she could hardly stop thinking about the nucleic acids, for a form was present in the tobacco mosaic virus, the subject of her new research. (She was to achieve impressive results on TMV before her death.)

Franklin's first step toward wider public recognition came only in 1968, and to many it was a backward step. The mythologising of Rosalind Franklin, and probably of DNA itself, began with the publication of The Double Helix , Watson's brilliant, entertaining, tactless bestseller. In it 'Rosy' Franklin appears as the villainess, the archetypal bluestocking, a harpy who might have been pretty if she had only bothered to take off her glasses and do something interesting with her hair.

'Clearly,' wrote Watson about Wilkins's dilemma, 'Rosy had to go or be put in her place _ unfortunately, Maurice could not see any decent way to give Rosy the boot.'

Chauvinist words like these were sufficient to launch the legend of Franklin, the wronged heroine. Since then the myth has grown and, abetted by the fact of her tragic early death from ovarian cancer at the age of 37, shows no signs of fading. Franklin has become a feminist icon, the Sylvia Plath of molecular biology, a genius whose gifts were sacrificed to the greater glory of the male. Her failure to win the Nobel Prize has been seen as the prime example of the entrenched misogyny of the science establishment, rather than the consequence of the Nobel policy against posthumous awards.

One aggrieved American neuroscientist, Candace Pert, blamed anti-female prejudice when she was passed over for an award she felt she deserved. It was just what had happened to Franklin, she argued. In her 1997 book, Molecules of Emotion , Pert goes so far as to suggest that Franklin's cancer 'had been exacerbated by the humiliation she suffered at the hands of these, and probably many other, old boys'.

A more substantial boost to Franklin's posthumous reputation was given by Sir Aaron Klug, now president of the Royal Society, who was Franklin's closest collaborator at Birk- beck. From studying her DNA lab books he has revealed that in March 1953 she was far closer to solving the structure of DNA than her contemporaries realised. Moreover, he spelled out her crucial contributions: establishing DNA's existence in two forms, A and B; working out the position of the phosphorous atoms in the molecule's backbone and, critically, taking the clearest photographs of its internal structure.

To him, her weakness was isolation: 'She needed a collaborator and she didn't have one - somebody to break the pattern of her thinking, to show what was right in front of her, to push her up and over.'

Signs of belated recognition proliferate. Franklin was accorded a highly sympathetic portrayal in the BBC Horizon programme's 1987 dramatisation, Life Story . The National Portrait Gallery placed her photograph beside that of Wilkins and beneath those of Watson and Crick in its science room. Her Cambridge college, Newnham, dedicated a graduate building to her. Her London school, St Paul's Girls', now has a Rosalind Franklin design technology engineering workshop.

Perhaps it is now Wilkins whose image needs burnishing. Outside of King's, where he is revered, he has suffered unfairly from his caricature in what he calls 'Jim's novel'. Over the years, he has been hounded by the charge that he holds a prize that rightfully belongs to someone else and that he was wrong to show Franklin's photograph to Watson. In fact, he held the photograph quite properly, as Franklin was turning over to him her materials preparatory to leaving King's. More hurtful has been being accused of being anti-female, which his colleagues and students know he is not. He has even suggested that the more fitting name for the new building would be the Hanson-Franklin-Wilkins building, in honour also of Dr Jean Hanson, his distinguished colleague at King's for many years.

Easily glossed over in the much-retold story is the substantial work that had already been done there on DNA fibres before Franklin's arrival. Because of it, she was able to pick up a new subject and race ahead with it. The college's pioneering work may be more appreciated when the full record of the events leading to the discovery can be read. Such an archive for the history of molecular biology is now being assembled by the Norman Publishing Company in San Francisco. Its representative, who will be on hand at the King's proceedings on 22 March, is Al Seckel, a cognitive neuroscientist from the California Institute of Technology. Seckel has already acquired papers, correspon dence and lab notebooks of many eminent scientists, including Franklin, Crick, Klug, Gosling and Max Perutz, and is keen for more.

The dedication of the Franklin-Wilkins building will bring together all the surviving principals of the race for DNA, except for Crick, who will appear on video from his home in California. There is, however, apprehension about what Watson will say. Now president of the Cold Spring Harbour Laboratory on Long Island and former director of the US human genome project, he is not only a candid author but an unpredictable speaker, with a penchant for making headlines with unguarded remarks. At the launch in September of the Harvard Center for Genomics Research, he opened his inaugural address before an overflow crowd of 1,000 students and faculty with a ingenuous denial of guilt: 'There's a myth which is that, you know, that Francis and I basically stole the structure from the people at King's. I was shown Rosalind Franklin's X-ray photograph and "Whooo! That was a helix!", and a month later, we had the structure; and [that] Wilkins should never have shown me the thing. I didn't go into the drawer and steal it. It was shown to me, and I was told the dimensions, a repeat of 34 angstroms, so, you know, I knew roughly what it meant and it was that the Franklin photograph was the key event _ psychologically, it mobilised us back into action.

'The truth is that we should have got the structure in the fall of '51. There was enough data. We wouldn't have been able to say with finality that it was right because, uh, that came with Rosalind's X-ray work, that was the proof it was right _ first slide. Oh, there _'

And up on the screen went Franklin's Photograph 51.

But why, we outsiders may ask, this intense surge of fascination for the personalities and lab politics of 1953? The answer, of course, is the growing popular awareness of the importance of DNA. This three-letter abbreviation for deoxyribonucleic acid, the molecule that lies in every gene, has entered the common vocabulary. It is in the tabloids every day. GM food, genetic engineering and all the rest are the consequence of the discovery that has edged out Einstein's relativity theory as the greatest of the twentieth century.

The names of Watson and Crick have joined Darwin and Copernicus among the immortals. If the names of Franklin and Wilkins are not among them, they at least will share a building on the South Bank of the Thames.

 Brenda Maddox is writing the biography of Rosalind Franklin for HarperCollins.

webTitle: Why won't my partner's ex be my friend?

fields.headline: Why won't my partner's ex be my friend?
fields.standfirst: Moral Muse
fields.trailText: Moral Muse
fields.body:
Three and a half years ago, one of my best friends left her husband for another man. They had been married five years and the three of us had been friends since school. My friendship with her husband turned to love and we are now moving in together. His ex-wife has accused me of betrayal. She is about to remarry. There are no children involved. I have no intention of breaking up with her ex-husband but would like to remain friends. I cannot understand what her problem is.

Karen of London

No rational person would censor you for finding love with this man. His wife has no further claim on his loyalty. Your three-way friendship has already been fractured by her betrayal and departure, and she is being unreasonable. She probably wants, as you do, to keep up your friendship, but might find it difficult or impossible if you have as your 'significant other' her discarded man.

Her antipathy is probably more deep-seated and atavistic than this simple explanation, however. Love-relationships are not amenable to civilised logic, and to understand the workings of her mind you will have to disengage yours from the erroneous notion that our society is exclusively, or even predominantly monogamous. We arrogantly perceive ourselves as superior to animals, but we are closer to them than we think, especially in our sexual strategies. Only our capacity for moral self-deception is unique to ourselves.

Probably both men and women betray their long-standing partners much more frequently than is generally realised, maybe even more often than not.One mechanism for stabilising relationships is a form of imprinting that goes on between lovers, an almost indelible bonding resulting from all those hours spent gazing into each others' eyes and exploring bodies.
