fields.headline: Scotland must take Spanish steps
fields.standfirst:
First Minister Donald Dewar and architect Enric Miralles are being vilified for the escalating cost of the new Scottish Parliament. Deyan Sudjic reports on the big public buildings with big overspends
Devolution in Scotland: special report
www.scottish.parliament.uk
fields.trailText: First Minister Donald Dewar and architect Enric Miralles are being vilified for the escalating cost of the new Scottish Parliament. Deyan Sudjic  reports on the big public buildings with big overspends
fields.body:
Scottish Parliament estimate £40m - Real cost £230m

Portcullis House estimate £165 - Real cost £250m

Dome estimate £758m - Real cost £1bn

Eight months ago, Scotland's First Minister Donald Dewar put a figure of £109 million on the cost of the new Parliament that he is building in Edinburgh. Last week, the Scottish Executive admitted that the latest estimate was £230m. Given that back in 1997, when Enric Miralles, the Catalan architect responsible for the project was appointed, the building was costed at £40m, it is hardly surprising that David Steel, the Parliament's Presiding Officer, should be worried enough to appoint his own assessor to probe the reasons for the apparent quadrupling of the costs.

The Scottish press scented blood. They seized on the figures as yet another stick with which to beat Dewar, one that made a welcome change from their onslaught on his determination to repeal Section 28. And it produced, sotto voce , a lot of murmurings about the folly of entrusting such a symbolically charged project to an untested Spaniard with a comic-opera accent, an unpronounceable name and a design that he himself suggested was modelled on a couple of upturned boats sitting on a beach.The Parliament was instantly seized on as Dewar's Dome.

But the problem with the Parliament building in Edinburgh is far from being a lack of ideas about its content. In fact, a lot of the extra costs have arisen because absolutely everybody had an idea of what the Parliament should be. Thus, in response to the original brief and its almost touching belief that a new Scotland would want to get away from the confrontational ways of bad old Westminster, Enric Miralles designed a gently curved, intimate debating chamber, rather than put members on opposing sets of benches two sword lengths apart. It was not as hostile as Westminster, nor as formal as a Continental-style amphitheatre chamber.

But David Steel thought it looked like a banana and insisted on another fact-finding tour of European parliaments and a redesign. Judging by the vitriol that is flying around the Scottish Parliament in its temporary home in the Church of Scotland assembly building, it takes more than a seating plan to instil a spirit of brotherly love in Scottish MSPs.

As with most high-profile cost overruns, it is clients changing their minds who push up figures rather than overweening architects. It was not Terry Farrell's design for the M16 ziggurat, for example, that allowed its costs to run off over the horizon; it was the 'refinements' that the spooks asked for after construction had started that made it so expensive.

On part of the Edinburgh site stands a much mutilated but undoubtedly historic seventeenth-century house. It became a requirement that it should be restored and made part of the design of the new Parliament. But then it turned out to be so badly decayed that, as Miralles puts it, 'a gust of wind could blow it down'. More money had to be found to deal with it, rather than run the wrath of conservationists by demolishing it.

And then, the MSPs started looking in detail at their offices. Not big enough, they concluded. It might also be added that Scotland's newspaper editors weren't much impressed by the size of the press gallery, either. And so the price grew and grew. And just like the Dome, which was originally adopted by Tony Blair from the nerveless grasp of the outgoing Major administration as a monumental celebration of the achievements of New Labour's first term, Dewar discovered that monument building is a double-edged political strategy. If it works, it creates the upbeat climate of a Barcelona or a Paris. If it doesn't, then the voters turn nasty.

But even if the Dome has had a battering on its lack of a coherent strategy and purpose, it has managed to survive remarkably unscathed on the issue of price. Very early on, the Government took what looked to be a big risk. It announced a price so enormous, so colossal, that at £758m we have simply accepted it as an immutable part of the landscape. It's so big that how could it possibly get any bigger? Every newspaper describes it as the £758m Dome.

But of course it isn't. Count in the cost of cleaning up the toxic waste that contaminated the site, the interest payments and any shortfall in paying customers on the original 12 million target and it is clear that it is actually the £1,000m Dome. And if you do count in those essential 'extras', Tony Blair's proud boast that not a penny of public money has gone into the Dome looks rather less than frank.

The cash from the Millennium Commission is Lottery-funded, which is not technically public money, though a lot of people might argue that it is. But the £120m clean-up cost comes directly from English Partnerships, and most certainly is public money. And yet we are still hypnotised by that awesome £758m.

The Scottish Parliament, on the other hand, has been haunted by an early tactical mistake, by announcing a figure that, while it might cover the cost of the parliamentary debating chamber, didn't include fees, site acquisition costs, VAT or that parliamentary office building.

But unlike the Dome, Miralles's Parliament is not a heroic one-liner, it's a complex design that responds to its remarkable site between Holyrood and Arthur's Seat. It doesn't shout and, despite Miralles much mocked original image of that pair of upturned boats, it's very hard to caricature. It is all a contemporary parliament should be.

Dewar, however , is showing the stamina and perspective that makes for leadership and is fighting back. He has insisted that the building is redesigned so it does come in on the £109m target. From his studio in Barcelona, Miralles says that's fine with him and it is perfectly possible to do a great building for that money. Judge it against the £250m cost of Westminster's unloved Portcullis House, which provides nothing more than parliamentary office space.

One Scottish newspaper came up with a front-page story personalising the row to the point of claiming that Miralles, with a fee based on a percentage of the final cost, now stood to make £18m and implied that he had a vested interest in inflating costs.

It precisely echoed previous headlines about Denys Lasdun, when the National Theatre was hit by the inflation of the 1970s, and saw galloping cost rises as the result of the pound losing 20 per cent of its value in a year. Jorn Utzon was driven out of Australia by similar headlines about his Sydney Opera House.

And, of course, it is nonsense in each case. Miralles is a young and gifted architect, with a reputation to make. He was all but unknown in Britain before he won the competition. In his native Barcelona, he had a certain reputation based on the work he had done for the city in the run-up to the 1992 Olympics, but his built works amounted to an archery stadium and a pergola.

The Parliament project is by far the largest thing he has done and the most prominent. It is a signature project and he has to get it right. The pity of the onslaught on Miralles is that just at the moment when Britain was getting round to the idea that it was not a crime for good architecture to be an issue in public buildings, we might be pushed back to an earlier time, when to be seen to be sensitive to architectural issues was in itself regarded as a sign of terminal extravagance.

Buildings had to look cheap, even if that could actually be the most expensive option. The truth is that construction projects with no architectural ambition whatsoever are just as likely to run riot financially.

Look at the less than inspired Hampden Stadium, the Lottery-funded Glasgow project that is having to be bailed out of bankruptcy, or the extra cash that had to be poured into Cardiff's new rugby stadium to ensure that it opened on time.

webTitle: Forget about Ken, Dobbo and Norris...

fields.headline: Forget about Ken, Dobbo and Norris...
fields.standfirst:
The Tory and Labour selection fiascos - which spilt over into public bickering on last week's Question Time - have hijacked the debate about the challenges for London's mayor. In the first of a series of interviews with the candidates, Jay Rayner asks Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer the five big questions Londoners want answered : 'I don't know why the cheapest way of financing the Tube has been rejected'

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The Tory and Labour selection fiascos - which spilt over into public bickering on last week's  Question Time - have hijacked the debate about the challenges for London's mayor. In the first of a series of interviews with the candidates,  Jay Rayner asks Liberal Democrat Susan Kramer the five big questions Londoners want answered :  'I don't know why the cheapest way of financing the Tube has been rejected'
fields.body:
Close to where Susan Kramer has set up her campaign headquarters, a vast balloon offers tourists a panoramic view of the capital. She has resisted the temptation to buy a ticket, even though it would give her a perfect view of the city she is fighting to govern. 'It would be a publicity nightmare,' she says. 'You can imagine all the headlines about mayoral candidates and hot air.'

It's a wise move. As Labour continues to reap a bitter harvest from the electoral process by which it has chosen Frank Dobson, and Lord Archer laments being uncer emoniously dropped by the Tories, all Kramer need do for now is avoid making gaffes.

Are you taking economic regeneration in east London seriously?

Kramer was not entirely convinced by the question, posed by the business organisation London First, which wants the mayor to get behind proposals for a new Thames crossing east of Canary Wharf. 'I think that's a very limited view of regeneration,' she said. 'We probably do need another crossing but it's not key. What we have to do is look at core communities and rebuild them. We need mixed-income housing.'

Her solution is taken from her experience of Chicago, where she worked as a banker for nine years. 'I want to see if we can introduce community banks, an idea that works very successfully in America. The bank focuses on a relatively small area and they know it very well and invest there.'

Where would the capital for these banks come from? 'There are significant pools of private money, significant pockets of ethical funding. Regeneration has to be holistic. You can't just tart up the housing. It has to be from the ground up.' She believes too many regeneration plans have been solely economic, pointing to the development at Canary Wharf. 'There must be more opportunities for people from local communities to get jobs in developments like that.'

How will you make Londoners happier and therefore healthier?

Kramer argues that, where health is concerned, the mayor's powers are grossly limited: while legislation specifies that the mayor will have responsibility for the public health of Londoners, the incumbent will have no budget. Responsibility for primary health care spending will remain with the health trusts and local authorities.

Her solution is to bring improvements in public health under the regeneration umbrella. 'We have to increase social housing,' she said. 'We need 100,000 affordable houses in London. Again we might be able to use community banks. We may be able to influence it through new planning laws which require developers to build a proportion of social housing. Some of it, of course, will require a battle with government for funds.' She also argues that an increase in employment will have a dramatic effect on health.

As to primary health care, Kramer wants to be able to appoint an auditor of health care resources for London.

How will you make the lives of Londoners more beautiful?

Kramer sees London as a city divided between the great national arts institutions at its core and outlying areas where arts provision is as impoverished as anywhere in the country.

'The national arts companies are too often perceived as a substitute for art in the communities. When you give money to the Royal Opera that's incredibly worthwhile but only for a small portion of London.' For Kramer the priority is making sure that London's youngsters have access to the arts. 'I'd like to work with the London Tourist Board and others to see if we could find a way for London's young people to really explore what the city has to offer.'

On the general question of public art, Kramer is less fired up. 'There are higher priorities than this,' she said.

How will you get London moving?

Kramer has made transport one of her priorities, in which she may not differ from all the candidates. 'You cannot ask people in a great city like London to use public transport that's unpleasant and crowded.' Her policies are drawn from the US where cities have issued bonds to raise finance, a solution the Government has rejected for the Underground in favour of public-private funding.

'I struggle to understand why the Government has a problem with this,' Kramer said. 'It is the cheapest form of financing bar a grant from central government. Essentially, we will be borrowing now against future revenues from fares and a congestion charge levied on cars coming into central London.'

The daily congestion charge would be in the region of 30 per cent above the cost of a two-zone rail pass - probably £5. 'I'm not aiming to wipe every car off the map but at the moment there's a positive incentive to use them. We want to change that.' She believes it will raise £200 million at first, reducing as public transport is improved. As the revenues from those charges fall, fare revenues should rise: 'It's a no-lose situation.'

How will you make Londoners feel safer?

Here, on the complex battleground of crime - the other great priority - Kramer's big idea is what she calls a Community Constabulary. 'When we talk about crime what we really mean is community safety. We need to deal with the things that make people feel it's unsafe on the streets; things like graffiti, smashed bus stops, kids on street corners causing "aggro".

'What we can do is bring people who are already out there - housing estate wardens, parks superintendents, traffic wardens - into a constabulary who can liaise with police and point them towards trouble spots.' They would receive training and have a uniform, Kramer said.

On her website she says their number 'would be boosted by new money from congestion charging'. That seems like over-allocation of the same funds, since congestion charging is also earmarked to fund the bonds issue. Kramer now says the funding - which she believes will be modest - is still to be worked out.

She also says the Met has a funding problem - officers' pay does not match the cost of living in London - that central government must address.

Finally, she would like to see business people from ethnic minorities recruited into the upper echelons of the police. 'If we wait for officers from minorities to rise up naturally through the ranks it will take 25 years and that is far too slow.'

fields.headline: The ideal clone exhibition
fields.standfirst: Glyndebourne's youth opera impresses with its slick handling of topical material
fields.trailText: Glyndebourne's youth opera impresses with its slick handling of topical material
fields.body:
Zoë Glyndebourne, Sussex
HMS Pinafore Savoy Theatre, London WC2
Stockhausen Royal Festival Hall, SE1

Hot Dogs rarely feature in the hampers at Glyndebourne's summer idyll. Nor do visitors come in school uniform, preferring a more exclusive conformity. The novel sight of hundreds of teenagers swarming into the theatre was a tonic even before a note had sounded.

Following Misper three years ago and written by the same team, Zoë is Glyndebourne's second commissioned opera for young people. May there be dozens more. The media had already sniffed scandal, announcing a plot based on a juvenile's love affair with a chief inspector of schools. In fact, the girl is 20, the affair with the unmarried college tutor only one of several story lines. If these overblown promises drew advance attention to Glyndebourne's activities, so much the better. The exuberant, hard-hitting piece, more musical theatre than opera, held its audience gripped from start to finish. Standards were impressive, the energy infectious; the only visibly unprofessional aspect was the final bow, which had a rakish and chaotic charm.

Stephen Plaice's libretto negotiated every possible preoccupation a young adult might have, from personal to social and political, without cliché or embarrassment. Warm, wry wit wins out over irony. As a regular script writer for The Bill , Plaice knows how to handle tough subjects without being heavy handed. Thus first kiss, jealousy, teenage pregnancy, eco-rebellion, citizenship, prison, biotechnology and cloning are woven seamlessly in to a moving drama, lightly held together with a love story. Zoë, a new college student with a striking resemblance to a famous film actress, turns out to be her clone. Her father, a sinister geneticist, has created her from a lock of his screen-idol's hair. The dramatic consequences have their own, unspoken message. The text moves fast, but the amplification combined with John Lunn's word-friendly music ensure that it is easy to follow.

Brighton Youth Orchestra, conducted by James Morgan, made light work of the score, an engaging tapestry of rock, pop, electronic and operatic styles, with an emphasis on melody and strong pulse. Professional singers added another layer of vocal colour, pointing the music towards Puccini in one direction or Bernstein in another. That Lunn could make this doubtful-sounding combination work so convincingly is a tribute to his versatility. Trained in the classical tradition, at home in film and a founder of the experimental group Man Jumping, he has no problem with crossing over, under or in between.

The greatest pleasure came from seeing talented 17- and 18-year olds singing and dancing with total commitment. Emily Gilchrist in the title role has a pure, still light but expressive voice. As Gemma, Rebecca Bowden showed real soul and guts. Gemma Ticehurst had powerful stage presence and Mark Enticknap gave a thoughtful performance. Stephen Langridge's production, with stylish designs by Conor Murphy, served them admirably. The whoops and whistles were deserved.

D'Oyly Carte, returning to its Savoy home after a long absence, could have learnt a thing or two from Glyndebourne. Gilbert and Sullivan, whatever your view, have long offered the young a route into theatre and opera. Children enjoy the tunes and apprehend the inanity of grown-ups playing at being pirates or fairies, even if Gilbert's satire is lost on them. Parents don't mind going. In the wake of Topsy Turvy , Mike Leigh's loving celebration of G and S, you might have expected a half-term matinée of HMS Pinafore to be sold out. Charging children full price (in my case a startling £70 for two) is hardly an incentive. The place was half empty.

Martin Duncan's crisply choreographed production, with bright, on-deck designs by Tim Hatley had an over-neat air of having just come back from the dry-cleaners. One of the joys of amateur G and S is studying the spectrum of physical types who make up the chorus line and wondering whether the leading lady will ever find her top note. No one can blame this row of sailors for looking uniformly dapper (even Dick Deadeye only looked slightly gruesome), or the soloists for singing with bright accuracy, yet their precision exposed Sullivan's music as even more lightweight than one had remembered. But there's still enough wit and sparkle to support it.

From G and S to Karlheinz Stockhausen is the perfect oxymoronic journey. The nimble septuagenarian guru, still a natty dresser all in white except for a vivid orange woolly, drew crowds for a rare performance of his seminal Gruppen , among the most important compositions of the last half century. Written for three orchestras and three conductors, this study in spatial sound caused panic when first performed in Cologne in 1958. Players complained at its fiendish difficulty, conductors, according to Stockhausen, 'threatened to throw themselves out of windows' if he continued.

He did. Now ensembles such as the BBC Symphony Orchestra, conducted by David Robertson, Martyn Brabbins and Pascal Rophé, tackle it with ease, playing it twice in the same concert. Stockhausen introduced the second performance with a mix of the impenetrable and the audacious. He stated that a concert hall should exist to play this work round the clock. When in 1974 Cornelius Cardew wrote Stockhausen Serves Imperialism , he did not realise that Stockhausen was his own Empire's Emperor. Fortunately, he does have clothes and they are richly woven.

fields.headline: Fast forward
fields.standfirst: We consume it, so you don't have to. This week: soaps on the net
fields.trailText: We consume it, so you don't have to. This week: soaps on the net
fields.body:
The latest in a long line of e-gimmicks? Well Freeserve, the UK's biggest internet service provider (ISP), has just announced plans to launch a web soap in what we imagine is a dramatic bid to attract new surfers. It's scheduled to go live at the end of the month and we're told online punters will be able to email the characters personally.

Surely web soaps already exist? They do, but this is the first homegrown one. In the US they've already got the likes of Schuyler Falls, Covington Bay and Stoney Grove. Web soaps even have their own review magazine called Episodic , which aims to separate the suds from the duds. As you would imagine, the net has its fair share of duds.

So how do they work? They look like 3-D books. Episodes are usually posted daily or weekly in a script format, and there are links to photos and biographies of the main characters (covering all their dark secrets). A few of the soaps are video-based. On some sites you can go on an interactive tour of the fictional settings; a bit like clicking your way around a map of Albert Square.

And are TV soap producers losing sleep? In the US, some web soaps have attracted thousands of viewers, but not over sustained periods. Although they have yet to successfully erode TV audiences, they are building appeal. Cheap to make, you can catch up with episodes 24 hours a day and you can chat online with other fans.

Does this mean that Dot Cotton might leave Albert Square and become Dot.com? Fag-smoking Dot and the rest of the EastEnders' cast already have their own site. There is even an interactive Dot game where you can change Dot's clothes (a welcome opportunity to ditch that old mac) and give her a virtual makeover at the touch of a button. The Beeb has also set up a number of web cams so fans can watch episodes being filmed. Meanwhile, over at Coronation Street's website, you're invited to download photos of the Street and save them on your computer desktop.

So is Freeserve wasting its time? Not at all. Unless the internet bubble suddenly bursts, Freeserve's soap looks set to create yet another e-commerce beanfeast.

fields.headline: Hit them where it hurts
fields.standfirst: Releasing a single may seem an unlikely way of getting even, but a good revenge ballad will always set the record straight. Chris Harvey lists five of the greatest
fields.trailText: Releasing a single may seem an unlikely way of getting even, but a good revenge ballad will always set the record straight. Chris Harvey lists five of the greatest
fields.body:
US R&B star Kelis has raced to the top of the charts with her single about a cheating lover, 'Caught Out There', with its furious chorus: 'I hate you so much right now.' But she isn't the first to commit righteous anger to disk.

1 'You Oughta Know' by Alanis Morisette

Bile gets you noticed and Alanis oughta know. Her debut single with its catchy line, 'Are you thinking of me when you fuck her', won best rock song at the 1996 Grammys - and was then bleeped out in her performance at the awards ceremony. 'You told me you'd hold me, until you died/ But you're still alive,' she ranted.

2 'Here, My Dear' by Marvin Gaye

Money may not have been uppermost in Marvin's mind when he married Motown boss Berry Gordy's sister Anna, 17 years his senior, in 1961. But it certainly was two decades later when they were finally divorced, after living apart for years. The money from this 1979 double album went towards the divorce settlement, hence the loving title.

3 'How Do You Sleep' by John Lennon

'The only thing you done was yesterday,' sang John on the Imagine album in 1970, in response to some mild criticism from former songwriting partner Paul McCartney. 'And since you're gone you're just another day,' he added. In the recording studio, though, he'd reportedly planned to scream: 'You probably pinched that bitch anyway,' before being talked down.

4 'EMI' by The Sex Pistols

George Michael's hymn to Sony, 'I'm never going to sing again. Bastards! Bastards!' sung to the tune of 'Careless Whisper' famously appeared on his answerphone but never received a general release. The Pistols were less circumspect. Dumped by EMI after the Bill Grundy affair, Johnny Rotten rattled off a paean to 'stupid fools who stand in line/like/EMI' just to show he didn't take it personally. The song appeared on the band's debut album Never Mind The Bollocks in 1977.

5 'Tramp the Dirt Down' by Elvis Costello

'Well I hope I don't die too soon,' sang Costello in 1989 in his personal tribute to the then prime minister, Margaret Thatcher, 'because there's one thing I know I'd like to live long enough to savour.' Which was: 'When they finally put you in the ground/I'll stand on your grave/And tramp the dirt down.' No flowers, then.

webTitle: Phil Hogan  puts his back into it

fields.headline: Phil Hogan  puts his back into it
fields.body:
I've got just the faintest signs of a chronic, agonising back spasm, which I am officially blaming on my 11-year-old for leaving his Bullworker on the landing in the full knowledge that I am clinically unable to walk past it without performing a bracing set of side-abdominal, upper-range isotonic push-ins despite my newly avowed contempt for muscle-toning ventures after discovering that bodybuilders are quite certainly afflicted with the same kind of self-hatred as those weird people who go to the doctor's and ask for their legs to be amputated. But I have no sooner limped downstairs, carefully holding my lower lumbar region for the benefit of anyone planning to ask me to move dining-room furniture, than I discover that my hopes of a perfect Sunday are further dimmed by my wife's sheepish announcement that: a) the shirts she very kindly picked up for me from the ironing woman in the village yesterday have somehow transformed themselves into a Victorian embroidered nightgown and two pairs of satin trousers; and b) that she (my wife again, not the ironing woman) has for reasons known only to professors of attention deficit disorder decided to keep the rabbit up to speed with world events by lining his hutch with today's newspaper. I am now in the kind of humour consistent with having to stand upright at the table eating my Frosties with nothing to peruse but the local rag, which after an unusually exciting news period of Korean airliners crashing into the woods and Afghan hijackers making everyone late for their skiing holidays has had to fall back on less adrenalin-charged goings-on such as tree-planting on the A120 and Wednesday's power cut, which is reported to have affected up to four shops in the high street with the result that they were very soon all open again.

I'm afraid spring is in the air, which means my wife is compelled to paint all the doors and to that end is busy removing the handles, thereby ensuring that we will spend the rest of the year locking ourselves in the toilet until she finally gets round to popping out to Do It All next December to buy some screws to replace the ones that by then will have been put away for safe keeping in an unrecorded location.

'I read somewhere that slouching about all day is very good for your back,' she says.

'And your humorous point is?' I ask.

'Oh nothing!' she trills merrily.

She agrees to help me into my socks, shoes and spinal corset while I read a letter sent to me by Help the Aged's crack marketing team asking whether I'd like to insure my caravan when I'm old and infirm enough in the head to want one. 'You don't even need a stamp!' it says. How did they guess?

Off I go for a therapeutic stroll, which as luck would have it brings me to the pub just in time for the 11.30 kick-off between Leeds and Man U. Unfortunately the doors aren't open till 12 and I can't believe the landlord isn't prepared to open early and risk losing his licence and livelihood for such a crucial Premiership clash. I notice through the grubby curtains, however, that the TV is switched on and find that by jumping up and down at the window I can make a passing car slow down and the policemen inside it look at me in an overattentive manner. I raise a jocular eyebrow and set off hobbling up the hill for a second newspaper, getting back just in time to miss everything except the whistle signalling the end of the first half. I had the idea that the pub would be packed with vein-bulging, shaven-headed, tattooed men dressed in animal skins, but in fact I'm the only person here. I order a pint and eat my osteopath's weight in the complimentary roast potatoes and cubes of cheese and other delicacies they put out to make you drink more and stop you going home for lunch. Eventually, help arrives in the shape of a Telegraph-reading pipe-smoker who plonks himself under the TV and sends fog drifting across the pitch for the rest of the game. It is quite a good match, though the wrong team wins owing to Leeds's failure to score from two yards after the ball has just bounced off the post, the bar, someone's knee and arrived with a note attached saying 'Kick Me, Someone!'

I get home quite tired after my exertions of drinking too much. By coincidence I also need to rest my back. 'I'm just going to lie down for five minutes, darling,' I say.

'Did you get a paper?' she asks.

'Yes, don't worry, I put it straight in the bin,' I say.

 OAP exercises to phil.hogan@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Health report: No whiffs and butts

fields.headline: Health report: No whiffs and butts
fields.standfirst: This Wednesday is No Smoking Day. Kathryn Flett limbers up with the help of her dog, several packets of Jaffa Cakes and a visit to a hypnotherapist
fields.trailText: This Wednesday is No Smoking Day. Kathryn Flett limbers up with the help of her dog, several packets of Jaffa Cakes and a visit to a hypnotherapist
fields.body:
Deciding to give up smoking was easy. In fact, it turned out to be less of a decision than it did a compulsion, because for several months I'd been becoming increasingly fetishistic about the cleanliness of ashtrays and the possibility of lingering smells, not to mention those intimate smokers' horridnesses you rarely hear about: Kleenex emerging from a brisk bit of nose-blowing looking like used pipe cleaners (not all of which can be blamed on urban noxiousness); a semi-permanent nicotine tint on the index and middle fingers; a dog who wrinkled up her sweet wet pink nose and sneezed resignedly whenever one lit up. No, I really didn't know what guilt felt like until I'd turned my dog into a reluctant passive Consulate smoker. And she isn't even a beagle.

For the past couple of years my smoking had become irritatingly habitual and instinctive, while offering very little in the way of pleasure. In fact, there was absolutely nothing I liked about the process of smoking any more - not even the paraphernalia (lighters and ashtrays), nor the existential glamour of a smoky twister caught in the light of a low-voltage bulb with Sketches of Spain playing in the background (have you noticed how terrible fag smoke looks in the glare of a halogen spotlight?) In short, I was no longer 'cool' (if ever I had been) - just a thirtysomething with parchmenty skin and the beginnings of fine lines around pursed lips. The cough clinched it, though. By the autumn of last year it was a constant presence, a wheezing Jiminy Cricket perched on my shoulder, whispering its regular, sour, hacking somethings into my ears.

I'd given up smoking once before, just over three years previously. Married to a non-smoker, I thought I was doing the decent thing by giving up. After hypnotherapy I had stopped for about three months but, on the night my husband told me he was leaving me, I walked straight round to the 24-hour garage and stocked up on Consulate, as if to say: 'Look what you made me do!' But he hadn't, of course, because you can probably only give up smoking if you are doing it for yourself.

Last year, two-and-half years and God knows how many thousands more cigarettes down the line, I was disgusted by the habit, bothered by the permanence of my cough and the tightness of my chest, and tired of feeling like a social pariah (bad tables in restaurants, habitually banished to balconies and gardens in people's homes), so I knew it had to stop. Smoking wasn't me any more - it was just something I did. And, as with most things I do, when I finally made the decision to quit, I made it fast.

But how to give up? Willpower alone was not going to be enough, because an uncontrolled experiment had already revealed that, on my own, I could last about an hour - maximum; while in company, I could push it to about two- and-a-half. I wasn't attracted to patches or gum or acupuncture either, because the thing I had loved about hypnotherapy was that it had been instantaneous: after just one session I didn't feel like a smoker so, ironically, I wanted to not feel like a smoker in the same way, but probably with a different hypnotherapist.

I found Iain McIntosh in, of all places, the Yellow Pages. He answered the phone himself and was confronted, I suspect, by a garbling madwoman, disappointed to discover that she couldn't get an appointment that very afternoon. I'd already booked for the following week before I remembered to ask the fee. Eek! It was a lot of money but, said McIntosh cheerily, it also came with a 'lifetime guarantee'. I would, he claimed with utter conviction, never smoke again after just one session. That was a hell of a claim.

In exchange, he gave me a tape: 'I don't normally do this, but if you feel yourself flagging you might want to stick it on.' Funny, but within 24 hours I'd lost the tape, without even hearing it.

Week one: the hardest bit was discovering how much of my day had previously been taken up with smoking or thinking about smoking. At first there seemed to be a terrifyingly large amount of day left over, to be filled with other things, like Jaffa Cakes. Bugger! And work was difficult. I timed the first Observer TV review I had ever written without a fag burning comfortingly alongside me and it took precisely two-and-a-half times as long as usual. I realised that previously I had used cigarettes as a reward for a paragraph well constructed, as a psychological pat on the back. I was bothered about the Jaffa Cakes, Pringles and cups of coffee, but I also figured this was going to be the worst week of cold turkey, so I shouldn't be too tough on myself. Still, I am altogether much snappier and more brusque, particularly on the phone - but I have also been out for dinner and drunk alcohol without feeling the need for a snout, so I'm chuffed about that.

Week two: still snacking for Britain - but do I detect a slightly less abrasive tone when dealing with well, everybody really, including the dog? Have broken out in an extraordinary selection of zits, which I can't even blame on PMS ('Healing crisis!' explains a friend, who has been there). Am also coughing even more than usual, replete with dark grey mucus. Even when smoking heavily, I have never coughed up anything other than the loveliest snowy white phlegm and am completely revolted. Almost enough to make one light up, but not quite.

Week three: spot-fest still under way, but I would also say that my roaring mood swings are now no more satanic than usual. Others may, of course, beg to differ. Happily, too, the desperately infantile need to have the closest thing to an adult rusk in my mouth at all times seems to be abating. Had had terrifying visions of being forced to buy a giant dummy to satisfy oral fixation. That or no, actually, let's not go there.

Week four: extraordinary! I forgot to keep the diary this week because I forgot there was anything to keep a diary about! At one dinner a friend said, excitedly: 'So, how's it going then?' 'Fine,' I had replied, slightly puzzled by her tone, 'How's it going with you?' 'Well, I've never smoked, remember?' Blimey - it's as if I'd never smoked either!

Meanwhile, my sense of smell is so vastly improved that the dog is banned from the bedroom. I always knew she smelt doggy, I just didn't know how doggy. I am also back up to speed with writing (prize cigarettes having been replaced by dancing to Cream Anthems 2000 in the living room), but the very oddest thing is that when I see other people smoking it is like seeing people with, for example, red hair and freckles - something I recognise but which isn't part of my life and doesn't resonate emotionally in any way. In fact, far from triggering a bout of smugness or sanctimonious judgment, smokers barely register with me at all. I must say that, in just four weeks, this feels like an almighty achievement - both for Mr McIntosh and for me. Still, I was clearly ready. Are you?

fields.headline: A right Charlie
fields.standfirst: Not content with Stavros, Loadsamoney and  The Fast Show , writer and actor Charlie Higson is now extending his comedy franchise. His latest venture involves Vic and Bob and the resurrection of a detective called Hopkirk (deceased)
fields.trailText: Not content with Stavros, Loadsamoney and  The Fast Show , writer and actor Charlie Higson is now extending his comedy franchise. His latest venture involves Vic and Bob and the resurrection of a detective called Hopkirk (deceased)
fields.body:
As we walk past a swanky staircase in Luton Hoo, the country seat in Bedfordshire noted for its Capability Brown gardens and its large collection of Fabergé jewellery, Charles Higson, the comedy writer and televisual personality, points out something which might be of passing intrigue, if one were interested in this sort of thing. That staircase is the very staircase down which an extremely famous supermodel wended her 'sexy' way, mislaying several of her clothes in the process, for a motorcar commercial.

Claudia Schiffer aside, Luton Hoo, originally built by Robert Adam in 1767-74, is today a favoured location for film and telly location shooting. And - here's a massive surprise - it's about to be turned into a hotel. So Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased) may be the last telly offering to be shot at this magnificent crumbling pile.

Charlie Higson, at 40, is already a veteran television comedy writer and performer. He read English and American Literature and Film Studies at the University of East Anglia. Here, he embarked upon an abortive attempt to become a pop star with his grisly band The Higsons. Their last album sold a measly 700 copies. 'I was never a great singer,' he tells me, somewhat crestfallen. 'I was hopeless.'

After the demise of The Higsons, he went into partnership with his friend Paul Whitehouse. Their first success came in 1987 on the cult TV show Saturday Night Live, for which they wrote the character of Stavros, a dim but loveable kebab shop proprietor portrayed by Harry Enfield. This was followed by Loadsamoney, a cash-waving irritant, again played by Enfield on Saturday Night Live, who was much imitated by London football fans who taunted Northern rivals by waving money at them in the last days of Thatcherism. 'It was weird to see Loadsamoney so quickly become part of society,' Higson says. 'It is quite exciting when you create something and it becomes part of the cultural backdrop.'

Since then, Smashy and Nicey, the disc jockeys portrayed by Harry Enfield and Paul Whitehouse in the BBC's Harry Enfield television series have become part of our cultural furniture, as has 'Suits you, sir!', a phrase much used by the men's clothes shop assistants played by Whitehouse and Mark Williams in The Fast Show, the BBC2 sketch show that Higson and Whitehouse began writing, producing and performing in 1994. Higson has also turned his hand to writing darkly comical (and hugely successful) novels: King of The Ants (1992), Happy Now (1993), Full Whack (1995) and Getting Rid of Mister Kitchen (1996).

But now he is concentrating on Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased). He is writer, producer, and occasional actor in this new version of an elderly TV concoction that ran from 1969-1971 and had as its premise a couple of private eyes, one of whom was dead (hence the name). The dead one had been run over by a motorcar but was able to appear before his living partner in dire situations - thanks to the wonders of filming technology - and offer much-required advice. In short, it was telly nonsense, fit only for the afternoon viewing of students and the unemployed. Spool forward 30 years and here it comes again starring not the original players Mike Pratt (as Jeff Randall) or Kenneth Cope (as Marty Hopkirk) but Vic Reeves and Bob Mortimer.

Vic Reeves is sporting a white suit just like the one he used to wear on Vic Reeves' Big Night Out. That suit was, in fact, directly nicked from Randall and Hopkirk (Deceased); Kenneth Cope was always dressed in one and the show has always been a favourite of Vic's. We are in a dilapidated room where cameras strut around a cast of men who are acting the parts of zombies, all stiff movements and unblinking eyes. Nothing much else happens. That is the way with filming, sitting around while some curmudgeonly old goat tinkers with lights and a third assistant best boy peers bemusedly at a clip-board.

Sitting in a trailer having fake whiskers applied for a scene, Higson explains why they chose this particular show to revive. 'It came about by a slightly roundabout route. Polygram had all the rights to the old ITC programmes: The Champions, Man in a Suitcase, Jason King ' I shuffle in my chair as I consider this 'golden age' of televisual ineptitude and, as the moustache takes some shape, the scriptwriter/actor continues: 'They looked through all of those old programmes to see if any of them would stand up to a re-make. Things like The Champions were very kitschy, 70s flares and sideburns kind of things, so it would have been very difficult to update them without going down the Austin Powers route.

'But Vic and Bob thought that Randall and Hopkirk was a very strong central idea because although people have tried to make things like that since, no one had ever done a thing with two detectives where one is dead and has a white suit. Also because it wasn't a series like The Avengers, people wouldn't get very precious about it. They would remember the white suit and that was about it. Anyway, Vic and Bob had been looking for some time to do a mainstream family adventure acting project and they had a ready-made partnership and that slightly off-beat humour that would work with the supernatural element.'

Despite the casting, the show, he insists, will be more than just a send-up. 'We said from the start that we had no interest in making it kitschy and a spoof. Because you've got to care about the characters, you've got to care about the plot. And you can't do that with a stream of gags. Vic and Bob wanted to do something that was a bit more serious than their other stuff. And I had, for a long time, been wanting to write something like The Prisoner - a big, escapist fantasy story which nobody makes anymore. You look at telly these days and it's all docu-soaps and it's Britain in your face. Which is fine. But I wanted to do something with a bit more sense of fun, so we set out to do a Saturday Night type thing - which is quite difficult to pull off. We were trying to get a timeless feel to it.'

The episode I am witness to is set in a loony bin for rich people not unlike the Priory. 'It's quite fun to have a go at these establishment things,' says Higson, a cheeky smile left playing around his sticky, fake-bearded chin. Among the guest stars appearing in the series are Richard Todd (star of the classic war flick The Dam Busters), Tom Baker (once a Doctor Who) and Dudley Sutton (bloke who once appeared, about a squillion years ago, in a motorbike film called The Leather Boys). 'Steven Berkoff is a secondary villain in this episode, too, and people assure me that it's going to look fantastic and reasonably outrageous. And we've got Charles Dance in the first episode. And I'm playing a zombie'

Dance, it appears, is 'a big Vic and Bob fan and a big Fast Show fan. It's been a good project like that: people really respond in that it isn't the normal thing they are asked to do. They can come in and enjoy themselves a bit.'

As for Richard Todd, well The Dam Busters is the first film Higson can remember seeing. 'I remember as a kid, you'd go to the cinema and you'd just turn up at anytime. You'd go in in the middle of a film and just sit and watch it round again. I remember going to see The Dam Busters like that; I went in and there were big dams exploding. But it didn't spoil it. There's something nice about watching films like that. Whenever the new James Bond film came out, you'd have an old James Bond film with it in a double bill. So, God knows how many times I've seen Doctor No.'

The chatter turns to discussion of the Vic Reeves and Bob Mortimer. 'I saw their live show years ago and I just thought it was the funniest thing I'd ever seen. I asked them if they wanted any help and they said, "Yeah, you can come along and wear 20-foot-long trousers." It's nice to work on that level of being just a fan. But Vic is a pretty complicated type of bloke, and I don't know if I've ever really got through to the inner him.

'As for Bob, I've had lots of chats with him, but afterwards you think, "Was half of that completely made up?" And the extraordinary things that you think must have been lies turn out to be actually true, and the mundane things he comes up with are made up. Having Bob to a dinner party is probably the worst thing that Bob could imagine. He has a terrible habit of going to the toilet at parties and you never see him again. I've asked them to do social things, but they never turn up. Could I ever get them round to my house? No. But I do love working with them. They are fun to work with - once they've decided to take it seriously.'

Of the characters he has created for television, Higson tells me that it is The Fast Show 's Ralph - the land-owning gent with an unrequited crush on his servant Ted - for whom he feels fondest. 'He's the first character of any substance that I did on the telly. I wasn't originally going to play the part. We were looking for a John Cleese-type actor to make up the numbers, but we never found anyone, so I ended up doing it by default. I really enjoy playing Ralph and I still enjoy watching The Fast Show. They had repeats on recently, and I know you're not supposed to sit and laugh at your stuff, but I do. My wife always tells me off, but it entertains me.'

As for Richard Todd, well The Dam Busters is the first film Higson can remember seeing. 'I remember as a kid, you'd go to the cinema and you'd just turn up at anytime. You'd go in in the middle of a film and just sit and watch it round again. I remember going to see The Dam Busters like that; I went in and there were big dams exploding. But it didn't spoil it. There's something nice about watching films like that. Whenever the new James Bond film came out, you'd have an old James Bond film with it in a double bill. So, God knows how many times I've seen Doctor No.' The chatter turns to discussion of the Vic Reeves and Bob Mortimer. 'I saw their live show years ago and I just thought it was the funniest thing I'd ever seen. I asked them if they wanted any help and they said, "Yeah, you can come along and wear 20-foot-long trousers." It's nice to work on that level of being just a fan. But Vic is a pretty complicated type of bloke, and I don't know if I've ever really got through to the inner him. 'As for Bob, I've had lots of chats with him, but afterwards you think, "Was half of that completely made up?" And the extraordinary things that you think must have been lies turn out to be actually true, and the mundane things he comes up with are made up. Having Bob to a dinner party is probably the worst thing that Bob could imagine. He has a terrible habit of going to the toilet at parties and you never see him again. I've asked them to do social things, but they never turn up. Could I ever get them round to my house? No. But I do love working with them. They are fun to work with - once they've decided to take it seriously.' Of the characters he has created for television, Higson tells me that it is The Fast Show 's Ralph - the land-owning gent with an unrequited crush on his servant Ted - for whom he feels fondest. 'He's the first character of any substance that I did on the telly. I wasn't originally going to play the part. We were looking for a John Cleese-type actor to make up the numbers, but we never found anyone, so I ended up doing it by default. I really enjoy playing Ralph and I still enjoy watching The Fast Show. They had repeats on recently, and I know you're not supposed to sit and laugh at your stuff, but I do. My wife always tells me off, but it entertains me.'

fields.headline: Mean streets
fields.standfirst: Milan was the first Italian city to declare a car-free Sunday. But is this radical move more than a passing trend? Rory Carroll reports
fields.trailText: Milan was the first Italian city to declare a car-free Sunday. But is this radical move more than a passing trend? Rory Carroll reports
fields.body:
It was a great show. With one stroke, Milan magicked away millions of cars, trucks and mopeds. Street after street fell silent. For the first time in living memory there were no traffic jams, no swirling roundabouts. This was a city at peace, not under curfew. Banishing traffic was a liberation. Rollerbladers, cyclists, pedestrians and horse riders charged in crisp sunshine over the empty asphalt, reclaiming it as their own and clinching another first for Milan.

Last month some 150 Italian cities signed up for car-free Sundays, but Milan stormed the stage a month early, in January. Stealing the limelight comes naturally to such a city. Once Italy looked to Rome for its politics and Turin for its commerce. Once the world looked to Paris for its fashion. Now they all gaze at Milan. It leads, others follow. Those who walked the streets that eerie day agreed it was a great show.

Now here's a dirty secret. Milan was first because it was the worst - the most polluted, poisoned, degraded city in Italy. The smog was so bad that it had no choice. People were choking and dying - it was an emergency. Dust particles called particulates rose above allowable levels for 28 consecutive days. Those with breathing problems could die; those without breathing problems acquired them. According to the World Health Organisation, more than 15,000 Italians die annually from smog-related illness.

Step beyond the glare of the catwalks and what awaits is the dark side of Milan's economic miracle: a toxic cocktail spews from factories, heating systems and car fumes. That is the real Milan, where geography, political cowardice, bureaucratic inertia and greed have allowed pollutants to be pumped into the air, ground and water. Milan is the last major European city to pump raw sewage into a river. Only a city dedicated to artifice could gloss over such filth to seduce the world.

Italy's love affair with the car is well known: it has the third-highest car-ownership ratio in the world. Not so well known is how Milan has escaped the international odium heaped on the less guilty Rome, Naples and Palermo.

A slick publicity machine projected the first car-free Sunday (16 January) as a triumph of planning, common sense and goodwill, but the truth was different. The authorities refused to provide free public transport. Tens of thousands of football fans were stranded on their way to see Inter Milan play Cagliari. Phone lines for motorists seeking exemptions were jammed. True, the 12-hour pause lowered pollution below danger levels, but the respite was temporary. Real solutions need to be as fundamental as the problem's sources.

'Milan is at a disadvantage because of its geographic situation, surrounded by mountains and lying on a plain where you get a thermal inversion,' says Aldo Iacomelli, of Greenpeace in Italy. 'That means that normally, during the day when the sun is out, the air should rise and move away. But often this doesn't happen during winter. And because millions of cars come into the city every day, the pollution remains and people end up breathing the same air all the time.'

Nature is unkind, but the Milanese are worse. Left and right solemnly agree radical steps are needed to combat the problem, yet they lobbied the European Union into granting Italy an extra two years to implement a ban on sales of leaded petrol.

Similarly, despite their affection for the Po river, the authorities have delayed building water-treatment plants for decades. Three plants will open by 2005, but, until then, sewage will continue to flow. 'It is disgraceful,' said Domenico Zampaglione, the city's environment councillor, who blames bureaucracy for the delay. Others point the finger at the region's small firms. Innovative they may be, but they are resolutely reluctant to sacrifice profits for the environment.

There is another culprit. The Milanese enjoy designer labels and flashy cars but, above all, they adore warmth - especially in winter. Inside temperatures are not supposed to exceed 20C, but the law has been flouted for decades. Making it worse is the fact that most heating systems in the city are antiquated guzzlers of petrol-based fuels rather than eco-friendly methane. The number of heating inspectors is set to rise from 6 to 60, but cynics doubt they will actually raid homes.

Milan's misfortune, says Iacomelli, is part of a wider, simpler phenomenon. 'Italians are just not very aware of environmental issues.'

webTitle: Look carefully at Wyner and Brock

fields.headline: Look carefully at Wyner and Brock
fields.trailText: The facts of the Ruth Wyner case (News, last week) are that drug-dealers were effectively given carte blanche to peddle heroin to the extent that Overstream House (of which Ruth Wyner was director) became a 'supermarket for heroin'.
fields.body:
The facts of the Ruth Wyner case (News, last week) are that drug-dealers were effectively given carte blanche to peddle heroin to the extent that Overstream House (of which Ruth Wyner was director) became a 'supermarket for heroin'. Addicts came from miles around to 'score' then went on their way. Dealers turned up in BMWs to ply their fare.

Against this background Ruth Wyner did nothing, claiming that her policy of confidentiality included the dealers, who in no way could be considered her 'clients'. The police had no option but to act.

Ruth Wyner is no stranger to controversy. In 1993 she was sacked from her £20,000-a-year job as manager of the St Martin's Homeless Trust in Norwich for allowing the use of drugs on the premises. It was for this reason, prior adverse publicity in both Cambridge and Norwich, that the trial was held at King's Lynn.
Dr. D.R. Keiller
Cambridge

 The case of Ruth Wyner and her co-worker John Brock has sent shockwaves through the voluntary sector which have spread well beyond Cambridge. It has also highlighted some of the basic faults in the current methods used to deal with drug abuse. It is for these reasons that I recently tabled a Statement of Opinion (equivalent to a House of Commons Early Day Motion) in the National Assembly for Wales calling on the Home Secretary to review both the case and the Misuse of Drugs Act.
Michael German AM
Arweinydd Grwp y Democratiaid Rhyddfrydol/Liberal Democrat Group Leader

fields.headline: Getting the GM facts straight
fields.trailText: Thank you for exposing the clique of overprivileged dilettantes who run Britain's environment pressure groups (Review, last week).
fields.body:
Thank you for exposing the clique of overprivileged dilettantes who run Britain's environment pressure groups (Review, last week). Widespread organically farmed food would result in a nightmare of pests, plant diseases and famine - exactly the rural idyll presided over by the ancestors of Prince Charles, Barons Porritt and Mond, and my Lords Worcester and Melchett before modern agriculture made food safe and affordable.

True environmentalists know that the planet is protected only by the most efficient use of resources. So-called 'organic' farming is the least efficient way of farming known to man, requiring twice the land, twice the labour and a new peasant underclass - which the eco-toffs and their nouveau riche hangers-on (Goldsmith, Costain and the like) would kindly supervise from the balconies of their country houses. By opposing GM food and efficient agriculture, this blinkered old-boys network threaten not only our own food self-sufficiency but could condemn to starvation the people of the developing world.
Dr Robert Johnston
Northampton

 'Eco-toffs' are a welcome addition to the Green Movement as they generate publicity. However, they, like the rest of us, have to be judged on their actions. Treading lightly on the Earth demands more than buying organic champagne!
Daniel Mittler
Secretary, Edinburgh Friends of the Earth

fields.headline: Life support
fields.standfirst: Domenico Dolce always said he wanted work alone, but now, nearly two decades since first meeting his design partner Stefano Gabbana, he believes it was destiny that brought them together
fields.trailText: Domenico Dolce always said he wanted work alone, but now, nearly two decades since first meeting his design partner Stefano Gabbana, he believes it was destiny that brought them together
fields.body:
Stefano Gabbana I first met Domenico Dolce in Milan 19 years ago, where we both worked as assistant designers in the same studio. Our desks faced each other, and I remember how he would hide all his sketches under a pile of books, just like a schoolboy, afraid that someone would pinch his ideas. He was very secretive indeed.

After a while, we decided to share an apartment together. From there, we started doing our own freelance projects for various Italian labels. Domenico would always get the best jobs, and some of them were just too much for him to do alone, so he would ask me to help. Working together soon became the norm, and we became familiar faces on the Milan fashion scene.

In the early days of Dolce & Gabbana, I learnt everything about the construction of clothes from Domenico. He is a genius tailor and one of the most talented people I have ever met. He is meticulous about the cut on a jacket, whereas I have more of an eye for the visual look of things. We have very different tastes, which is a good thing. When it comes to design, Domenico is more Yves Saint Laurent, while I'm more Fiorucci.

After all these years, I don't think there is anyone who knows Domenico Dolce better then me. Sometimes I joke with him saying that I know him better than his own mother. I know that he hates ignorance, and I know that anything to do with glamour makes him laugh. I also know that sometimes he is too sensitive for his own good.

We have been through some of the most difficult situations together and always managed to get through them unscathed. The best example of this can be seen right at the beginning of our career. In 1985 we were asked to show during the Milan collections as new designers, but immediately afterwards, our manufacturers pulled out of producing the line. Rather than give up, we drove around Italy in search of new producers. Just about everybody turned us down, so we carried on driving until we got to Sicily where we asked Dolce's family, clothing producers in their own right, for help.

They gave us some start-up money and agreed to do our production. Aside from his determination, I admire Domenico for his passion for work, and the way he always achieves what he sets out to do. If he wasn't a designer, there are a million things he could do. He could be a painter, an interior designer or even an inventor.

At work, we share the same studio and still sit with our desks facing each other, just as we did in the old days. Sometimes, we do need a break from each other; when this happens, I just get on my bike or go and see a film.

Our work is totally verbal and we talk as soon as we get in in the morning, about anything and everything, then we make visual notes and get to work. Each season feels like it's our first, and on the run-up to the shows we are as nervous as we were at the beginning of our career. Actually, doing a collection was easier five years ago. Today it is much worse, because the global fashion system has changed so much. Whereas once it was all about clothes, now it's all about business and money. Creativity means less, and money is the new competition.

Domenico Dolce I came to Milan from Sicily because I wanted to live and work in the city. I already had lots of friends in Milan who wanted me to design with them, but I said no as I had always wanted to work alone. Stefano laughs at me because I say that it was destiny that we met - I am very superstitious, and once I start on about dreams and the like, he just tells me to keep all that mumbo jumbo stuff to myself. But I really do believe in life's pre-planned events and the fact that we were just simply destined to meet.

My first memory of him is of a young man with a great childlike energy and a slight cheekiness. Even now, spending all day in the office with him is good fun, because he is always joking. When I first arrived in Milan, I was very into that whole corporate clothing style which marked the early 80s. I loved all the androgynous shapes and severe tailoring that went with it and was keen to weave it into the first Dolce & Gabbana collection.

But it was Stefano who made me change my mind by making me take a fresh look at my native Sicily. His love of Mediterranean women and the rich colours and prints that I had taken for granted made me realise that what I had embedded deep within me would be our fortune.

At work, we do most things together, but if we are on deadline, then we have to do certain tasks alone. There are some things I like to do, and vice versa. Stefano, for example, dislikes the business side of things, and I would rather stay in the background when it comes to public relations. When that happens, we just help each other out. When it comes to making decisions, it's not really Dolce nor is it Gabbana who calls the shots. We take more of a cocktail kind of approach to things. For example, Stefano says I want this dress to be red, and I say I want white, which is then followed by a whole series of heated discussions until we finally decide on pink.

We are quite opposite in many respects, but more often than not we see things the same. For example, if I am out on my own and I see a great pair of shoes in a window, he'll come back and tell me that he has seen the exact same pair. It's become so comical that we now play this little game where we write down a list of things we have seen on our own and then compare them later on.

One thing that amazes me about Stefano is his unique ability to know which pieces of the collection will sell. He always picks the bestsellers, and I always get them wrong. As for Stefano's personality, I admire the way that he never holds a grudge, whereas I tend to sulk a bit and hold things in. Even if we argue over something, he just gets on with the next thing as if nothing has happened.

I think it's healthy to have a bit of confrontation in a relationship like ours. If there are two of you, you have the courage to say what you think about the other's idea. That's what makes a collection work. Now I can't imagine ever working on my own. Quite honestly, if it weren't for Stefano, I wouldn't be doing this.

fields.headline: What rape gene?
fields.trailText: Research commissioned by the Home Office a few years ago found that the most common behaviour in the rape of women was the rapist laughing and jeering at the sufferings of the victim.
fields.body:
Research commissioned by the Home Office a few years ago found that the most common behaviour in the rape of women was the rapist laughing and jeering at the sufferings of the victim. Which gene drives that impulse if, as [evolutionary psychologists] Thornbill and Palmer claim, rape is only an act committed by men who are 'particularly desperate to plant their seed' (Review, last week)? Boys, girls and men who are raped may also ponder what part they play in the 'evolved mating strategy' of these products of the 'human evolutionary heritage'.
Una Freeley
London N8

fields.headline: Ritalin v culture
fields.trailText: The proposed new drug-prescribing powers for behaviourally 'disordered' children (News, last week) completely miss the point by chronically misdiagnosing what is at root a profound cultural malaise.
fields.body:
The proposed new drug-prescribing powers for behaviourally 'disordered' children (News, last week) completely miss the point by chronically misdiagnosing what is at root a profound cultural malaise.

For rather than 'attention deficit' and 'hyperactivity' being medically pathologised, and sufferers subjected to normalising bio-medical treatment, these symptoms are far better understood as children's healthy response to the routine violence that culture is doing to children's healthy development - not least, its inappropriate 'left-brain' distortions of early child development.

Until we possess the insight to recognise and then respond to this malaise at a cultural level, the prevalence of children's 'behavioural difficulties' will inevitably escalate - Ritalin or no Ritalin.
Dr Richard House
Norwich

 Anthony Browne (News last week) expressed legitimate concerns about the proposed Mental Health Act regarding children, but I was disappointed with the use of such emotive terms as 'chemical cosh' and 'mind control drug', which do a great disservice to parents and children struggling with ADHD. Ritalin may not be the answer for all children with ADHD and not all children with behavioural problems are sufferers but it is an invaluable tool.
Richard Showers
Denbigh
North Wales
fields.bodyText: The proposed new drug-prescribing powers for behaviourally 'disordered' children (News, last week) completely miss the point by chronically misdiagnosing what is at root a profound cultural malaise. For rather than 'attention deficit' and 'hyperactivity' being medically pathologised, and sufferers subjected to normalising bio-medical treatment, these symptoms are far better understood as children's healthy response to the routine violence that culture is doing to children's healthy development - not least, its inappropriate 'left-brain' distortions of early child development. Until we possess the insight to recognise and then respond to this malaise at a cultural level, the prevalence of children's 'behavioural difficulties' will inevitably escalate - Ritalin or no Ritalin. Dr Richard House Norwich  Anthony Browne (News last week) expressed legitimate concerns about the proposed Mental Health Act regarding children, but I was disappointed with the use of such emotive terms as 'chemical cosh' and 'mind control drug', which do a great disservice to parents and children struggling with ADHD. Ritalin may not be the answer for all children with ADHD and not all children with behavioural problems are sufferers but it is an invaluable tool. Richard Showers Denbigh North Wales

fields.headline: Don't let Ken in
fields.trailText: Your editorial urging Ken Livingstone to run for Mayor of London (Comment, last week) is probably the most irresponsible in  The Observer 's long and distinguished history.
fields.body:
Your editorial urging Ken Livingstone to run for Mayor of London (Comment, last week) is probably the most irresponsible in The Observer 's long and distinguished history. While you have been critical, and often properly so, of some aspects of this Labour Government, you know and your readers know that it has been hugely better for all the causes you support than the alternative that was available in 1997.

You will the ends of a Labour Government and, yes, you want it do more. But in your support for Ken Livingstone standing against the Labour candidate you are scuppering the means. Such a campaign would divide the Labour Party in London and, regardless of who won, hand more Parliamentary seats to the Tories at the next general election. And it would demoralise the Labour Party in the rest of the country to the same effect.
Cllr Pete Ruhemann
Reading Borough Council

fields.trailText: I enjoyed Andrew Rawnsley's excellent Labour alphabet (News, last week).
fields.body:
I enjoyed Andrew Rawnsley's excellent Labour alphabet (News, last week). However, as he found room to deny the Mandelson Mushy Peas story, it would have been educational if he had also pointed out that unemployment at the time of Saatchi's 'Labour isn't Working' ad, 1979, was actually below one million and falling, a figure it has not returned to since.
Lynne Armstrong
Portsmouth

fields.headline: Boycott not first
fields.trailText: You say that Rosie Boycott is 'Fleet Street's first female daily newspaper editor' (Review, last week).
fields.body:
You say that Rosie Boycott is 'Fleet Street's first female daily newspaper editor' (Review, last week). Not so. Mary Howarth was launch editor of the Daily Mirror on 2 November 1903. Incidentally, the first woman known to edit a journal was Mrs Mary de la Riviere Manley, who in June 1711 succeeded Jonathan Swift on The Examiner .
Dennis Griffiths
Editor, Encyclopedia of the World Press
Gerrards Cross
Bucks

fields.headline: Dewar must take charge
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Anyone who has ever been involved in the simplest refurbishment of an office will recognise at least some of the ills besetting the plans for the Holyrood parliament. Parkinson's Law said that work expands to fill the available time. It may now be reformulated as Donald's Dictum - that aspirations of parliamentarians and Ministers expand to exceed the available space.
fields.body:
Anyone who has ever been involved in the simplest refurbishment of an office will recognise at least some of the ills besetting the plans for the Holyrood parliament. Parkinson's Law said that work expands to fill the available time. It may now be reformulated as Donald's Dictum - that aspirations of parliamentarians and Ministers expand to exceed the available space.

Enric Miralles's new parliament is eloquently defended today in the Review (page 6) by Deyan Sudjic, who also deals with some of the presentational errors that have allowed it to become another target for those elements of the Scottish press which have been hostile to devolution and all its works.

In Edinburgh this week there is to be a seminar on the press and the parliament. It has much to chew over. From the start the thrust of the coverage was negative, often concentrating on trivial questions of pay and conditions. But much more serious turbulence then shook the Executive, culminating in the resignation of Dewar's political adviser, John Rafferty, in highly contentious circumstances involving press briefing, although again the issues involved were trivial.

That there are faults on both sides is evident. Large sections of the Scottish press have given up checking facts or attributing quotations. This is not entirely their fault: the press briefing system depends heavily on anonymity. Even though Dewar's spokesman, David Whitton, speaks on the record, he stands as if alone in a jungle clearing; from the undergrowth all around comes the sound of girning voices who speak but do not declare their names.

One day in the Scotsman last week a large part of the story on the parliament's troubles consisted of quotations from a 'senior government source'. No doubt he exists; no doubt he lives in the reporter's notebooks. But without his name the remarks attributed to him have small value. In its campaign against Section 28, the Record 's use of smear and slant has become both tedious and unpleasant. It seems it too has depended on a mole on the Executive who may be hostile to Dewar.

The habit of speaking to the press without attribution is a perfect mechanism for settling scores and stabbing enemies in the back or, less pettily, of trying to undermine the principle of coalition with the Lib Dems. Some of the briefing seems to come from colleagues hostile to Dewar himself, or who wish to open up the leadership to challenge.

On the question of the parliament, the problem has clearly been the failure of any single figure to assume responsibility. Miralles has been cheaply lampooned largely because he is a foreigner. His potential fee has been ludicrously overstated - it will be percentage of construction costs, not total costs, and will be shared with others. As Secretary of State, Dewar was ill advised to allow the publication of a written answer which, misleadingly, gave only the construction costs.

Since then Sir David Steel and the corporate body, which he chairs, has been responsible for progress. It has been assailed by new demands for space by Ministers and parliamentarians. The presiding officer is suggesting that Ministers should cut their cloth by sharing offices in the parliament. It is even possible that parts of the building may have to be built later.

Sir David must now 'take ownership' of the project. As presiding officer he is best placed to moderate expectations. His friends say he is determined to see the project through. He is now in the last four years of his political life and it would be a substantial legacy to leave.

It is time, too, for Dewar to 'take ownership' of the Executive and tell his enemies in the undergrowth to put a sock in it. He must become pro-active and less defensive. He must seize the initiative rather than each day responding querulously to the drip of bile. Scotland must keep faith with its nascent parliament if it is not to earn - and deserve - international contempt.

fields.headline: Buildings for a better future
fields.trailText: Over the last 10 years, British housebuilders have built new housing estates using land more extravagantly than anywhere else in Europe and the United States. They have argued against 'socialist planning' which might limit their appetite and insisted that market forces be allowed to dictate land use and urban development so that, on average, only 23 house units have been built on every hectare of land. The result has been the creation of massive urban sprawls and the erosion of green spaces.
fields.body:
Over the last 10 years, British housebuilders have built new housing estates using land more extravagantly than anywhere else in Europe and the United States. They have argued against 'socialist planning' which might limit their appetite and insisted that market forces be allowed to dictate land use and urban development so that, on average, only 23 house units have been built on every hectare of land. The result has been the creation of massive urban sprawls and the erosion of green spaces.

Something must give. Either Britain has to accept a wave of further urbanisation or it has to use the space in existing urban areas - brownfield sites - more efficiently. For months, John Prescott has been fighting a lonely battle in favour of toughening up planning regulations in favour of higher density building, and as we report today, it seems he has won the first round of his battle. The Government is to issue planning guidelines demanding that houses in future are built so they consume less land, and is to back up its recommendation by lifting VAT on house renovations, so encouraging the construction of additional rooms in existing houses.

This is only a beginning. If the Government is serious about limiting suburban sprawl and is to meet its own demanding targets that 60 per cent of all new homes are built on brownfield sites, it must go much further. It will have to revisit the planning permission given for the construction of 650,000 households on rural land already, and it will have to tell housebuilders who have bought 90 per cent of the greenfield land allocated for new development over the next 20 years that it reserves the right to withdraw such land from development. And it will need to tax greenfield development while increasing the incentives for brownfield development.

But just building within our existing cities to slightly higher densities is not enough. We need urban development to be informed by a richer vision of what urban life should be. We like the high density housing we find in the Georgian areas of our cities. We should encourage such creativity again. Mr Prescott has won round one; he must now win rounds two, three and four.
