webTitle: Give us the right to life

fields.headline: Give us the right to life
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: In the midst of the continuing loyalist feud in mid-Ulster there has been a reminder of the bizarre parallel moral universes which all paramilitaries and their supporters inhabit. The Ulster Freedom Fighters joined the propaganda front of the internal loyalist war last week by publicly condemning the butchery of two teenagers outside Tandragee. In their statement the UFF noted that Protestants were now in more danger of being killed by fellow Protestants than their republican enemies.
fields.body:
In the midst of the continuing loyalist feud in mid-Ulster there has been a reminder of the bizarre parallel moral universes which all paramilitaries and their supporters inhabit. The Ulster Freedom Fighters joined the propaganda front of the internal loyalist war last week by publicly condemning the butchery of two teenagers outside Tandragee. In their statement the UFF noted that Protestants were now in more danger of being killed by fellow Protestants than their republican enemies.

The implication here is that it is somehow worse that loyalist paramilitaries should be killing members of their own community instead of those on the other side of the sectarian divide. The suspicion that Taigs can still be regarded as fair game (theoretically, of course, in the eyes of pro-ceasefire loyalists) while fellow Prods are out of bounds was bolstered by the silence of groups like the UFF last Wednesday when dissident loyalists attempted to murder a Catholic cyclist in Antrim.

The UFF are not the only loyalist grouping guilty of such double standards. Take the case of two young women savagely tortured and then killed by members of the UVF in the early Nineties. In 1992 Anne Marie Smyth was severely beaten and then had her throat cut.

Some of those involved in this murder were later taken onto the UVF wing in the Maze and are due to be released early under the terms of the Good Friday Agreement.

Two years later another young woman, Margaret Wright, was beaten, shot in the head and dumped in a rubbish bin. Two of Ms Wright's killers were shot dead by the UVF for their part in her murder; the others, under pain of death, had to plead guilty in the courts. So, while some of Ms Smyth's killers eventually gained from the UVF's ceasefire, Ms Wright's killers got a bullet in the head from the same organi sation. The difference between the two was, of course, that Ms Wright was a Protestant and Ms Smyth was a Catholic.

In the former case the UVF responded rapidly to the widespread revulsion and anger in the Protestant community. There were no such demands though for rough justice over the slaughter of Anne Marie Smyth. Now no one who truly believes in human rights could ever excuse the perverted justice meted out to the likes of Margaret Wright's killers. However, the double standards exhibited in these two cases exposes the moral contradictions pervading the communities from which terrorist groups sprang, where the People spoke out about Margaret Wright but turned a blind eye to Anne-Marie Smyth.

Highlighting the parallel moral universes of paramilitarism brings us to the launch this week of a public consultation process aimed at drawing up a Bill of Rights for Northern Ireland. If the Bill is to have any practical relevance then Article 1 must deal with these contradictions _ that no one should die because of his or her political or religious beliefs.

All the parties, especially those intrinsically linked to paramilitary forces, should be obliged to sign this charter, thus committing them to exclusively peaceful means. A right-to-life clause is infinitely more important than any other rights such as those dealing with culture, economics, language and so on. The Bill of Rights will not be worth the paper it is written on unless that fundamental freedom from death and injury at the hands of political opponents is central to it.

To argue that the only human rights are those that protect the citizen from the state is outmoded. We live in a society where there is a state, possibly dual states, within a state in which human rights are abused every day.

In the absence of such an imperative the moral double-think of terror groups, who see no evil in burning the other, but cry foul when their former brothers burn their own, will continue to thrive and go unchallenged.

 Henry McDonald's new biography of David Trimble is published this month by Bloomsbury at £16.99

fields.headline: Letters to the Editor
fields.standfirst: Bragg's praise for Blair is misled
fields.trailText: Bragg's praise for Blair is misled
fields.body:
Melvyn Bragg has entirely underestimated the angry sense of betrayal, from those of us on the Left, who worked hard to see an end to a generation of Tory rule (Comment extra, last week).

Of course we don't want a return to the nightmare of Conservative government. However, neither do we want a Blair administration to adopt all the old Tory public spending targets and embrace their rolling programme of privatisation with the single minded zeal of a convert!

Bragg's billing of Blairism as 'a moral crusade' is stretching the messianic to the point of absurdity. To many activists on the Left, Blair's revolution is Orwellian in merely replacing one exclusive élite with another. For New Labour read New Tory. Some of us looking from the outside in are finding it increasingly hard to spot the difference!
Richard Denton-White
Co-chair UK-wide Tactical Voting Campaign 1997
Portland
Dorset

 As a newly resigned ex-member of the Labour Party I read Melvyn Bragg's article with great interest. It confirmed my long-held belief that people will believe what they wish to believe, whatever the facts. The facts are that there is growing disillusion with New Labour throughout the UK. Not because of 'control freakery' or the 'dark forces of conservatism' but quite simply because of the Government's ready abandonment of the promises, commitments and policy statements made when in Opposition. Miracles were not expected after the last election, the problems were too serious and deep seated for instant cures, but what was expected was that commitments previously made would start to be implemented.
C.P. Cooper
Barnsley
S Yorks

 It would appear that Lord Bragg has yet to awaken from the vinous reverie that made him miss the dawn of Tony's Brave New World, otherwise he might have tempered his embar rassing hagiography. Mandelson's loan, Northern Ireland, humanitarian bombing in Kosovo, Iraq, GM U-turn, Railtrack U-turn, Alun Michael fiasco, China visit protesters gagged , the Labour Mayoral election - all swept away by the Bragg gush. But then this particular Tony crony - oops, sorry about the canard - long ago lost all objectivity, witness his S outh Bank plug for Michael Douglas.
William Golden
Rothwell
Northamptonshire

 Praising Mr Blair and his policies, Melvyn Bragg writes, 'Keir Hardie will be smiling in his grave'. MPs have just received an increase in salary of £26 per week. State pensions for the elderly are due to rise by 75p per week. Thus the gap between rich and poor is widened. Keir Hardie may be weeping in his grave.
John Close
Glasgow

 The irony that Melvyn Bragg writes an article in praise of the Prime Minister, from the House of Lords, to which he was appointed by no less than the Prime Minister, appears utterly lost on Lord Bragg. No wonder New Labour is rapidly losing the plot.
John Killah
Frome

fields.headline: A time to give
fields.trailText: Lady Bountiful is not quite dead: she is still there to open the féte or the sale of work. But in modern Britain she is outnumbered by an army of volunteers. Once it was thought that the reach of the welfare state could and should be limitless. Thatcherism's recruitment of the volunteer in its attack on the 'nanny state' reinforced suspicions that the 'third sector', as it has been called, was simply a euphemism for cheap labour which might erode essential public services.
fields.body:
Lady Bountiful is not quite dead: she is still there to open the féte or the sale of work. But in modern Britain she is outnumbered by an army of volunteers. Once it was thought that the reach of the welfare state could and should be limitless. Thatcherism's recruitment of the volunteer in its attack on the 'nanny state' reinforced suspicions that the 'third sector', as it has been called, was simply a euphemism for cheap labour which might erode essential public services.

Not just for reasons of fiscal realism Tony Blair has rightly come to see that volunteering is not just a means of containing costs. It is dynamic and creative, responsive beyond the capacity of bureaucrats to human needs. Its energy often flows from personal bereavement, social outrage or a community of suffering, whether at home or abroad, in tragedies which are either intensely public, as in Mozambique, or intimately private, as in the onset of disease.

The emergence of this vital force in society has bred resentments in the sector itself. It has complained that its goodwill has been exploited and that it has been denied consistent funding or involvement in making policies it helps to deliver. Four years ago the Deakin Commission proposed a 'compact' between the state and the sector, an idea accepted by the Labour Government after some initial reluctance. Last week the Prime Minister endorsed it as a keynote theme for the new millennium.

It's a move we welcome. Our culture often seems rampantly consumerist and self-centred. Yet the reality is not so bleak; many thousands of people already give their time for causes in which they believe. But, as Mr Blair noted, they are still too few. The sector has complex obligations and, increasingly, is professionally managed. Yet it depends on those who are bountiful not with condescension but with their time, their energy and their passion for a better world. The Prime Minister promised them support and more systematic sustenance; they deserve it.

Its energy often flows from personal bereavement, social outrage or a community of suffering, whether at home or abroad, in tragedies which are either intensely public, as in Mozambique, or intimately private, as in the onset of disease. The emergence of this vital force in society has bred resentments in the sector itself. It has complained that its goodwill has been exploited and that it has been denied consistent funding or involvement in making policies it helps to deliver. Four years ago the Deakin Commission proposed a 'compact' between the state and the sector, an idea accepted by the Labour Government after some initial reluctance. Last week the Prime Minister endorsed it as a keynote theme for the new millennium. It's a move we welcome. Our culture often seems rampantly consumerist and self-centred. Yet the reality is not so bleak; many thousands of people already give their time for causes in which they believe. But, as Mr Blair noted, they are still too few. The sector has complex obligations and, increasingly, is professionally managed. Yet it depends on those who are bountiful not with condescension but with their time, their energy and their passion for a better world. The Prime Minister promised them support and more systematic sustenance; they deserve it.

webTitle: Turkish web hero Cagri tastes power

fields.headline: Turkish web hero Cagri tastes power
fields.standfirst: Forbes.com
fields.trailText: Accidental Internet star Mahir Cagri, the Turkish bachelor who found fame after greeting the world with a chaste kiss from his website, has made it onto  Forbes magazine's Power 100 list of the most influential people in the entertainment industry.
fields.body:
Accidental Internet star Mahir Cagri, the Turkish bachelor who found fame after greeting the world with a chaste kiss from his website, has made it onto Forbes magazine's Power 100 list of the most influential people in the entertainment industry.

The 37-year-old teacher-cum-poet-cum-musician has crept on to the list at number 100, hot on the heels of such celebrities as George and Barbara Bush at 76, and supermodels Tyra Banks and Christy Turlington, who come in at 80 and 84 respectively.

Cagri first came to public attention in this country last November, when The Observer highlighted the phenomenal popularity of his guileless personal website. Since then, his celebrity has gone global.

President Clinton and Bill Gates have sent him personal e-mails and he recently kissed the US TV personality Roseanne Barr, live on her show. (The comedienne is only 26 places above him on the Forbes list.)

Opening with the welcoming words 'I Kiss You', Cagri's original website took visitors through the essential details of his life and displayed ingenuous snapshots of him sunbathing, at the table tennis table and enjoying playing the accordion with friends in Turkey. He also invited the women of the world to come to stay with him in Izmir. Within 24 hours his site had been visited by 500,000 people.

The Forbes list is headed by actress Julia Roberts who earns $50m and has 41 million web hits, or 'eyeballs', to her name. At number 25, the British children's writer J.K. Rowling, creator of Harry Potter, makes her first appearance this year, but there is generally little space afforded to non-Americans. The Turk joins Australian Mel Gibson, the British members of The Rolling Stones, the German Michael Schumacher and a few tennis stars as the only foreigners.

When Cagri arrived in America recently he was greeted by a band of fans waving banners. In England last week it was a different story.

Cagri stepped incognito onto British soil for the first time last Thursday night as the guest of a leading London advertising agency who hope to work with him on a campaign this spring.

Before he flew back to Turkey yesterday, Cagri told The Observer over lunch that he was determined to use his fame to improve the world. When he first realised that he was something of a hero to ordinary web-users everywhere, Cagri added an appeal for world peace and for an end to poverty to the end of his webpage.

Cagri has been quick too, to restore his reputation. While he certainly owes part of his fame to the fact that his website once said he liked sex and to 'take foto-camera (amimals, towns, nice nude models and peoples)' these sentences were in fact naughty additions to his site made by a Turkish prankster.

Still it is an ill wind that blows nobody any good and although Cagri is not exactly a dotcom billionaire, having earned only around $5,000 from his fame so far, that all looks set to change.

webTitle: Spotless star's dark secret shakes Israel

fields.headline: Spotless star's dark secret shakes Israel
fields.standfirst: 'Isn't it time for the citizens of Israel to relate to Aids asthey do to cancer or dysentery?'
fields.trailText: 'Isn't it time for the citizens of Israel to relate to Aids asthey do to cancer or dysentery?'
fields.body:
They say the bereaved pass through several stages of grief, but in Israel the legions of fans of the singer Ofra Haza have been stuck on anger ever since a newspaper dared to print what had been circulating as rumour for days. The entertainer with a spotless private life, whose rise to stardom from the slums of Tel Aviv chimed so well with Israel's self-image as a land of opportunity, had died of complications from Aids.

In the days since the front-page report in the Haaretz newspaper - which has yet to be confirmed by Haza's ferociously private family -- there has been intense debate on radio and television chat shows on whether the press was right to reveal the cause of the singer's death.

The focus has been not on the attitudes of a still traditional society but on assigning blame. Haza's husband of two years, businessman Doron Ashkenazi, emerged in weekend supplements on Friday as the favourite villain.

'We just could not believe such a thing could happen to Ofra, because Ofra was like a saint,' says Tsedi Tsarfati, a music director who worked with Haza for 15 years. 'The first time I saw her holding hands with a man was at the henna ceremony one week before her marriage. In my mind, she was like a nun, and all Israelis think this way, although they might not say it: she can't be married, she can't be with a man, and there is no way she could have Aids. We have to blame somebody because we just can't understand this.'

If Haza, who was 41, did indeed die of Aids - and the reports have not been denied - she would be Israel's first celebrity known to have done so, and Haza's fame was international. Introducing her soulful version of Yemenite music to European audiences in the Eighties with the much-sampled 'Im Nin Alu' hit, she went on to perform at the Nobel prize ceremony honouring the Israeli-Palestinian peace process, and to provide backing music on Hollywood film scores. She sang the role of Moses's mother in the animated film Prince of Egypt .

Israelis loved her because she was a living success story. She began making her escape from the poverty of her Hatikva neighbourhood in south Tel Aviv while still a teenager. The clutter of mean, narrow streets has been home to waves of poor immigrants. In Haza's youth it was a ghetto for Jews from Yemen, Iraq and Morocco who came to Israel after independence only to wind up as second-class citizens in the Zionist state. The European cultural élite called them primitive.

Haza was the youngest in a Yemenite family of nine, who overcame their misgivings about letting a daughter out in an alien world when a local impresario set up a theatre group. Haza began touring kibbutzim and small towns, and went on to entertain the troops in the Sinai and Golan during the October 1973 war.

She was always a trouper, her friends recall. 'Everybody loved her,' says Mikhail Sinuani, another Hatikva resident. 'She was never spoilt. During the war, there were times when we could not shower for a week or two, we were in bunkers, but she never complained.'

But even after she made it big, Haza evidently felt unable to tell her fans about her illness, which is what prompted Haaretz to break a taboo -- and strict privacy laws - to announce she had Aids. In the resulting furore, staff at the hospital, who are furious that they were not told, demanded an inquiry into her stay there.

'We are talking about a human disease which in our eyes is just like any other disease,' Yoel Esteron, the deputy editor of Haaretz, told a talk show last week. 'The more the days passed, and the more this conspiracy of secrecy grew to reach monstrous dimensions, the more we thought we ought to publish. Isn't it time the citizens of Israel relate to Aids as they do to cancer or dysentery?'

Maybe not. Aviram Germanovitch, executive director of the Israel Aids Task Force in Tel Aviv, says the organisation's hotline has 'exploded' from the volume of calls since the story broke, and that the number of clients at its anonymous testing centres has doubled. Testing centres at hospitals report a similar pattern.

He argues it is unrealistic to suppose that Israel can banish the stigma attached to the disease so long as the Health Ministry spends just seven US cents per citizen on Aids awareness -- compared to an average of $1.50 in the European Union. Although Israel officially has 2,500 peo ple with HIV, the United Nations and the local Aids Task Force say the true number is four times that figure.

'The whole hoo-ha about Ofra Haza has brought a microscope on what is happening in this country,' Germanovitch, who is HIV positive, said. 'The majority of people with HIV are living in secrecy, and in fear of being discovered, and having to live with shame. Magic Johnson took the issue and he made a great leap forward in awareness. He said: "This Aids thing, it's a virus, it's not me." But we have not had anyone like that in Israel.'

In hindsight, Haza was a most unlikely emissary for Aids awareness. In the entertainment world, she re-mained a mystery even to her closest collaborators. For 27 years she was the virtual property of her manager, Bezalel Aloni, who, other singers say, kept her aloof from her colleagues. She lived in the second half of a duplex with the Aloni family, breaking free only when she married Ashkenazi.

According to Aloni, that was her undoing, and he was so bitter at the manner of her death that he did not attend her funeral. 'I was everything for her,' he says. 'Then that guy came and took her away.'

In Hatikvah, they will never forgive the press for exposing Haza's fiercely guarded secret. Her parents live there still, in a modest house on Boaz Street that has been embellished with coach lamps and expensive window shutters that are firmly closed despite a sunny day in early spring that has coaxed most of the neighbours outdoors.

'Please don't bother us any more,' said one. 'She kept herself to herself when she was alive. Why should we know all her private details now that she is gone? Let her rest in peace.'

webTitle: The killer who was a victim

fields.headline: The killer who was a victim
fields.standfirst:
A dazed America is desperately seeking someone to blame after a six-year-old shot his classmate dead with his uncle's gun.

Gun violence in America: special report
fields.trailText: A dazed America is desperately seeking someone to blame after a six-year-old shot his classmate dead with his uncle's gun
fields.body:
Who should take the rap? The authorities in Michigan are trying to work out the answer in a case which defies imagination but cannot defy the law. Who pays the price for the death of Kayla Rolland, aged six, who set off for school on Tuesday but never came back - shot dead by one of her classmates?

Her killer was also six. The pair had been 'acting pretty age-proportionate,' says his court-appointed lawyer, Douglas Theodriff. 'The little girl was spinning her hair, and the kids were just kind of slapping at each other.' The pair had quarrelled the previous day.

Then out came the gun, a .32 semi-automatic that blasted Kayla Rolland to - her parents inisist - paradise. The boy later told detectives that he only meant to scare her.

On Friday night, they buried little Kayla, laid out in a tiny white casket. She looked like a porcelain doll, dressed in a red shirt, a white bunny rabbit at her side. A thousand people packed the funeral home, wearing pink ribbons. Beside the embalmed body, her mother wept; her sister buried her face in her kneeling mother's left shoulder. A scary-looking man dressed in biker gear said: 'I will always love you'.

Kayla had been a shy girl, who prayed before eating school lunch. She kept herself to herself, and played with her Barbie doll during breaktime. She went to Sunday school. She played kickball, she had difficulty with spelling and said she wanted to be a doctor when she grew up.

She spurned the shadowy world of drugs and violence around her, as did her mother and stepfather. Along with a brother, sister and three dogs, the family lived in a small house and survived on modest means. A neighbour, Don Mark aged 75, said that 'the whole family is real nice. There ain't nothing they wouldn't do for anybody'.

The authorities, meanwhile, began the process of law on Friday, by arresting the boy's uncle, with whom he lived - Jamelle Andrew James, aged 19. James kept the the gun underneath blankets in the bedroom of his home, and is charged with involuntary manslaughter, for having allowed his nephew access to the weapon. He was arrested on an outstanding warrant for receiving stolen property - another gun was also found, loaded and stolen.

In an apparent gesture of the seriousness of the arrest, James was held in lieu of $100,000 bail. Another man, whom the police decline to name, is reported to have turned himself in, saying that he had the handgun before the boy found it.

There are no plans to arrest the boy himself, said the Genesee County prosecutor Arthur Busch - he cannot be charged because of his age. Detectives, he said, were convinced the killer had 'no idea what he had done'. After his interview with detectives, the boy had 'sat there drawing pictures'.

Had he expressed remorse? 'As much as a six-year-old boy can. I think he realised he had dome something naughty, but not the enormity or gravity of what had actually occurred.'

Mr Busch added: 'We are not looking for scapegoats in this case. We are looking for justice for Kayla'.

Mr James's home, where the killer lived with his eight-year-old brother, begins in itself to describe the depravity and tragedy of the case, set as it is in a landscape of wretched, comfortless urban despair in boom-time Amer ica.

The house sits back from the street in a working class district of Mount Norris Township, just north of the auto-manufacturing centre of Flint. It is a community of 23,000, where more than 80 per cent of the children at the Theo Buell Elementary school qualify for the federally-funded school lunch programme - a euphemism to mean that they live below the poverty level.

Michael Moore, the film director, made a famous documentary about Flint's decline, with that of the auto-industry recession of the 1980s, and said on Friday: 'When you put abject poverty together with easy access to guns, you have a recipe for this kind of violence'.

The county prosecutor said that the boy's 'immersion into the drug culture by the adults who cared for him, and the violence that goes with it, combined to turn him into a young killer'.

The building in which he lived is bordered on one side by a mud driveway. Garbage bags are taped over the broken windows. In the front yard lies an empty vodka bottle beside a car without wheels propped on four breeze blocks.

A few months ago, neighbours watched the police arrive and take away two youths in handcuffs. These little boys were growing up in a crack den. They didn't even have a bed to sleep on. People were constantly coming and going, doing deals.

The boys' father, Cedric Owens, is in jail after a conviction for burglary - he had been paroled but violated the terms, and was picked up 11 days ago. Upon hearing of the shooting, Mr Owens said he had had a'a cold, sinking feeling, because he knew it was his son,' said Genessee County Sheriff, Robert Pickel.

The boy's mother, Tamara, had taken him and his brother to live in the drug-dealing nest after being evicted from her own home. She knew the house well, having gone there on several occasions to feed her own crack habit. A fortnight ago she moved on, dumping the boys on her brother, James.

But even before then, life had been hard for the children - the warning signs were plentiful. Tamara Owens was convicted in 1992 for abusing the killer's older brother. Tamara was herself involved in drugs for years.

The boy had been singled out at school as needing help, under a programme which is supposed to identify children with special prolems.

He had been assigned a social worker and undergone children's counselling. A memo quoted in the affidavit from the social work department had earmarked the boys as 'living in a dangerous environment' and being 'at imminent risk'.

As it turns out, the risk was to his classmates. The boy had found the weapon under his uncle's pile of blankets, tucked it into his trouser pocket and walked off to school. It was loaded with three bullets.

Police believe that he had shown the gun to his friends before pulling it out of his pocket shortly after 10am as his teacher, Alicia Judd, was lining up the class, single file, to go to the computer lab. He had pointed it at another boy, then suddenly whirled round, honed in on Kayla Rolland and opened fire. After hitting the little girl in the chest, the boy returned to his own desk, carefully put the gun away and reported to the school office.

In a bizarre counterpoint to the authorities' efforts to date, Kayla's father Ricky Rolland has retained Geoffrey Fieger as his attorney - the former candidate for governor of Michigan best known as lawyer for 'Dr Death', Jack Kevorkian, convicted for his role in a string of assisted suicides.

Mr Fieger also represented the parents of two children killed at the Columbine school shooting in Colorado, in pursuit of a civil law verdict of wrongful killing. In this case, Fieger said, he would also be targeting the authorities at the children's school - Theo Buell Elementary - whom he says were acting improperly in failing to safeguard the children's safety.

The school countered yesterday, superintendent Ira Rutherford saying that the 'events were an aberrration, highly, highy unusual'. Parents, however, have protested against lax security at the school.

The boy's father has said from prison that his son was once suspeded from school for fighting, and had stabbed a girl with a pencil - details which the school authorities would not confirm yesterday. Mr Owens had asked: "why do you do this?'. 'I hate them,' the boy had replied.

'I can only say that we were aware there were problems with him,' said superintendent Rutherford of Kayla's killer who now takes his place in the record books as America's youngest ever school killer.

He had pointed it at another boy, then suddenly whirled round, honed in on Kayla Rolland and opened fire. After hitting the little girl in the chest, the boy returned to his own desk, carefully put the gun away and reported to the school office. In a bizarre counterpoint to the authorities' efforts to date, Kayla's father Ricky Rolland has retained Geoffrey Fieger as his attorney - the former candidate for governor of Michigan best known as lawyer for 'Dr Death', Jack Kevorkian, convicted for his role in a string of assisted suicides. Mr Fieger also represented the parents of two children killed at the Columbine school shooting in Colorado, in pursuit of a civil law verdict of wrongful killing. In this case, Fieger said, he would also be targeting the authorities at the children's school - Theo Buell Elementary - whom he says were acting improperly in failing to safeguard the children's safety. The school countered yesterday, superintendent Ira Rutherford saying that the 'events were an aberrration, highly, highy unusual'. Parents, however, have protested against lax security at the school. The boy's father has said from prison that his son was once suspeded from school for fighting, and had stabbed a girl with a pencil - details which the school authorities would not confirm yesterday. Mr Owens had asked: "why do you do this?'. 'I hate them,' the boy had replied. 'I can only say that we were aware there were problems with him,' said superintendent Rutherford of Kayla's killer who now takes his place in the record books as America's youngest ever school killer.

fields.headline: Infamous five rile German literati
fields.standfirst:
New writers under fire as they abandon literary theory for champagne

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: New writers under fire as they abandon literary theory for champagne
fields.body:
They are young, moneyed and successful, but the five authors of Germany's most talked about book for years have become hate figures for the literary and intellectual establishment. Dismissed in Der Spiegel as 'the blathering five' and denounced by the wife of President Johannes Rau as 'dreadful', the writers known as 'the pop-cultural quintet' have received a critical bashing that is intense even by Germany's robust standards.

Yet their book, Tristesse Royale, contains no sex, violence or foul language and is not racist, sexist or homo-phobic. It is nothing more threatening than a 200-page conversation between five friends during a weekend at a Berlin's smartest hotel.

Joachim Bessing, Christian Kracht, Eckhart Nickel, Alexander von Schönburg and Benjamin von Stuckrad-Barre share a taste for champagne, designer labels and unfashionable rock music.

They go into raptures about such life-enhancing details as the way lavatory paper in hotel rooms is folded into a triangle at the end and endlessly list their favourite designers, brands and commercials. But their enthusiasms are matched by a haughty disdain for everything they see as 'proletarian', and much of their conversation is characterised by the crudest snobbery.

'These phoneys look like Silesian gherkin canapés and they write like that too. You could feel sorry for them if they weren't so arrogant,' snorted Feridun Zaimoglu, a German writer who is of Turkish origin.

Der Spiegel branded the book humourless and banal. 'This highly embarrassing quintet reminds one involuntarily of those little groups in old people's homes whose conversations turn first thing in the morning to how the digestion was and what there will be for dinner this evening,' the magazine wrote.One newspaper simply ran the headline: 'Stuckrad-Barre must die.'

The extraordinary hostility evoked may owe something to the fact that, unattractive as Tristesse Royale undeniably is, it presents a telling snapshot of a new generation of Germans who live to consume and party.

This generation, which shares none of the gloomy self-doubt of the postwar Germans and lacks the reforming passion of the rebels of 1968, has transformed German culture in recent years and dominates the world of the arts.

Films such as Tom Tykwer's Run Lola Run have brought a new energy to German cinema after decades under the shadow of Fassbinder, Wenders and Schlöndorff. German-produced music is more popular than ever before, diversifying to include such curiosities as German rap and reggae.

It is in the world of literature that the most dramatic change has taken place, however, as the postwar generation of writer-thinkers, such as last year's Nobel laureate, Günter Grass, and Christa Wolf, gives way to a group of successful young writers.

They are marketed like pop stars, appear in advertisements for fashion houses and sell books in numbers most new writers would not dare to dream of.

Writers such as Grass, Heinrich Böll and Martin Walser, who belonged to the postwar Gruppe 47, produced their greatest work at a time when the legitimacy of literature itself was being called into question. In the wake of the Holocaust, many German writers set their faces against narrative altogether and, in the spirit of the 1968 student revolt, declared that all 'bourgeois literature' was dead.

By the Eighties, German literature itself appeared to be dead and, apart from Patrick Süskind's Perfume - which was published in Switzerland after German publishers rejected it - no German novel made an impact abroad.

In contrast with the Grass generation, the new writers appear unburdened by history, political purpose or literary theory. The writers of Tristesse Royale have taken this carefree spirit further than most. But their unreflective, politically unaware outlook is typical not only of their literary peers but of their entire generation.

 Denis Staunton writes for the 'Irish Times'

fields.headline: Stench of Biafra returns
fields.standfirst: Ben Brown  reports from Kaduna on the savage violence between Muslims and Christians that is threatening to drown hopes for Nigeria's new-born democracy in bloodshed
fields.trailText: The spectre of a new Biafra is haunting Nigeria, after a wave of sectarian killings that may have claimed 2,000 lives.
fields.body:
The spectre of a new Biafra is haunting Nigeria, after a wave of sectarian killings that may have claimed 2,000 lives.

Over the last fortnight, gangs of Christians and Muslims have been slaughtering each other, using guns, clubs, swords, machetes, bows and arrows and the infamous African 'necklaces': tyres put over the head, doused in petrol and then set on fire.

In the northern city of Kaduna alone, it is estimated 1,000 may have died. Mortuaries ran out of room for the dead and corpses had to be piled up on the floor. Mounds of red earth - mass graves, to prevent the outbreak of disease - have sprung up around the city.

Kaduna's communal killings were ignited by the controversial plans of some northern Nigerian states to introduce Sharia, the strict Islamic code of justice. A Christian march against the plan turned into a riot, and the violence spread like bushfire to other parts of this vast country, the most populous in Africa. In the south-eastern city of Aba, Christian Ibos went on the rampage when bodies of their friends or relatives were shipped home from Kaduna. The death toll in Aba was another 400 at least. Once unleashed, this cycle of revenge is hard to stop.

A young Christian vigilante in the Rigasa district of Kaduna told me he had no choice but to fight. 'The Muslims came at us with everything. We had to defend ourselves, we had to fight back.' He took me down a lonely back street, which was still littered with rotting and bloated corpses.

Pigs were nibbling away at the dead, who often lie just a yard or two from the front door of their homes. Victims were dragged out and would then have their religion checked, before they were either freed or put to death. Some were judged by the fervour with which they could reply to a religious incantation. Others, often the more prosperous, were denounced by jealous neighbours. My Muslim driver told me he now carries a Bible in his car, in case he is accosted by Christian militants.

In mixed districts, the gangs were careful whom and what they attacked. On a street corner in Kaduna, there are two petrol stations next to each other: the Muslim one has been razed, the Christian one hasn't been touched. The hatred was meticulous: in a gutted church, the face of a stone statuette of Jesus was gouged out.

Eye-witnesses say unemployed youths of both religions roamed around the city clutching cans of petrol. Systematically, they set light to houses, businesses and human beings. Entire districts have been destroyed. Kaduna looks like a war zone.

Both Christians and Muslims were quite simply attempting to exterminate their rival community, and over a three-day period they set about it with a zeal and clinical efficiency.

'My father had his throat slit,' said Emmanuel Dogara, a Catholic. 'He was slaughtered like a goat, while my mother was stabbed and beaten senseless. Jesus says we should love our neighbours as we love ourselves, but we are frightened. We cannot live with them.'

Like thousands of others, from both religious communities, Emmanuel is joining a panic-stricken exodus out of Kaduna. 'Most likely there'll be more violence,' predicted Charles Ibeh, a Christian Ibo who decided to seek protection in the city's army barracks. 'They've already written on our homes that we've been sentenced to death.'

In a Catholic missionary hospital, Adamu Haruna, a Muslim, had just regained consciousness after being clubbed and stoned. His mistake was to be driving around with a message from the Koran plastered across his windscreen.

Ironically, Adamu, a Muslim attacked by Christians, is now being treated by Christians. But the hospital is so basic that flies swarm over the patients' open wounds. A terribly burnt boy, 12 years old, was trying to swat them away. A mob had wrapped him in dried grass and set it alight.

The violence amounts to an awesome test for President Olusegun Obasanjo, elected just a year ago, and for Nigeria's new democracy. There are some who suggest discontented elements within the army may have helped orchestrate the violence, in order to have an excuse for seizing back power.

Aliyo Abdul Hamid was a boy in Biafra, and agonising memories of the conflict linger within him. Three decades on, he lives in Kaduna, or rather he did. His comfortable home, equipped with satellite television, is now a charred shell. 'No one who was in Biafra wants to see such a thing ever again. Nigeria breaking up is hard to believe, but these events have given everyone a shock. Now you can't trust your neighbour any more.'

The trouble is that many of the young killers here are not old enough to remember the horror of Biafra.

 Ben Brown is Foreign Affairs Correspondent for the BBC.

webTitle: Elixir of youth could rejuvenate elderly

fields.headline: Elixir of youth could rejuvenate elderly
fields.trailText: An elixir that will rejuvenate the hearts and other muscles of elderly people is being developed by scientists. The breakthrough could soon enable 80-year-olds to throw away their walking sticks and Zimmer frames.
fields.body:
An elixir that will rejuvenate the hearts and other muscles of elderly people is being developed by scientists. The breakthrough could soon enable 80-year-olds to throw away their walking sticks and Zimmer frames.

Research on the drugs - called breakers - is being pioneered by one of America's leading medical researchers, Professor Tony Cerami. Last week he revealed they had re-invigorated the muscles and arteries of dogs and monkeys.

'We can't teach old dogs new tricks but we have found we can put a spring back in their step,' said Cerami, a member of the prestigious US National Academy of Sciences. 'Hopefully, we will soon do that for humans.' His trials found that old dogs given breakers began pumping blood around their bodies with the vigour of puppies, while elderly rhesus monkeys were restored to the muscular vitality of their middle years.

Now tests are to begin on similar drugs for people, though Cerami told a Novartis Foundation symposium on ageing last week that it would take several years' further research and development before human breakers would be ready for sale.

Cerami, who is based at the Kenneth Warren laboratories in New York, has spent much of his career investigating the impact of glucose.

This 'provides us with power to run our bodies but over the years also causes proteins in us to become linked together,' he said. The cross-linking is implicated in ageing, Cerami has discovered. For instance, the brown flecks of tissue that appear on the old people's bones, teeth and corneas are by-products of glucose that has caused proteins to combine into larger clumps.

'You see the same sort of effect when you bake a ham or chicken with sugar coating - it causes the flesh to brown,' he said. 'And so it is with ageing. It's the effect of cooking your body with glucose at 37 degrees Celsius for decades.'

Cross-linking also causes joints, arteries and heart tissue to stiffen. As a result, people find it increasingly difficult to move quickly as they get older, while their hearts cannot pump blood round the body so efficiently. These effects are particularly noticeable in diabetics, who have excess glucose surging round their bodies and who are therefore especially vulnerable to protein cross-linking and to eye and heart damage. 'Diabetes is, in a sense, a disease of early ageing.'

It was research on diabetes that led Cerami to search for chemicals that might slow down and even block the cross-linking. A few years ago, his team reported they had developed such inhibitors and could stop some of the stiffening of muscle, heart and artery tissue.

Now they have gone a critical stage further by creating a drug, ALT-711 - called a breaker because it can break the bonds between proteins, so undoing the effects of ageing.

The results of the trials on dogs and monkeys are to be published by the National Academy of Science within a few weeks. They will reveal that, when Cerami administered elderly monkeys aged over 20 years and dogs aged over 12 years with ALT-711, their hearts and arteries were restored to the functioning of young animals.

'We used standard tests, such as pulse wave velocity, to ascertain their improve ment, and found their blood flow and heart function got much, much better,' he said. 'They were rejuvenated.'

The US biotechnology company Alteon is now preparing drugs based on ALT-711 for tests in human clinical trials. 'By the end of the decade, we should be able to use these things on humans,' added Cerami. 'Then we will truly have turned back the clock of ageing.'

fields.headline: How TV crossed taste barrier
fields.standfirst: The hidden past of the groom on Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire has sparked a backlash against voyeur programming.
fields.trailText: The hidden past of the groom on Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire has sparked a backlash against voyeur programming.
fields.body:
It was a big 'gut feeling', always the genesis of a good piece of investigative journalism. It was the hunch that Rick Rockwell, the 'multimillionaire' who had just married a woman he'd never met in a landmark moment of notoriety for American television, was not all he appeared to the 23 million voyeurs watching.

For while the ratings were good, Rupert Murdoch's Fox Television has been left clutching a can of worms after two New York reporters made good on that gut feeling over Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire, unearthing court documents that revealed Rockwell's ex-fiancée had once accused him of hitting her and threatening her life.

For once, the furore over the wedding fiasco was too much even for the normally unembarrassable Fox network, which has spent more than a decade plumbing the depths of human gullibility, stupidity and depravity for profit as the pioneer of so-called 'shockumentaries'. Faster than Rick Rockwell and bride Darva Conger could get their 'quickie annulment', Fox publicly divorced itself from the highly profitable and often perverse genre.

'They're gone, they're over,' Fox Entertainment chairman Sandy Grushow told the New York Times , pronouncing the end of what he called 'exploitative reality specials' on the network.

Thanks to the investigative enterprise of a tiny Internet 'e-zine', TheSmokingGun.com, American viewers have been spared - for the moment - 'anything that is exploitative, that reeks of desperation, anything that's merely out for ratings' on the network behind World's Scariest Police Chases , When Good Pets Go Bad and World's Worst Drivers . Little gems such as Plastic Surgery Nightmares, Busted on the Job 5 and The World's Biggest Bitches have been scrapped.

Not bad going for TheSmokingGun, which is so small it doesn't even have an office. Founded three years ago by Village Voice investigative crime reporter William Bastone and freelancer Daniel Green, TheSmokingGun.com was set up on a budget of $500 a month and a hunch that the raw materials of journalism - lawsuits, police reports, affidavits and the like - would make good Internet reading.

Apart from causing a minor sensation last year with its disclosure that Malcolm X's bullet-ridden pocket diary had disappeared from prosecution evidence and ended up on the cyber-auctioneer eBay, TheSmokingGun.com has gone largely unrecognised. Until now.

'We knew it was a huge story, seeing how obsessed the country was with this farce of a wedding,' says Bas tone. 'But neither of us expected Fox to drop the Millionaire re-run, let alone walk away from the genre.'

Neither Bastone nor Green actually saw the TV wedding in which 50 women paraded around in their 'beachwear' vying to marry a man they couldn't even see. 'This sorry spectacle just wasn't on our radar,' says Bastone, 'but a friend of ours saw it, had a gut feeling, and pushed us to look into Rockwell's background.'

Green checked court files in San Diego, where Rockwell lives, but found nothing. But since it had emerged Rockwell had once been an entertainer, he must have spent time in Los Angeles. That was where Green hit pay-dirt, unearthing a 14-page restraining order imposed on Rockwell in 1991.

'Let's just see if Fox ever 'fesses up about what really happened,' says Bastone, 'what farce of a background check Fox actually did. And I can't imagine they did one.' Fox also overlooked Rockwell's past as a comic and actor, appearing in Attack of the Killer Tomatoes 2 and even popping up on previous Fox shows. He did not even possess anything like the $2 million minimum required to qualify for the show. (Conger, it also turns out, was not the Gulf War veteran she claimed to be.) 'At first we expected an explosion of lawsuits,' Bastone says, 'you know, Conger vs Fox, Fox vs Next Entertainment (the production company), Next vs Rockwell, ad nauseam. But no sign of that.'

Now more than two weeks since the infamous TV wedding, there's little sign of Rockwell-Conger fatigue or any dampening of the heated national debate on television standards. And everyone - Fox excepted - is cashing in. ABC's newsmagazine 20/20 had Darva baring her soul. People Weekly had Rick and Darva on their cover with the headline 'Has TV gone too far?' And with two million hits a day, TheSmokingGun.com says its web traffic has grown 20-fold.

But far more worrying for the Fox executive behind the fiasco, was this headline in the New York Times: 'Fox's Point Man For Perversity - World's Scariest Programmer'. For at the epicentre of the row is a single television executive - Mike Darnell - credited, perhaps unfairly, with singlehandedly inspiring the dumbing down of TV in the civilised world.

Fox's decision to abandon Darnell's particular brand of show leaves the notorious executive with little choice but to lay low and rein in his programming instincts. This may prove challenging, given his track record. Darnell is the man who once considered producing a special called The World's Most Embarrassing Throw-up Moments .

But then Fox executives are accustomed to keeping Darnell from following his instincts too far. Last year they balked when Darnell, executive vice-president of specials and alternative programming, suggested crashing an airplane in the desert. In 1997, the network pulled Prisoners Out of Control , an hour-long special about violent prison rioting.

'I will do almost anything for a good number,' Darnell told the Atlanta Journal and Constitution two years ago. 'As long as it doesn't hurt me, the company or my audience. I don't cross over into human suffering, making fun of hurting a person.' Of a 1998 special showing a woman undergoing surgery to remove a 303lb tumour, he said: 'You have to do something gross in each episode'. Last year he told the Sacramento Bee that audiences sometimes want 'a guilty pleasure'.

Confronted by the New York Times on the day of the Smoking Gun scoop, he said: 'This is the worst day of my life.' Darnell has since been 'unavailable for comment'. But as Fox scrambles to find replacement programming for the dozen shows it has scrapped, there is no sign it intends to part with Darnell.

'Whatever you think of Darnell and his programming, so-called reality TV is here to stay. The other networks would snap him up in an instant,' says Robert Thompson, director of the Centre for the Study of Popular Television at Syracuse University in upstate New York. 'I don't believe Fox is really backing away from the reality genre. It'll all be different when the smoke has cleared on this one.'

Sounding the death-knell for the reality genre may be a good PR move for Fox, but bad business. An hour-long Darnell special could be counted on to score big ratings among the young men so coveted by advertisers at a half to a third of the production cost of a sitcom or drama.

Few American networks will be able to resist for long the temptation to put real people in TV-induced life dramas for easy profit, industry insiders predict. 'The competitive pressures are too great,' says Toby Miller, a media and popular culture professor at New York University.

'The networks know that people watch these programmes, whether they admit it or not. There's a big market out there, and it's the voyeur in all of us, but the question is where will the line be drawn?'

No industry insider is prepared to predict how long it may be, for instance, before an 'ordinary' person gets hurt or killed in a real-life act for the camera, or a network is bankrupted in a barrage of multi-million dollar lawsuits.

CBS thinks it's a risk worth taking. Undeterred by the Fox fiasco, it plans two new 'reality' series this summer: Survivor , a show inspired by Castaways, stranding contestants on a desert island to compete for $1 million; and Big Brother , in which volunteers will live in a house full of cameras and microphones recording every move they make. 'I think this train has left the station, and nothing, not even Rick Rockwell can derail it,' says Thompson.

'Next year we'll look back to the quiz craze inspired by ABC's Who Wants to Be A Millionaire? and I bet all the Fox, CBS and NBC spin-offs, even Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire , will probably look classy.'

It was the hunch that Rick Rockwell, the 'multimillionaire' who had just married a woman he'd never met in a landmark moment of notoriety for American television, was not all he appeared to the 23 million voyeurs watching. For while the ratings were good, Rupert Murdoch's Fox Television has been left clutching a can of worms after two New York reporters made good on that gut feeling over Who Wants to Marry a Millionaire, unearthing court documents that revealed Rockwell's ex-fiancée had once accused him of hitting her and threatening her life. For once, the furore over the wedding fiasco was too much even for the normally unembarrassable Fox network, which has spent more than a decade plumbing the depths of human gullibility, stupidity and depravity for profit as the pioneer of so-called 'shockumentaries'. Faster than Rick Rockwell and bride Darva Conger could get their 'quickie annulment', Fox publicly divorced itself from the highly profitable and often perverse genre. 'They're gone, they're over,' Fox Entertainment chairman Sandy Grushow told the New York Times , pronouncing the end of what he called 'exploitative reality specials' on the network. Thanks to the investigative enterprise of a tiny Internet 'e-zine', TheSmokingGun.com, American viewers have been spared - for the moment - 'anything that is exploitative, that reeks of desperation, anything that's merely out for ratings' on the network behind World's Scariest Police Chases , When Good Pets Go Bad and World's Worst Drivers . Little gems such as Plastic Surgery Nightmares, Busted on the Job 5 and The World's Biggest Bitches have been scrapped. Not bad going for TheSmokingGun, which is so small it doesn't even have an office. Founded three years ago by Village Voice investigative crime reporter William Bastone and freelancer Daniel Green, TheSmokingGun.com was set up on a budget of $500 a month and a hunch that the raw materials of journalism - lawsuits, police reports, affidavits and the like - would make good Internet reading. Apart from causing a minor sensation last year with its disclosure that Malcolm X's bullet-ridden pocket diary had disappeared from prosecution evidence and ended up on the cyber-auctioneer eBay, TheSmokingGun.com has gone largely unrecognised. Until now. 'We knew it was a huge story, seeing how obsessed the country was with this farce of a wedding,' says Bas tone. 'But neither of us expected Fox to drop the Millionaire re-run, let alone walk away from the genre.' Neither Bastone nor Green actually saw the TV wedding in which 50 women paraded around in their 'beachwear' vying to marry a man they couldn't even see. 'This sorry spectacle just wasn't on our radar,' says Bastone, 'but a friend of ours saw it, had a gut feeling, and pushed us to look into Rockwell's background.' Green checked court files in San Diego, where Rockwell lives, but found nothing. But since it had emerged Rockwell had once been an entertainer, he must have spent time in Los Angeles. That was where Green hit pay-dirt, unearthing a 14-page restraining order imposed on Rockwell in 1991. 'Let's just see if Fox ever 'fesses up about what really happened,' says Bastone, 'what farce of a background check Fox actually did. And I can't imagine they did one.' 'At first we expected an explosion of lawsuits,' Bastone says, 'you know, Conger vs Fox, Fox vs Next Entertainment (the production company), Next vs Rockwell, ad nauseam. But no sign of that.' Now more than two weeks since the infamous TV wedding, there's little sign of Rockwell-Conger fatigue or any dampening of the heated national debate on television standards. And everyone - Fox excepted - is cashing in. ABC's newsmagazine 20/20 had Darva baring her soul. People Weekly had Rick and Darva on their cover with the headline 'Has TV gone too far?' And with two million hits a day, TheSmokingGun.com says its web traffic has grown 20-fold. But far more worrying for the Fox executive behind the fiasco, was this headline in the New York Times: 'Fox's Point Man For Perversity - World's Scariest Programmer'. For at the epicentre of the row is a single television executive - Mike Darnell - credited, perhaps unfairly, with singlehandedly inspiring the dumbing down of TV in the civilised world. Fox's decision to abandon Darnell's particular brand of show leaves the notorious executive with little choice but to lay low and rein in his programming instincts. This may prove challenging, given his track record. Darnell is the man who once considered producing a special called The World's Most Embarrassing Throw-up Moments . But then Fox executives are accustomed to keeping Darnell from following his instincts too far. Last year they balked when Darnell, executive vice-president of specials and alternative programming, suggested crashing an airplane in the desert. In 1997, the network pulled Prisoners Out of Control , an hour-long special about violent prison rioting. 'I will do almost anything for a good number,' Darnell told the Atlanta Journal and Constitution two years ago. 'As long as it doesn't hurt me, the company or my audience. I don't cross over into human suffering, making fun of hurting a person.' Of a 1998 special showing a woman undergoing surgery to remove a 303lb tumour, he said: 'You have to do something gross in each episode'. Last year he told the Sacramento Bee that audiences sometimes want 'a guilty pleasure'. Confronted by the New York Times on the day of the Smoking Gun scoop, he said: 'This is the worst day of my life.' Darnell has since been 'unavailable for comment'. But as Fox scrambles to find replacement programming for the dozen shows it has scrapped, there is no sign it intends to part with Darnell. fields.headline: The Unquiet American - Susan Sontag
fields.standfirst:
Has Old Skunk Head gone soft? America's foremost writer, critic and cultural guerrilla has a new book out - an historical romance

Books Unlimited
fields.trailText: Has Old Skunk Head gone soft? America's foremost writer, critic and cultural guerrilla has a new book out - an historical romance
fields.body:
In the sixties she was the high priestess of the avant-garde, and America's most Parisian intellectual. She took the French New Wave to New York and forced the American Old Wave to bow to its superior aesthetic. She could not write about the new art or the new cinema or the new music without striving for a superior vocabulary. She could not invent a new term without that term becoming the standard cultural lexicon. She was the one who made it witty to be camp. She sent an entire generation of photographers on 'social safari'. She herself went on numerous political safaris - to oppose the wars in Vietnam, in Bosnia, and in Kosovo, to fight for human rights in all those places and everywhere else, too.

Everywhere she went, she wore the sort of scruffy clothes that made you think she was in the middle of painting a house and had just dashed out for a pack of cigarettes. But no matter what she wore, she looked beautiful, glamorous, passionately committed - and terrifying. Nothing could faze this woman. When she fell ill with cancer in the late Seventies, she refused to stop work, or even take time off to feel sorry about herself. Instead she wrote an extraordinary book called Illness as Metaphor in which she argued that it was very bad for your health to think about illness metaphorically. Years later, when she sat down to do her research for the sequel, AIDS and its Metaphors , she found that her ideas had so influenced the earlier discussion of the epidemic that she felt like a plagiarist. But then she found a way to advance beyond her own metaphors. Yet again, her friends and associates shook their heads with admiration and wondered where it was she got her relentless energy. Behind her back, her enemies derided her for her relentless arrogance. They nicknamed her 'Old Skunk Head' - in reference to her famous lock of white hair - but she is unlikely to know this, as no one ever ever dared to use that nickname to her face.

They kept quiet, too, when she did that infamous 'sixty-something as sex kitten' photo-shoot for her companion, Annie Leibowitz. It was only behind closed doors that they agreed kitten was not quite appropriate for a woman of her great height, and started referring to her as 'the lynx'. But now she has done something that could destroy her mystique forever. She's gone and written an historical romance, In America , that Michiko Kakutani of the New York Times calls a 'banal, flat-footed narrative - a thoroughly conventional imitation of a thoroughly conventional nineteenth-century novel'. This is not her first work of fiction, and not her first historical romance. That came out eight years ago. It was about Nelson and his mistress. But it was still very, very brainy. Kakutani called it 'enthralling - an encyclopaedic novel of ideas'. It had so many twists and games that you could easily think Sontag had gone post-modern.

Certainly no one could say that about the new book. So, people are daring to ask, what is going on? Has she lost her touch, or was she always like this, and we were just too cowed to say so in public? It is nice to know that there is still a place in the world where people argue about such things. Only in New York, you might say. Only in the New Yorker . In the new issue, an old friend of Susan Sontag, named Joan Acocella, comes out in passionate defence of Sontag's artistic U-turn. She claims that, in spite of all those anti-trad essays that made her name, Sontag's heart always did belong to Hawthorne and George Eliot. What's more, those essays made her miserable, as the form never allowed her to express her full nature. 'I was involved in an intense self-mortification,' Acocella quotes Sontag as saying. 'Those essays aren't just austere, they're positively ascetic, as if I didn't trust the sensuality of my imagination. I was afraid of getting lost. I just wanted to support things that were good, and that would be improving to people, and that was natural to me, because I always had a moralistic frame of mind.'

Acocella goes on to insist that Sontag was never really avant-garde. She was, at heart, always a child of the nineteenth century. This was partly to do with her odd and lonely childhood. She was born in 1933 and her father, whom she hardly knew, died when she was very young. Her mother, who was a rather serious secret drinker, hardly ever talked to her. She found her salvation in the Modern Library classics series. This only served to widen intellectual gap between her and her classmates. She'd read so much by the time she was 15 that her teacher decided that she should leave high school then and there and go straight to college. She started at UC Berkeley and then transferred to the University of Chicago. By the age of 17, she was married to the scholar Phillip Rieff. She was 19 when she gave birth to David, her one and only child. And then it was off to graduate school at Harvard.

It was a good time to be there, thanks to the brain drain from Hitler's Germany. The best year was the year Herbert Marcuse was their lodger. It was ideas, ideas, ideas, from dawn to dusk. Little David would toddle around saying 'Hegel, Hegel, Hegel'. So when the marriage ended, and Sontag and son moved to New York, and she had her first real look at contemporary culture, it really did shock her. If she had something compelling and original to say about it, it was because she was looking at it through a sensibility that was still, Acocella and Sontag now claim, deeply rooted in European phil and lit. And so they still are. According to this new gospel, it's not Sontag that's changed her tune. It's the rest of the world. 'It never occurred to me that all the stuff I had cherished, and all the people I had cared about in my university education, could be dethroned. All that would happen is that you would set up an annex - you know, a playhouse - in which you could study these naughty people, who challenged things. And you could have it all! Little did I know that the avant-garde transgressiveness of the Sixties was to become absolutely institutionalised and that most of the gods of high culture would be dethroned and mocked.'

In her view, she is still streets ahead of the rest of us. To write a conventional novel in this day and age, to dare to pay homage to the gods of high culture when everyone else is cutting them up into witty little pieces - this is really taking a big risk. To be sure, Sontag hedges her risks by never reading her book reviews. On and off the printed page she has little time for people who disagree with her. She makes no secret of the fact that she considers herself and her son David to be intellectually superior to all other living beings. According to one long-time associate, she has not had a proper argument for years. This self-willed isolation has, this person believes, dulled her senses. People don't argue with Sontag because life is already dangerous enough even when you are agreeing with her.

I had a taste of this myself about 10 years ago, when I was deputised to drive her and her son David around Miami. My first mistake was to apologise for the age and sorry state of my car. This made her snort in disgust. 'Oh my God, what a stupid thing to say. Do you think someone like me cares about cars?' My next mistake was to obey her when she commanded me to park in a space that was a little too tight. When she saw I was having trouble, she began to shriek, 'Don't tell me I am going to have to teach you to parallel park, too!' And then she tried, her shriek getting worse with my every mistake. It was, 'Go right! Go left! No, I said right! I mean, left!' Finally it was, 'This is just awful. Get out of the car! I'm going to have to have my son do this.' Afterwards I got even by collecting other Sontag anecdotes. My favourite is the one where she is looking at an invitation to the première of a little theatre production of one of her plays, trying to decide whether or not she should go. She asks herself: 'Would Kafka do it? No. Would Proust do it? No. So fuck it.' She was not speaking ironically. She really does put herself on the same pedestal as Kafka, Proust, Mann, Canetti, and George Eliot.

But this cannot be an easy place to live. It may be that she has no time for other people's criticisms because she knows no one could set standards more punishing than the ones she sets herself. As one former friend said to me, she must be very lonely. When she started out, she was one politically engaged intellectual among many. Now she's the only one left, all the others having 'thrown in the towel and joined low culture'. But she's still soldiering on, still daring to look people straight in the face to say, 'All my work says be serious, be passionate, wake up.' There's something rather admirable about her refusal to forget her fallen idols and change with the times. As wrong-headed and defended and self-justifying as she is, she still deserves an 'A' for heroic effort.

Susan Sontag

Educated: UC Berkeley, University of Chicago, Harvard

Family: Married Phillip Rieff (separated); one son, David

Latest novel: In America

Other novels: The Benefactor , Death Kit , The Volcano Lover

Other works: Illness as Metaphor , Aids and its Metaphors

Companion: Photographer Annie Leibowitz

webTitle: Byers carpets banks over hole-in-the-wall charges

fields.headline: Byers carpets banks over hole-in-the-wall charges
fields.standfirst: A compromise could cut the planned £1 fee, writes  Maria  Scott
fields.trailText: A compromise could cut the planned £1 fee, writes Maria Scott
fields.body:
It is hard to believe that something as humdrum as a cash machine can generate so much fury. Like supermarket trollies and mobile phones, cash machines are a necessary evil.

The row that has engulfed them continued to escalate last week. The detail is devilishly complex, but because the machines are now so much a part of our lives, the outcome of the controversy could affect everyone.

So, let me take you though it gently.

Barclays started it all last year by deciding that it wanted to charge £1 every time a non-customer used one of its machines. It paraded this as a great leap forward for consumers, because it would display the charge on machines, allowing people to walk away if they didn't want to pay.

It would scrap charges previously levied on its own customers for using other banks' machines. But what Barclays had overlooked, or ignored, was that customers of many of its rivals would also be asked to pay 'disloyalty fees' when using Barclays machines. An Abbey National customer would pay £2.50 to get cash out of a Barclays machine under the new arrangement.

Nationwide building society, which levies no charges, threatened to take legal action against Barclays, and the bank shelved its plans.

So why didn't it end there?

When it comes to charges, banks don't give up. Barclays and the other banks that run the Link cash machine network decided to vote on whether surcharges of the type favoured by Barclays - and others too shy to own up to it - should be allowed.

That vote took place last Tuesday, and most Link members backed surcharging, with no limit on the amount.

But does it really cost £1, much less £2.50, to push some of my own cash through a hole in the wall?

Don Cruickshank, the former telecommunications regulator who is investigating the banks for the Government, puts the real figure at no more than 30p, and as little as 15p.

Late on Friday, a leaked report from the banks showed that the cost is no higher than 28p for a machine at a branch, and 40p at a supermarket.

So at £1 a time, a bank could make 70p. Using information given to us by Barclays, Cash calculated that this bank alone would profit by almost £75 million a year from non-customers.

Why do the banks think they can charge more?

Even among bankers there was consternation at the public relations disaster Link members inflicted on themselves by seeming to defy Cruickshank. The fall-out stretched as far as the Prime Minister; the Government reacted with anger to the banks' decision last week, particularly the idea that people can be charged twice to use a machine.

John Bridgeman, director general of Fair Trading, expressed his distaste. The Consumers' Association was outraged.

So is this a rip-off too far?

Certainly, if Cruickshank has his way. He has made it clear that the big four banks - Barclays, Lloyds TSB, HSBC and NatWest - risk fines for price collusion.

The banks are now trying to limit the damage done by their decision.

Barclays says its £1 fee plan was just a 'stake in the ground', while Lloyds TSB told Trade Secretary Stephen Byers that Link should have put off a decision.

Abbey National, which supports Barclays-style surcharges, says it will ensure that its customers don't face double charging, leading to fees of up to £2.50.

So is that the end of it?

No. The banks still insist that it costs more than 30p to process a cash machine transaction. Byers has summoned them to a meeting to justify their position, and on Friday John Bridgeman warned that he would be watching for any evidence of price collusion.

The most likely outcome is big compromises all round about the amount of the charge.

So how do I protect myself?

Check whether you are already paying charges to use the machines. Most big banks and Abbey National are taking up to £1.50 a time for the use of ATMs not run by their own bank or one with which it has an agreement.

You will probably have had a letter about this, and the fees appear on statements.

The Link meeting did agree that all charges - whether from a customer's own bank, or the one running the machine being used - should be flashed on to the screen during the transaction. Previously, banks had claimed this was a technical impossibility.

I know all about my banks' charges, and I go to machines I know are free. So why can't everyone else?

You may want to change banks at some time in the future, perhaps to an Internet operator with no machines of its own.

So it's in everyone's interests that the banks don't get away with daylight robbery at the hole in the wall. The banks are keen to squeeze these new upstart competitors which have no cash machine networks.

You may move to a village with only one ATM, run by Barclays.

So do any banks offer free access to their customers when using other cash machines?

Barclays does this now, but do you really want to join a bank that seeks to charge other people £1? Customers of the former TSB also get a free service.

Among the other mainstream operators, Nationwide, Cooperative Bank and Royal Bank of Scotland do the same.

In theory they could go on with the free service, and pay any future surcharges themselves. But they say they cannot afford to do so if the cost is as high as £1 a time.
