fields.bodyText: It is hard to believe that something as humdrum as a cash machine can generate so much fury. Like supermarket trollies and mobile phones, cash machines are a necessary evil. The row that has engulfed them continued to escalate last week. The detail is devilishly complex, but because the machines are now so much a part of our lives, the outcome of the controversy could affect everyone. So, let me take you though it gently. Barclays started it all last year by deciding that it wanted to charge £1 every time a non-customer used one of its machines. It paraded this as a great leap forward for consumers, because it would display the charge on machines, allowing people to walk away if they didn't want to pay. It would scrap charges previously levied on its own customers for using other banks' machines. But what Barclays had overlooked, or ignored, was that customers of many of its rivals would also be asked to pay 'disloyalty fees' when using Barclays machines. An Abbey National customer would pay £2.50 to get cash out of a Barclays machine under the new arrangement. Nationwide building society, which levies no charges, threatened to take legal action against Barclays, and the bank shelved its plans. So why didn't it end there? When it comes to charges, banks don't give up. Barclays and the other banks that run the Link cash machine network decided to vote on whether surcharges of the type favoured by Barclays - and others too shy to own up to it - should be allowed. That vote took place last Tuesday, and most Link members backed surcharging, with no limit on the amount. But does it really cost £1, much less £2.50, to push some of my own cash through a hole in the wall? Don Cruickshank, the former telecommunications regulator who is investigating the banks for the Government, puts the real figure at no more than 30p, and as little as 15p. Late on Friday, a leaked report from the banks showed that the cost is no higher than 28p for a machine at a branch, and 40p at a supermarket. So at £1 a time, a bank could make 70p. Using information given to us by Barclays, Cash calculated that this bank alone would profit by almost £75 million a year from non-customers. Why do the banks think they can charge more? Even among bankers there was consternation at the public relations disaster Link members inflicted on themselves by seeming to defy Cruickshank. The fall-out stretched as far as the Prime Minister; the Government reacted with anger to the banks' decision last week, particularly the idea that people can be charged twice to use a machine. John Bridgeman, director general of Fair Trading, expressed his distaste. The Consumers' Association was outraged. So is this a rip-off too far? Certainly, if Cruickshank has his way. He has made it clear that the big four banks - Barclays, Lloyds TSB, HSBC and NatWest - risk fines for price collusion. The banks are now trying to limit the damage done by their decision. Barclays says its £1 fee plan was just a 'stake in the ground', while Lloyds TSB told Trade Secretary Stephen Byers that Link should have put off a decision. Abbey National, which supports Barclays-style surcharges, says it will ensure that its customers don't face double charging, leading to fees of up to £2.50. So is that the end of it? No. The banks still insist that it costs more than 30p to process a cash machine transaction. Byers has summoned them to a meeting to justify their position, and on Friday John Bridgeman warned that he would be watching for any evidence of price collusion. The most likely outcome is big compromises all round about the amount of the charge. So how do I protect myself? Check whether you are already paying charges to use the machines. Most big banks and Abbey National are taking up to £1.50 a time for the use of ATMs not run by their own bank or one with which it has an agreement. You will probably have had a letter about this, and the fees appear on statements. The Link meeting did agree that all charges - whether from a customer's own bank, or the one running the machine being used - should be flashed on to the screen during the transaction. Previously, banks had claimed this was a technical impossibility. I know all about my banks' charges, and I go to machines I know are free. So why can't everyone else? You may want to change banks at some time in the future, perhaps to an Internet operator with no machines of its own. So it's in everyone's interests that the banks don't get away with daylight robbery at the hole in the wall. The banks are keen to squeeze these new upstart competitors which have no cash machine networks. You may move to a village with only one ATM, run by Barclays. So do any banks offer free access to their customers when using other cash machines? Barclays does this now, but do you really want to join a bank that seeks to charge other people £1? Customers of the former TSB also get a free service. Among the other mainstream operators, Nationwide, Cooperative Bank and Royal Bank of Scotland do the same. In theory they could go on with the free service, and pay any future surcharges themselves. But they say they cannot afford to do so if the cost is as high as £1 a time. However, even if surcharges become the norm, Nationwide and others may absorb some of the costs, and make low-cost access to ATMs a selling point for their current accounts. So, if the banks are so monopolistic in the way they run their machines, why can't someone else do it and offer a better deal? Cruickshank wants the network thrown open to competition, and Link agreed to this last week. It could be helpful in the long run.

webTitle: Start early and pay less for a pension

fields.headline: Start early and pay less for a pension
fields.trailText: 'People really start worrying about pensions in their thirties,' says financial adviser Nick Bamford.
fields.body:
'People really start worrying about pensions in their thirties,' says financial adviser Nick Bamford.

The later you leave it, the more you have to pay to build a good retirement income. A man of 30 wanting a pension worth half his salary on retiring needs to put in 13 per cent of his gross salary now. If he waits until he's 40, the amount increases to 19 per cent.

Such a level may be achievable for someone in a company scheme, where the employer is contributing, but it is harder - and perhaps not wise - for someone funding a personal pension scheme.

Pensions are a tax-efficient way of saving: your premiums get tax relief, contributions and earnings roll up free of income and capital gains tax, and up to 25 per cent of your eventual fund may be taken as tax-free cash.

But there are two big disadvantages, says Bamford of adviser Informed Choice in Cranleigh, Surrey. First, you cannot get at any money in a pension scheme before you are 50.

Second, most of the fund must be used to buy an annuity, to provide an income until you die. Unfortunately, the income levels provided by annuities now are distressingly low. According to the Annuity Bureau, a non-smoking man of 60 who retired with a pension fund of £100,000 could expect a level (not linked to inflation) annuity income of £7,900 a year. A woman of the same age would get only £7,500 a year, because she would be expected to live longer.

Experts believe these rates are unlikely to improve, because the Government is issuing fewer gilts (on which annuities are based), and people are living longer.

Investors must balance tax efficiency, control over capital and flexibility, says Bamford. 'Although individual savings accounts [Isas] don't offer the same tax benefits, they offer a lot more flexibility, and access to the money in emergencies. I'd recommend a combination of the two.'

How much can you contribute?

Members of company pension schemes can contribute up to 15 per cent of their gross earnings every year, excluding the firm's contributions.

Contributions below the maximum can be topped up by buying 'extra years' in final salary schemes, where the pension income is based on the final level of salary and the number of years worked. Members in money purchase schemes, where the income is based on the size of pension fund built up, may make additional voluntary contributions, provided the usual contribution and top up payment do not exceed the 15 per cent limit for that year.

The size of contributions to personal pension plans depends on an investor's age and earnings.

Personal pensions can be topped up by 'carrying forward' allowances unused in the previous six years, though this option is due to end when the low-cost stakeholder pension scheme is introduced in April 2001.

webTitle: Fancy the patter of tiny feet? Be prepared

fields.headline: Fancy the patter of tiny feet? Be prepared
fields.trailText: We all know that children cost an arm and a leg, but few of us prepare in advance. The average child costs £54,000 to raise up to the age of 17, according to research by Sue Middleton at the Centre for Research in Social Policy at Loughborough University. At £3,200 a year, you may be able to afford this out of your on-going income, but Middleton points out that most parents in her survey were not paying for childcare. This means the average figure is unrepresentative for someone who is paying for a full-time nursery (up to £800 a month per child) or nanny (up to £1,400 a month).
fields.body:
We all know that children cost an arm and a leg, but few of us prepare in advance. The average child costs £54,000 to raise up to the age of 17, according to research by Sue Middleton at the Centre for Research in Social Policy at Loughborough University. At £3,200 a year, you may be able to afford this out of your on-going income, but Middleton points out that most parents in her survey were not paying for childcare. This means the average figure is unrepresentative for someone who is paying for a full-time nursery (up to £800 a month per child) or nanny (up to £1,400 a month).

Chris Wicks, of Glossop independent financial adviser Bridgewater and a 36-year old father of three (with one on the way), says: 'The only way I could have kept up with the cost was to start saving before I met my wife! If you think you might want kids, you can't start saving too soon. They are horribly expensive.'

Wicks recommends bank and building society accounts, particularly Isas, for short-term savings of up to two years. Internet bank Smile (www.smile.co.uk) is paying 7.25 per cent gross on sums of £1 upwards, while telephone bank First Direct (0800 482448) pays 6.85 per cent gross. You can invest up to £3,000 in a cash mini Isa this tax year (ending on 5 April), and up to £1,000 in subsequent tax years.

For longer-term investments, Wicks recommends a stocks and shares Isa, favouring growth funds run by Fidelity and Henderson. He adds: 'If you are planning to invest more than £3,000, you should forget about having a cash mini Isa and go for a full stocks and shares maxi Isa.'

fields.headline: Cooling effect of merger fever
fields.trailText: Whatever has happened to merger mania? A few years ago, a takeover or merger was almost guaranteed to get a company's shares racing ahead. Now, investors seem positively hostile - just look at the sharp drops in the shares of Royal Bank of Scotland since it won the battle for NatWest, or the falls in the shares of CGU and Norwich Union, or GlaxoWellcome and SmithKline Beecham since they announced their respective engagements.
fields.body:
Whatever has happened to merger mania? A few years ago, a takeover or merger was almost guaranteed to get a company's shares racing ahead. Now, investors seem positively hostile - just look at the sharp drops in the shares of Royal Bank of Scotland since it won the battle for NatWest, or the falls in the shares of CGU and Norwich Union, or GlaxoWellcome and SmithKline Beecham since they announced their respective engagements.

Yet all these companies are promising that shareholders will be handsomely rewarded. Royal Bank of Scotland says it can produce £1.4 billion in cost savings and additional revenue; CGU and Norwich Union reckon they can save £250 million. And each deal makes strategic sense: there are too many banks and insurance companies; they must cut costs to compete with Internet operators.

Why, then, are investors so unenthusiastic about the current crop of deals? Studies show that the majority of takeovers fail to live up to their promises. Cost-saving targets are missed; integrating two companies disrupts the business and costs revenue; key staff are dissatisfied and leave. Agreed deals are slightly less risky than hostile ones, but can still go hopelessly wrong.

Investors are aware of the risks but usually ignore them until a profits collapse or strategic mistake makes that impossible. The current lack of interest in bids owes more to technology mania in the City than to rational analysis.

The large deals on the table mainly involve swapping shares in one company for shares in another. But what investors really want is cash to pour into Geo Interactive, or whatever fledgling technology stock is taking their fancy.

So should private shareholders also dump stocks when bids are announced? Or should they take advantage of falling share prices and buy? As always, each deal has to be assessed on its merits. GlaxoWellcome and SmithKline seem to have settled the differences that scuppered previous talks. Both are experienced at bedding down acquisitions and both are in fast-growing markets. Recent falls make their shares look cheap.

The merger between Commercial Union and General Accident, which created CGU, was also a success, but its decision to follow that up with the Norwich Union deal underlines how exposed it is to the competition that is forcing general insurance premiums lower. Increasingly savvy investors, the Internet and stakeholder pensions mean pressure is also spreading to investment products. Both are, however, well-managed companies and could be an attractive buy for the long term.

The fall in Royal Bank's shares has been the most severe, not surprisingly given that NatWest is more than twice its size and fought valiantly to escape. On conventional measures, its shares look a bargain. But integrating NatWest, never mind achieving the savings and growth promised, will be a mammoth task. Stay away until it proves it can do it.

fields.headline: Cashpoints
fields.trailText:
Eagles flying high

The Golden Eagle Nest Investment Club from Bridlington in Yorkshire has won the Proshare Most Successful Investment Club of the Year award.
fields.body:
Eagles flying high

The Golden Eagle Nest Investment Club from Bridlington in Yorkshire has won the Proshare Most Successful Investment Club of the Year award.

The Golden Eagle portfolio grew by a staggering 2,439 per cent over 12 months. The 13 work colleagues who manage the portfolio have achieved these amazing results by concentrating on technology shares, although they are now planning to diversify into other sectors.

The team made most of its gain by investing in AIM-listed technology company Infobank, spending £600 in January on shares that were worth £13,000 by the end of the year.

Investment clubs are groups of friends or colleagues who pool their resources to invest in the stock market.

The Proshare Investment Club Manual (£26.50 plus £3 postage) gives detailed information on setting up and running a club. Proshare also publishes a simple introductory guide - A Way to Learn, A Way to Earn (£5.99).

Call 0171 394 5200 or visit www.proshare.org.uk

Top-up reviews
If you have bought a pension top-up scheme, known as a Free Standing Additional Voluntary Contribution Scheme (FSAVC) from an insurance company over the past few years when you could have joined your employer's top-up scheme, it may be worthwhile requesting a review of your case to see if the insurer mis-sold the policy.

The Financial Services Authority has announced that insurers must contact people in three categories thought most likely to have been mis-sold an FSAVC between 29 April 1988 and 15 August 1999 and invite them to a review. Others can ask for a review. Investors who want their cases reviewed have until 30 June 2001 to apply. A leaflet on boosting pension provision is available from the FSA on 0800 917 3311.

Annuity reform
The requirement for new pensioners to buy annuities as soon as they cash in a personal pension or 'money purchase' company scheme should be reformed, according to a report published last week. The Retirement Income Working Party, headed by Oonagh McDonald, recommended that individuals should have freedom over how to invest their retirement funds, after first buying an index-linked annuity. Pensioners with large funds, £250,000 or more, can already delay purchase of an annuity, but low annuity rates are hitting those with smaller funds.

Ronnie Lymburn of the Annuity Bureau said most people did not have funds large enough to benefit from the proposals. They would still be locked into buying an annuity.

Policy on Fairplay
People with criminal convictions who find it difficult to get insurance are being offered a new buildings and contents policy by Fairplay Insurance Services. The typical customer would be the businessperson who nevertheless has a minor conviction such as possession of cannabis. Tel: 01424 220110. Website: www.fairplayhelp.com

fields.headline: Stumped by widening options
fields.standfirst: Switch my career, switch my money. Alan Crickett talks to  Margaret Dibben
fields.trailText: Switch my career, switch my money. Alan Crickett talks to Margaret Dibben
fields.body:
Vital statistics

Age: 28
Lives in: Oldham
Occupation: Leisure centre assistant manager
Earns: £13,000
Mortgage: None
Debts: Credit card
Investments: Windfall shares, Tessa, deposit account
Pensions: Ten years of contributions and AVCs with previous employer
Aims: To plan future investments

Alan Crickett has just made a big career change. Since leaving college 10 years ago, he worked as a clerical officer in the environmental services department of Oldham council.

While at the council, Alan had also been working part-time in the bar of a leisure centre and was offered the chance of a full-time job there. He was tempted and felt the time had come to branch out, because he saw little prospect of training or promotion, or even of an increase in his salary of £11,500, with the council.

So, in February he resigned and has started work as assistant manager at the leisure centre for £13,000 a year.

Part of the new job's appeal was that it offered the opportunity for additional training, and he has already completed a course on cellar work. The job is hard work but 'I am loving it', he says.

Alan works all day Saturday, Sunday and Monday and on other evenings. This does not leave Alan with time for a social life but he hopes he will find it easier to save as a result. His savings include windfall shares from Halifax and Northern Rock; £4,700 invested in a Northern Rock Tessa maturing in May 2001; and £800 in Virgin Direct.

During his 10 years with the council, he contributed to the pension scheme and, for the past three, also paid Additional Voluntary Contributions.

He does not have a pension with his new job, but wants to do something about it. Like so many people, he is confused by the many choices available and asks: 'Where should I go for a pension? And what should I do with the small pension fund I already have?'

Within the next two years, he wants to buy a home and wonders if he should start a regular savings scheme now. He also needs advice on existing investments: 'Should I use my Tessa fund as a deposit towards my own home when it matures? Should I open an Isa?'

Alan is single, rents a room, runs a car and has credit card debt of about £145.

Adviser 1: Julie Lord
Before Alan considers investing, he needs to protect his ability to earn, because clearly, if he has no income, he cannot save. His first priority should be an income protection plan, which provides income if he is unable to work, and a critical illness plan, which gives a tax-free lump sum on the diagnosis of a serious illness.

His next priority is his pension. There are plenty of excellent performing arrangements available but I urge Alan to take specialist advice, as this is one of the most important investments he will ever make. He should certainly include a waiver of premium benefit, so premiums continue if he falls ill.

In his previous job, he contributed 6 per cent to his pension scheme and he ought really to continue paying the same.

He should ask his new employer for a pension immediately - ahead of stakeholder pensions in April 2001 - and possibly transfer to it the council pension, although he ought to keep the AVC separate.

I suggest he puts down a 5 per cent deposit when he buys a house and spends the rest of his money on furnishings. With interest rates so low, taking a maximum mortgage is probably a good idea, so long as Alan feels this is affordable.

I advise him to sell his two shareholdings and invest in an Isa that will take small regular contributions as well as lump sums. As he already has a Tessa, he should concentrate on a stocks and shares (maxi) Isa: I suggest the Fidelity Managed International Oeic for a well diversified international investment.
 Julie Lord works for Cavendish Financial Management in Cardiff.

Adviser 2: Ian Williams
The pension that Alan built up with Oldham council should be reviewed. Past experience shows that it probably should not be moved, but it is worth looking at as he has such a long time to retirement. He should pay an independent financial adviser for a review.

Alan should set up a personal pension as he does not have one through his new employer. He should choose a new stakeholder-style scheme with low charges and considerable flexibility to stop, start and vary premiums.

The lowest cost plan on the market at the moment is Friends Provident's New Generation scheme, on a nil-commission basis. This particular scheme is with a mutual company, and he may well benefit from demutualisation at some time in the future. This is not a basis for selecting a pension as it is a long-term investment, but it can help swing the pendulum in favour of one particular company in a very competitive market.

Alan could use the Tessa money as a deposit on his house. Depending on his attitude to risk he should consider a repayment mortgage for a low risk, or an interest-only with a savings scheme for medium-to high risk.

He could consider an Isa as the savings scheme; if he set this up a year before he bought the house, he should be able to pay off the mortgage a year early, thus saving a year's interest.

The Isa route will be effective only if he uses an equity-based investment, as he needs to outperform the interest rate on the loan. A cash Isa is not appropriate.
 Ian Williams works for Bath-based Chartwell Investments. Advice is for guidance only

 Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

Part of the new job's appeal was that it offered the opportunity for additional training, and he has already completed a course on cellar work. The job is hard work but 'I am loving it', he says. Alan works all day Saturday, Sunday and Monday and on other evenings. This does not leave Alan with time for a social life but he hopes he will find it easier to save as a result. His savings include windfall shares from Halifax and Northern Rock; £4,700 invested in a Northern Rock Tessa maturing in May 2001; and £800 in Virgin Direct. During his 10 years with the council, he contributed to the pension scheme and, for the past three, also paid Additional Voluntary Contributions. He does not have a pension with his new job, but wants to do something about it. Like so many people, he is confused by the many choices available and asks: 'Where should I go for a pension? And what should I do with the small pension fund I already have?' Within the next two years, he wants to buy a home and wonders if he should start a regular savings scheme now. He also needs advice on existing investments: 'Should I use my Tessa fund as a deposit towards my own home when it matures? Should I open an Isa?' Alan is single, rents a room, runs a car and has credit card debt of about £145. Adviser 1: Julie Lord Before Alan considers investing, he needs to protect his ability to earn, because clearly, if he has no income, he cannot save. His first priority should be an income protection plan, which provides income if he is unable to work, and a critical illness plan, which gives a tax-free lump sum on the diagnosis of a serious illness. His next priority is his pension. There are plenty of excellent performing arrangements available but I urge Alan to take specialist advice, as this is one of the most important investments he will ever make. He should certainly include a waiver of premium benefit, so premiums continue if he falls ill. In his previous job, he contributed 6 per cent to his pension scheme and he ought really to continue paying the same. He should ask his new employer for a pension immediately - ahead of stakeholder pensions in April 2001 - and possibly transfer to it the council pension, although he ought to keep the AVC separate. I suggest he puts down a 5 per cent deposit when he buys a house and spends the rest of his money on furnishings. With interest rates so low, taking a maximum mortgage is probably a good idea, so long as Alan feels this is affordable. I advise him to sell his two shareholdings and invest in an Isa that will take small regular contributions as well as lump sums. As he already has a Tessa, he should concentrate on a stocks and shares (maxi) Isa: I suggest the Fidelity Managed International Oeic for a well diversified international investment.  Julie Lord works for Cavendish Financial Management in Cardiff. Adviser 2: Ian Williams The pension that Alan built up with Oldham council should be reviewed. Past experience shows that it probably should not be moved, but it is worth looking at as he has such a long time to retirement. He should pay an independent financial adviser for a review. Alan should set up a personal pension as he does not have one through his new employer. He should choose a new stakeholder-style scheme with low charges and considerable flexibility to stop, start and vary premiums. The lowest cost plan on the market at the moment is Friends Provident's New Generation scheme, on a nil-commission basis. This particular scheme is with a mutual company, and he may well benefit from demutualisation at some time in the future. This is not a basis for selecting a pension as it is a long-term investment, but it can help swing the pendulum in favour of one particular company in a very competitive market. Alan could use the Tessa money as a deposit on his house. Depending on his attitude to risk he should consider a repayment mortgage for a low risk, or an interest-only with a savings scheme for medium-to high risk. He could consider an Isa as the savings scheme; if he set this up a year before he bought the house, he should be able to pay off the mortgage a year early, thus saving a year's interest. The Isa route will be effective only if he uses an equity-based investment, as he needs to outperform the interest rate on the loan. A cash Isa is not appropriate.  Ian Williams works for Bath-based Chartwell Investments. Advice is for guidance only  Do you want to appear in Wealthcheck? Write, including daytime and evening telephone numbers, a brief list of circumstances and any investments, to: Wealthcheck, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER, or e-mail: cash@observer.co.uk. You must be prepared to be interviewed and photographed.

webTitle: Borrowers not a-loan in blame for problems

fields.headline: Borrowers not a-loan in blame for problems
fields.trailText: An envelope dropped on to my doormat recently, bearing a second-class stamp and with an address in computer-produced fake handwriting. Obviously not a letter from a friend; maybe an appeal letter from a small charity? No, it was an invitation from credit card company Capital One to take out a Platinum card. In a crowded market, the marketing tactics of the 'plastic' peddlers are getting ever sharper.
fields.body:
An envelope dropped on to my doormat recently, bearing a second-class stamp and with an address in computer-produced fake handwriting. Obviously not a letter from a friend; maybe an appeal letter from a small charity? No, it was an invitation from credit card company Capital One to take out a Platinum card. In a crowded market, the marketing tactics of the 'plastic' peddlers are getting ever sharper.

Lenders claim their credit-checking systems are so effective that credit limits are never given to people who can't handle them, but evidence is building that suggests that is not the case.

The National Association of Citizens Advice Bureaux last week reported sharp increases in the number of clients with debt problems. Among the CAB cases were a 32-year-old single man, suffering from depression, who got a loan of £12,000 from a high street bank, a 61-year-old disabled man on income support who got a secured loan of £15,000 from a finance company and an elderly couple, about to retire, who were offered an increased mortgage to take over existing debts of £17,000 on credit cards.

Some people do mishandle credit cards, but lenders are paying too little attention to borrowers' commitments and income security. It's worth remembering that the last time lenders protested innocence in a credit boom was in the late Eighties.

 Standard Life has seen off an attempt by policyholder Fred Woollard to get it to demutualise, by ruling his proposal invalid. But Woollard vows he will be back. This battle is not over.

webTitle: Virtual ways to leave your lover

fields.headline: Virtual ways to leave your lover
fields.standfirst: The Net has made it easy to get legal advice, but beware of logging on to untie the knot, says  Rachel Fixsen
fields.trailText: The Net has made it easy to get legal advice, but beware of logging on to untie the knot, says Rachel Fixsen
fields.body:
Holidays, birthday cakes and paper clips are just some of the things you can now buy on the Internet, simply by clicking your mouse. The possibilities of e-commerce seem endless. But how would you feel about ending your closest personal relationship with an electronic transaction?

A firm of solicitors in Stratford-upon-Avon, Woolley & Co, has opened two virtual offices, in Solihull and Worcester, and is offering a do-it-yourself divorce package over the Internet. The web service is still being tested, but senior partner Andrew Woolley says it should be up and running within a month.

The service costs £99 including VAT, although court costs of £180 would be added to this. Woolley points out that the service simply ends a marriage legally and does not take account of proceedings such as arrangements for children or division of finances.

The package includes divorce forms - either accessed on a CD or downloaded from the Internet - advice on how to complete them and an hour's telephone support. The forms are then sent to the court by post. 'If you want to save money and keep control of your own life and your own divorce, it's a good method,' Woolley says.

The website, which is still under construction, is at www.e-lawfirm.co.uk

Woolley says he set up the service in response to demand, but admits that it would not suit everyone. 'For many people it's actually a very personal, private, sensitive and emotional issue. A lot of people want to sit in a private room with a solicitor.'

Other lawyers believe that an Internet service is completely inappropriate. Liz Cowell, family partner at Pannone & Partners in Manchester, says: 'My concern is that when people are in a highly emotional state, as they usually are during divorce proceedings, they are being faced with a machine rather than a person.'

During a meeting with a solicitor, the client would get feedback, such as the suggestion that they get counselling before going ahead with the divorce, says Cowell.

In any case, Internet divorce services are hardly cheaper than consulting a solicitor in the conventional way, she adds, and the high level of legal fees widely associated with divorce are not in fact for the divorce itself, but to cover the arrangements for children and money. 'The way to save money is not by using the Internet but by having mediation,' she says.

The average firm of solicitors charges between £300 and £600 for a divorce. 'The deals on the Internet are not that much cheaper when you add them up,' she says.

And some people are entitled to Legal Aid to cover their divorce costs. There is no Legal Aid available for undefended divorces, but help may be on offer for the cost of financial settlements or for making arrangements for the children.

People on income support and some others do qualify for financial help from the Legal Aid board in uncontested divorces, although this is not strictly Legal Aid.

Other critics say an Internet service may allow people to rush into a divorce, doing the whole thing online on the home computer in the aftermath of a row.

But Woolley counters that it would be almost as easy to go to see a high street solicitor on the spur of the moment, and start proceedings that way.

The Law Society says it recognises that the Internet and information technology will change the way that legal services are provided. 'We welcome any innovative new schemes that could increase access to legal advice for the public,' says Law Society President Robert Sayer.

But he adds that there are many circumstances in which it is still better to consult a solicitor directly. 'In complicated proceedings such as a divorce where children or complex financial arrangements are involved, there is still no substitute for seeing a solicitor face to face.'

However, it is inevitable that legal services, like many others, will increasingly be offered over the Internet.

'Some legal services are based on the preparation of documents, and these are the ones which are easiest to offer via the Internet,' says Delia Venables, a lawyers' computer consultant. 'Uncontested divorces fall into this category, as do "simple" wills, changes of name, powers of attorney, simple leases for renting out a property and certain sorts of letters of complaint or claims for compensation.'

Woolley says his firm intends to produce an Internet package similar to the divorce service, for clients who want to pursue debtors.

There is already a wealth of information on legal issues available on the Net: some firms of solicitors offer free initial advice on topics such as wills, tax and personal finances. Venables maintains a web site providing links to free legal information for the public at www.venables.co.uk.

One company, called Desktop Lawyer - which is not a firm of solicitors - provides documents for a variety of legal uses through its website at www.desktoplawyer.net and through Internet service providers such as Freeserve and Lineone.

Anyone using them is advised to be extremely careful, however, particularly as many of the legal services available on the Internet are offered by companies other than solicitors.

'If in doubt go to a solicitor,' says Venables. 'If the document you get over the Internet is incorrect in some way, the consequences could be very serious.'

fields.headline: Padding out your pension
fields.standfirst: Pamela Atherton  offers a beginner's guide to the newest pensions on the block - the stakeholder
fields.trailText: Pamela Atherton offers a beginner's guide to the newest pensions on the block - the stakeholder
fields.body:
Just when most of us had become accustomed to personal pensions, along come stakeholder pensions to add further byways to the maze.

Stakeholder pensions, due to be launched in April next year are part of Chancellor Gordon Brown's plan to encourage more people, particularly the lower paid, to save for retirement. These pensions are aimed at the estimated four million people in the UK who are not making any provision for their old age.

The Government has in its sights those earning between £9,000 and £18,500 a year and those with no earnings at all. The latter will now be allowed to contribute to pensions from sources of income other than taxable earnings.

There will be two types of stakeholder pensions: personal stakeholders sold to individuals by pension providers, and occupational stakeholders provided by employers. Stakeholder pensions are money purchase plans whose benefits can be taken between the ages of 50 and 75.

Anyone (except those in a final salary pension scheme or who contribute to a retirement annuity contract) will be allowed to contribute up to £3,600 gross per year into a stakeholder. (Final salary schemes, or 'defined benefit' schemes, pay a pension based on length of service and salary at retirement.)

The £3,600 limit will include contributions made on your behalf by an employer. However, it will be possible to belong concurrently to a money purchase occupational pension scheme. These schemes, also known as 'defined contribution', pay a pension based on the amount you have saved during your working life and the investment performance of your contributions.

Concurrent membership will also be possible with other money purchase arrangements such as group personal pensions and personal pensions.

Contributions up to the £3,600 limit will be permitted from any source, such as savings, gifts from partners, benefits, redundancy payments, divorce settlements or even lottery winnings. This will benefit non-earning housewives, students, those on benefits and carers who have not been able to save via a pension.

To contribute more than £3,600 of your taxable earnings into a pension, you can pay the excess over £3,600 into a personal pension, provided you do not exceed contribution limits. For personal pensions, these are based on a percentage of your salary and age in the tax year in which you make the contribution. They range from 17.5 per cent of salary for those aged 35 or under, to up to 40 per cent of salary for those aged 61 and over.

So, stakeholder pensions will be a subset of personal pensions - the normal personal pension rules will kick in once the £3,600 stakeholder limit is exceeded.

The stakeholder will have its charges capped and the employed, self-employed and unemployed will have contributions topped up with basic rate tax relief. This also applies if they put in more than £3,600. Higher rate taxpayers will have to claim higher rate tax relief through their self-assessment tax form.

If you contribute more than £3,600 a year and lose your job, you will be allowed to continue contributing at the higher level for up to five years after your taxable earnings have ceased.

Crucially, charges on stakeholder will be capped at 1 per cent a year which is considerably cheaper than the average personal pension. This 1 per cent charge must cover all annual expenses and allow savers to increase, decrease, stop and start contributions, and transfer to another stakeholder without penalty.

You will be allowed to contribute from as little as £20 a month. If you pay via an occupational stakeholder, you will be allowed to vary your contribution at six-monthly intervals.

You will have to pay for advice as the Government excluded provision for advice from the 1 per cent cap on charges. This means it is unlikely providers will offer extras such as life assurance and waiver of premium to cover contributions if you are unable to pay because of illness or unemployment.

Providers will have to offer a range of funds and plan holders will receive benefit statements at least once a year.

From October 2001 all employers, except those with exemptions, will have to offer employees access to a stakeholder pension, provided they employ five or more staff. Deductions will usually be made monthly from payroll.

Employers offering all employees aged over 18 membership of an occupational pension scheme will be exempt, as will those providing all employees membership of a group personal pension to which the employer contributes 3 per cent a year of employees' salaries, provided there are no exit charges. Employees earning less than the lower earnings level for triggering National Insurance contributions (£3,432 a year in the 1999-2000 tax year) will also be exempt.

Some providers such Axa Sun Life, CGU, Eagle Star Direct, Friends Provident, Legal & General, Liberty Pensions, Marks & Spencer, Norwich Union, Scottish Widows and Virgin Direct are already selling 'stakeholder compliant' pensions. Check that what you are buying meets stakeholder requirements; this may mean buying your pension through an independent adviser who can rebate all commission to keep charges down.

But, you will almost certainly have to pay a fee to the adviser. If you decide to buy a 'non-stakeholder compliant' pension, ensure your provider guarantees a penalty free transfer to a stakeholder of your choice from April 2001.

The Government is considering allowing 'partial concurrency' for lower earners in final salary schemes but definitive regulations will not be announced until later this year.

fields.headline: Money matters for kids
fields.standfirst: Classroom advice on basic finance will improve consumer understanding, writes  Neasa MacErlean
fields.trailText: Classroom advice on basic finance will improve consumer understanding, writes Neasa MacErlean
fields.body:
Moves are afoot to bring personal finance into the classroom. And, no, it will not be a case of teaching eight-year-olds about pensions and encouraging 12-year-olds to consider long-term care.

Instead, the approach will aim to make the subject entertaining. From this week, for example, four-year-olds up and down the country will be learning about money by playing with huge cardboard cut-outs of coins.

The purveyor of the coins game, Megamoney, is the Financial Services Authority - better known until now as a regulator than a games manufacturer. The FSA launches Megamoney (price £9.41 including VAT and P&P) on Tuesday at its first teachers' conference. Part of the regulator's remit is to encourage consumer understanding - and it has decided to do this in ways that will mean the most to the children and adults it eventually hopes to reach.

Educating ordinary people will improve their lives considerably, says Gill Hind, former maths teacher and organiser of the FSA conference: 'There is a lot of evidence that the man on the Clapham omnibus is making a lot of bad and irrational decisions because he doesn't have a basic understanding of money. Many people don't understand the issues surrounding "risk" and "return". They don't know the questions to ask when making a financial decision.'

It is common knowledge that women are often better buyers of financial products because they do not mind asking basic questions that might make them look ignorant.

Tuesday's conference is being taken seriously by the Government, which will be represented by Jacqui Smith, Schools Minister. The conference aims to help teachers bring personal finance into the classroom when new curriculum demands come into force in September. The Government's new National Numeracy Strategy says schoolchildren should have a maths or numeracy class once a day. And new additions to the curriculum - in the form of Personal, Social and Health Education and Citizenship - include elements of personal finance. So far, teachers have had little guidance on how to teach the subject of money.

The FSA's conference will be an annual event. This year it is aimed at primary school teachers. Next year it will target secondary schools. In the meantime, the FSA is working with the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority to send guidelines to schools during the summer term.

A major opportunity in teaching has been identified in maths classes. Instead of making children do tortuous calculations of how long it takes a man to cycle around the perimeter of Eaton Socon, there is growing pressure on teachers to use examples which make sense to the young. In its own material, the FSA is looking at examples where teenage girls try to work out how much money they need to earn from their Saturday job to get a mobile phone or a pair of trainers. Other suggestions include the notion of a '£1 shop' for children as young as four - where they start to understand the idea of money, how to save and spend it, in a shop where everything costs £1.

Although much of its attention will focus on schools, the FSA is hoping to encourage financial understanding across the age ranges for adults. For example, it is launching a website in the spring which will help students with a range of money issues but particularly debt.

The Institute and Faculty of Actuaries is also playing a role in encouraging numeracy and financial understanding, developing initiatives from discussing the concept of financial education programmes with the BBC to trying to put a question, based on a personal finance example, into a schools examination paper.

The Government has espoused the cause for greater personal finance education, but has been less enthusiastic when it comes to discussing the details. However, one useful development could be the planned production of pension statements from 2003 - bringing together state and private entitlements. Providing this sort of information can be educational: if people have a basic understanding of what sort of pension level they are on course for, they are often encouraged to find out more about their pension.

 Visit the FSA website at www.fsa.gov.uk. Megamoney can be ordered on 020 7684 3330.

And new additions to the curriculum - in the form of Personal, Social and Health Education and Citizenship - include elements of personal finance. So far, teachers have had little guidance on how to teach the subject of money. The FSA's conference will be an annual event. This year it is aimed at primary school teachers. Next year it will target secondary schools. In the meantime, the FSA is working with the Qualifications and Curriculum Authority to send guidelines to schools during the summer term. A major opportunity in teaching has been identified in maths classes. Instead of making children do tortuous calculations of how long it takes a man to cycle around the perimeter of Eaton Socon, there is growing pressure on teachers to use examples which make sense to the young. In its own material, the FSA is looking at examples where teenage girls try to work out how much money they need to earn from their Saturday job to get a mobile phone or a pair of trainers. Other suggestions include the notion of a '£1 shop' for children as young as four - where they start to understand the idea of money, how to save and spend it, in a shop where everything costs £1. Although much of its attention will focus on schools, the FSA is hoping to encourage financial understanding across the age ranges for adults. For example, it is launching a website in the spring which will help students with a range of money issues but particularly debt. The Institute and Faculty of Actuaries is also playing a role in encouraging numeracy and financial understanding, developing initiatives from discussing the concept of financial education programmes with the BBC to trying to put a question, based on a personal finance example, into a schools examination paper. The Government has espoused the cause for greater personal finance education, but has been less enthusiastic when it comes to discussing the details. However, one useful development could be the planned production of pension statements from 2003 - bringing together state and private entitlements. Providing this sort of information can be educational: if people have a basic understanding of what sort of pension level they are on course for, they are often encouraged to find out more about their pension.  Visit the FSA website at www.fsa.gov.uk. fields.headline: It's pinned to the art
fields.standfirst: Medals have broken free from their dull old commemorative mould. Now they're sculptures - and they're collectable, says  John Windsor
fields.trailText: Medals have broken free from their dull old commemorative mould. Now they're sculptures - and they're collectable, says John Windsor
fields.body:
They were once called medals, then 'art medals' and now 'hand-held sculpture'. Which is what they have become.

It was in eastern Europe in the Seventies - in Poland, Hungary and Bulgaria - that medal makers broke the mould of the dull disc-with-ribbon. Bored with casting officially commissioned medals bearing portraits of worthies, they began making pocket-sized sculptures that were politically or sexually subversive - or which innocently celebrated weddings and christenings.

British medal makers and sculptors have followed their lead. Among the unusual shapes being bought by collectors in the UK are: a tiny squashed Coke can, a hinged human brain with male and female genitalia inside that slot together, a slice of cake with a filling of a loving couple on one side and writhing maggots on the other, and a low-relief of a wheatsheaf that is a coded mockery of Strathclyde council.

Most contemporary art medals cost less than £100. You can view the British Museum's exhibition of 78 of them, mostly in bronze, from its own collection, then stroll down the road to the Simmons Gallery, the first gallery to specialise in medals, and buy medals from some of the editions that are in the museum's collection. Simmons is also offering a choice of 130 British and East European medals from this year's British Art Medal Society Student Medal Project, an international competition. In May, an exhibition of art medals, mostly in precious metals, opens at Goldsmiths' Hall in east London.

Among established artists in Britain who have made art medals are Damien Hirst, Henry Moore, Elizabeth Frink, Lynn Chadwick, Dhruva Mistry, Ian Hamilton Finlay (whose studio was raided by Strathclyde council) and cartoonist Ronald Searle.

A Chadwick medal of 1984, from one of the six editions offered annually to members of the British Art Medal Society (BAMS), which is based at the British Museum, sold for £800 at a Christie's sculpture auction a few years ago. BAMS members had bought 128 at £25 each. Ian Hamilton Finlay's BAMS medal of the same year sold only 43 at the same price and would retail at £225 - if any could be found.

Whether art medals turn out to be good investments depends largely on whether potential collectors continue to be put off by the word 'medal'. Luke Syson, curator of medals at the British Museum, made sure to omit the 'm' word from the exhibition title. It is called 'Size immaterial: hand-held sculpture of the 1990s'. A visitor to the exhibition, in the museum's coins and medals department, was heard to mutter: 'What are these things doing here?'

The museum's collection was only a year old when Syson joined the staff and in the nine years since then he has put together almost all of it. He says: 'Classifying art medals as sculpture is one way of rescuing them from being ghettoised as some side-alley of the applied arts. They are small, but enormous artistically. The weight of them in the hand, the way they feel, is part of their emotional impact and appeal.'

Nevertheless, much of their wittiness derives from the way they ape the conventions of traditional medal design. For instance, most of the sculptures are still double-sided - literally, two-faced - giving ample opportunity for juxtapositions satirising the social respectability, military might or civic pride medals once commemorated.

The unification of East and West Germany has been a rich source of double-sided medallic lampoons. The museum's collection contains the German Carsten Theumer's medal inscribed 'Ex occidente felicitas' (Happiness from the West), showing on one side a God-like hand offering a banana, and on the other a bony, naked East German, with bananas stuffed into every orifice, clutching a soft drink.

The exhibit that most resembles a traditional coin or medal is one of the most subversive. It bears a portrait of the gay film director Derek Jarman, encircled by his name and date of death, 1991, in respectable Roman-style lettering. Its British sculptor, Ian Rank-Broadley, is used to sculpting queens; Queen Elizabeth's current portrait on British currency is by him. Syson says: 'The medal questions who the great and the good really are by thrusting an outsider into their ranks.'

Rank-Broadley is one of Britain's finest portrait sculptors and a bit of a character. He was once escorted out of the Royal Mint by a security guard after telling the Mint's deputy master that his output of coins and medals was rubbish aesthetically.

American Richard Tuttle's exhibit is a wooden box marked MEDALS in bold black capitals, which opens to reveal four blobs in aluminium, copper, silver and gold, all bearing the imprints of man's fingers or tools. Work that one out.

The most unrecognisable medal is not Damien Hirst's screenprint dots on perspex but the Dutch Mirjam Mieras's 'South Pole', an alabaster disc with a delicate snowy surface bearing an account of Scott's tragic 1911 expedition. It must be handled with a pair of white gloves, and is concealed in two felt pouches at the dark end of a sleeve-length silk bag. You have to journey into the unknown to reach it.

In search of more handy hand-held sculpture, I visited Howard and Frances Simmons's gallery in Lamb's Conduit Street, where Frances Simmons was unpacking nine cardboard boxes containing the 130 medals from 14 British art colleges and others in Prague and Sofia that had just been scrutinised by BAMS judges.

I fell for the third prize winner, Euan McWhirter's slice of cake with lovers and maggots, 'To have your cake and eat it'. The maggots, McWhirter states, are 'a metaphor for the human condition of never feeling satisfied'. Price £260 from an edition of 10.

McWhirter is a first-year jewellery student at Central St Martin's School of Art and Design, London. This is the first year that entries from jewellery students have been admitted to the BAMS Student Medal Project, (the sculptors having overcome their professional territoriality) - and jewellers have carried off six of the nine British prizes.

That signals a fresh influx of talent. Howard Simmons says: 'Sculptors think big, but jewellers think about such things as the maximum distance at which a small object will have impact and how it will look against the skin on a male or female form.'

We begin unpacking the eastern European medals. Frances Simmons says: 'This is where it gets exciting.' From the jewellery studio of Prague's Academy of Arts there is Lukas Macke's heavy steel wheel, like a child's top, with a finely ground spike on each side, titled 'Tolerable Easiness of Motion' (£120). From the same academy's glass and medal studio, Pavlina Plackova's 'Glass Medal' (£225), a split circle in glowing cherry-red glass with a polished protrusion. There are medals made from brass (cheaper than bronze), glass, resin, cardboard, dried blood.

Only one of the 10 BAMS prizes is allocated to the east Europeans. Theirs is cutting edge stuff and there are fears that they might sweep the board. At art schools over there, students can expect to spend a year or two learning relief modelling. No such tradition exists in Britain.

Eventually, I pay £75 for the British metalworker and jeweller Hazel White's bronze medal, a clay-like slab at which a God-like hand appears to have torn, revealing a female torso. It is inscribed with its title, a line from Robert Burns's eulogy to Auld Nature, 'And then she made the lasses, O'.

The medal was a BAMS offer in 1996, when members bought 52 at £55 each; it appears, illuminated monumentally, on the poster for the British Museum's current exhibition - and three jewellery students at Sheffield Hallam University, where White is course leader of the metalwork and jewellery department, have won prizes in this year's BAMS Student Medal Project. I shall watch their careers with interest.

 Size Immaterial is at the British Museum until 9 April. British Art Medal Society: members pay £20 annually, receive the journal The Medal twice yearly and buy at least one medal a year at £40-£120: inquiries to BAMS, c/o Department of Coins and Medals, British Museum, London WC1 (020 7323 8260); www.bams.org.uk BAMS Student Medal Project entries are on show until 17 March at the Simmons Gallery, 53 Lamb's Conduit Street, London WC1 (020 7831 2080).

 The Goldsmith's Company's collection of twentieth-century art medals will be on show 25 May-21 July in 'Treasures of the Twentieth Century', Goldsmiths' Hall, Foster Lane, London EC2 (020 7606 7010).

webTitle: 'Twin' trusts are flip sides of same coin

fields.headline: 'Twin' trusts are flip sides of same coin
fields.standfirst: Alex Garrett  dispels investors' confusion between unit and investment trusts
fields.trailText: Alex Garrett dispels investors' confusion between unit and investment trusts
fields.body:
For investors in Henderson Technology investment trust, 1999 was a great year, with £100 turning into £282 in 12 months. For investors in Henderson Global Technology unit trust it wasn't a bad year either; their £100 turned into £271.60 over that time.

Henderson is not the only fund manager with an investment trust and unit trust bearing similar names and objectives. Perpetual, Gartmore and Edinburgh Fund Managers have a trust of both types devoted to the UK smaller companies sector; Schroder has three Japanese unit trusts and one investment trust; Murray Johnstone has one of each specialising in UK equity income.

Investors may be confused about the relationship between the two trusts and why the fund manager even offers a choice. In the case of Henderson's technology funds, the investment trust - originally called Touche Remnant Technology - came first, and the unit trust followed in 1984. Both are managed by Henderson's technology team headed by Brian Ashford-Russell, who says the choice between the two is largely a matter of preference.

'The unit trust tends to operate with a heavier US weighting,' he says, 'but if you look at the top 10 or top 20 holdings of each, around 60-65 per cent are the same.'

There is not even a significant difference in terms of size: the unit trust has around £950 million under management, while the investment trust has a net asset value of around £750m.

At Perpetual, deputy chairman Roger Cornick says its smaller company unit trust and investment trust each service distinct markets. 'The majority of people like the more stable environment of unit trusts, but the more sophisticated investors prefer to have marginally more risk, and tend to look down on unit trusts.'

The two trusts are run by the same team and Cornick says their underlying investments are 'not dissimilar'. The unit trust has fared slightly better over one year and three years.

Conventional wisdom has it that investment trusts are higher risk because of the discount and gearing. The discount tends to exaggerate the changing value of underlying assets, while borrowings enhance performance during a bull run, and reduce performance when things turn bearish.

Jonathan Fry, managing director of fund manager Premier, says this makes investment trusts ideal for regular savings, benefiting from the effect of pound cost averaging - the evening out of share prices when you buy small tranches over a long period of time.

Rob Noble-Warren, a certified financial planner at Murray Noble, says the biggest factor in choice is charges. 'Unit trusts have an initial charge which you can usually get largely rebated if you go to a discount broker. But they also have an annual charge, including ongoing commission; investment trusts don't have that, so overall charges tend to be lower,' he says.

Actively managed unit trusts charge about 1.5 per cent annually, with 0.5 per cent going to the adviser who sold the investment. Investment trusts' annual charges are typically in the range of 0.5 - 1 per cent, if purchased in an ISA, although some make no charge.

There can be exceptions to the rule. The Henderson Technology investment trust has a built-in performance-related fee and last year's return led to a management charge of 3.25 per cent, compared to 1.5 per cent on the Henderson Global Technology unit trust.

If in doubt about trusts, ask the fund manager what differences there are between the two funds. Even if the names are identical, the objectives may have a different emphasis and carry a different level of risk.

fields.headline: Death throes, or just poorly?
fields.standfirst: As returns on equity income funds look sick, managers have had to make changes, says Christine Stopp
fields.trailText: As returns on equity income funds look sick, managers have had to make changes, says Christine Stopp
fields.body:
Some of the best known fund managers have made losses for investors in UK equity income funds over the past year. And when the sector produced an average return of only 5.1 per cent in the year to 1 February, investors are justified in asking questions.

Investors may wonder why they have done so badly when, by contrast, the UK All Companies performance category averaged an 18.1 per cent total return over the year.

Within the equity income sector, performance varied a lot. The top fund was ABN Amro Equity Income, which produced a 58.7 per cent return for investors. Clearly, funds like this can produce the goods even when markets are against them.

Equity income funds have an impressive history. They aim to give an income which, though it may not be high initially, should grow over a number of years. The funds seek to provide capital growth - and evidence shows they have achieved this.

An investor buying £1,000 of units in Jupiter Income, the sector's top 10-year performer, at the 1989 high of 109p, would have got £32 in income in the first year. In 1999 the same investment, if left untouched, would have given income of £1,250 (or 12.5 per cent on the initial investment) and the holding would have been worth £3,471.

The strategy income funds have used for achieving high total returns (returns made up of income and growth) is to buy undervalued stocks with relatively high yields.

The stock is held until the share price goes up, reducing the yield. It is then sold, and replaced with cheaper stocks which have higher yields. Income funds have therefore had a continuous discipline for buying cheap and selling dear - a successful recipe for growth as well as yield.

In the past year or so this strategy has failed to deliver the goods, because the big performers in the market have been companies with low or no yield but enormous growth prospects. Higher-yielding companies in traditional sectors have seen very little share price growth. This is why funds still run according to a traditional strategy have been so disappointing. Equity income funds have let investors down by focusing too much on income and not enough on growth, says Norwich Union's Scott McKenzie.

Some managers have sought to adapt to the changing market by adopting a new strategy. Last October McKenzie, formerly of Britannic, became manager of Norwich UK Equity Income trust, which is sixth in the sector with 13.8 per cent growth over one year. He set about restructuring the trust.

The yield was reduced to remove its reliance on out-of-favour high-yielding stocks and to provide a new base for steady income growth. A number of more fashionable technology stocks were added to the portfolio.

Some of these stocks pay no dividend - an extreme approach for an income fund, admits McKenzie - but they are balanced by high-yielding stocks with low valuations, such as Halifax and Scottish Power, which will provide a yield and the possibility of future dividend growth. A 10 per cent exposure to convertibles further boosts yield.

Dividend yields in the equity income sector are usually low compared with deposit returns: they currently average 3.2 per cent. The attraction of such funds is their ability to keep pace with inflation in both income and capital terms. They are not for the immediate high income seeker who wants no risk to capital. Investors who are risk averse and want a high income should look at corporate bonds, says Scott McKenzie.

George Luckraft, manager of the top-performing ABN Amro fund, also holds a combination of traditional income stocks plus growth stocks. If you hold traditional stocks, you are guaranteed losses at the moment, he says.

He also feels that stocks that have been the staple fodder of income funds will have fundamental problems in future. As businesses, they will find it harder to increase the prices they charge their consumers because of downward price pressure of increasing competition - much of it due to the Internet. They will therefore have great difficulties increasing their dividend payouts. Such stocks will see falling share prices raising dividend yields to double figures. They will be like junk bonds, with fixed payments and no scope for growth, says Luckraft.

Some stocks have already reached this situation. He points to five or six motor dealers with yields of 10 per cent or more. However, traditional stocks have further to fall before a turnaround comes, in Luckraft's view.

Is the new approach of funds such as Norwich Union and ABN Amro a permanent change or a temporary strategy? The traditional business model is seriously threatened by new-economy stocks. Companies have to get used to lower long-term margins. In that sense, Luckraft says, the change is permanent.

Rumours of the death of the income fund may be greatly exaggerated.

'If someone says "this is the death" of something, that is the time to buy,' says Kean Seager of Bristol investment adviser Whitechurch Securities. His colleague Warren Perry likes the ABN Amro and Norwich Union funds, plus Gartmore UK Growth and Income, which has also maintained growth through investment in technology.

'The winners of tomorrow are the funds that invest on a total return basis, and I regard these three to be among the best,' says Perry.

A 10 per cent exposure to convertibles further boosts yield. Dividend yields in the equity income sector are usually low compared with deposit returns: they currently average 3.2 per cent. The attraction of such funds is their ability to keep pace with inflation in both income and capital terms. They are not for the immediate high income seeker who wants no risk to capital. Investors who are risk averse and want a high income should look at corporate bonds, says Scott McKenzie. George Luckraft, manager of the top-performing ABN Amro fund, also holds a combination of traditional income stocks plus growth stocks. If you hold traditional stocks, you are guaranteed losses at the moment, he says. He also feels that stocks that have been the staple fodder of income funds will have fundamental problems in future. As businesses, they will find it harder to increase the prices they charge their consumers because of downward price pressure of increasing competition - much of it due to the Internet. They will therefore have great difficulties increasing their dividend payouts. Such stocks will see falling share prices raising dividend yields to double figures. They will be like junk bonds, with fixed payments and no scope for growth, says Luckraft. Some stocks have already reached this situation. He points to five or six motor dealers with yields of 10 per cent or more. However, traditional stocks have further to fall before a turnaround comes, in Luckraft's view. Is the new approach of funds such as Norwich Union and ABN Amro a permanent change or a temporary strategy? The traditional business model is seriously threatened by new-economy stocks. Companies have to get used to lower long-term margins. In that sense, Luckraft says, the change is permanent. Rumours of the death of the income fund may be greatly exaggerated. 'If someone says "this is the death" of something, that is the time to buy,' says Kean Seager of Bristol investment adviser Whitechurch Securities. His colleague Warren Perry likes the ABN Amro and Norwich Union funds, plus Gartmore UK Growth and Income, which has also maintained growth through investment in technology. 'The winners of tomorrow are the funds that invest on a total return basis, and I regard these three to be among the best,' says Perry.

webTitle: Highs and lows of earning a good living

fields.headline: Highs and lows of earning a good living
fields.standfirst: Jill Insley  asks  where can savers put their trust?
fields.trailText: Jill Insley asks where can savers put their trust?
fields.body:
One of the UK's leading investment advisers, Best Investment, is warning investors against buying the high-yielding income shares of split-capital investment trusts.

Several fund managers, including Quilters and Hargreaves Lansdown, are preparing to launch split-capital investment trusts offering high-yielding income shares. Hargreaves Lansdown expects to offer income shares yielding 9 per cent - a level of income that is very attractive to investors earning paltry amounts on bank and building society savings accounts.

But Jason Hollands, deputy managing director of Best Investment, warns that split-capital income shares are too risky, and that investors could lose much of their original capital. He fears that people will be seduced into investing by the high yields on offer, without understanding that they stand to lose much of their original capital.

'The vast majority of income investors should not be buying these shares. People who need a high income tend to be elderly, and they don't need that level of risk,' he says.

Although private investors will be able to buy shares in the Hargreaves Lansdown High Income Trust, the fund has been designed for the institutional market, and chairman Peter Hargreaves agrees that the trust will not be suitable for the typical income investor.

So if investors safely are to avoid the income shares of split-capital investment trusts, where can they safely go for a high level of income?

For those still interested in high-yielding investment trust shares, Hollands recommends funds that invest in split-capital income shares, which reduce risk by spreading investors' money around. This, he argues, would allow investors to benefit from the high yields on offer, but reduce the risk for investors investors by spreading i investors' their money over a range of professionally managed shares. He recommends the Investec Guinness Flight Income Share (gross yield 5.84 per cent), Jupiter Monthly Income (8 per cent gross) and Exeter High Income (8.36 per cent gross).

However, he thinks high-yield corporate bond funds, which invest in a combination of high- and lower-quality or sub-investment grade bonds, offer a safer, better value way of investing for income. The prices of high- quality corporate bonds have fallen in response to the Bank of England's interest rate rises and, as a result, their yields have risen, providing a good investment opportunity for income seekers. Hollands suggests the Fidelity Extra Income fund (7.4 per cent gross) and the M&G High Yield Corporate Bond fund (8.1 per cent gross).

Ian Millward at Bath independent financial adviser Chase de Vere Investments recommends the Aberdeen Fixed Interest fund, one of the oldest high-yield corporate bond funds, which is yielding 8.2 per cent gross. As a more secure alternative, he suggests a new Scottish Mutual stock market bond which goes on sale tomorrow until 14 April (available only through IFAs). The Income Bond will run for three years, paying 8 per cent net a year. Return of capital is linked to the performance of the Dow Jones Euro Stoxx 50 Index: provided the index does not fall by more than 20 per cent from its level at the start of the investment period, investors will get all their capital back. Even if it falls by more than 20 per cent at any point, they will still get full return of capital, provided the index has recovered to the original level by the end of the three years.

Millward says he likes with-profits bonds - single premium investments into the with-profits funds of life insurance companies. 'They're messy, complicated things, but once you are in, they rarely let you down.'

With-profits bonds earn returns in the form of guaranteed annual bonuses, and investors are usually entitled to a terminal bonus when they withdraw their cash. The combined annual and terminal bonus produces an annual yield of about 7 per cent net. The investor can withdraw up to 5 per cent of the original investment capital as income. Millward recommends bonds sold by Norwich Union and Friends Provident.
