fields.headline: Les rosbifs sont arrivés
fields.standfirst: Natalie Sutton wakes up to the reality of French village life in the second part of her  maison-buying diary
fields.trailText: Natalie Sutton wakes up to the reality of French village life in the second part of her maison-buying diary
fields.body:
Well, we've done it. We've signed the Acte de Vente. And yet, now that I am back in England, even the pride of ownership is hard to grasp. As Thomas Mann said: 'Space, like time, engenders forgetfulness and, if it works less thoroughly, does so more quickly.' It is almost impossible to recall that feeling I had, just a few weeks ago, of being the owner of a beautiful little cluster of houses in southern France with the most breathtaking view. Although that process was, of course, the very reason for choosing a place that was so remote: to quickly forget a noisy, overcrowded London.

Foolishly, I had been looking forward to something resembling a holiday when we crossed the Channel for five days in January to take possession of the property, but it turned out to be a scramble through unfamiliar metres of red tape and official paperwork. The holiday feeling was, in any case, eradicated when, for reasons too complicated to explain, our first night's accommodation was at minus 10 C inside.

The completion of the sale in the presence of the vendor and the notaire was reasonably straightforward - in as much as we had very little to contribute; except the monies from our French bank account which we had already transferred.

We followed most of the notaire's explanations - probably as well as we would those of an English solicitor - but were confused by his frequent departures into obscure legal anecdotes; although we were just as reassured by everyone else's look of bewilderment. The biggest shock of the proceedings was discovering that the vendor had to pay 10 per cent of the sale price to the estate agent (apparently justified by the extreme remoteness of the property). Fond as I am of the estate agent, judging by everything she had told us relating to the property, this was earned without any recourse to factual accuracy. Plus ça change .

We toasted the sale with the vendor in a local cafe and suddenly felt the enormity of what we had done. Apart from anything else, according to local gossip, the last two owners had suffered a variety of misadventures and tragedy well, it would be rewarding to breathe a little happiness into the place.

With that in mind, we hurried to the local insurance broker and took out every available cover. The houses themselves contain nothing of value at the moment, but insurance premiums appear to rise sharply once you go beyond buildings cover and venture towards a contents value of more than £10,000, as do the minimum security requirements. Since we are surrounded only by the elements, natural catastrophe seems the most likely calamity. Indeed, practically everyone we met was at pains to impress on us how important it is to clear undergrowth to at least 50 metres from the buildings. Forest fires in the summer are feared, not for their frequency but because just one can devastate a whole region. Besides, to be the newly arrived rosbifs and responsible for 100,000 hectares of charcoal would be embarrassing in the local bar. Imagine the silence, the angry glares.

As far as neighbourly relations go, we assumed at first that we were just being warmly accepted for what we are: a fairly eccentric (for which read lunatics willing to live in the middle of nowhere) but tolerable English couple. Then we heard the rumours had circulated concerning the potential purchasers - the worst of which was that it was to be bought either by a quasi hippy/religious sect or by a platoon of Jesuits. Apparently we were witnessing a certain amount of relief. That said, the welcome we received was exceptional by any standards. The hospitality was so genuine we felt it must be ingrained in the characters of all we met.

The nearby village is enjoying something of a renaissance: the local school is opening for the first time in 20 years because there are finally enough children (10) to warrant one. Supplementing the more established residents are a few baba-cools (travellers who have ground to a halt). One of these seemed keen to recognise us as one of his own and with no electricity, no particular sanitation, and without mains water, we were hard pressed to deny fellowship but, hey man, we're hip to that. He had been introduced to us as someone who could help with some of the restoration of our buildings, a skill which would be invaluable.

However, we remain undecided as to his architectural input. His own living room contained a sizeable tree trunk, rising up through the ceiling and emerging through the roof to a height of 40ft. He told us that he had built the house around his caravan and not until the third wall was erected did he realise that the tree was destined to be a permanent guest. Now, we have a tree growing in one of our buildings and have nothing, per se, against the inclusion of trees in our domestic arrangements. It's his approach to planning that worries us.

Our closest neighbour lives 4 kilometres away and will keep an eye on the place when we're not there in exchange for the hunting rights on our land. This seemed a reasonable exchange as I can't see either of us hurling ourselves down the mountain in hot pursuit of the sanglier (wild boar) which would, without doubt, win. He and his wife invited us to their one-room cabin on the edge of the mountain at 11am and gave us enough Pastis for us to be smashed by noon. They rescued us from this state by giving us a lunch cooked entirely from those things caught or grown by themselves. It gave us the idea, however misguided (or tipsy) that, if hardly already accepted, we might be in the future.

We met the mayor who helped us to prove our acquisition by signing an Acte de Domiciliation. He had quite an impressive array of forms, official documents and certificates at the ready covering everything from birth to demise. Proof of residence is needed for most formalities in France and is usually accepted in the form of a utilities bill. Since our property simply does not have any utilities servicing it, we were rather stuck. Still, Monsieur le Maire was very helpful and we were lucky to catch him as he only has one day a week in his office. We discussed whether the postman could be expected to travel the full 15km round trip of forestry roads every day so that we received mail. We agreed that a letterbox assigned to us in the village would be perfectly adequate.

Buying a car was another complicated process. Having found one, we needed insurance, obviously, before we could drive it. The broker looked rather surprised when we opted for the fully comprehensive option (or Menu Gourmand as he described it) to cover a 22-year-old heap of junk which had clearly had more than its fair share of paint jobs and probably been involved in several laps of the local 4x4 rally.

We made our decision based on the possibility at some time of getting into an argument with a very angry Frenchman whose car we had just trashed on a lonely mountain road. Transferring ownership of a vehicle involves a carte grise issued by the police. More documents proving everything from identity to inside leg measurement were needed, each one rubber stamped by the correct official.

The next step is the installation of electricity. There is a generator, but it seems pointless to invest in a place because of the very peace and calm it offers, and then run a machine which rivals Hanger Lane for noise and produces enough power to operate one or two flickering light bulbs.

We are so far from the end of the electricity line that the EDF (Electricité de France) are going to have to run a connection over the mountainside just for us (the cost of which we will have to bear). Permission is needed from anybody whose land is crossed in the process and, although most of the surveys have now been done, after last year's storms, there is a lot of repair work in the region which takes priority. So I won't be packing my hair dryer just yet.

We will also be trying to make the place more habitable by offering ourselves a few home comforts - perhaps a bed or even a chair or two. This may be interesting: somehow, I can't see a queue forming to deliver furniture. At least next time it shouldn't be quite so cold - except for those buildings lacking a roof.

webTitle: News Corp bloodied in Asia brawl

fields.headline: News Corp bloodied in Asia brawl
fields.standfirst: Emily Bell in London and  John Gittings in Hong Kong on why Rupert Murdoch's telephone call was cut off by Richard Li
fields.trailText: Emily Bell in London and John Gittings in Hong Kong on why Rupert Murdoch's telephone call was cut off by Richard Li
fields.body:
When Rupert Murdoch snatched Star TV in an audacious $850 million deal in 1993 his Far Eastern prospects were very much on the rise. His News Corp stormtroopers had snuck in and 'stolen' the company from a rival bidder, the languid British media company Pearson.

But, after a week of shocking wheeler-dealing in the Far East, the question remains whether Murdoch's Far Eastern promise is turning into a busted flush. In what looked like a spat for an unexciting telephone company, Murdoch found himself pitted against the same dynasty which sold him Star TV - the powerful Li family. This time he was not dealing with Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's most powerful tycoon, but with his son Richard Li, the 33-year-old dynamo who is proving to be a worthy business successor to his father.

The prize in this fight was Hong Kong Telecom, a subsidiary of the UK's Cable & Wireless company. Li junior, against all the odds, made a successful £22.5 billion offer for HKT, beating Singapore Telecom which had been backed at the eleventh hour by $1 billion of Rupert Murdoch's money.

On the face of it, Li's newborn Pacific Century CyberWorks (PCCW) was not in the same league as rival Singapore Telecom (SingTel) in the struggle for HKT. Politely described as a 'highflying Internet concept stock', PCCW has no subscribers and no proven track record - and it was less than a year old.

But the cards on the table in the world of Hong Kong big-dealing are never quite what they seem, and Li had several hidden aces.

Paradoxically, the one ace in the open - the strength of the Li name - is the one most vigorously denied. Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's former 'plastic flower king' who made a fortune and stormed the British hongs, has nothing to do with the HKT affair, insist executives at PCCW and at his Cheung Kong (Holdings).

Liu Jinbao, general manager of the Bank of China in Hong Kong, tells a different story, saying that Li Ka-shing asked the Bank to support the PCCW bid 'on a number of occasions'.

So what about the China card? The Bank of China has joined a four-bank consortium putting up a mammoth US$13bn bridge loan to PCCW, without which the deal would never have gone through. And the speed with which the loan was arranged knocked the socks off C&W's UK-based management.

Richard Li denies that a trip to Beijing last month had anything to do with raising funds, saying the suggestion is just 'bull'.

Hong Kong's chief secretary, Anson Chan, leapt to deny the suggestion that Beijing had leant on her government to keep HKT in local hands. 'On this occasion,' she said, 'we have not received any direction ... nor any intervention from the central government.' But locally, there is little doubt this was seen as a victory for Hong Kong Chinese business against their rival, Singapore.

Richard Li says he wants to reach out to Asia's millions who have TV sets but no telephones, delivering an interactive digital service via satellite and local cable which will link them to the Web. HKT, with its near-total fixed line coverage of Hong Kong, offers a test bed for broadband delivery - via the telephone line rather than by satellite - to millions of TVs.

It is this aspect which caused Murdoch some anxiety and points to why he made his late intervention. True, Murdoch's banking adviser Goldman Sachs was also adviser to the SingTel bid for HKT, but the last thing Murdoch wants is a war at the gate of the potentially most lucrative market in the world with the favoured local boy. So why risk one? Perhaps because he feared Star TV would be rendered impotent by a new rival TV system.

Despite being of the old media, Murdoch has always been quicker than his peers to adapt to changing circumstances. Star TV's chief executive had, in the charming parlance of News Corp, been 'terminated', and Murdoch has parachuted his youngest child, 27-year-old James Murdoch, into the territory. James now has to pick the bones out of potential conflicts with his contemporary, Li. Pleasantries were exchanged after the deal, with News Corp and PCCW making enthusiastic noises about working together, but beneath the surface it is certain Li will want to at least test the parameters of any deal with Murdoch by bringing in competition.

The episode also richly demonstrates the struggle Murdoch is having in squaring the dominance of his old media pre-eminence with the stellar rise in values of new media companies. Few of the Internet generation can match Murdoch's strategic poise, but an alarming number can match his cash. Again, what Li accomplished with PCCW demonstrated that the cyber dollar is a powerful tool. And just as AOL turned its silly Internet valuation into an opportunity to purchase Time Warner, so Li spotted the opportunity to get real value out of his PCCW conjuring trick.

Though some fund managers have criticised Li's decision to link his new-tech concept to a decidedly old-economy firm, suggesting that HKT may drag PCCW down, others argue for a reverse logic. He has now acquired fixed assets, products and customers where he had none before.

The Hong Kong punters watching the stock price displays this week were in no doubt what is the key factor. The phrase on the street was that 'anything with the Li family name can't go wrong'. Most were buying into Li Ka-shing's unrelated launch of his new Internet company Tom.com - its launch issue was 369 times over-subscribed - another concept with as yet no proven value. But other Hong Kongers helped Richard Li raise US$1bn through a share placement which was 40 times oversubscribed.

Empire is not an overstatement for an enterprise in which Li Ka-shing, eldest son Victor Li and Richard dominate companies with a current market value of $129bn - and now with HKT lays claim to one third of the total capitalisation of the Hong Kong stock market. Richard's HKT plus his father's Hutchison Whampoa will own 60 per cent of Hong Kong's telecommunication business - and if Richard sells the mobile end of HKT, his dad is a likely buyer. A few anxious voices have been raised in Hong Kong but behind the smiles, the Li family do not appear to enjoy being criticised. Hong Kong's press has tiptoed round the inside story of the Li imperial court. Few questions have been asked about the role in it of Ms Chau Hoi-shuen, an associate of Li Ka-shing who is a substantial shareholder in Tom.com.

'Publications that want to draw conclusions about their relationship,' says the South China Morning Post , 'may find themselves suddenly devoid of advertising from Mr Li's companies.' These include one of Hong Kong's two main supermarket chains and the leading electronic goods retailer.

Enterprising journalists will also recall a puzzling affair last year when an independent business website, www webb-site.com, raised critical questions about another Richard Li enterprise. Hong Kong's proposed Cyberport project had just been awarded to Pacific Century in unusual circumstances without a tender process.

The website director was urged to reveal his sources by an 'independent journalist' - who turned out to be working for a worldwide investigation agency. The agency admitted that this was part of a 'wider project' - but the identity of its client remains unknown.

For Murdoch - senior and junior - the issue of whether to bolster News Corp with an Internet partnership is pressing. Last weekend, through the crusty pages of the New Yorker , news filtered out that Murdoch was open-minded about a partnership with Yahoo! Despite both sides having vehemently denied at the time of the AOL/Time Warner deal that they were interested in any type of partnership, the two are edging closer to at least an 'agreement' accompanied by a stock swap. James Murdoch and 31-year-old Yahoo! founder Jerry Yang reportedly have a good working relationship, while Murdoch senior is very close to the Soft Bank venture capital fund which has been key to Yahoo's success.

Murdoch's experience in the Far East has been a bruising one, but he is not about to sit on the sidelines while the Richard Lis create a new order in global media and communications.
fields.bodyText: When Rupert Murdoch snatched Star TV in an audacious $850 million deal in 1993 his Far Eastern prospects were very much on the rise. His News Corp stormtroopers had snuck in and 'stolen' the company from a rival bidder, the languid British media company Pearson. But, after a week of shocking wheeler-dealing in the Far East, the question remains whether Murdoch's Far Eastern promise is turning into a busted flush. In what looked like a spat for an unexciting telephone company, Murdoch found himself pitted against the same dynasty which sold him Star TV - the powerful Li family. This time he was not dealing with Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's most powerful tycoon, but with his son Richard Li, the 33-year-old dynamo who is proving to be a worthy business successor to his father. The prize in this fight was Hong Kong Telecom, a subsidiary of the UK's Cable & Wireless company. Li junior, against all the odds, made a successful £22.5 billion offer for HKT, beating Singapore Telecom which had been backed at the eleventh hour by $1 billion of Rupert Murdoch's money. On the face of it, Li's newborn Pacific Century CyberWorks (PCCW) was not in the same league as rival Singapore Telecom (SingTel) in the struggle for HKT. Politely described as a 'highflying Internet concept stock', PCCW has no subscribers and no proven track record - and it was less than a year old. But the cards on the table in the world of Hong Kong big-dealing are never quite what they seem, and Li had several hidden aces. Paradoxically, the one ace in the open - the strength of the Li name - is the one most vigorously denied. Li Ka-shing, Hong Kong's former 'plastic flower king' who made a fortune and stormed the British hongs, has nothing to do with the HKT affair, insist executives at PCCW and at his Cheung Kong (Holdings). Liu Jinbao, general manager of the Bank of China in Hong Kong, tells a different story, saying that Li Ka-shing asked the Bank to support the PCCW bid 'on a number of occasions'. So what about the China card? The Bank of China has joined a four-bank consortium putting up a mammoth US$13bn bridge loan to PCCW, without which the deal would never have gone through. And the speed with which the loan was arranged knocked the socks off C&W's UK-based management. Richard Li denies that a trip to Beijing last month had anything to do with raising funds, saying the suggestion is just 'bull'. Hong Kong's chief secretary, Anson Chan, leapt to deny the suggestion that Beijing had leant on her government to keep HKT in local hands. 'On this occasion,' she said, 'we have not received any direction ... nor any intervention from the central government.' But locally, there is little doubt this was seen as a victory for Hong Kong Chinese business against their rival, Singapore. Richard Li says he wants to reach out to Asia's millions who have TV sets but no telephones, delivering an interactive digital service via satellite and local cable which will link them to the Web. HKT, with its near-total fixed line coverage of Hong Kong, offers a test bed for broadband delivery - via the telephone line rather than by satellite - to millions of TVs. It is this aspect which caused Murdoch some anxiety and points to why he made his late intervention. True, Murdoch's banking adviser Goldman Sachs was also adviser to the SingTel bid for HKT, but the last thing Murdoch wants is a war at the gate of the potentially most lucrative market in the world with the favoured local boy. So why risk one? Perhaps because he feared Star TV would be rendered impotent by a new rival TV system. Despite being of the old media, Murdoch has always been quicker than his peers to adapt to changing circumstances. Star TV's chief executive had, in the charming parlance of News Corp, been 'terminated', and Murdoch has parachuted his youngest child, 27-year-old James Murdoch, into the territory. James now has to pick the bones out of potential conflicts with his contemporary, Li. Pleasantries were exchanged after the deal, with News Corp and PCCW making enthusiastic noises about working together, but beneath the surface it is certain Li will want to at least test the parameters of any deal with Murdoch by bringing in competition. The episode also richly demonstrates the struggle Murdoch is having in squaring the dominance of his old media pre-eminence with the stellar rise in values of new media companies. Few of the Internet generation can match Murdoch's strategic poise, but an alarming number can match his cash. Again, what Li accomplished with PCCW demonstrated that the cyber dollar is a powerful tool. And just as AOL turned its silly Internet valuation into an opportunity to purchase Time Warner, so Li spotted the opportunity to get real value out of his PCCW conjuring trick. Though some fund managers have criticised Li's decision to link his new-tech concept to a decidedly old-economy firm, suggesting that HKT may drag PCCW down, others argue for a reverse logic. He has now acquired fixed assets, products and customers where he had none before. The Hong Kong punters watching the stock price displays this week were in no doubt what is the key factor. The phrase on the street was that 'anything with the Li family name can't go wrong'. Most were buying into Li Ka-shing's unrelated launch of his new Internet company Tom.com - its launch issue was 369 times over-subscribed - another concept with as yet no proven value. But other Hong Kongers helped Richard Li raise US$1bn through a share placement which was 40 times oversubscribed. Empire is not an overstatement for an enterprise in which Li Ka-shing, eldest son Victor Li and Richard dominate companies with a current market value of $129bn - and now with HKT lays claim to one third of the total capitalisation of the Hong Kong stock market. Richard's HKT plus his father's Hutchison Whampoa will own 60 per cent of Hong Kong's telecommunication business - and if Richard sells the mobile end of HKT, his dad is a likely buyer. A few anxious voices have been raised in Hong Kong but behind the smiles, the Li family do not appear to enjoy being criticised. Hong Kong's press has tiptoed round the inside story of the Li imperial court. Few questions have been asked about the role in it of Ms Chau Hoi-shuen, an associate of Li Ka-shing who is a substantial shareholder in Tom.com. 'Publications that want to draw conclusions about their relationship,' says the South China Morning Post , 'may find themselves suddenly devoid of advertising from Mr Li's companies.' These include one of Hong Kong's two main supermarket chains and the leading electronic goods retailer. Enterprising journalists will also recall a puzzling affair last year when an independent business website, www webb-site.com, raised critical questions about another Richard Li enterprise. Hong Kong's proposed Cyberport project had just been awarded to Pacific Century in unusual circumstances without a tender process. The website director was urged to reveal his sources by an 'independent journalist' - who turned out to be working for a worldwide investigation agency. The agency admitted that this was part of a 'wider project' - but the identity of its client remains unknown. For Murdoch - senior and junior - the issue of whether to bolster News Corp with an Internet partnership is pressing. Last weekend, through the crusty pages of the New Yorker , news filtered out that Murdoch was open-minded about a partnership with Yahoo! Despite both sides having vehemently denied at the time of the AOL/Time Warner deal that they were interested in any type of partnership, the two are edging closer to at least an 'agreement' accompanied by a stock swap. James Murdoch and 31-year-old Yahoo! founder Jerry Yang reportedly have a good working relationship, while Murdoch senior is very close to the Soft Bank venture capital fund which has been key to Yahoo's success. Murdoch's experience in the Far East has been a bruising one, but he is not about to sit on the sidelines while the Richard Lis create a new order in global media and communications.

fields.headline: BA denies Ayling departure
fields.trailText: British Airways moved this weekend to quash rumours that professional headhunters have been briefed to find a replacement for chief executive Bob Ayling.
fields.body:
British Airways moved this weekend to quash rumours that professional headhunters have been briefed to find a replacement for chief executive Bob Ayling.

As influential institutional shareholders expressed support for such a plan because of the company's disastrous financial performance, airline executives denied that Ayling plans to leave in the summer.

In a terse statement, BA's chairman Lord Marshall, said: 'It is untrue. It is a lie.'

The headhunting firm, Spencer Stuart, is understood to have been consulted by the nominations committee of the BA board of directors, which includes non-executive directors Sir Michael Angus, Michael Davies and Baroness Detta O'Cathain.

It is believed that Ayling aims to leave by the annual general meeting this summer.

He is chairman of the New Millennium Experience Company, which oversees the Dome. Industry observers agree that an anticipated knighthood and elevation to a Labour peerage for Ayling would be contingent on the Dome proving a success.

One significant shareholder said that if Ayling were to leave 'the market would take it quite well'.

Another said that the institutions were not putting pressure on the company to make changes at the top because 'people have just voted with their feet. A lot of UK institutional holders have sold rather than say something must be done. But people are less than happy.'

He said BA had scored too many 'own goals' in the last two years with Ayling failing to pull off a full-blown airline alliance, angering staff and attracting a bad press.

Earlier, Ayling said the airline had turned the corner, with improving business traffic and better prospects for the next financial year, based on capacity restrictions and new on-board products. A spokesman for BA said that Ayling's departure was 'inconceivable'.

webTitle: PCCW set for attack on UK

fields.headline: PCCW set for attack on UK
fields.trailText: A dramatic entry to the UK television market by Richard Li's Pacific Century CyberWorks, which last week acquired Cable & Wireless Hong Kong, will exacerbate tensions between Li and Rupert Murdoch.
fields.body:
A dramatic entry to the UK television market by Richard Li's Pacific Century CyberWorks, which last week acquired Cable & Wireless Hong Kong, will exacerbate tensions between Li and Rupert Murdoch.

PCCW, which is only 10 months old, is to launch a multi-billion dollar global TV company with its partner TWI, the broadcasting arm of IMG, the world's largest sports marketing firm. The new company will establish a range of services in Asia, including business, music and sports channels, by the middle of this year and spread them across the world.

PCCW has remained secretive about his plans for Europe until now, but Bill Sinrich, TWI's managing director, signalled that Li was keen to become a major media player here. 'We are in in-depth discussions with a number of carriage partners, focusing in the English-speaking world,' Sinrich said.

The company, Network of the World, or NOW, is to employ 250 people in London to oversee the roll out.

The move would have major repercussions for BSkyB, the UK satellite broadcaster 40 per cent owned by Murdoch's News Corporation. BSkyB has built its business plan around buying up sports rights, notably for Premier League football, to win viewers.

As part of its deal with TWI, which holds an equity stake in the new company, PCCW has exclusive access to the broadcasters' archives. In addition to holding huge amounts of sports footage, IMG owns or manages many of the world's biggest sports events, including the World Match Play golf and the ATP tennis tour. This would bolster any attempt it made to bid for rights.

Murdoch knows IMG's strength in sport. He has said: 'Everywhere we go, IMG got there first.'

Even more serious for Murdoch is the threat Li now poses to his Asian plans. The News Corp chief tried to thwart Li's media expansion plans last week when he backed SingTel, a rival bidder for Cable & Wireless Hong Kong. PCCW eventually won with a deal worth $38 billion, leading to speculation that Murdoch's relationship with Li, who has extensive contacts in China, was irreparably damaged.

News Corp wanted to combine C&W Hong Kong Telecom's Internet services with its Star TV digital platform.

Last week's deal suggests this is now unlikely, as PCCW is keen to develop NOW's Internet capabilities. The new service will allow connection to the Net, allowing viewers to surf the Web through their television screens.

The plan is to integrate the two services so that programmes link to websites. 'This has never been done before,' Sinrich said.

He declined to say how much money PCCW and TWI were pouring into the venture. 'It's an extraordinary amount of money. Let's just say that on an annual basis we're talking nine figures.'

fields.headline: Card that wouldn't go away
fields.standfirst: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.trailText: Has your bank, building society or insurer treated you badly? We seek justice for our readers
fields.body:
Last summer, I closed my Barclaycard Visa account, destroyed the card and told Barclays what I had done. I did not receive acknowledgment, but got a statement showing no money was due.

Later in the year, I received several invitations to borrow money from Barclaycard, which I destroyed, and an invitation to take a gold card, which I also destroyed. In December, a gold card arrived unsolicited. I made repeated attempts to telephone and cancel it, but without success. I then sent a letter by recorded delivery telling them not to dispatch a PIN and asked for an apology and compensation for the money I had wasted on postage and phone calls.

I did not receive a reply, and the PIN arrived. Now, what I believe to be a chequebook has arrived from Barclaycard. I am a retired medical secretary aged 69 and, if they knew what my income was, they would not trust me with a credit card.

AN, Bristol

Barclaycard says it did not receive your letter closing your account and 'therefore when your card was due for renewal, we upgraded to a Barclaycard gold', which is surely a non-sequitur.

It claims to have notified you three weeks before sending the gold card, and says it would have cancelled the upgrade if you had written back. It is hard to tell whether this 'notification' is - what sounded to you like an 'invitation', but reasonable for you to ignore it as your account was closed.

Barclaycard has no explanation for failing to find your letter sent by recorded delivery, which must have been signed for, but it has now deleted your name from its mailing list and sent you £20 to cover your out-of-pocket expenses.

Dividend money: Wise too late
On 29 November I purchased 2,500 Debenhams shares through Dealwise. That was the last date for registered owners to be entitled to the dividend. I was the registered owner with Dealwise on that date, but they refuse to pay me the dividend.
WJ, Butleigh

Unfortunately, the Debenhams shares actually went ex-dividend on Monday 29 November, so whoever bought shares that day bought them without the right to receive the next dividend. The closing price on the previous Friday was 197.75p, and on the 29th it dropped to 188.25p but, even more unfortunately, your deal went through at around 197p, the price being quoted by marketmakers to Dealwise when you phoned.

So you paid the same price as investors who received the dividend. Dealwise is an execution-only stockbroker, so the onus is on you to make sure the details are accurate in all respects. If you had asked, the clerk should have confirmed whether the price was cum or ex-dividend - if she had that information in front of her.

The details printed on Dealwise's contract notes are provided automatically by Reuters the previous night so, if your contract note failed to mention that the shares were ex-dividend, Reuters had omitted it and possibly the clerk would not have known either.

Paying in euros: What choices?
From January, Lloyds Bank has withdrawn its eurocheque facility. I frequently pay for books from French publishers and take out subscriptions to French sports magazines. I can open a euro account, and pay a charge of £30 every six months, or pay by foreign draft, which attracts a surcharge of £10 per transaction. I have also considered opening an account with a French bank, but would have to lodge £400.

What method do you recommend for buying goods by mail from EU countries; not all accept payment by debit card?

NH, Guisborough

Your only option is to move to another bank that still provides eurocheques. Lloyds TSB says it withdrew them because most customers now pay for overseas purchases by plastic, and it is likely that other banks will eventually follow suit. Banks are entitled to make whatever commercial decisions they choose, and Lloyds obviously believes that it risks losing only a few customers over this.

Gifts to children: Tax implications
 We want to transfer some capital to our children. How much can we transfer in this financial year without needing to declare to the Inland Revenue?

MC, Bradford on Avon

If your whole estate is below £231,000 when you die, you pay no inheritance tax. In addition to that figure, during your lifetime, each person can give away £3,000 a year and make numerous small gifts worth up to £250 to each recipient. If a child marries this year, you can give them another £5,000.

You can also make regular payments out of taxed income, provided it does not affect your standard of living. Keep a note of these transactions in case the Revenue queries them later. If you show a capital gain on any investments or assets you give away, you must declare this on your tax return.

 Write to Margaret Dibben, Money Writes, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER and include a telephone number. Do not enclose SAEs or original documents. Letters are selected for publication and we cannot give personal replies. The newspaper accepts no legal responsibility for advice.

webTitle: Dyed-in-the-wool bear may be right wood

fields.headline: Dyed-in-the-wool bear may be right wood
fields.trailText: Emily Bell
fields.body:
Bye, bye Mr Tony Dye, took our pensions to your fund but the returns were not high... (enough).

Rarely does the retirement of a fund manager merit such attention as that of Tony Dye, P&D's chief investment officer. Dye's notoriety in the City was as the biggest bear of them all - a philosophy that landed P&D with a poor track record over the past five years but which one instinctively felt meant that Dye was wrong, but for all the right reasons. If Dye had been an offensive and oafish figure, there would have been plenty of ammunition with which to dispatch him in the past three years, but the fact that he was articulate and pleasant and erudite makes his exit somehow a victory for the ignorance economy.

His approach was one of investing for value - picking companies undervalued by the market and waiting for the inevitable rise in share price. But of course over the past few years that just hasn't materialised. All the upward mobility in both the FTSE and the Dow has been underpinned by the dreaded tech stocks and telecoms companies. Some of them, such as Vodafone Airtouch, have fully justified their stellar prices, but these are the rare exceptions to the rule.

Dye's overwhelmingly good sense made one feel that one's money would be safe in his hands. But, unfortunately for those wishing to cash in on the raging bull market, safe has meant sorry. Nowhere is there a clearer illustration of this than in the likely ins and outs of the FTSE 100, which will be decided next week. Strange names whose business most people no nothing of, such as Baltimore Technology, Thus and Kingston Telecom will now appear on the index, while out slide of Thames Water, Scottish & Newcastle and Imperial Tobacco.

A man in a sharp suit on CNN's Moneyline the other night prattled on about the abandonment of the traditional valuation model in favour of what I suspect is basically nothing more scientific than sticking your finger in the air. Market debutant Lastminute.com, which many of us thought privately would be the first IPO to really fail, appears to be sallying forth down the slipway confident of a market valuation north of £300 million. But on what? A turnover of in excess of £2m? Well, the company may handle annual inventory worth these sums, but as a retailer of opportunity it keeps only a fraction of the deal, so in real turnover we are looking at only a couple of hundred thousand a year. If we ever dreamt of applying the 'old model' for valuation to Lastminute, we would find that it stands not a snowball's in Hades of ever making the numbers.

And now we have the final confirmation that old values are dead with the exit of Dye. Though P&D, with its new partner Brinson, claims that it will be sticking absolutely with the value-over-speculation philosophy so soundly expounded by Dye. Well one hopes so, because otherwise the departure of Dye may foreshadow the market catastrophe he has so consistently warned of. This is not just the application of sod's law - that having dropped his toast butter-side down for the past five years, it's about to land right way up with jam on it. It is pure market theory.

When the last bear has turned into a bull, there is literally no one left to enter the market. So what happens? Everyone starts to sell. Or at least that's the way it ought to work. Once the enthusiasm of the major investors wanes, it will take only a handful of the more volatile shares to have their access to capital cut off before the row of dominoes is tipped over. These are not just ramblings of the Dye-hard traditionalists.

The high priestess of technology stocks, Morgan Stanley's US analyst Mary Meeker, had barely picked up her $15m bonus last year before she was casually suggesting there would be a spring clean of the markets. In other words, the overdue shake-out of technology stocks will happen any day now. Beware the Ides of March, and all that. It is not inconceivable that Dye has departed just as things are about to start going his way.

This is not just the application of sod's law - that having dropped his toast butter-side down for the past five years, it's about to land right way up with jam on it. It is pure market theory. When the last bear has turned into a bull, there is literally no one left to enter the market. So what happens? Everyone starts to sell. Or at least that's the way it ought to work. Once the enthusiasm of the major investors wanes, it will take only a handful of the more volatile shares to have their access to capital cut off before the row of dominoes is tipped over. These are not just ramblings of the Dye-hard traditionalists. The high priestess of technology stocks, Morgan Stanley's US analyst Mary Meeker, had barely picked up her $15m bonus last year before she was casually suggesting there would be a spring clean of the markets. In other words, the overdue shake-out of technology stocks will happen any day now. Beware the Ides of March, and all that. It is not inconceivable that Dye has departed just as things are about to start going his way. emily.bell@observer.co.uk

webTitle: Energy firms enter row over utilities bill

fields.headline: Energy firms enter row over utilities bill
fields.trailText: The Government's beleaguered utilities Bill faces further crisis next week as electricity and gas companies demand ministers dilute key measures following the withdrawal of the telecoms and water sectors from the legislation last week.
fields.body:
The Government's beleaguered utilities Bill faces further crisis next week as electricity and gas companies demand ministers dilute key measures following the withdrawal of the telecoms and water sectors from the legislation last week.

The Electricity Association (EA) has demanded talks with DTI ministers and is expecting to meet Stephen Byers and Minister for Competition Kim Howells this week. It has also sought meetings with officials in the Prime Minster's office. Gas pipeline operator Transco and supplier Centrica are also pushing for meetings. They are demanding changes which would weaken the Bill.

Energy executives are furious that Trade and Industry Secretary Stephen Byers bowed to lobbying from telecoms companies who said the Bill would stifle innovation, and to water companies and environment department officials who said the sector should be dealt with under the forthcoming water Bill. One electricity company source said: 'We have lobbied reasonably for months on this and had no response. Just because Vodafone writes one letter they get pulled out. We are now going to make Ministers listen to our concerns and make sure they make changes to meet them.'

The utilities Bill was drawn up to cover the four sectors and aimed to balance the interests of companies with those of consumers, beef up regulation and introduce electricity trading arangements to replace the 'pool' system. It is now at its committee stage in the Commons.

The EA is demanding radical changes to measures allowing regulators to impose unlimited fines on companies for past and future performance. Companies say they are already covered by the 1989 Electricity Act, which allows fines from regulators as well as the threat of legal action from consumers. It is also concerned about the Government's wide powers to change company licences in preparation for new trading arrangements without consultation.

The EA said: 'What we want taken out are draconian powers to fine companies, which come on top of existing measures, and cause triple jeopardy.

'We are also unhappy with the power to change licences, and will be saying this forcefully.'

fields.headline: Unity, the new Co-op divi
fields.standfirst: The merger of retail and wholesale should allow the reborn movement to take on Sainsbury and Tesco.
fields.trailText: The merger of retail and wholesale should allow the reborn movement to take on Sainsbury and Tesco.
fields.body:
The vote at London's Regents Park Hotel yesterday was a result Senator John McCain could only dream of. Members of Co-operative Retail Services overwhelmingly backed a merger with the Co-operative Wholesale Society, sealing a long-cherished ambition to revitalise one of the country's best loved high street names.

With the deal in the bag, the new Co-op force is already looking towards the total unification of the movement founded by the Rochdale pioneers 150 years ago. Ten days ago, Tony Blair sponsored the foundation of a new commission of the great and the good in the Labour Party and trade unions to look at the whole future of the Co-op. New legislation, freeing the venerable institution to compete better with the likes of Tesco and Sainsbury, is already one certain outcome. And after 50 years of mergers of small co-ops up and down the land, United Norwest - the last big independent - faces intense pressure to join the fold.

'The merger of CWS and CRS will transform the movement in one fell swoop,' Graham Melmoth, CWS's seasoned chief executive, said this weekend. 'The co-op sector has to perform as effectively as the big four retailers to survive. We are now creating the conditions to do this.'

The developments were not borne only of fear of the co-op's giant rivals. Three years ago, borrowing tactics from the dirtiest of stock market takeover battles, Melmoth saw off carpetbaggers led by City whiz kid Andrew Regan who wanted to plunder the co-op as building societies have been pillaged for windfalls before. The battle - featuring a Serious Fraud Office pursuit of traitors in the ranks - was won decisively, but the war was far from over. As The Observer disclosed last May, new get-rich-quick-merchants in the City attempted to recruit top Co-op names to front a fresh bid for the CWS and its prize assets, which include the Co-op Bank, the Co-op Insurance Society and Britain's biggest farmer and funeral arranger.

And, as we can reveal today, there was intense concern among senior 'co-operators' about New Labour's interest in the movement at all. Nicolas Lethbridge, the financier putting together the new bid, was thought to have an inside track to Downing Street. His partner, Margaret McCabe, is a barrister who knows Cherie Blair.

One co-op adviser said: 'We don't spend all our time looking over a shoulder. But there was a worry that the Prime Minister's benign interest in the Co-op might vanish in the name of so-called modernisation.'

From conversations last June between Melmoth and the then Labour Party finance director, David Pitt-Watson, plus subsequent meetings at the No 10 Policy Unit attended by Phil Wilson, Blair's aide from his Sedgefield constituency, the Co-op Commission was born.

In parallel, Melmoth reactivated talks with the CRS. Previous ones had foundered on personality clashes with Harry Moore, the CRS's long-standing chief executive, over who would head a merged organisation. By last summer, however, Moore had gone, replaced by Andy Meehan, a senior executive of Storehouse, the BhS and Mothercare chain, who was charged with completing a fundamental reorganisation. More importantly, heavy losses had driven the CRS into financial trouble which had led to the £150 million sale of its non-food stores to cut debt. Yesterday's decision means the CWS is again fulfilling its role as saviour of last resort for failing Co-ops around the country.

One CWS director said: 'The merger had to happen. Otherwise Co-op assets would simply have been sold off to the highest bidder - assets built up by members over a century and a half.'

The Co-op hopes that the commission, chaired by TUC general secretary John Monks, will give the movement fresh impetus. In particular, senior figures want new legislation that will revamp Co-op boards along commercial lines, with clear accountability to members and let in experienced non-executive directors from outside.

Management and staff are likely to be rewarded with new incentives, possibly new, income-bearing shares. And, as with building societies, directors want the threshold for conversion to company status to be raised from a bare majority to 75 per cent to deter carpetbaggers.

Instead of conversion, with building society-style windfalls, the movement hopes to define the 'Co-op difference' with new dividends for customer loyalty and clear objectives for funding social projects in local communities.

To achieve those ambitions, however, the Co-op must survive and become as efficient as its rivals in a fiercely competitive market. Last year, the CWS made operating profits of £113m on sales of £3.2 billion. And for the first time in 22 years, its 640 supermarkets and convenience stores increased their market share. That compares well with CRS, which runs 470 shops and made operating losses of £29m on sales of £1.3bn. At 8 per cent, however, the return on capital from CWS's shops is only half the industry average. And each percentage point it lags behind means £5m of cash it lacks to update its stores, reward customers and invest in communities.

United Norwest meanwhile, under chief executive Martin Beaumont, has a far more successful record than CRS. With 550 outlets in all, last year it made trading profits of £19m on sales of £740m. Along with the smaller Southern and Tamworth Co-ops, however, it remains outside the CWS's centralised buying operation, the Co-operative Retail Trading Group, which serves Britain's 44 other Co-ops. And by staying aloof from all that buying power, it sacrifices up to 3 per cent on its profit margin, say analysts.

The last fundamental review of the movement, chaired by former Labour leader Hugh Gaitskell in 1958, was followed by an increasing number of mergers which has reduced the number of independent Co-op societies from more than 1,000 to 47 now. The new commission is very much driven by the CWS and, while it is unlikely to instruct United Norwest and the smaller independents to merge, the pressure to do so will be clear.

Personalities will play as important a role as commercial logic, however.

'At 61, Melmoth is not getting any younger and the search will be on for a successor,' a CWS director said.

'The CRS merger has changed the balance of the movement for good. And if Martin Beaumont wants the job he'd better bring Norwest into the fold quickly.'

It all began in Rochdale...

1844: Foundation of the Rochdale Equitable Pioneers Society, the first Co-op founded

1863: Foundation of CWS as a food-buying organisation.

1934: Establishment of CRS to open Co-op shops

fields.headline: Media Diary
fields.trailText: Piers, the saga continues | Most Thankless Task in Television
fields.body:
Office poets couplet to mirror the plight of poor Piers
Despite the fact that we are a share-free zone on Media Diary, our piety is not so great that we can't confess to being slightly pleased to hear of Piers Morgan returning, in one piece, to the editor's chair of the Mirror . His first office conference was, allegedly, held with him in chirpy mood, insisting that 'Viglen is not the brightest thing I have ever done', but onwards and upwards etc. A newsroom so relieved that Morgan was not replaced by the long list of potential candidates who had been auditioning for his job, celebrated by composing a long piece of doggerel which encapsulates his showbiz past and current financial plight.

It's not as wittily written as the Mirror but here's a taste:

'Alas poor Piers that deal too many,
Cost more than just a pretty penny.
The famous faded out of sight,

Not even Wham! could ease his plight.
'And so he sits alone in tears,
No more to dine with Britney Spears.

He waits to speak with one Old Bill
For having fingers in the till...'

When he emerges from his Piers purdah we urge him to respond in rhyme. Though anything which scans and rhymes with Anil Bhoyrul seems to be obscene, so be careful.

Good times for the little man
For anyone who followed the cracking libel case of Keith Burstein vs the Times, whereby Mr Burstein successfully contested that the Thunderer's account of his concert-going as a man who went to the works of modern composers specifically with a view to disrupting them, there are one or two juicy details. Not only did Mr Burstein win, but the judge lambasted the Times , describing it as a major newspaper with funds to take a bold stance, which they used in an attempt 'to make the little man go away'. The judge continued: 'Their defence was somewhere between the boundaries of totally hopeless and a dead duck'... Ooer, or Booo! as they would say at Wapping.

Sky's donkey work
Red faces - and more - at Sky, where a new media problem has raised its very ugly head. Those anxious for online news who try the following address: www.skynews.org will not be greeted by the dashing Adam Boulton or harrowing reports from Keith Graves. Instead they will find themselves confronted by a woman in a too-tight undergarment fondling a rather bemused looking donkey. For anyone who thinks that this is a sneaky way of looking at porn undetected be warned - your computer will not record the surfing as a visit to Sky News but as the rather less cerebral Sexhorse.com.

Big-hearted Barclays
Barclays Bank, bless it, is launching a new ad campaign tomorrow which is fronted by Hannibal Lecter - sorry, Sir Anthony Hopkins. Barclays, coos the press release is a 'big bank in a big world'. And what's more it will 'embrace change for the benefit of our customers'. Is this the same Barclays Bank which decided last week that it would fleece us for an extra £1 every time we use its cash machines? The Barclays Bank which is sticking to this punitive charging procedure and tax on the poor even though the Government-backed Cruikshank inquiry says it has no right to be charging more than 30p a time?

Master of television's most thankless task
And finally a word on the 'race' to replace the ITV chief executive, Richard Eyre. Despite the fact he has now departed, the headhunters seem to be making heavy weather of finding a replacement for the 'Most Thankless Task in Television'. The usual roster of candidates has run out but there are a couple of fresh names to add to the frame, one being former advertising executive and now inhabitant of Warner Bros. London, Nigel Sharrocks, who is, for the record, Mr Fiona Bruce - so possibly an ugly conflict of interest there. There are also intriguing rumours of a Man From Mars arriving to take the job. Not sadly from the planet with no atmosphere, but rather from the continent with no culture, Mr Mars is reckoned to be an American. Let's hope he wasn't just the man who counts the M&Ms off the production line a la Dome disaster...

webTitle: BMW moves to set up car 'department stores'

fields.headline: BMW moves to set up car 'department stores'
fields.trailText: BMW is planning a worldwide sales shake-up that will see Mini, MG, Rover, Land Rover, BMW and even Rolls-Royce vehicles sold under the same roof in vast 'department store' dealerships.
fields.body:
BMW is planning a worldwide sales shake-up that will see Mini, MG, Rover, Land Rover, BMW and even Rolls-Royce vehicles sold under the same roof in vast 'department store' dealerships.

The German carmaker is hoping that thousands of separate Rover and BMW dealers will merge in a drive to improve profitability and boost investment in larger, plusher showrooms.

But Rover chairman Werner Samann warned last week that dealers selling fewer than 200 cars a year were vulnerable: 'We need strong, big dealers that are able to invest and present the cars in the right manner, with proper levels of service,' he said. 'We eliminate weak dealers and small dealerships... I am afraid they will not survive.'

BMW owns the Rover group, which includes the Land Rover, Range Rover, Mini and MG brands, and it has the right to produce Rolls-Royce cars from 2003.

The Rover and BMW marques have been kept apart until now in order to avoid consumer confusion and any undermining of BMW as a premium brand.

But BMW has spent the past two years trying to integrate as many of the group's functions as possible.

Now it plans to offer the group's entire range in selected super-dealers, dubbed BMW 'villages', selling up to 1,500 vehicles a year. Samann said: 'It is already on the way. One model is fully integrated dealerships, within which all the brands are separated in their own "brand world" like a department store. You keep a customer for life: they'll start off buying a Mini and work up through the range.'

There are 350 Rover and Land Rover dealers in the UK and 165 BMW outlets.

You keep a customer for life: they'll start off buying a Mini and work up through the range.' There are 350 Rover and Land Rover dealers in the UK and 165 BMW outlets.

fields.headline: Stockwatch
fields.trailText: BhS's bambino | Papercup.com
fields.body:
BhS's bambino
Goodbye cruel world? For Storehouse, at least, it looks as if the end is nigh, with bidders lining up for all or part of the unloved BhS and Mothercare group.

BhS's value as a brand has long been in doubt, and suitors would no doubt view it just as a means of getting hold of 4.5 million sq ft of handy retail space. A bidder for Mothercare, however, could do mums and dads up and down the land a big favour. It is a scandal that the leading High Street brand for young kids has been allowed to slip so much, with uninspiring product ranges and so-so customer service.

Many people should be interested in Mothercare. But our favourite is Pré natal, the wonderful Italian chain - if it summons the courage to enter the UK, possibly with venture capital backing.

It is a measure of Storehouse's decline that at 46p, brokers such as Salomon Smith Barney believe it already to be fairly valued. Hold on, but while bid talk sweeps the sector, have a look, too, at House of Fraser, New Look and Selfridges.

T&S one to watch

Sticking with the High Street, T&S Stores is one of those consistent performers whose shares have plateaued of late. With turnover set to break the magical £1 billion barrier within a few years, the central plank of T&S's success in the 1990s has been a shift from cut-price fags to a convenience store format.

Indeed, from just 35 'C-stores' in 1989, they now account for two-thirds of the chain and 80 per cent of profits. Fifty more are due to open this year, and by 2002 analysts reckon T&S will have 1,000 in all, supported by strong distribution and modern point-of-sale technology.

At 388p, T&S shares are trading at just 13 times forecast earnings for the current year. That underrates its solid track record and prospects, says broker Charterhouse, which has set a 12-month target price of 500p.

Papercup.com
Bunzl is another mystery company. Profits last week were ahead of expectations; the firm is confident about prospects; and pretty much every broker rates it a buy. Yet for no apparent reason the shares have slumped from 365p to 318p this year. Maybe it's the name: it all too easily becomes 'Bungle'.

So why not try plasticbag.com? After all, the group is trialling Internet ordering for its paper and plastic products. And adding a punctuation mark plus three silly letters is a sure way to double your share price.

Restructuring has left four core divisions: paper distribution, cigarette filter production, plastic components and outsourcing of disposable packaging and other supplies for supermarkets, where promising growth is seen.

At 318p, the putative papercup.com is trading at just 12 times prospective earnings, which is half the market average. Buy.

Big beer
Don't take too seriously Scottish & Newcastle's suggestions that it expects to get only £800m or so for its Center Parcs and Pontins operations, put up for sale last week.

Privately, S&N is hoping for around £950m when the holidays business goes. It believes it can justify the price by the large sums it has invested in Center Parcs in the past few years - and the upturn in profitability that is finally showing through.

S&N is the only large national British brewer showing real commitment to beer production. But it has expanded about as far as it can in the UK, with its market share nudging 30 per cent. It would love to clinch the takeover of Kronenbourg. Shares in S&N, bombed out along with those of is rivals in the sector, look cheap and an excellent defensive play. Buy.

webTitle: Monaco stake points to new bid by Green

fields.headline: Monaco stake points to new bid by Green
fields.trailText: Evidence has emerged that Monaco-based investors are building up a stake in retail group Storehouse, according to sources close to the company - strengthening suggestions that entrepreneur Philip Green is planning a bid for the beleaguered group.
fields.body:
Evidence has emerged that Monaco-based investors are building up a stake in retail group Storehouse, according to sources close to the company - strengthening suggestions that entrepreneur Philip Green is planning a bid for the beleaguered group.

Green, himself based in Monaco, last month abandoned an assault on Marks & Spencer. He has tried to quash reports that he is now interested in going for Storehouse, which is sounding out possible buyers for the company or its constituent parts, Mothercare and BhS.

But despite Green's denials, it is understood that he has made efforts to find out more about Storehouse and how much it could be worth.

Reports last week that investment group Alchemy is one of the possible bidders for Storehouse are now understood to be wide of the mark. Alchemy is understood to have looked at Mothercare last year. But it decided to back away after it gleaned figurs about Mothercare's declining customer totals and its rising rent costs.

The companies that have looked at Mothercare include Prenatal of Italy, a family-controlled chain of 354 children's clothing shops. Its operations already extend into Spain, Germany, Portugal, Greece, Mexico and Argentina.

webTitle: Wary City smells a rat in empty Rentokil promises

fields.headline: Wary City smells a rat in empty Rentokil promises
fields.trailText: Throg Street
fields.body:
The city is clearly trying to get a message across to Sir Clive Thompson, chief executive of pest control-to-pot plant group Rentokil Initial. A year ago, he insisted he would not abandon his target of 20 per cent annual profits growth, although it was becoming obvious that Rentokil could not achieve it. Since then, the shares have lost two-thirds of their value.

Last week, he set new targets - sales growth of 6-10 per cent, producing profits growth of 8-14 per cent, and outperforming the support services sector over the next five years - and the shares fell by more than a fifth.

The problem is not the targets per se - although 10 per cent sales growth is paltry compared with what technology companies claim they can achieve - but whether Rentokil can achieve them. Last year's results produced plenty of disappointments, starting with the profits themselves.

On the face of it, a 10 per cent increase in profit to £541 million was comfortably within analysts' expectations. But an examination of the small print showed that that was after the writeback of a £17.6m provision; without that, profits would have grown by a much more pedestrian 6.3 per cent.

Then there was the disposals programme. The City had been expecting sales of non-core businesses to raise between £700m and £1 billion, and hoped for news of at least one big sale with the results. Now, Rentokil is estimating between £600m and £700m, and promises the sales will be completed by the year end. If the price achieved is at the lower end, that would hit profits by a swingeing 12.6 per cent.

The £1.5bn share buy-back confirmed last week will compensate - assuming the share price does not rise too much before it is carried out. But that news was overshadowed by the planned acquisition of Ratin, the Danish investment company whose sole asset is 32 per cent of Rentokil's shares. Thompson says the move will improve liquidity, and pre-empts Ratin's decision to distribute the shares next spring. But investors are concerned that the 19,000 Danish shareholders who will turn up on its register will offload their shares.

Thompson admits that the new targets are achievable in the 'medium term'. On the basis of last year's figures, even that looks ambitious. Stripping out the businesses to be sold, sales grew by just 3.4 per cent. True, profits were 10.5 per cent higher, but there must be a question over how long Rentokil can continue increasing margins.

It could, of course, fall back on acquisitions. Its cashflow remains enviably strong and, even after the buy-back, it could comfortably afford to spend £1bn.

But Rentokil's problems stem partly from its reliance on acquisitions to meet its old 20 per cent target. It needs to convince investors that it has changed. On a rating of 11 times forecast earnings, its shares look cheap, but there is a lot better value elsewhere.

Get a stake in L&G
David Prosser, chief executive of Legal & General, sees no need for a merger of the kind proposed by Norwich Union and CGU: they have an eye to the global market, while L&G sees plenty of opportunities in the UK.

Last year's results suggest he is right, so far. New business grew by 27 per cent, exceeding £500m in the UK for the first time; operating profit before tax rose 12 per cent and the dividend is increased by a generous 14 per cent. If Prosser is right about the potential in stakeholder pensions, there should be much more to come.

L&G has already invested considerable resources in preparing for stakeholder pensions. Its focus will be on deals through the workplace and affinity groups, such as the Computer Services and Software Association, with which it has just formed an alliance. Prosser thinks the market could be worth as much as £20bn in the first three years and hopes L&G can take as much as 10 per cent of that market, double its share of other investment products. It is building on its Internet capability, already used by independent advisers and its own salesmen, both to cut the costs and make it easy for stakeholders to monitor their pensions.

L&G has an enviable record of increasing market share by offering good value products that people want to buy. That has helped it treble its new business in the past five years. If anyone can make a success of stakeholder pensions, it can. The shares have been under a cloud since the collapse of its proposed merger with NatWest but they deserve a re-rating. Buy.

Techno wizardry
Private shareholders are constantly being told not even to consider investing in technology shares on their own, but to spread their risk by buying a technology fund. That is sound advice: even the professionals do not know which of the new breed of companies will prosper, so what hope have retail investors?

The problem is that even the technology funds are now starting to look expensive. The price of unit trusts reflects the value of the underlying investments but, as even the most bullish techno-buff will tell you, many of these will prove hopelessly optimistic. Demand for technology investment trusts is so great that many are standing at above their net asset value. There is, therefore, a risk that anyone buying now will end up losing money.

One way round this is to look for trusts with significant technology exposure but which, perhaps because they do not have technology in their titles, have not been caught up in the boom.

The price of trusts such as Dresdner RCM Smaller Companies, Henderson Smaller Companies and Discovery Trust - run by Friends Ivory & Sime - stands at 15 per cent or more below their asset values. Yet all have a significant exposure to technology stocks - 50 per cent for Discovery; more than 60 per cent for the other two - and hold shares in such market favourites as JSB Software, Infobank, Geo Interactive, Colt Telecom and ARM Holdings.

Of course, they would not be immune to a fall-out in technology stocks - and the managers of Murray Enterprise, another technology-rich small companies trust, warned that its investment policy is higher-risk, although potentially higher-reward, than usual. But they are not over-exposed to one company - Henderson, with 10 per cent of its assets in Colt, is the most concentrated. And the discounts to net asset value are high enough to compensate for a sizeable fall in technology stocks.

fields.headline: Be happy in your work
fields.trailText: How to...
fields.body:
1 Recognise how important it is to enjoy your work. Like a bad marriage, a bad job will ultimately distort your personality.

2 Work out the factors that give you most satisfaction - usually involving the task itself (you love train driving), a sense of achievement, and the people (camaraderie often makes army life worthwhile). To discover your own motivations, conduct exercises such as listing the 20 work (and non-work) landmarks in your life. If your great love was playing in the school football team, teamwork and camaraderie may be the main drivers for you.

3 Accept that few people know that they were destined for one profession from childhood. So you have to make a determined effort to achieve happiness at work. Note down the areas of your job that you dislike - particularly the stress factors - and work at reducing them. If you are a stressed-out middle manager who can do nothing to cut the workload, learning time management skills is an absolute must, says trainer and author Terry Gillen. 'Most people have something to learn from a very good time management course.'

4 Take on other responsibilities outside work if your ticket-collecting job is a cul-de-sac. 'If you feel better in one area of your life, it has a knock-on effect in others,' says Gillen.

5 Decide on ways to exercise more control. Anyone who feels that they are just on the receiving end of fate is inclined to feel stressed and depressed. The singing bus conductor or the tea lady with a smile are far happier than their colleagues because they are engaging with other human beings, improving the quality of life of others and are probably far more open to new opportunities as they come along.

6 Keep a long-term focus and a sense of direction. Promise yourself to stop doing a job you hate and start building up skills - even things like dealing with unpleasant people - to get you there in the end.

webTitle: Can I claim for RSI pain?

fields.headline: Can I claim for RSI pain?
fields.trailText: Agony aunt
fields.body:
My sister believes she may be suffering from repetitive strain injury (RSI) caused by her work inputting computer information from application forms. Could she bring a claim against her employers and win compensation?

Many employers neglect the duty of all businesses to provide a safe working environment for their employees by breaking Health & Safety guidelines on assessing the risks staff face and making modifications as a result.

So an employee who feels she is suffering from RSI could well have the starting point of a claim, arguing that she has suffered ill health as a consequence of her employer's negligence. But the damages awards are not very high, and it can be a lengthy process.

Some unions are taking the RSI issue very seriously and winning damages for members. Your sister would be best off going through a union. Any case involving medical evidence can be very costly.

According to the Trades Union Congress, the typical compensation payment ordered by the courts is between £2,000 and £7,000 for the pain and suffering of the victim. In the recent case of the Midland Bank's Frimley cheque processing centre in Surrey, several RSI sufferers won claims averaging £7,000.

The TUC is urging a doubling in financial value for this kind of compensation payment. It estimates that 200,000 people a year suffer symptoms of RSI.

 Problem at work? Write to Neasa MacErlean, The Observer, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. Answers are for guidance only.

fields.headline: Tourists caught in insurers' alcotrap
fields.trailText: A cold beer or chilled glass of white wine under a hot Mediterranean sky are highlights of a summer holiday for many people. But beware: if you have an accident after drinking, your insurer will probably not pay up.
fields.body:
A cold beer or chilled glass of white wine under a hot Mediterranean sky are highlights of a summer holiday for many people. But beware: if you have an accident after drinking, your insurer will probably not pay up.

Young people who have accidents on holiday after drinking too much are getting a poor deal from travel insurers, according to the Insurance Ombudsman Bureau. Travel policies frequently exclude alcohol-related claims and the Ombudsman believes that insurers are interpreting the clauses too harshly.

In the latest annual report for the Bureau, Reidy Flynn says: 'Some tour operators encourage their clients to drink, and it is a major feature of many 18-30 holidays. If someone has the misfortune to suffer a serious accident, can it be fair to deny him benefit because of an exclusion which was not highlighted? And how much worse is this situation for his family if this exclusion is also applied to their claim for his medical expenses?'

Flynn told The Observer: 'I don't think it is clear to the public that they can lose cover if they have more than a couple of glasses of wine.'

She said that insurers providing cover for young people's holidays, particularly those where alcohol was included in the package should cover claims related to drinking or give clear warnings where it was not.

However it is not just the 18-30 age group that can be caught out. One case handled by the Ombudsman bureau involved a 34-year-old man who went on holiday to Spain with his fiancée. After a long drive they had dinner and shared a bottle of wine. They walked around the town for most of the night and the man drank two glasses of whisky before the couple returned to their hotel at about 4.30 in the morning. Soon afterwards, he fell from a balcony outside his room and died.

The autopsy showed his blood alcohol level was more than three times the legal limit for driving in the UK, although relatives disputed the accuracy of the reading.

The policyholder's estate claimed under the personal accident section but the insurer refused to pay out. The insurer met the cost of bringing the body back to the UK but later asked the estate for the money back.

The Ombudsman said: 'The mere fact that the policyholder had ingested some alcohol during the evening preceding his death was not sufficient grounds for declining liability. It would be something of a rarity if a young holidaymaker in similar circumstances had not.'

The company was ordered to pay the accidental death benefit and to withdraw its claim for repatriation costs.
