webTitle: Could this be the best kept pension secret?

fields.headline: Could this be the best kept pension secret?
fields.standfirst: Investment trusts schemes are cheap and flexible, says  Helen Pridham
fields.trailText: Although often considered fuddy duddy, investment trust groups have frequently shown they can be ahead of the game. So it has been with pensions.
fields.body:
Although often considered fuddy duddy, investment trust groups have frequently shown they can be ahead of the game. So it has been with pensions.

Led by the pioneering Foreign & Colonial in 1994, a number of groups introduced what looked like stakeholder pensions several years before the term was even mentioned by the Labour Party.

Unlike traditional personal pensions, which had heavy initial charges and penalised those who did not stay the course, investment trust pensions are low-cost, transparent and flexible. However, they have remained relatively unknown because of low-key marketing.

The fact that they pay little or no commission to intermediaries has not helped sales. Even Flemings, which has done more than most to promote its scheme, still has less than 4,000 pension plans on its books after five years, though its average investment tends to be high and it has more than £15 million under management.

Recently the introduction of cheap 'stakeholder-friendly' pensions by a number of mainstream pension providers has also taken away many of the cost advantages offered by the investment trust schemes. Still, for most people who choose them, it is the trusts themselves that are the main attraction.

Scottish-based financial adviser Robert Graham, who has an investment trust personal pension, says: 'Those of my clients who have taken out these pensions tend to be people who already have a clear idea of how investment trusts work and want the kind of investment performance the trusts can provide. However, they are in the minority. This type of pension is still very much a niche product.'

There are four groups offering investment trust pensions: Alliance Trust, Edinburgh Fund Managers, Fleming and Foreign & Colonial. All except Alliance also have a free standing additional voluntary contribution facility for savers who are already members of a company pension scheme.

Investors can choose any trust from a manager's range. This gives them the chance to select from trusts such as those investing in emerging markets or venture capital.

However, Fleming found that 60 per cent of its pension holders were prepared to let someone else do the choosing and were opting for its 'managed' option, which included a selection of its 18 trusts. As a result it recently created a dedicated 'trust of trusts' for this purpose.

Alliance Trust and Edinburgh Fund Managers also offer access to other managers' trusts. This gives people who like to make their own investment decisions the scope to cherry pick the best trusts and switch between different managers' trusts.

Although Edinburgh offers a more restricted range of choice than Alliance, Graham has found it is willing to consider other trusts.

Minimum investments in the pension plans typically start at £50 a month or a lump sum of £1,000 and there are no penalties for stopping or changing your contributions. Managers find they are particularly popular with lump sum investors. Such investors often have other pension plans and are using their single premium contributions to gain more investment diversity.

Charges vary. Edinburgh and Foreign & Colonial both have a setting-up fee of £100, but Alliance and Flemings do not charge. Normally there are no charges for buying the trusts of your choice apart from stamp duty, although Foreign & Colonial does levy dealing commission of 0.2 per cent and Alliance's plan, which is transaction- based, charges a range of commissions depending on the trusts bought and sold.

The annual management charges on the investment trusts themselves are usually well under 1 per cent. Foreign & Colonial Investment Trust, for example, charges only 0.3 per cent a year. However, all the groups apart from Alliance make an extra annual administration charge for the provision of the pension plan itself.

At Edinburgh it is a modest £50 plus 0.25 per cent, while Fleming has a sliding scale of fees reducing from 0.5 per cent to 0.25 per cent and with an overall cap on charges of £175 a year - so once the pension fund is worth more than £70,000 there is nothing extra to pay.

Although these charges are modest by past pension standards, whether the investment trust schemes will be able to adapt to the requirements of stakeholder pensions - which must have an annual charge of 1 per cent or less and no other charges - is not certain. Edinburgh Fund Managers marketing manager Leslie Drummond says: 'They already look very much like stakeholders and we are reviewing the situation, but we can't promise anything at present.'

One of the stipulations of stakeholders is that the minimum investment must be no more than £20. This could be a tough condition to meet. Georgette Harrison at Foreign & Colonial says: 'I am not convinced that it would be a viable proposition for us. The key to success will be attracting large volumes of business. We are still deliberating.'

At Flemings, Vicky Bond also points out that unless the Chancellor, Gordon Brown, removes stamp duty on shares in the Budget, keeping within the 1 per cent annual charge limit could be difficult.

Still, charges are not everything, and the investment choices that are offered by the plans will undoubtedly remain their greatest attraction.

fields.headline: Single,solvent and sorted
fields.standfirst: Forget Bridget Jones.  A new generation seems happy not to be in couples...   Jill Insley looks at financial realities for today's thirtysomethings
fields.trailText: Forget Bridget Jones. A new generation seems happy not to be in couples... Jill Insley looks at financial realities for today's thirtysomethings
fields.body:
David is 36, tall, dark, attractive - and single. Ten years ago people might have regarded his unmarried status with a certain amount of suspicion. Then, most single men in their thirties were either gay or divorced. Either way, they would have plenty of emotional and financial baggage.

In fact David is one of an increasing number of men and women who have postponed getting married and having a family. His work as a civil engineer has led to him spending long periods overseas - he has lived in Africa, the Far East, the Middle East and the US. Although he has now returned to Britain, David's £33,000 salary means he can still travel widely for pleasure and enjoy a healthy social life that keeps him out most nights. And while he has had relationships during the past 15 years, he has not felt the need to settle down.

'I'm not sure I actively decided to postpone getting married - it is just the way it has ended up,' he says. 'I have never met the right person. I hope I will get married and possibly have a family in the future.'

David is a classic 'sorted': single, own residence, thirtysomething, employed deferrer - an independent, financially comfortable adult who continually puts off major lifestyle decisions, says Martin Hayward, director of consumer consultancy at the Henley Centre.

A rapid increase in the number of 'sorteds' over the past decade has surprised market analysts. Demographic changes usually happen gradually, but according to the Office of National Statistics, the number of single and never married thirtysomethings rose from 969,900 in 1987 to 2.3 million in 1997.

Unlike Bridget Jones, the man-fixated thirtysomething creation of writer Helen Fielding, 'sorteds' are not at all keen on giving up their freedom for happy coupledom.

Hayward says: 'Thirtysomethings now are equivalent to twentysomethings 10 years ago. They are not settling down. They are less likely to get married or to have children. They are therefore more affluent and like going out to spend their money.'

The average household is now 40 per cent better off in real terms than 14 years ago. This means single thirtysomethings have a lot of spare cash to spend as they like. And they are spending hugely. Last year, for the first time since records have been kept, people aged between 30 and 50 spent more on pleasure than on groceries: an average of £71.10 a week on leisure goods and services, compared with £64.50 a week on food and non-alcoholic drinks. Health clubs, eating out, clothes and holidays were the most popular extravagances, closely followed by cars, home improvements and new homes.

And after 10 or 15 years of self-indulgence, many are reluctant to surrender their lifestyle. Hayward says: 'They are finding it harder and harder to make the commitment to settle down and share their lives.'

Leading psychologist Professor Cary Cooper believes pressure of work is preventing many of them from developing emotional relationships. 'We have Americanised our careers,' says Cooper, of the University of Manchester Institute of Science and Technology.

'Work is much more demanding, and hours are longer, so professional people have neither the capacity nor the opportunity to meet other people and form relationships.'

However, he believes the gloss of singledom tends to dull by the time people hit their mid-thirties, when it becomes apparent that there should more to life than work.

Work pressures are affecting the lives of those who do marry by encouraging them to wait until they are older to start families. Ten years ago the average married mother had her first baby at 26. Now she is likely to be over 30.

This delay dramatically affects women's finances, according to a Government report earlier this month. A working mother on a middle income, such as a secretary or nurse, loses £299,000 in earnings if she starts her family at 24, whereas delaying childbirth until 30, reduces the loss to £89,000, a 'saving' of £165,000, according to the report, commissioned by Ministers for Women Baroness Jay and Tessa Jowell.

And because these women are older and more established in their careers, they are less likely to be full-time mothers. Where both parents work, they can afford childcare and other domestic help, though this uses up a significant slice of disposable income.

Sarah, 34, an events organiser, is about to return to work after having her second child. She will spend £1,200 a month on childcare - only £200 a month less than her net pay.

'Getting married didn't much affect my finances,' she says. 'The enormous change came with having the children. I'm working basically to keep them in nursery, but because I'm really interested in my job and my husband works at home a lot, we think this is the best solution.'

webTitle: FTSE swaps beer and fags for phones and dot.coms

fields.headline: FTSE swaps beer and fags for phones and dot.coms
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The London stock market will lurch further into the new economy on Wednesday when a clutch of brewing, cigarette and building companies are ejected from the FTSE 100 index in favour of telephone, Internet and computer companies.
fields.body:
The London stock market will lurch further into the new economy on Wednesday when a clutch of brewing, cigarette and building companies are ejected from the FTSE 100 index in favour of telephone, Internet and computer companies.

The most startling promotion will be that of Baltimore Technologies, which supplies secure systems for doing business on the Web. At last week's closing price, it is worth almost £4.5 billion yet, as recently as six months ago, it was worth less than £300 million. It only graduated in December from the FTSE Fledgling index of companies too tiny to be counted as small to the FTSE 250 index.

Baltimore is expected to be joined in the FTSE 100 by at least four other new technology stars: Freeserve, the Internet service provider, telephone companies Thus and Kingston Communications, and Psion, the maker of hand-held organisers. The first two have been large enough to make the FTSE for some months, but were barred until now on the grounds that they were subsidiaries of other FTSE 100 companies - Dixons and Scottish Power respectively.

FTSE 100 entry could push their already soaring share prices even higher, as it will force the managers of indexed funds, who seek to track the index exactly, to buy into them. Dixons still holds 80 per cent of Freeserve, while Scottish Power has 51 per cent of Thus, so the number of shares available for purchase is limited.

Among the stalwarts of the old economy which are expected to be ejected from the FTSE 100 are Scottish & Newcastle, Imperial Tobacco, Wolseley and Thames Water. The difference in their FTSE fortunes is reflected in the differences in their results, although not in the way you would expect. Psion's profits before tax, excluding exceptional and investment in its Symbian mobile operating system, dropped from £13.2m to £10.8m; Baltimore lost £33.3m on sales of £23.3m; and neither Thus nor Freeserve are expected to make profits for years.

S & N, Imperial Tobacco and Thames Water all make more than £300m of profit a year and all, apart from Thames, are expected to increase their earnings this year. But that no longer impresses a City which is dazzled by the potential of the Internet and its expansion on to mobile telephones, and obsessed with sales rather than profit growth.

webTitle: Cover to keep you in the house to which you're accustomed

fields.headline: Cover to keep you in the house to which you're accustomed
fields.standfirst: If your dream home is listed or thatched, specialist insurance may offer more protection at less cost, writes  Virginia Wallis
fields.trailText: If your dream home is listed or thatched, specialist insurance may offer more protection at less cost
fields.body:
The fact that mortgage lenders can no longer force customers to buy the building insurance they offer has been good news for all borrowers. But it has been particularly good news for people who live in unusual or high-cost properties.

For owners of thatched cottages, listed buildings or other property built of non-standard materials, the mainstream policies offered by lenders are not only expensive but they can also offer inappropriate cover.

If you live in a thatched property, some companies - Direct Line, for example - won't insure you at all. Other general insurers, such as Norwich Union, will load the premium - sometimes quite substantially - because of the increased fire risk posed by thatched properties.

Dennis Ratcliffe, Chairman of Country Thatch Insurance Agency, thinks that standard insurers, because they lack expert knowledge, overestimate the risk and so load the premium unnecessarily. You are likely to get a much better deal by going to a specialist who understands the risks of living in a thatched property.

One of the reasons that specialists can keep the price down is that they are more likely to ask detailed questions about the state of the property. They will also insist on safety checks being carried out. 'Too many fires are caused by faulty electrics and when there is a fire it is almost invariably a total loss,' says Ratcliffe. Both Country Thatch and Holman Insurance Brokers, for example, insist that owners have their wiring, chimneys, fireplaces and other heating appliances checked.

You may also find that it is a condition of the insurance that you take certain fire-prevention measures such as having a fire extinguisher on every floor, not using naked flames in the roof space and not lighting fires within a certain distance of the property. These are all things that benefit the insurer (because they reduce the likelihood of a claim), but expert advice on anti-fire measures also benefits owners who are unlikely to want to see their homes rapidly go up in smoke.

As Maureen Galloway of Holman Insurance Brokers points out, such advice is particularly valuable for people new to living in thatched properties who may not be aware of the hazards involved.

Mainstream insurers may not agree, but people who live in listed buildings should be less worried about fire and more worried about the risk of being underinsured. 'Owners of listed buildings tend to be under-insured by as much as a third - sometimes more,' says Nicholas Tufton, an independent surveyor who specialises in valuing listed buildings and other period properties. 'The biggest mistake people make is insuring for the market value of the property rather than the cost of rebuilding it.'

The problem of under-insurance is particularly acute for owners of listed property for two main reasons. First, rebuilding costs tend to be higher because of the specialist materials and labour involved. Second, where owners of conventional properties have choices in rebuilding, owners of listed buildings do not. English Heritage has the legal right to insist that a property is restored to its former glory - which can include specifying the exact materials to be used for the restoration as well as the contractor who will carry out the work.

In the case of the owner of a burnt-down listed property in Sussex which cost £2 million to rebuild, the stringent requirements of English Heritage contributed to the additional £500,000 he had to find to make up for his under-insurance.

Andrew Jobson of brokers Jobson Needham believes that owners of listed buildings should consider a policy from a specialist insurer such as Chubb (which has no connection to the lock company) or Hiscox. These insurers are primarily targeting very affluent property owners who also have antiques, fine art collections and valuable jewellery to insure. But these policies can be equally suitable for people who own homes (whether listed or not) with a rebuilding cost in the region of £250,000 to £300,000 (and contents worth a minimum of £75,000).

But does specialist mean more expensive? Jobson says not, and points out that the cover is better. What is worth having is the guarantees they are prepared to offer. Provided you have a recent specialist valuation of the rebuilding cost of your property (Chubb has its own valuers to do this; Hiscox can point you in the direction of a suitable expert), they will agree not to cap the sum insured. This means that even if the cost of rebuilding your home turns out to be more than the figure you were insured for, the claim will be met in full. A similar guarantee is available with the Mansion Plan policy from James Hampden Insurance Brokers.

 Country Thatch Insurance Agency: 0800 0562999

 Holman Insurance Brokers: 01268 730733

 Nicholas Tufton: 01763 848888; for other surveyors specialising in listed buildings, contact the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors on 020 7222 7000

 Needham Jobson: 020 8944 8870

 For brokers who sell Chubb policies, phone 0700 248 2207 or e-mail masterpiece-uk@chubb.com; for those who sell Hiscox policies phone 020 7448 6000

 James Hampden Insurance Brokers: 0800 028 3849

webTitle: Great product, huge market, keen buyers...

fields.headline: Great product, huge market, keen buyers...
fields.standfirst: Management strategies may reveal the best way to tackle the drugs trade, writes  Enid Mumford
fields.trailText: Management strategies may reveal the best way to tackle the drugs trade, writes Enid Mumford
fields.body:
Imagine this: you are an MBA student sitting your final exam on business strategy and the question on your exam paper is: You have developed a new product, emotec, which gives customers sensations of pleasure, confidence and calm when they use it. For cost reasons you want to develop it in Indonesia. What is your strategy for setting up the company and making it a business success?

Answers to this question could help devise a new and more effective strategy for combating illegal drugs. At present, as the FT pointed out last week, efforts to control the trade are an expensive failure. Occasional successes pale into insignificance compared with the scale and growth of the illegal trade.

Surprisingly, the drugs trade is rarely viewed and described as an industry. But that's what it is - one run by clever and talented entrepreneurs who produce a product, transport it to market and sell it to enthusiastic customers who are not very concerned about price.

The aim of most governments, Britain's included, is to suppress the industry or its influence - but this approach focuses solely on the market: identifying customers, their needs and, most importantly, the means of persuading them to stop consuming. If persuasion doesn't work, the policy is then to get heavy: threatening users with stiff penalties, including imprisonment.

The reason for the concentration on the market and its mostly young consumers is that drugs are defined as a social problem, along with their undesirable side effects of addiction, violence and burglary. The unfortunate result is that only the output end of a complex system is paid proper attention. Public debate would be better informed by discussion of the whole chain of the production process - and its weak links.

So, back to the MBA exam paper. In his, or her, answer, the student may suggest the following five-step analysis for the launch of the new product. Studying its strengths and weaknesses could show us how to destroy, or at least slow the growth of, the drugs trade.

The first step is to understand the big picture. What are the technical, economic, organisational and social processes involved in getting the product from source to market? Who and what will this involve? How much will it cost and who are the best potential customers?

Second: what are the weak links in the management process? There are potential problems at every stage of the drug production chain. Crops have to be treated to make them usable, transport has to be obtained, customs bypassed, and local staff organised to handle payment and distribution. All of these activities are risky and difficult - and these weaknesses are potential strengths for the anti-drugs strategist.

Third, what systems of accountability, reward and punishment can be used to coordinate this complex set of management activities? While the orthodox industrialist uses payment, promotion and dismissal, the drug baron has recourse to more extreme incentives and disincentives, ranging from huge bribes for 'good' performance, to death as the consequence for failure. An anti-drug strategy needs to take account of all of these.

Fourth, what kind of information is required at each stage of the journey from supply to market? Finding the answer may suggest ways of penetrating the drug barons' communications networks or disrupting their supply chains from outside.

Fifth and last, the major responsibility of the new company's managing director is to ensure that all of these complex activities are integrated, monitored and controlled so that the product arrives successfully at its market destination.

Usefully applying this set of analytical management tools to understand an industry's power is nothing new - the 'big picture' approach is favoured by most management teachers.

A business approach suggests further possibilities for action. For example, both the legitimate manager and the drug entrepreneur have the task of managing the profits. This is much more difficult for the drug baron who, unlike his counterpart, needs to turn 'dirty' money into 'clean' before it can be spent, a process that demands amenable and influential partners. It is here that the fastest progress in reducing the power of the drug industry could probably be made.

At present, $200 billion is laundered globally every year. Tightening financial controls to make money laundering harder would, at a stroke, make the drugs trade much less attractive.

It is also important to note, that, as with any other product, the demand for drugs alters over time as a result of fashion, product development and changing prices.

Technology also plays a part. Chemical-based drugs such as ecstasy can now be manufactured locally from recipes downloaded from the Internet. Cannabis can also be bought online - an innovation that could have impact spreading beyond users. As the net becomes a major selling agent, users who once funded their habit through small-time drug dealing may find this opportunity no longer exists, and crime such as theft may actually increase.

The most interesting question forced to the surface by a management strategy approach is, of course, the most basic: should drugs be turned into a legitimate business?

Legalisation would make price and quality subject to regulation, as in other businesses such as alcohol and tobacco. Decriminalisation, on the other hand, although removing punishment for personal use, would leave the business in the hands of criminals, with all the associated uncertainty and dangers.

Leaving things as they are while discussion focuses more on customers than on producers seems the least desirable option. If we are sticking with this strategy, the debate and action should at least be extended from the drug users to the total drug management system.

 Enid Mumford, Emeritus Professor at Manchester University, is author of 'Dangerous Decisions: Problem Solving in Tomorrow's World' (Kluwer Academic/Plenum 1999)

webTitle: Flexible friends are needed to hold hands in the fast changing world of IT

fields.headline: Flexible friends are needed to hold hands in the fast changing world of IT
fields.standfirst: There are jobs galore, but the Internet has fostered demand for a new type of employee, reports  Jamie Doward
fields.trailText: There are jobs galore, but the Internet has fostered demand for a new type of employee, reports Jamie Doward
fields.body:
The threat of the millennium bug may have vanished, but the demand for workers with IT skills continues to grow, according to experts. This is good news for the 3,000 people who will descend on Wembley this week for one of the UK's largest graduate IT fairs.

'There's a bigger influx of graduates compared with recent years, but there is still a shortage in the areas we're interested in, which are IT and engineering,' said Alison Munn, director of recruitment at electronics giant Marconi, who will attend the fair.

Increasingly, companies such as Marconi are targeting specialist recruitment fairs because they offer a critical mass of potential employees. And talent spotting at fairs is more cost-effective than hiring recruitment agencies.

'If we wanted to hire a permanent employee in the IT field, we would expect to pay an agency around 30 per cent of the person's salary,' said Corin Gunn, professional services operations manager with Information Builders, another firm at the fair.

With employers fighting among themselves for staff, IT workers are in the driving seat. Even so, securing the right job is a tough prospect.

'Last year hundreds of graduates came to the stand. We interviewed 30 or 40 and whittled them down to 10, to get just three,' Gunn said.

The Internet, and its offshoots such as e-commerce, have fostered demand for a new type of employee. It's no longer acceptable to sell soft ware or hardware to a a business and then leave it to get on with it. There is more focus on developing relationships with clients, and IT firms need graduates with good interpersonal skills.

But the greatest quality a potential employee can offer is the ability to be flexible.

Munn said: 'Things are moving at such a pace that skills today become obsolete tomorrow. The ability to be flexible means an employee can keep ahead of the field.'

 Graduates in IT, Greenwich Room, Wembley Conference Centre, 7-8 March.
